ومن نفس الرحمن تشريع الاجتهاد في الحكم في الأصول والفروع ومراعاة الاختلاف وثبوت الحكم من جانب الحق بإثباته إياه أنه حكم شرعي في حق المجتهد تحرم عليه مخالفته مع التقابل في الأحكام فقرر الحكمين المتقابلين وجعل المجتهدين في ذلك مأجورين فشرع المجتهد من الشرع الذي أذن الله فيه لهذه الأمة المحمدية أن يشرعه ولا أدري هل خصت به أو لم يزل ذلك فيمن قبلها من الأمم والظاهر أنه لم يزل في الأمم فإن نفس الرحمن يقتضي العموم ولا سيما وقد جاء في القرآن ما يدل على أن ذلك لم يزل في الأمم في قوله تعالى ورَهْبانِيَّةً ابْتَدَعُوها وما ابتدعوها إلا باجتهاد منهم وطلب مصلحة عامة أو خاصة وأثنى على من رعاها حق رعايتها وذكر هذا في بنى إسرائيل وكذلك في قوله في الأصول ومن يَدْعُ مَعَ الله إِلهاً آخَرَ لا بُرْهانَ لَهُ به يعني في زعمه فإنه في نفس الأمر ليس إلا إله واحد ولهذا قرر صلى الله عليه وسلم حكم المجتهد سواء أصاب أو أخطأ بعد توفيته حق الاجتهاد جهد طاقته وما رزقه الله من قوة النظر في ذلك وقرر له الأجر مرة واحدة إن أخطأ ومرتين إن أصاب فاعلم أن المجتهد قد يخطئ ما هو الأمر عليه في نفسه ومع هذا قد تعبده به وأعطاه على ذلك أجر الاجتهاد لما فيه من المشقة لأنه من الجهد والجهد بذل الوسع خاصة فإن الله ما كلف عباده إلا وسعهم في نفس الأمر ولم يخص صلى الله عليه وسلم في الاجتهاد فرعا من أصل بل عم فمن خصص ذلك بالفروع دون الأصول فهو من الاجتهاد أيضا تخصيص ذلك وتعميمه وكلاهما مأجور في اجتهاده‏


ومن نفس الرحمن أيضا قوله تعالى حكاية عن معصوم في قوله عن الخطاء وهو رسول الله صلى الله عليه وسلم ما من دَابَّةٍ إِلَّا هُوَ آخِذٌ بِناصِيَتِها
فأخرج وضيق المتسع فنفس الله بتمام الآية والتعريف بقوله إِنَّ رَبِّي عَلى‏ صِراطٍ مُسْتَقِيمٍ فقوله اهْدِنَا الصِّراطَ الْمُسْتَقِيمَ بالألف واللام اللذين للعهد وهو هذا الصراط الذي عليه الرب أن يكون مشهودا لنا في وقت مشي الحق فيه بنا فإنه صراط من أنعم عليه ومن غضب الله عليه وأصله في السبيل التي فرقته عن سبيله وهو الصراط الذي هو عليه حجبته عن شهوده فلا يشهده إلا سعيد وإن لم يشهده وآمن به وجعله كأنه يشهده فهو سعيد ومعلوم أن تصرف كل دابة قد يتعلق به لسان حمد أو ذم لأمور عرضية في الطريق عينتها الأحوال وأحكام الأسماء والأصل محفوظ في نفس الأمر تشهده الرسل سلام الله عليهم والخاصة من عباد الله‏


ومن نفس الرحمن الذي نفس الله به عن عباده المؤمنين بالرسل قوله وهُوَ مَعَكُمْ أَيْنَ ما كُنْتُمْ فنفس الله بذلك عن قلوب كان قد قام بها إن الله تعالى لا يعلم الجزئيات وإن كان القائل بذلك قد قصد التنزيه لكنه ممن اجتهد فأخطأ أن قال ذلك عن اجتهاد فله الأجر فإن الأمر لا يتغير عما هو عليه في نفسه ولا يؤثر فيه حكم المجتهد لا بالإصابة ولا بالخطإ وإذا لم يتغير الأمر في نفسه بتغير الاجتهاد فالحكم له فلا يكون منه في العقبي إلا الخير فإنه الخير المحض الذي لا شر فيه فما عند المجتهدين من التغيير من جهته إلا ما تغيروا به من نفوسهم ف إِنَّ الله لا يُغَيِّرُ ما بِقَوْمٍ حَتَّى يُغَيِّرُوا ما بِأَنْفُسِهِمْ وما غيروا به أنفسهم فذلك تغيير الله بهم لأنهم ما خرجوا عما أعطاهم الله فإن الله ما كلف نَفْساً إِلَّا ما آتاها فما آتاها في هذا الوقت إلا ما سماه تغييرا فهو معهم في حال تغيرهم إلى أن ينقضي مدته فيبدو لَهُمْ من الله ما لَمْ يَكُونُوا يَحْتَسِبُونَ وهو مشاهدة ما هو الأمر عليه في نفسه فنفس الله عنهم بما بدا لهم منه وما يبدو من الخير إلا الخير كما قال المعتزلي الذي كان يقول بإنفاذ الوعيد فيمن مات عن غير توبة فلما مات وهو على هذا الاعتقاد وحصل له بعد الموت شهود الأمر على ما هو به رؤي في النوم فقيل له ما فعل الله بك فقال وجدنا الأمر أهون مما كنا نعتقده وأخبر أنه رحم ولم ينفذ فيه الوعيد الذي كان يعتقد نفوذه في أمثاله وليس إنباء الحق عباده يوم القيامة بما عملوه من الجرائم واجترحوه من الآثام على جهة التوبيخ والتقرير وإنما ذلك على طريق الإعلام باتساع رحمة الله حيث نالها لاتساعها من لا يستحقها وذلك بشفاعة أعيان تلك الأفعال المسماة جرائم فإن فاعلها لما كان سببا في إيجاد أعيانها من كونها أفعالا وأقام نشأتها وهي معصية في حقه لكنها نشأة مطيعة مسبحة ربها عز وجل تستغفر للسبب الموجب لوجودها فيجيب الله دعاءها واستغفارها لصاحبها فإنه لا علم لها بأنها معصية أو طاعة فإنها غير مكلفة بذلك ولا خلقت له فيقبل الله شفاعتها فيه فيكون ما له إلى الرحمة التي وَسِعَتْ كُلَّ شَيْ‏ءٍ وما في العالم إلا من هو منشئ صور أعمال منعوتة في الشرع بطاعة ومعصية ولا طاعة ولا معصية فإذا انتشأت فلا غذاء لها إلا التسبيح بحمد الله وهنا أعني في هذه الحضرة تتساوى أعمال الطاعة والمعصية فإن كونها طاعة ومعصية ما هو عينها وإنما ذلك حكم الله فيها وهي مقبولة السؤال عند الله فإنها من أصناف المعتنى بهم المفطورين على تعظيم الله تعالى والثناء عليه بما هو أهله ولو لا أنه ما كان معنا أينما كنا ما ظهرت أعيان هذه الأعمال إذ هو منشئها فينا بنا أو عندنا على حسب ما يعطيه نظر كل ناظر فقل كيف شئت وهذا القدر كاف في باب النفس الرحماني وما رأيت أحدا ممن غير من أهل هذا الشأن تكلم عليه مثلنا ولا فصله تفصيلنا والله يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ‏


( «بسم الله الرحمن الرحيم»)
content.en:
Chapter One Hundred and Ninety-Eight: Concerning the Knowledge of the Breath (Nafs, with a fatha on the fā’)

The Breath of the Universes is from His Breath,
And it is the Revelation of the Real (al-Haqq) in its sound.
The Speech of the Real (al-Haqq) is its witness,
An effect in the Cosmos from His Breath.
Indeed, Moses saw it before,
In the kindling of the fire in its flame.
The mine of comforts is within it, so who
Is looking into it and into its guard?

The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, before he was known for his divine protection (عصمته) from people—which is His saying, <<وَاللهُ يَعْصِمُكَ مِنَ النَّاسِ>> (And Allah will protect you from the people)—would say, when he stopped at a place, "Who will guard us tonight?" despite knowing that Allah is <<عَلَى كُلِّ شَيْءٍ حَفِيظٌ>> (over all things a Guardian).

And he, peace be upon him, said when the distress he faced from the adversaries intensified, "The Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) comes to me from the direction of Yemen."

And that was the Ansar.

### [That the Existents are the Words of Allah that are inexhaustible]

Know that the existents (الموجودات) are the Words of Allah that are inexhaustible. He, the Exalted, said concerning the existence of Jesus, peace be upon him, that he is <<كَلِمَتُهُ أَلْقَاهَا إِلَى مَرْيَمَ>> (His Word, which He cast unto Maryam), and that is Jesus, peace be upon him. For this reason, we say that the existents are the Words of Allah, based on the transmitted evidence (الدلالة السمعية), since not everyone would accept our claim regarding the unveiling (الكشف) or the divine definition (التعريف الإلهي). The words known in common usage are formed by the arrangement of letters from the breath (النفس) that issues from the breather, interrupted at the points of articulation (المخارج). In that interruption, the essences of the letters (أعيان الحروف) appear according to specific proportions, forming the words.

Having alerted you to this, so that you may pay attention to what we present in this chapter, know that Allah, the Glorified, did not establish Himself upon His Throne (استواء على عرشه) except by the Name *al-Rahman* (The All-Merciful), thereby announcing that He intended nothing by creation (الإيجاد) except mercy for the existents (الموجودين). He did not mention any other Name. He mentioned the establishment upon the greatest of creatures in terms of encompassing the world of bodies (عالم الأجسام), for pain is only located in composition (التركيب). As for the simple substances (البسائط), they do not accept the subsistence of a meaning within their essence (ذاتها); rather, they are the very essence of the meaning. This indicates the comprehensiveness of Mercy (الرحمة) for the Cosmos (العالم). Even if the accidents of afflictions (عوارض البلايا) occur, they are still mercy, just as we mentioned regarding drinking bitter medicine: the purpose is not to torture or cause pain to the one who drinks it, but rather the intended outcome of its use is the comfort and health to which the user returns.

### [That Allah the Exalted named Himself The Manifest and The Hidden]

Then know after this that the Real (الحق) named Himself The Manifest (الظاهر) and The Hidden (الباطن). The Manifest is for the forms (الصور) in which He transforms, and the Hidden is for the meaning (المعنى) that accepts that transformation and manifestation in those forms. Thus, He is the world of the Unseen (عالم الغيب) by virtue of being the Hidden, and the world of Witnessing (الشهادة) by virtue of being the Manifest. I have informed you that the Cosmos (العالم) is a divine copy (نسخة إلهية) upon the form of the Real (صورة حق). Therefore, we said that Allah’s knowledge of things is His knowledge of Himself. For this reason, we judged Him by the Form (بالصورة).

And thus the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية) were revealed, and it is mentioned in the *Sahih* collection: that Allah created Adam upon His Form (على صورته).

This Form is the Perfect Human (الإنسان الكامل), the summary who is manifested by all the realities of the Cosmos (حقائق الكون), both recent and ancient. The Glorified One made the breath (النفس) issue from the heart for a known reason that we have established. The breather finds the points of articulation (المخارج) when intending speech. If speech is not intended, the breath is specifically the falling letter (الحرف الهاوي). What we consider to be the letters, when falling, fall in three stages of essential falling (هويا ذاتيا). This is expressed by the *Alif* (ألف), which the reciters call the falling letter (الحرف الهاوي). When it passes through the celestial spirits (الأرواح العلوية) in its fall, the *Wāw* of prolongation (واو العلة) arises from them—which is the extension of the air from the breather due to the closing of the letter (ضم الحرف), and it is the saturation of the *ḍammah* vowel movement. When it passes through the lower natural bodies (الأجسام الطبيعية السفلية) in its fall, the *Yā’* of prolongation (ياء العلة) arises from that—which is the extension of the air from the breather due to the lowering of the letter (خفض الحرف), and it is the saturation of the *kasrah* vowel movement, because the lowering (خفض) is from the lower world. This breath, in its fall, has no more than these three levels (المراتب). Know this.

Thus, the message of the Angel (رسالة الملك) arose with the *Wāw* preceded by a *ḍammah*, and the message of the Human (رسالة البشر) arose with the *Yā’* preceded by a *kasrah*. The *Alif* remained upon the Origin, from Allah, and it is the cause of all causes.

When Allah mentioned concerning Himself that He is the Manifest and the Hidden, and that He has Speech (كلام) and Words (كلمات), He mentioned that He has a Breath (نفسا) from the Name *al-Rahman* (The All-Merciful), by which He established Himself upon the Throne. So, <<فَاسْأَلْ بِهِ خَبِيرًا>> (Ask concerning Him one who is well-informed)—and that is the Gnostic (*al-’Arif*) among Allah’s servants, whether a prophet or any other of His servants whom Allah wills, because He said, <<يُؤْتِي الْحِكْمَةَ مَنْ يَشَاءُ>> (He grants wisdom to whom He wills). He left the matter indefinite (نكر الأمر) and did not define it. Thus, it is indefinite in a gnosis (معرفة) that He alone knows, because matters are specific and detailed with Him; there is no generality (إجمال) or ambiguity (إبهام) concerning Him, even though He knows the general in relation to those for whom the matter is general, ambiguous, or otherwise.

Since we know that He has a Breath (نفسا), and that He is the Hidden (الباطن), and that He has Speech (كلاما), and that the existents are His Words (كلماته), we know that Allah only informed us of this so that we might grasp the realities of things (حقائق الأمور) by virtue of being upon the Form (على الصورة). Thus, we accept everything that the Divinity (الألوهة) attributes to itself through the tongues of its messengers and its revealed books.

He made articulation (النطق) in the human being the most complete existence (أتم الوجود). He made for it twenty-eight points of articulation (مقطعا) for the breath (النفس), in each point a specific letter appears, which is not the essence of the other. The point of articulation distinguishes it, even though it is nothing other than the breath. The essence (العين) is one in that it is breath, but manifold in terms of the points of articulation. He made them twenty-eight because the Cosmos (العالم) is based on twenty-eight mansions (المنازل) in which the wandering stars revolve, and in their constellations (بروجها), which are their places in the revolving sphere, just as the points of articulation are places for the breath to bring the Cosmos into existence and what is suitable for it. To every world, these points of articulation have given rise to the essences of the letters (أعيان الحروف).

Then He divided these points of articulation into three sections: an extreme section, and the other extreme section, and the middle section. The first extreme is called the letters of the throat (حروف الحلق), which are in layers. The second extreme is the letters of the lips (حروف الشفتين). And between them are the letters of the middle. For the Divine Presence (الحضرة الإلهية) is in three levels (مراتب): Hidden (باطن), Manifest (ظاهر), and Middle (وسط)—which is that by which the Manifest is distinguished from the Hidden and separated from it, and that is the Isthmus (البرزخ). It has a face toward the Hidden and a face toward the Manifest; rather, it is the face itself, for it is indivisible. This is the Perfect Human (الإنسان الكامل), whom the Real (الحق) established as an Isthmus (برزخا) between the Real and the Cosmos. He manifests by the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية), thus being the Real, and He manifests by the reality of possibility (حقيقة الإمكان), thus being the creation (خلق).

He made the Perfect Human upon three levels: Intellect (عقل) and Sense (حس), which are the two extremes, and Imagination (خيال), which is the middle Isthmus between the meaning (المعنى) and the sense.

When Allah made Himself known to us as Hidden and Manifest, and that He has a Breath and a Word and Words, we looked at what manifested from that which is not attributed to His Essence (ذاته)—namely, the Breath and what arises from it. We said: the essence of the Breath (عين النفس) is the Cloud (العماء). For the breath of the breather, which is intended for expression, descends to the level of vapor (البخار), not the level of wind (الريح). This is the reality of the Breath wherever it is. From it came the Cloud (العماء), just as the Cloud arises from the vapor of the humidities of the elements (رطوبات الأركان), ascending and rising, manifesting first as the Cloud, then thickening afterwards, carried by the air and driven by the wind. Thus, it is not the essence of the air, but the essence of the vapor.

For this reason, it came in the description of the Cloud (العماء) in which our Lord was before the creation of creation: that it is a Cloud, with no air above it and no air below it.

He mentioned that it has an Above, which is the Real being in it, and a Below, which is the Cosmos being in it. There was nothing there but the Breath of the Real (نفس الحق). In it is the air, and the winds blew, ranging between violent (زعزع) and gentle (رخاء)—these are the strong (الشديدة) and soft (الرخوة) letters. From this Breath appeared the sounds of thunder, like the voiced letters (الحروف المجهورة), and the blowing of the breeze, which are the whispered letters (الحروف المهموسة). The layers (الطباق) appeared in the spheres (الأفلاك) like the emphatic letters (الحروف المطبقة) from the human breathing when intending speech. In the Divine realm, this is when we intend to say to it, "Be!" (كن). The emphatic letters in the Divine Breath (النفس الإلهي) are the existence of seven layered heavens (سبع سماوات طباقا), and every existent in the Cosmos is in a state of layering (انطباق).

In this Divine Breath, He manifested the opening of Existence (افتتاح الوجود) with the Being (الكون), since He was, and nothing was with Him. He made this the reality of the open letters (الحروف المنفتحة) in the breather. Then, when He brought the Cosmos into existence and opened its form in the Cloud (العماء)—which is the Breath that is the Real created by it—He established the levels (مراتب) and essences (أعيان) of the Cosmos and clarified its mansions (منازله). He made the world of bodies (عالم الأجسام) from it, like the lowered letters (الحروف المنسفلة), because they are from the side of Nature (الطبيعة), which is the limit of dark Being (الكون الظلم). And He made the world of spirits (عالم الأرواح) from it, which are the elevated letters (الحروف المستعلية) in the breather by the human breath (بالنفس الإنساني).

All of this is the Words of the Cosmos (كلمات العالم). In the human being, they are called letters (حروفا) in terms of their individual units, and words (كلمات) in terms of their composition. Likewise, the essences of the existents (أعيان الموجودات) are letters in terms of their individual units, and words in terms of their mixtures.

In the Divine Breath, He placed the cause of creation (علة الإيجاد) from the side of Mercy (الرحمة) toward the creation (الخلق), to bring them out of the evil of non-existence (شر العدم) into the good of existence (خير الوجود). This was through the falling letter (الحرف الهاوي). Then He also clarified for them the existence of what leads to felicity (السعادة) through the sending of the angelic messenger (الرسول الملكي) and the human messenger (البشرى), which is the sending of mercy. This resulted in the soft letters (حروف اللين) in the human breather.

Then, in this Breath, He created the Sound (الصوت) upon its exit from the Hidden to the Manifest by way of Revelation (الوحي), which the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, likened to a chain on a smooth stone (سلسلة على صفوان). This resulted in the sibilant letters (حروف الصفير) in human breathing.

Then that Divine Breath spread out (انفش) over the fixed entities of the Cosmos (أعيان العالم الثابتة), which had no existence. The equivalent of this in human speech is the spreading letters (حروف التفشي).

Then the existents (الأكوان) extended their claim and control over the Divine Breath (النفس الإلهي) where they were counted and multiplied, though its essence is one (أحدي العين). In the breath of the human breather, this is the elongated letter (الحرف المستطيل), which is the *Ḍād* (ضاد) alone, because it extends until it reaches the point of articulation of the *Lām* (لام).

Then, in the creation of the Divine Laws (الشرائع), this Divine Breath established a straight path (طريقا مستقيما) and a deviation from this specific straightness. This deviation is called distortion (تحريفا), which is His saying, <<يُحَرِّفُونَهُ مِنْ بَعْدِ مَا عَقَلُوهُ>> (They distort it after they have understood it), even though <<إِلَيْهِ يُرْجَعُ الْأَمْرُ كُلُّهُ>> (To Him all matters are returned). He says: even if it multiplies, the Breath gathers it. This distortion (التحريف) in the breath of the human breather is called the deviated letter (الحرف المنحرف), which mixes with most letters—and that is the *Lām* (لام). No other letter has this rank. It is like certain rulings in which the Divine Laws converge.

Then, in the Divine Breath, He manifested in the forms of similitudes (الصور الأمثال), so distinction did not occur, and repetition (التكرار) was imagined, though the reality dictates that there is no repetition. This appeared in the world of human letters as the repeated letter (الحرف المكرر), which is the *Rā’* (راء).

Since the breath carries scents, it is known that its exit is through the nostrils. This is called the nasal letters (حروف الغنة) in human articulation, because they come from the nasal cavity (الخيشوم).

The levels of the letters (مراتب الحروف) are thus completed in their perfection. Praise be to Allah. End of Volume One Hundred and Eighteen.

(In the Name of Allah, the All-Merciful, the Compassionate)

### [The Breeze of the Spirits and the Breeze of the Winds]

We have seen a group of men of scents (رجال الروائح), and Abdul Qadir al-Jili was among them. He would recognize a person by smell. My companion, Abu al-Badr, informed me about him that Ibn Qa’id al-Awani came to him, and Ibn Qa’id considered himself to have a share in the Path. Abdul Qadir smelled him about three times, then said to him, "I do not recognize you." This was a spiritual training (تربية) for him, which raised Ibn Qa’id’s aspiration until he attained the rank of the Solitary Ones (الإفراد).

The Breath (النفس) always manifests its ruling most strongly in the lovers and passionate devotees (المحبين العشاق). This is their station and rank. They attribute this to the breath of the winds (نسيم الرياح), not to the breath of the spirits (نسيم الأرواح), as one of them said:

I adjure you by Allah, O breeze of the East (نسيم الصبا),
From where is this sweet breath?
Did you deposit your coolness at dawn
In the place where Zaynab cast her necklace?
Or did your fragrance mingle with the garden of the sanctuary (روض الحمى),
While she trailed her skirt over it?
So bring me, and favor me with news of her,
For your acquaintance with her today is closer.

These verses, despite their subtlety and tenderness, are among the densest things said about the love of spirits (عشق الأرواح), because the breeze of the spirits (نسيم الأرواح) is subtler than the breeze of the winds (نسيم الرياح), as the former is far removed from the world of nature (عالم الطبيعة), while the latter is not. When the spirits breathe, they only carry sweetness (طيبا), for they blow from the Essential Presence (الحضرة الذاتية) of the Most Holy Unseen (الغيب الأقدس), and thus bring nothing but all that is sweet and pure. The winds are not like that, for they are from the world of nature: if they pass over something foul, they bring foulness, and if they pass over something sweet, they bring sweetness. But the breeze of the spirits, if it passes over foulness, turns it sweet, and if it passes over sweetness, it increases its sweetness.

If this speaker were a true lover, not speaking a false claim, he would not have attributed the sweetness to Zaynab, even if she is sweet. He should have mentioned that her sweetness increased the sweetness of the place. He made his beloved reveal her secrets to the winds, meaning she is not in a protected sanctuary (منيعة الحمى), and the world of nature—which is the wind—penetrates it. He began to satirize the wind by wondering where it got this sweet breath. If he had conveyed the sweetness by way of comparison, saying, "From where is this *sweeter* breath?" (النفس الأطيب), it would have been more poetic, for the wind would not possess anything extra beyond the breath of his beloved, if he truly realized it, since she is the very essence of sweetness wherever sweetness appears.

Some of my companions asked me to explain these verses if they were spoken by a Gnostic (عارف) among the Divine Lovers (المحبين الإلهيين). I agreed to do so.

I shall explain them, if Allah wills, then return to the discussion on the realization of the Breath (النفس) in this chapter. We say, and <<وَاللهُ يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وَهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (And Allah speaks the Truth, and He guides to the Way).

### [Explanation of the Verses]

His saying, addressing the breeze of the East (نسيم الصبا), "I adjure you by Allah (ناشدتك الله)": Know that *al-Ṣabā* (the East wind) is the wind of Acceptance (القبول), and *al-Ṣabā* (the inclination) is inclination (الميل), and inclination is acceptance. It was named *al-Ṣabā* (Acceptance) because when the Arabs wanted to identify the winds so they could name them and know them, they faced the sunrise. Every wind that blew upon them from the direction of the sunrise, which they faced since their face was toward that direction, they named *Qabūl* (Acceptance). What came to them from the wind from behind while they were facing that direction, they named *Dabūr* (West wind). What came to them from their right side, they named *Janūb* (South wind), and from their left side, *Shimāl* (North wind). Every wind that blew between two of these directions they named *Nakbā’* (Adverse wind), from *nukūb*, meaning deviation, i.e., it deviated from these four directions.

The *Nasīm* (breeze) is the first blowing of the wind. Something delightful, when it first surprises you, is sweeter than its continuation, like the saying: "Sweeter than security to the fearful and anxious." For this reason, the bliss of the Gardens (نعيم الجنان) is new in every breath. Therefore, he only adjured the breeze (*al-Nasīm*) due to the delight he found in it. He made it the breeze of the East (*al-Ṣabā*) because it is an eastern wind of acceptance. The wind gave him news of the sweetness it brought, which is what its acceptance would give if it approached, or what seeing it would give if it rose upon him, just as the sun rises, because *al-Ṣabā* is an eastern wind, and *shurūq* is the rising of the sun, and *ishrāq* is the light of the sun.

His saying, "I adjure you (ناشدتك)": meaning, I demand of you, swearing by Allah. The adjurer (*al-nāshid*) is the seeker, so he is like one who inquires. This indicates his lack of knowledge of his beloved, as he made similitudes for her, by his saying, "From where is this sweet breath?" For there are others who have sweet breaths. If he had been fully occupied with his beloved and had witnessed none but her, he would not have inquired, since everyone who inquires has brought that possibility into his mind. This poet brought partnership into his mind, thus testifying to his own lack of gnosis if he is a Gnostic, and lack of love if he is a passionate lover.

If he intended the multiplicity of the beloved’s faces and her self-disclosure (تجليه) in multiple entities, like the Divine Names of Allah, despite His being one Essence (ذات واحدة), and yet He has ninety-nine Names and more—then he means: in which Name was it, when this wind blew? This breeze is a subtle divine breath of acceptance (نسمة قبول إلهي لطيفة الهبوب) that instilled subtlety and tenderness in the heart by its blowing. So he inquired of the wind about the delightful sweetness it brought, saying:

"Did you deposit your coolness at dawn
In the place where Zaynab cast her necklace?"

Know that this verse is the clearest proof that he is not a lover, and that this saying is closer to satirizing the beloved than to praising and commending her. This is because when the wind brought him this sweet breath, he attributed that sweetness to what occurred in the place where Zaynab cast her necklace. This is praise for the necklace, for he means that her necklace was ambergris, possessing sweetness, and the place became sweet by that necklace. He did not mention that the necklace acquired its sweetness from Zaynab’s scents, fragrance, or breaths. If he had proceeded in his speech by saying that the sweetness of the place came from Zaynab breathing in it, if he had said, for example, what we said:

Did you deposit your coolness at dawn
In the sweetness of a place Zaynab made sweet?
Its breaths are from the sweetness of her breaths,
So her sweetness from its sweetness is more wondrous.

We have a similar meaning in a different rhyme:

The sweetness in musk is only the sweetness of her fragrance,
And the light in the sun is only from her countenance.
Eternity is the abode of the beautiful houris who dwell in it,
But her Essence is the abode of the Gardens of Eternity.

As for his saying after this:

"Or did your fragrance mingle with the garden of the sanctuary,
While she trailed her skirt over it?"

This is like the first one. He made the sweetness belong to the garden from Zaynab’s skirt when she trailed it over that place. It became sweet from the sweetness of her skirt, and the sweetness of her skirt is from the perfume with which she scented her clothes, just like the necklace. He did not mention anything that indicates that the sweetness of these places comes from the sweetness of her breaths. If this is the case, then only that which is not sweet, or does not possess that sweetness, becomes sweet. That is why we said that if he had said "the sweeter breath" (النفس الأطيب) instead of "the sweet breath" (النفس الطيب), it would have been more poetic and firmer in praise.

Then his saying to the breeze:

"So bring me, and favor me with news of her,
For your acquaintance with her today is closer."

This is unsubstantiated speech, for the breeze of the wind has a close acquaintance only with the place and the garden of the sanctuary, not with Zaynab. The sweetness belongs to the place from the necklace, and to the garden from the skirt. This breeze did not convey anything of her sweetness specific to her Essence (ذاتها). Even if she was witnessed by the breeze when it blew over the place and the garden, by his saying "while she trailed her skirt," he mentioned something that allows for ambiguity in the situation. It is possible that the situation in his saying "while she trailed her skirt" means that during her passing, she imparted this sweetness to the garden from her skirt. It is also possible that the wind witnessed her while she was passing over the garden of the sanctuary, but the former is closer. For if it had passed by her, witnessing her while she was trailing her skirt over the garden, it would have conveyed the sweetness of her skirt, not the sweetness of the garden from her skirt. This indicates that the breeze of the wind did not witness her. If it did not witness her, its acquaintance with her is not close; rather, its acquaintance is close to the place she passed over.

Furthermore, there is a deficiency in his saying "closer" (أقرب), describing it with a general matter applicable to all sweetness, since a place where sweetness remains is only recently acquainted with the sweetness due to her sitting there or passing over it. This is not specific to her. Rather, if he had said that her sweetness in the place does not vanish after it acquired it from her, and that the wind is distantly acquainted with her, yet the sweetness remains due to the strength of its dominion, it would have been more poetic. The breeze only conveyed to him the sweetness of the place and the garden, so he should have been truthful and said, "for your acquaintance with *it* (the place) today is closer," or "with *them* (the garden and the place) is closer," or "with *them* (plural) is closer." But he lied by saying "with *her* is closer."

Moreover, the sweetness of the place or the garden is not necessarily caused by casting the necklace or the sweetness of the skirt. The sweetness of the garden might come from the flowers, and the sweetness of the place from another matter, despite the presence of the necklace and the trailing of the skirt over the garden. Thus, he is deficient in every respect.

This is poetry with subtle, beautiful wording, but in terms of meaning, it is nothing. For the beauty of poetry and speech is to combine refined wording (اللفظ الرائق) with sublime meaning (المعنى الفائق), so that the observer and listener are bewildered, unable to tell whether the wording or the meaning is better, or if they are equal. When one looks at either of them, the other distracts him with its beauty, and when he looks at both together, they confuse him. Only one with a dense heart (قلب كثيف) appreciates such poetry, for the wording is subtle but the meaning is dense. If the meaning is ugly in the view of sound contemplation, the beauty of the wording does not conceal the ugliness of the meaning. Its example, in my view, is like someone who loves an extremely beautiful image painted on a wall, adorned with various pigments, perfect in form but without a spirit. For the meaning is to the wording as the spirit is to the form—it is its true beauty.

Look at the inimitability of the Quran (إعجاز القرآن); you will find it as we described: beautiful composition combined with abundant meaning, excellent flow, and the gathering of meanings together in concise, well-composed wording. You will not find this in the Quran, even with the repetition of a single story, such as the stories of the nations like Adam, Moses, Noah, and others, which are repeated with an increase or decrease in wording, yet you will not find any deficiency in the meaning whatsoever. The reason for this is that it is the Word of Truth (قول حق) in which there is no fabrication.

Since we have come to point out what is in the saying of this poet, even though it does not depart from the reality of this chapter—for it is the chapter of the Breath (*Nafs* with *fatha*), and poetry is speech, so it is from the category of breaths (الأنفاس)—there are breaths from which the realization of meanings emerges exactly as they are in their composition with one another, and there are breaths that are the opposite.

### [From the Breath of the All-Merciful appeared the letters of the existents and the words of the Cosmos]

Let us return to the Merciful Breath (النفس الرحماني) from which the letters of the existents (حروف الكائنات) and the words of the Cosmos (كلمات العالم) appeared, according to the levels of the points of articulation (مخارج الحروف) of the human breather’s breath, which is the most complete of all formations (النشآت) in the Cosmos. These are twenty-eight letters. Each letter has a name that defines its point of articulation (مقطع نفسه). The first is the *Hā’* (هاء) and the last is the *Wāw* (واو). There is no conceivable letter beyond that. Among them are letters with a single point of articulation, like the elongated letter (المستطيل), the deviated letter (المنحرف), and the repeated letter (المكرر). Among them are those that share a point of articulation, like the sibilant letters (حروف الصفير). Even if there is a difference between those that share, it is close to one another. The correct articulator finds the difference between the two shared letters when pronouncing them, such as the *Ṭā’* (ط), *Tā’* (ت), and *Dāl* (د). Although these three come from one point of articulation, it is based on proximity, not exact identity. For this reason, their titles differ due to the difference in their states at the points of articulation.

Thus, a single letter may have multiple titles due to the degrees it possesses in the Breath during its formation in the letter’s point of articulation, by which it is distinguished from what is close to it in the articulation point that necessitated it being called shared. For example, the unpointed *Ṣād* (صاد) is one of the whispered letters (الحروف المهموسة), and it shares whispering with the *Kāf* (ك). It is one of the sibilant letters, and it shares sibilance with the *Zāy* (ز). It is one of the emphatic letters (الحروف المطبقة), and it shares emphasis with the *Ṭā’* (ط). It is one of the soft letters (الحروف الرخوة), and it shares softness with the *’Ayn* (ع). It is one of the elevated letters (الحروف المستعلية), and it shares elevation with the *Qāf* (ق). This is a single letter upon which many titles differ due to its manifestation in multiple levels, accepting by its essence every level suitable for it. Thus, the considerations differed, and the names differed.

Likewise, we say concerning the First Intellect (العقل الأول): we call it Intellect for a meaning that differs from the meaning for which we call it Pen (قلم), which differs from the meaning for which we call it Spirit (روح), which differs from the meaning for which we call it Heart (قلب).

The Essence (al-’Ayn) is one, but the ruling differs,
Thus the spirits and forms are varied.

Likewise, the Real (الحق) is the origin of Existence (الوجود), the One, the Unique (الواحد الأحد), who does not accept number. Although He is one in Essence (واحد العين), He is named The Living (الحي), The Self-Subsisting (القيوم), The Mighty (العزيز), The Supreme (المتكبر), The Compeller (الجبار), up to ninety-nine Names, for one Essence and different rulings. The meaning understood from the Name The Living is not the meaning understood from the Name The Willing, nor The Powerful, nor The Omnipotent, just as we said concerning the letter *Ṣād*, and likewise all the other letters.

The letters issued from the breath of the human breather, who is the most complete of all formations, and by him all the letters appeared, so he was upon the Divine Form (الصورة الإلهية) by the Merciful Breath (النفس الرحماني). The manifestation of the letters of the existents and the world of Words are equivalent. All of them—the human breath—are twenty-eight letters, realizing the essences of the Divine Words (أعيان الكلمات الإلهية) that issued from the Merciful Breath, which are twenty-eight Words, each Word having faces.

What issued from the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن)—which is the Cloud (العماء) in which our Lord was before He created creation—was the Cloud being like the human breath, and the manifestation of the Cosmos in its extension in the Void (الخلأ) according to the levels of the existents, like the human breath from the heart and its extension to the mouth, and the manifestation of the letters and words along the path, like the manifestation of the Cosmos from the Cloud, which is the Breath of the Merciful Real (نفس الحق الرحماني), in the predetermined levels in the imagined extension, not in a body—and that is the Void that the Cosmos filled.

Just as the first letter that appeared from the essences of the Cosmos from this Breath, when it sought to exit to the limit—which is the end of the Void, just as the limit of the breath’s extension is to the lips—the *Hā’* (هاء) appeared first and the *Wāw* (واو) last. Thus, the genera of the Cosmos (أجناس العالم) are confined, but its individuals (أشخاصه) are inexhaustible in existence, for they continue to arise as long as the cause exists, and the cause does not cease. Therefore, the creation of the individuals of the species does not cease.

As for the confinement of the Cosmos to the number of letters from the Breath, which are twenty-eight, neither increasing nor decreasing: the first of these is the Intellect (العقل), which is the Pen (القلم). This is the saying of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, that "The first thing Allah created was the Intellect."

And in another report: "The first thing Allah created was the Pen."

Thus, the first creation Allah created from the Breath (النفس), which is the Cloud (العماء) capable of opening the forms of the Cosmos within it, is the Intellect, which is the Pen. Then the Soul (النفس), which is the Tablet (اللوح). Then Nature (الطبيعة). Then the Haba’ (الهباء - Primordial Dust). Then the Body (الجسم). Then the Form (الشكل). Then the Throne (العرش). Then the Footstool (الكرسي). Then the Unstarred Sphere (الأطلس). Then the Sphere of the Fixed Stars (فلك الكواكب الثابتة). Then the First Heaven, then the Second, then the Third, then the Fourth, then the Fifth, then the Sixth, then the Seventh. Then the Sphere of Fire. Then the Sphere of Air. Then the Sphere of Water. Then the Earth (التراب). Then the Mineral (المعدن). Then the Plant (النبات). Then the Animal (الحيوان). Then the Angel (الملك). Then the Jinn (الجن). Then the Human (البشر). Then the Rank (المرتبة).

The Rank (المرتبة) is the limit in every existent, just as the *Wāw* is the limit of the letters of the Breath. I intended to mention the names of the Cosmos, not the order of its existence, just as the intention in *Abjad Hawwaz Ḥuṭṭī Kalaman Sa’faṣ Qarashat Thakhadh Ḍaẓagh* is the confinement of the letters, not the order of their existence in the points of articulation. Every existent we mentioned has a known rank (مرتبة), rulings (أحكام), and proportions (نسب) known to the Gnostics of Allah. Each one has a known station (مقام معلوم) by which it is distinguished and which the other does not possess, just as it has matters in which it shares with others, both in creation and ruling. As for creation, this is like the individuals of the same species, and the species of the same genus, such as the spheres sharing in spherical rotation and corporeality in terms of composition.

We only mentioned what is specific to the world of this life (عالم الدنيا), just as we only mentioned the letters specific to the human breath today, since we only speak concerning existence. We do not encompass Allah with knowledge, so we speak according to the measure of knowledge He has granted us concerning Him. There is nothing more wondrous possible than what He created, because He is the Truthful One, and He said that He created the Cosmos upon His Form, and there cannot be anything more perfect than this Cosmos.

An unveiling (واقعة) occurred to us concerning this chapter, which has been mentioned previously.

Then know that the closest resemblance to the Breath, or rather, the very essence of the Breath, are the letters of prolongation (حروف العلة): the *Alif*, the *Wāw* preceded by a *ḍammah*, and the *Yā’* preceded by a *kasrah*. These three letters are not among the sound letters (الحروف الصحاح) that are truly letters; they are more sublime than that. Applying the term "letter" to them is metaphorical. They are only indicated by the letter when it is opened and the *fatḥah* is saturated, or closed and the *ḍammah* is saturated, or broken and the *kasrah* is saturated. That is the evidence for the manifestation of these letters, just as the Cosmos, by virtue of its origination (حدوثه)—which is equivalent to the saturation of the vowels in the letters—is evidence for the existence of the Real (الحق) itself. Understand what we have mentioned.

Furthermore, the letters have properties (خواص) that they possess, which the points of articulation granted them. They are gathered in the Breath, since it collects them, but separated in the essences of the letters and words. When the Breath flows from the beginning of the letters to their limit, every letter whose existence is delayed due to the delay of its point of articulation when the breath is cut off, performs what every preceding letter performs in its point of articulation. It contains the power of every preceding letter, because the Breath passed through those points of articulation during its exit until it was cut off at this point of articulation, thus conveying the rank of every letter with it.

This appeared in the power of the delayed letter. The last of the letters is the *Wāw*. Thus, the *Wāw* contains the power of all the letters, just as the *Hā’* is the least in action among all the letters, for it is the beginning. The word *Huwa* (هو - He) gathered all the powers of the letters in the world of Words. For this reason, the Identity (الهوية) is the greatest of things in action.

Likewise, the Human (الإنسان) is the final limit of the Breath and the Divine Words in the genera. In the Human is the power of every existent in the Cosmos. He possesses all the levels (المراتب). For this reason, he alone was distinguished by the Form (بالصورة). He combined the Divine Realities (الحقائق الإلهية), which are the Names, and the realities of the Cosmos, for he is the last existent. The Merciful Breath (النفس الرحماني) did not cease until it reached his existence, bringing with it the power of all the levels of the Cosmos.

Thus, what manifests through the Human does not manifest through any single part of the Cosmos, nor through every single Name of the Divine Realities, for one Name does not grant what the other grants in terms of distinction. Therefore, the Human is the most complete of existents (أكمل الموجودات), and the *Wāw* is the most complete of letters. This is also true in action, according to those who know the operation of the letters.

Everything other than the Human is creation (خلق), except the Human, for he is creation and the Real (حق). The Perfect Human (الإنسان الكامل) is, in reality, the Real created by it (الحق المخلوق به), meaning the Cosmos was created because of him. This is because the limit (الغاية) is the object sought by the creation that precedes it. What preceded it was only created for its sake and for the manifestation of its essence. The limit is the matter by which what preceded it—the causes of its manifestation—was created. That is the Perfect Human.

We only said "Perfect" (الكامل) because the name "human" may be applied to the one who resembles the Form, as you say that Zayd is a human and 'Amr is a human, even if the Divine Realities manifested in Zayd but did not manifest in 'Amr. 'Amr is, in reality, an animal in the form of a human, just as the ball resembles the sphere in roundness, but where is the perfection of the sphere compared to the ball? This is what I mean by "Perfect."

The Human thus acquired all the levels by his rank, just as the *Wāw* acquired all the powers of the letters. This indicates that the *Wāw* was the object sought by the Speech (الكلام) so that it might exist. Because of it, everything that existed along the path was found, through the readiness of the points of articulation of the letters, until it reached the *Wāw*.

### [That the breath of the breather was nothing other than the hidden aspect of the breather]

Then know that the breath of the breather (نفس المتنفس) was nothing other than the hidden aspect of the breather (باطن المتنفس). The breath thus became manifest (ظاهرا), and that is the essences of the letters and words. The Manifest was not something added to the Hidden; rather, it is its very essence. The readiness of the points of articulation to define the letters in the breath is the readiness of the Fixed Entities (الأعيان الثابتة) of the Cosmos in the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن). Thus, the essence of the dispositional ruling (الحكم الاستعدادي) that is in the manifest Cosmos appeared in the Breath.

For this reason, the Exalted One said to His Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, <<وَمَا رَمَيْتَ إِذْ رَمَيْتَ وَلَكِنَّ اللَّهَ رَمَى>> (And you did not throw when you threw, but Allah threw). And He said to the tranquil soul (النفس المطمئنة), <<ارْجِعِي إِلَى رَبِّكِ رَاضِيَةً>> (Return to your Lord, well-pleased), just as He said, <<طَوْعًا وَكَرْهًا>> (Willingly or unwillingly). Meaning, if you do not return well-pleased by your own essence, you will be compelled to return to your Lord, so that you may know that you are not you.

If it returns well-pleased, it is the knowing soul (النفس العالمة) that is pleasing to Allah. It entered among His servants, and was not attributed or affiliated to anyone else, such as those <<مَنِ اتَّخَذَ إِلَهَهُ هَوَاهُ>> (who take their own desire as their god). And it entered His Garden (جَنَّتِهِ), meaning His protection and covering (كنفه وستره). This soul became veiled by Him, so He was the Manifest, and it was the Unseen within Him, thus it is Hidden (باطنة), since it is the essence of the Breath, and the Breath is Hidden.

It stood for the All-Merciful (الرحمن) with this description of entering the veil attributed to Him by His saying, "My Garden" (جَنَّتِي), holding the station of the spirit to the formal body (الجسم الصوري), for the spirit is a veil over it. The body is witnessed, but the ruling belongs to the spirit, which is the readiness of the Cosmos that manifested the difference in the Manifest Real. This is the meaning of His saying, <<وَادْخُلِي جَنَّتِي>> (And enter My Garden), and His attribution of it to Himself.

The Lord and the lorded are linked,
Existence is doubled by Him, yet He is not doubled.
I have neither seen nor heard of anything like it,
Except what they said about the two 'Umars (al-’Umarān).

They mean by "the two 'Umars" (al-’Umarān) Abu Bakr and 'Umar, and the sun and the moon. <<وَاللَّهُ خَلَقَكُمْ وَمَا تَعْمَلُونَ>> (And Allah created you and what you do). He affirmed by the pronoun and negated by the act, which is creation, just as Abu Bakr was negated, and no name appeared for him in the term *al-’Umarān*, yet He affirmed him by the dual pronoun, which is their saying *al-’Umarān*. Glory be to Him who concealed His wisdom concerning him!

Thus, the Knower (العليم) who is not known appeared in Existence, like the thrower who did not throw. The letters are not other than the Breath, nor are they the essence of the Breath. The Word is not other than the letters, nor is it the essence of the letters.

The Gathering (al-Jam’) is a state whose essence has no existence,
And the control belongs to it, not to the individuals.

Know that when Allah said, <<قُلِ ادْعُوا اللَّهَ أَوِ ادْعُوا الرَّحْمَنَ أَيًّا مَا تَدْعُوا فَلَهُ الْأَسْمَاءُ الْحُسْنَى>> (Say: Call upon Allah or call upon the All-Merciful. Whichever you call upon, to Him belong the Most Beautiful Names), He made the Most Beautiful Names (الأسماء الحسنى) belong to Allah, just as they belong to the All-Merciful. However, there is a subtlety here: the Name has a meaning (معنى) and a form (صورة). Allah is called upon by the meaning of the Name, and the All-Merciful (الرحمن) is called upon by its form, because the All-Merciful is described by the Breath (بالنفس), and by the Breath the Divine Words appeared in the levels of the Void (الخلأ) in which the Cosmos appeared.

We only call upon Him by the form of the Name. It has two forms: a form with us, derived from our breaths and the composition of our letters, and this is what we call upon Him with. These are the names of the Divine Names (أسماء الأسماء الإلهية), and they are like the robes cast upon them. We, by the form of these names derived from our breaths, are translators of the Divine Names. The Divine Names have forms derived from the Breath of the All-Merciful, by virtue of His being the Speaker and described by Speech (الكلام). Behind those forms are the meanings (المعاني) that are like the spirits (الأرواح) for those forms.

The forms of the Divine Names (صور الأسماء الإلهية) by which the Real mentions Himself through His Speech have their existence from the Breath of the All-Merciful. To Him belong the Most Beautiful Names. The spirits of those forms are those that belong to the Name Allah, outside the ruling of the Breath, and are not described by modality (الكيفية). They are to the forms of the essential Merciful Names (الأسماء النفسية الرحمانية) as meanings are to the letters.

Since we knew this, and we were commanded to call upon Him by His Most Beautiful Names, and we were given the choice between Allah and the All-Merciful, if we wish, we call upon Him by the form of the essential Merciful Names (الأسماء النفسية الرحمانية), which are the cosmic aspirations (الهمم الكونية) in our spirits. And if we wish, we call upon Him by the Names derived from our breaths, by way of translation, which are the Names articulated in the world of witnessing (عالم الشهادة). When we articulate them, we bring into our souls: as for Allah, we contemplate the meaning; and as for the All-Merciful, we contemplate the form of the essential Merciful Divine Name, however we wish to do so. For the indication of the two forms—from us and from the All-Merciful—upon the meaning is one and the same, whether we know it or not.

Since the mention of His Names is the very praise of Him, we mention in this chapter what is in us that is like His Word "Be!" (كن) from Him—and that is the *Basmala* (Bismillah). The people of Allah say that *Bismillah* from us, in the creation of acts, is equivalent to *Kun* (Be!) from Him.

Since the Quran is a Remembrance (ذكر) and a collection of His Names, both forms and meanings, we made recitation (التلاوة) in this chapter part of the Remembrances (الأذكار). We only mention from the Remembrances what is specific to the Quran. We mention Him by His Speech, based on His knowledge of that, not based on our knowledge, so that He is the one who remembers Himself, not us.

Since our supplication is by His Quranic Names, and we are remembering and reciting, we are obligated to seek refuge (التعوذ), which is part of the Remembrance. He grants us refuge.

We have included the Remembrances: *Al-Ḥamdulillāh* (Praise be to Allah), *Subḥānallāh* (Glory be to Allah), *Allāhu Akbar* (Allah is Greater), *Lā ilāha illā Allāh* (There is no god but Allah), and *Lā ḥawla wa lā quwwata illā billāh* (There is no power and no strength except with Allah).

Let us mention the index of what I shall mention in this chapter, concerning the sections that deal with the Divine Breath (النفس الإلهي) and the levels of the rememberers (الذاكرين) in the Cosmos in remembrance, because the rememberers are the highest of groups, for He is their companion. For this reason, Allah concluded the descriptions of the intimate ones (المقربين) among the people of Allah, both male and female rememberers, with their remembrance. He, the Exalted, said: <<إِنَّ الْمُسْلِمِينَ وَالْمُسْلِمَاتِ وَالْمُؤْمِنِينَ وَالْمُؤْمِنَاتِ وَالْقَانِتِينَ وَالْقَانِتَاتِ وَالصَّادِقِينَ وَالصَّادِقَاتِ وَالصَّابِرِينَ وَالصَّابِرَاتِ وَالْخَاشِعِينَ وَالْخَاشِعَاتِ وَالْمُتَصَدِّقِينَ وَالْمُتَصَدِّقَاتِ وَالصَّائِمِينَ وَالصَّائِمَاتِ وَالْحَافِظِينَ فُرُوجَهُمْ وَالْحَافِظَاتِ وَالذَّاكِرِينَ اللَّهَ كَثِيرًا وَالذَّاكِرَاتِ>> (Indeed, the Muslim men and Muslim women, the believing men and believing women, the obedient men and obedient women, the truthful men and truthful women, the patient men and patient women, the humble men and humble women, the charitable men and charitable women, the fasting men and fasting women, the men who guard their private parts and the women who guard [theirs], and the men who remember Allah often and the women who remember [Him]). He did not mention anything after the women who remember.

Remembrance (الذكر) is one of the attributes of His being a Speaker (متكلما), and that is the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) in which the realities of the letters of the existents and the words of the Presence (كلمات الحضرة) appeared.

(Chapter Two) Concerning the Speech of Allah and His Words.
(Chapter Three) Concerning the Remembrance of Seeking Refuge (التعوذ).
(Chapter Four) Concerning the Remembrance by the *Basmala*.
(Chapter Five) Concerning the Word of the Presence (كلمة الحضرة), which is the Word *Kun* (Be!).
(Chapter Six) Concerning the Remembrance by Praise (*Al-Ḥamd*).
(Chapter Seven) Concerning the Remembrance by Glorification (*Al-Tasbīḥ*).
(Chapter Eight) Concerning the Remembrance by Magnification (*Al-Takbīr*).

(Chapter One) Concerning Allah’s remembrance of Himself by the Breath of the All-Merciful

It is mentioned in the sound *Hadith* (الحديث الصحيح), by way of unveiling (كشفا) and not confirmed by transmission (نقلا) from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, concerning his Lord, Glorious and Exalted, that He said—and this is its meaning: "I was a hidden treasure (كنزا لم أعرف), and I loved to be known, so I created the creation and introduced Myself to them, and they knew Me."

When He mentioned love (المحبة), we knew from the reality of love and its necessary consequences what the lover finds within himself. We have explained that love only relates to a non-existent thing whose existence is possible, but which is not existent in the present state. The Cosmos is originated (محدث), and Allah was, and nothing was with Him. He knew the Cosmos from His knowledge of Himself. He only manifested in the Cosmos what He is in Himself. It is as if He was Hidden (باطنا) and became Manifest (ظاهرا) through the Cosmos.

The Cosmos manifested the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) to remove the ruling of love and to breathe out what the lover finds. Thus, He knew Himself by witnessing (شهودا) the Manifest, and He remembered Himself by what He manifested—a remembrance of gnosis and knowledge (ذكر معرفة وعلم).

This is the remembrance of the Cloud (العماء) attributed to the Lord before the creation of creation. It is the general, summarized remembrance. The Words of the Cosmos (كلمات العالم) in their totality are summarized in this Merciful Breath (النفس الرحماني), and their details are inexhaustible.

From this point, those who hold that the division of the body (قسمة الجسم) intellectually extends *ad infinitum* speak, even though it has entered into existence, and everything that enters into existence is finite (متناه). Division has not entered into existence, so it is not characterized by finitude. These are the ones who denied the indivisible atom (الجوهر الفرد), which is the part that cannot be divided.

Likewise, even though the Cloud (العماء) exists, the details of the forms of the Cosmos within it, in terms of arrangement (دنيا وآخرة), are inexhaustible in detail. This is because the Merciful Breath (النفس الرحماني) from the Name The Hidden (الباطن) receives continuous sustenance (الإمداد له دائما), and the remembrance for it is always in summary (الإجمال). Thus, it is in the Cosmos like Adam is among humanity.

When He <<عَلَّمَ آدَمَ الْأَسْمَاءَ كُلَّهَا>> (taught Adam all the Names), He informed us by this that the Cloud, insofar as it is the Merciful Breath capable of receiving the forms of the letters and words of the Cosmos, is the bearer of all the Names. The Words of Allah are inexhaustible, so the remembrance of Allah is continuous. The All-Merciful remembers Allah by His Names, and He is also named by them, for <<فَلَهُ الْأَسْمَاءُ الْحُسْنَى>> (To Him belong the Most Beautiful Names). He remembers Himself by virtue of being the Speaker and the Detailer. Thus, the remembrance of the All-Merciful is summarized, and the remembrance of Allah is detailed.

(Chapter Two) Concerning the Speech of Allah and His Words.

Command (القول) and Speech (الكلام) are two attributes of God. By the Command (القول), the non-existent (المعدوم) hears, and this is His saying, the Exalted: <<إِنَّما قَوْلُنا لِشَيْ‏ءٍ إِذا أَرَدْناهُ أَنْ نَقُولَ لَهُ كُنْ>> (Indeed, Our only word to a thing, when We intend it, is that We say to it: 'Be!'). By the Speech (الكلام), the existent (الموجود) hears, and this is His saying, the Exalted: <<وكَلَّمَ الله مُوسى‏ تَكْلِيماً>> (And Allah spoke to Moses, speaking directly).

Speech (الكلام) may also be applied to the translation in the tongue of the translator, and the Speech is then attributed to the one being translated in that context. Thus, the Command (القول) has an effect on the non-existent, which is Existence (الوجود), and the Speech (الكلام) has an effect on the existent, which is Knowledge (العلم).

The description of alteration (التبديل) in His saying: <<يُحَرِّفُونَهُ من بَعْدِ ما عَقَلُوهُ>> (They distort it after they have understood it), and His saying: <<يُرِيدُونَ أَنْ يُبَدِّلُوا كَلامَ الله>> (They wish to alter the Speech of Allah), refers to the translation (الترجمة), for translation accepts alteration (التبديل). The meanings are dependent upon the Speech (الكلام), so the meaning understood from the original text is not understood from the command that has been distorted (حرف) and altered (بدل). For this reason, alteration and distortion (التحريف) were attached to the original text, even though the original text does not accept distortion or alteration, because it is Divine Speech (كلام إلهي) that cannot be recounted or described by intrinsic description (الوصف الذاتي).

When the Theophany (التجلي) occurs in any form, it must either be one of the forms conventionally attributed with speech, or not. If it is one of the forms conventionally attributed with speech, its speech is of the same kind as the speech attributed to it, due to the form’s ruling over the Theophany, such as His saying: <<عُلِّمْنا مَنْطِقَ الطَّيْرِ>> (We were taught the language of the birds), and <<وقالَتْ نَمْلَةٌ>> (And an ant said).

If it is a form to which speech is not conventionally attributed, it must either be one to which Command (القول) is attributed by faith, such as His saying: <<هذا كِتابُنا يَنْطِقُ عَلَيْكُمْ بِالْحَقِّ>> (This Our Book speaks against you with the truth), and His saying: <<قالَتا أَتَيْنا طائِعِينَ>> (They both said: 'We come willingly'), and His saying: <<يَوْمَ تَشْهَدُ عَلَيْهِمْ أَلْسِنَتُهُمْ وأَيْدِيهِمْ وأَرْجُلُهُمْ>> (The Day when their tongues, their hands, and their feet will testify against them), and His saying: <<قالُوا أَنْطَقَنَا الله>> (They will say: 'Allah has made us speak').

Or, it may be a form to which neither Command nor articulation (نطق) is attributed, and this is the form to which glorification (التسبيح) is attributed, which we do not fathom (لا يفقه). What it says is not heard, since Speech (الكلام) or Command (القول) is that which is inherently related to hearing (السمع). If glorification were a Command or Speech, our hearing would be negated from it. Rather, what is negated from us is our understanding (فقهنا), which is Knowledge (العلم). Knowledge may result from Speech and Command, or it may not.

Thus, when God discloses Himself (تجلى) in such forms, the articulation (النطق) occurs according to what the Discloser (المتجلي) wills, matching the glorification (تسبيح) of that form, and not exceeding it. From the speech of that Discloser, the glorification of that form is understood. This is a wondrous knowledge (علم عجيب) that few among the People of Allah (أهل الله) attain. The Speech attributed to Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, in such forms is contingent upon the state of those forms.

This applies when the Theophany occurs in luminous or natural matters. If the Theophany occurs in neither luminous nor natural matter, but discloses Itself in abstract meanings (المعاني المجردة), then what is said in such a case to be "Speech" is so by virtue of its effect on the recipient of the Theophany, not by virtue of God having spoken specific words.

These effects are all layers of the Speech previously mentioned, called the Words of Allah (كلمات الله), which are the essences of created beings (أعيان الكائنات). The Exalted said: <<وكَلِمَتُهُ أَلْقاها إِلى‏ مَرْيَمَ>> (And His Word which He cast unto Mary), and this Word is the very essence of Jesus (‘Isa). He cast nothing else unto her, nor did she know anything else. If the Divine Word (الكلمة الإلهية) had been a Command or Speech from God, like His Speech to Moses, peace be upon him, she would have been comforted and would not have said: <<يا لَيْتَنِي مِتُّ قَبْلَ هذا وكُنْتُ نَسْياً مَنْسِيًّا>> (Oh, would that I had died before this and become a thing forgotten, utterly forgotten!).

The Divine Word cast unto her was nothing but the essence of Jesus, the Spirit of God and His Word, and His servant. Jesus then spoke, proclaiming his mother’s innocence in an unusual state, so that it might be a sign. His articulation was the Speech of God in the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن). By this, God relieved his mother of the distress caused by the words of her people, who had accused her of what God had purified her from.

It is from this perspective that the Mu‘tazila said that the speaker is the one who creates the speech in that which is not inherently capable of speech, such as inanimate objects, plants, and the state of Jesus, except for those who hold the doctrine of the strange form (الشكل الغريب), who consider such instances to be contingent forms arising in the cosmos.

We have explained to you the meaning of the Speech of God (كلام الله) and His Words (كلماته). The Speech of God, the Exalted, is His Knowledge (علمه), and His Knowledge is His Essence (ذاته). It is not valid for His Speech to be other than Him, for then He would be described as being subject to judgment due to something added to His Essence, and He, the Mighty and Majestic, is not subject to judgment.

Every being possessing speech is described as being capable of speaking and inherently enabled to do so. The Real (الحق) is not described as being capable of speaking in a way that would make His Speech created. His Speech is eternal according to the Ash‘ari school, and the very essence of His Being according to others among the rational thinkers.

The attribution of Speech to God is unknown (مجهولة) and cannot be grasped, just as His Essence (ذاته) cannot be grasped. Speech is only established for the Deity through revelation (شرعاً); the power of the intellect cannot grasp it through its own reflection.

Understand that the Breath (النفس) belongs to the All-Merciful (الرحمن), and the Speech (الكلام) and the Command (القول) belong to Allah. The Command is the culmination of the Breath into the essence of one of the Words (الكلمات), whereby its essence becomes manifest after its latency, and its detail after its generality.

If you say that the purpose of Speech is to make one hear, and there is nothing in Existence (الوجود) but Allah, and He is the Speaker, whom does He make hear? We reply: It is not a condition for the listener to be existent (موجوداً). For He says to the non-existent (المعدوم) in its state of non-existence: "Be!" (كن), and the non-existent comes into being when the Speech of God and His Command for existence relate to its fixed, essential hearing (سمعه الثبوتي). Similarly, the cause of the visible is the permissibility of its existence, or rather, its preparedness and readiness, whether it is existent or non-existent.

The other answer is that just as He speaks by virtue of being described as having Speech, His Speech is heard by virtue of His being the Hearer, and these are two distinct relations.

If you say that the benefit of hearing the Speech is the acquisition of Knowledge, and He is Knower by virtue of His Essence, we reply: Not all speech is intended for the acquisition of what is unknown. The Speaker praises Himself with what He already knows about Himself, not to gain benefit, but for the joy (الابتهاج) of intrinsic perfection (الكمال الذاتي).

The Real has always been a Speaker, and if a manifestation occurs in the cosmos, it does not imply its contingency in reality. The Exalted said: <<ما يَأْتِيهِمْ من ذِكْرٍ من رَبِّهِمْ مُحْدَثٍ>> (No fresh remembrance comes to them from their Lord), meaning fresh *to them*, even if He had spoken it with others before this, such as what is in the Torah and other scriptures that is also in the Quran. This is if we assume that He means the Speech of God which is an Attribute of His. However, the apparent meaning is that the listener only heard the speech of the translator on behalf of God, as He said: "Indeed, Allah said upon the tongue of His servant: 'Allah hears the one who praises Him.'"

Let us now mention the sections concerning the Divine Invocations (الأذكار الإلهية) that are available in the Quran, beginning with seeking refuge (التعوذ) because it is one of the invocations of the Quran.

### (Chapter Three: Concerning the Invocation of Seeking Refuge)

The Exalted said: <<فَإِذا قَرَأْتَ الْقُرْآنَ فَاسْتَعِذْ بِاللَّهِ>> (So when you recite the Quran, seek refuge in Allah). And the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "And I seek refuge in You from You."

Here, the Real (الحق) is the one remembering through the Quran itself. Thus, seeking refuge (التعوذ) is by one Divine Name from another Divine Name, which is what the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, drew attention to with his saying: "And I seek refuge in You from You."

If the reciter—meaning the one remembering through the Quran—is one over whom Satan has sway, then he must say: *A‘udhu billahi min al-shaytan al-rajim* (I seek refuge in Allah from the accursed Satan).

The Real’s seeking refuge is by virtue of His attributes of sanctification (التقديس) and transcendence (التنزيه) from what is attributed to Him that is unfitting for Him, as the Exalted said: <<الله عما يقول الظالمون علوا كبيرا>> (Exalted is Allah far above what the wrongdoers say, with great loftiness), and <<سُبْحانَ رَبِّكَ رَبِّ الْعِزَّةِ>> (Glorified be your Lord, the Lord of Might, above what they describe). Thus, the seeking of refuge is in the Lord of Might <<عَمَّا يَصِفُونَ>> (from what they describe), meaning from the attributes applied to Him that are inappropriate for His Majesty, such as having a consort, a child, or rivals. This is all Divine seeking of refuge, because it is His Speech.

As for seeking refuge *in Him from Him*, this refers to His Theophany (تجلي) in a form that is terrifying (صورة تنكر), so the recipient of the Theophany seeks refuge from it by means of a Theophany in a recognizable form (صورة يعرف), which is the very essence of the first and second forms. We have explained to you in this book that He is the Manifest (الظاهر) in the manifestations of the essences (مظاهر الأعيان). Thus, He is the one sought refuge in, from Himself.

From this category is the saying: "I seek refuge in Your pleasure from Your wrath, and in Your forgiveness from Your punishment." This relates to His saying: <<إِنَّ رَبَّكَ سَرِيعُ الْعِقابِ>> (Indeed, your Lord is swift in punishment), and <<إِنَّهُ لَغَفُورٌ رَحِيمٌ>> (And indeed, He is Forgiving and Merciful). And His saying: <<إِنْ يَنْصُرْكُمُ الله فَلا غالِبَ لَكُمْ وإِنْ يَخْذُلْكُمْ فَمَنْ ذَا الَّذِي يَنْصُرُكُمْ>> (If Allah should aid you, no one can overcome you; but if He should forsake you, who is there that can aid you?). Thus, one seeks refuge in the Helper (الناصر) from the Abandoner (الخاذل), and in the Benefactor (النافع) from the Harm-doer (الضار), and He is the one who speaks the seeking of refuge that manifests through the tongue of the servant.

### (Chapter Four: Concerning the Invocation of the Basmala)

The *Basmala* is your saying: *Bismillah* (In the Name of Allah). For the servant, it is the word of the Presence of Formation (حضرة الكون) for creation, analogous to the Word of the Presence in His saying: *Kun* (Be!). When the servant realizes the *Basmala*, things respond to him just as they respond to *Kun*. It is as if he says: "In the Name of Allah, the cosmos appears."

This is a declaration of a reality coupled with the sincerity of a beloved servant, whose hearing and tongue the Real (الحق) has become. Thus, what proceeds from him is what proceeds from *Kun*. This is His saying: <<فَتَنْفُخُ فِيها فَتَكُونُ طَيْراً بِإِذْنِي>> (And you breathe into it, and it becomes a bird by My permission). The phrase *bi-idhni* (by My permission) relates to the saying *fatunfakhu* (and you breathe). And <<تُبْرِئُ الْأَكْمَهَ والْأَبْرَصَ بِإِذْنِي وإِذْ تُخْرِجُ الْمَوْتى‏ بِإِذْنِي>> (And you heal the blind and the leper by My permission, and when you bring forth the dead by My permission)—meaning, by My command, because I was your tongue and your sight, things that are not possible for one whose tongue I do not speak upon were formed through you. Thus, formation (التكوين) in both cases belongs to Me. Therefore, *Bismillah* is the very essence of *Kun*.

### (Chapter Five: Concerning the Word of the Divine Presence)

This is the Word *Kun* (Be!). God has a Theophany (تجلي) in forms that accept Command and Speech through the arrangement of letters, just as He has a Theophany in other ways, which we mentioned in the Divine Theophany narrated by Muslim in his *Sahih*.

The Exalted said: <<إِنَّما قَوْلُنا لِشَيْ‏ءٍ إِذا أَرَدْناهُ>> (Indeed, Our only word to a thing, when We intend it). Our Command (قولنا) is His being the Speaker, <<أَنْ نَقُولَ لَهُ كُنْ>> (is that We say to it: 'Be!'). *Kun* is the very essence of what He spoke, and from it appeared that which was commanded to be. Thus, He attributed the formation (التكوين) to the thing that comes into being, not to the Real (الحق) nor to Power (القدرة). Rather, He commanded, and the listener, in its state of non-existence (عدمه) as a thingness (شيئية) and fixed essence (ثبوته), obeyed the Command of the Real through an essential hearing (سمع ثبوتي). His Command is His Power, and the acceptance of the commanded entity to be formed is its preparedness (استعداده).

Thus, the essences (الأعيان) appeared in the Breath of the All-Merciful (النفس الرحماني) just as letters appear in the human breath. The thing that comes into being is only the specific form, like the appearance of an engraved image in wood, or a form in despised water, or a form in a rib, or a form in clay. If you say that you came from existence, you speak truly. If you say that you were not, you speak truly.

> If you saw what we saw,
> You would only say: "I am He, and you are He."
> Know that what you heard
> From the Command *Kun*, you were created from it.

> The manifest aspect of the Command was the saying,
> And the inner aspect of the Command was that you were *Kun*.

> The form is the very essence of what appeared to me,
> And it is the Existence (الوجود) that you saw.

> My Lord’s Command established the thing;
> Had that not been, you would not have existed.

> Pure non-existence (العدم المحض) contains no
> Establishment of an essence, so say: "I speak truly."

> Had you not been there, O my beloved,
> When He said *Kun*, you would not have heard.

> So, what did you accept from Him?
> The cosmos, or the essence of you?

The Word of the Presence (كلمة الحضرة) consists of Words (كلمات), as He said: <<وما أَمْرُنا إِلَّا واحِدَةٌ>> (And Our Command is but a single one). He did not repeat it. The essence of the Command is the essence of the formation (التكوين). There is no Divine Command except *Kun*.

*Kun* is a word of existence (حرف وجودي) according to Sibawayh, belonging to the Necessary Existent (واجب الوجود) and not accepting contingent events. The matter itself is difficult to conceive from the perspective sought by the intellect (الفكر), yet it is extremely easy from the perspective established by the Law (الشرع).

The intellect says: There was nothing, then something appeared from nothing. But the Law says—and it is the true Command:

> Nay, there was a thing, and it became a cosmos,
> It was hidden, and it became manifest.

Look at <<إِلَى الْإِبِلِ كَيْفَ خُلِقَتْ>> (Look at the camels, how they were created)—meaning the clouds (السحاب) that come into being from the vapors rising due to the heat within them. The vapors are elemental breath (نفس عنصري) and are not something added to the cloud. It was not a cloud in the breathing out, but it was a thing, and it appeared as a cloud, then condensed, then dissolved into water and descended, then formed vapor, then ascended, and became a cloud.

So look at <<إِلَى الْإِبِلِ كَيْفَ خُلِقَتْ>>. <<أَ لَمْ تَرَ أَنَّ الله يُزْجِي سَحاباً ثُمَّ يُؤَلِّفُ بَيْنَهُ ثُمَّ يَجْعَلُهُ رُكاماً فَتَرَى الْوَدْقَ يَخْرُجُ من خِلالِهِ>> (Do you not see that Allah drives clouds, then joins them together, then makes them into a mass, and you see the rain emerge from within it?). And <<وأَنْزَلْنا من الْمُعْصِراتِ ماءً ثَجَّاجاً>> (And We sent down from the rain clouds pouring water). He creates it as clouds, <<فَيَبْسُطُهُ في السَّماءِ كَيْفَ يَشاءُ ويَجْعَلُهُ كِسَفاً>> (Then He spreads it in the sky however He wills and makes it fragments), which is the multiplicity of essences (تعدد الأعيان). <<فَتَرَى الْوَدْقَ يَخْرُجُ من خِلالِهِ فَإِذا أَصابَ به من يَشاءُ من عِبادِهِ إِذا هُمْ يَسْتَبْشِرُونَ>> (And you see the rain emerge from within it. And when He causes it to fall upon whom He wills of His servants, immediately they rejoice).

The water in the cloud becomes heavy and descends, just as it ascended with the heat it contained, for the smaller seeks the greater. When it becomes heavy, it rests upon the air, and the air is compressed, moving downward, rubbing against the surface of the earth. The heat in the air is strengthened, and the air, with its strong heat, seeks to ascend, seeking the Greatest Pillar (الركن الأعظم). It finds the cloud piled up, and its density prevents it from ascending. The air ignites, and God creates in that flame an angel called lightning (برق), illuminating the atmosphere. Then it is extinguished by the force of the wind, just as a lamp is extinguished, so its light vanishes while its essence remains. Its state of being lightning vanishes, but the essence remains as a cosmos (كون) glorifying God.

Then, the face of the cloud facing the earth is split open. When the air mingles with it, it is like a marriage. From that fusion, God creates an angel called thunder (رعد), which glorifies with the praise of God. Thus, thunder must follow lightning, unless the lightning was *khulb* (false lightning). Every lightning that occurs as we described must be followed by thunder, because the air ascends ignited, and God creates it as an angel called lightning. After this, He splits the underside of the cloud, and God creates the thunder, glorifying with the praise of its Lord, because He brought it into existence. <<وَإِنْ مِنْ شَيْءٍ إِلَّا يُسَبِّحُ بِحَمْدِهِ وَلَكِنْ لَا تَفْقَهُونَ تَسْبِيحَهُمْ>> (There is nothing that does not glorify Him with His praise, but you do not understand their glorification).

There is also lightning that consists of angels created by God during the summer from the heat of the atmosphere due to the sun’s elevation. The sun’s rays descend, and when they burn the ethereal pillar, the heat increases, and the atmosphere ignites from above, and there are no clouds there, because the strength of the heat rarefies the rising vapors, preventing the cloud from manifesting its essence. There, the ruling of the letter *Shin* (ش) applies, which is why it is called the letter of diffusion (حرف التفشي). From that ignition, God creates *khulb* lightning, which is never accompanied by thunder.

All these are contingent events whose essences appeared from the Word *Kun* in breaths (أنفاس). We have brought this example only to familiarize you, so that you may know the forms and essences that God has opened up in this elemental breath (النفس العنصري) called the vapor of formation (بخار التكون). There is a lesson for you, if you possess insight, to transcend this observation to the formation of the world from the Breath of the All-Merciful (النفس الرحماني), which manifests from God’s love that His creation should know Him.

There is nothing in the world, or rather, the world itself is nothing but the Words of God (كلمات الله). The Words of God are His Command (أمره), and His Command is a single one, and it is <<كَلَمْحِ الْبَصَرِ أَوْ هُوَ أَقْرَبُ>> (Like the twinkling of an eye, or even nearer). For there is nothing faster than the twinkling of an eye; the time of its glance is the time of its attachment to the utmost limit it can reach in relation. Similarly, the power of hearing is less than that.

Ponder, O my brother, the Speech of God (كلام الله) and this Glorious Quran, and the details of its verses and chapters. It is a singular Speech (أحدي الكلام) despite this enumeration, which includes the Torah, the Criterion (Furqan), the Gospel, the Psalms, and the Scrolls. So, what is it that enumerated the One, or unified the number?

Look at how the matter stands. If you know this, you will know the Word of the Presence (كلمة الحضرة). If you know the Word of the Presence, you will know its distinction among the Words by the Word *Kun* for every thing, despite the difference in what appeared, and its distinction among the manifest letters by the *Kaf* and the *Nun*, and among the latent letters by the *Waw*.

And how the contingent (العارض) ruled over the fixed (الثابت) by assisting it, returning it to latency (غيباً) after it had been manifestation (شهادة). For the quiescence (السكون) is the ruler from the *Nun*, and it is a contingent state, because the Divine Command (الأمر الإلهي) occurred to it and made it quiescent. It found the quiescence of the *Waw*, and sought its aid against it, just as the servant seeks aid from his Lord against his Lord.

When two quiescent letters met, and the *Nun* desired connection with the *Kaf* due to the speed of the Command’s penetration—so that it would be nearer than the twinkling of an eye, as He informed—the *Waw* vanished from the middle, and the *Kaf* directly touched the *Nun*. If the *Waw* had remained, there would have been slowness in the Command, for the *Waw* must be a *Waw* of causality (واو علة) due to the *dammah* (vowel) on the *Kaf*. The breath would not reach the quiescent *Nun* by the Command until the manifestation of the *Waw* of causality was realized, thus slowing the Command. Since it is a *Waw* of causality, the formation (*Kawn*) would result from two causes: the *Waw* and the Divine Command, and He has no partner.
