If it were permissible for the commanded entity to be slow in formation for a single moment—which is the duration of the *Waw*’s manifestation if it remained and was not deleted—it would be permissible for the commanded entity to remain longer than that, and thus the Command of God would be deficient, and His Will would not be executed, whereas His Will is executed. Therefore, the deletion of the *Waw* from the Word of the Presence is necessary, and speed is necessary. The appearance of the cosmos from the Word of the Presence with speed is necessary.

The cosmos appeared, and the *Waw* appeared in the cosmos (الكون) to indicate that it was present in *Kun*, but only vanished due to a contingent matter. It operated in the latent realm (الغيب) and appeared in the cosmos when the cosmos appeared in the form of *Kun* before the deletion of the *Waw*, to indicate that the *Waw* was not annihilated, but only disappeared for the wisdom we mentioned.

Thus, the cosmos is not an addition to *Kun* with its latent *Waw*. The cosmos appeared in the image of *Kun*. *Kun* is His Command, and His Command is His Speech, and His Speech is His Knowledge, and His Knowledge is His Essence. Thus, the world appeared in His image, and Adam was created in His image, and he accepted the Divine Names. We have explained what is sufficient for the rational person concerning the Word of the Presence. And Allah presents parables to His servants.

### (Chapter Six: Concerning the Invocation of Praise - Tahmid)

Praise (الحمد) is a general commendation unless the speaker restricts it with a specific matter. It has three levels (مراتب): the praise of praise (*Hamd al-Hamd*), the praised entity praising itself, and others praising it. There is no fourth level of praise.

Furthermore, praise, whether the thing praises itself or others praise it, has two divisions: either praising by an attribute of Act (صفة فعل) or praising by an attribute of Transcendence (صفة تنزيه). There is no third type of praise here.

As for the praise of praise (*Hamd al-Hamd*), it resides in the two types of praise by virtue of His Essence (ذاته), for if the Essence were not, the praise would not be valid for them.

> The praise of praise grants praise within it,
> And were it not for the Praise, the Praised One (الحميد) would not be.

Praise directed toward the Praised One (المحمود) is of two kinds: The first is praising Him for what He is intrinsically, which is the general praise (الحمد الأعم). The second is praising Him for what proceeds from Him, which is gratitude (الشكر), and this is the more specific.

Thus, the divisions of commendations and praises are confined, but the specific words that denote what we have mentioned are inexhaustible.

The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said concerning the Praised Station (المقام المحمود): "I shall praise Him with praises I do not know now." And he said: "I cannot enumerate praise upon You."

Because what is inexhaustible cannot enter into existence. Since every essence in the world—which are the Words of the Real (كلمات الحق) manifested from the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن)—is both praising and praised, and the Breath of the All-Merciful is the manifestation of the Inner Name (الاسم الباطن) and the ruling of the Latent (الغيب)—for He is the Manifest and the Latent—the consequences of praise return to Him. Thus, there is no praiser but Allah, and no praised one but Allah.

The praise of praise is His Attribute, because praise is His Attribute, and His Attribute is His Essence, for He does not multiply.

> And He is not perfected by addition, exalted is Allah!
> So the praise of praise is He, and there is none but He.

> None praised Allah but the Deity,
> And His Praised One is His Essence, none other than Him.

Whoever praises God in this manner has truly praised Him. Whoever diminishes anything from that, it is according to the measure of his diminution. If you are a praiser of God, then praise Him with this Presence (حضور) and this conception (تصور), and the recompense from God for the one whose praise is this will be his very essence. Understand this.

### (Chapter Seven: Concerning the Invocation of Glorification - Tasbih)

Glorification (التسبيح) is Transcendence (التنزيه). <<فَسَبِّحْ بِحَمْدِ رَبِّكَ واسْتَغْفِرْهُ>> (So glorify the praises of your Lord and ask His forgiveness)—this is a command. <<سُبْحانَ الَّذِي أَسْرى‏ بِعَبْدِهِ>> (Glorified is He who took His servant on a night journey)—this is a statement.

#### [Glorification is a Division of Praise]

Glorification is a division of Praise (الحمد). For this reason, Praise fills the Scale (الميزان) absolutely, and *Subhan Allah* (Glorified is Allah) and other invocations are encompassed by Praise.

When glorification manifests, look at how you glorify Him, for ignorance subtly penetrates this station in a hidden way that one does not perceive.

This is like when the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said to Hassan ibn Thabit, when he wanted to satirize the Quraysh in defense of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, after the Quraysh had satirized him—and he was from them, so their own breath satirized them without their knowing, but the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, knew it, for he is the most complete Knower.

The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, knew that the satire of the Quraysh that Hassan ibn Thabit was moved to utter was something that pleased God due to Hassan’s good intention. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, only knew this because he saw the Holy Spirit (روح القدس) that came to him also coming to Hassan ibn Thabit, supporting him, without Hassan realizing it, as long as he was defending the honor of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him.

God only affirmed this as a sign to the Quraysh that their deeds would return upon them, since satire was a deed they performed <<لِتُجْزى‏ كُلُّ نَفْسٍ بِما (كَسَبَتْ)>> (so that every soul may be recompensed for what it earned). They acted so that they might know the truthfulness of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him.

The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said to him: "I am one of them, so watch what you say and how you say it. Go to Abu Bakr, for he is more knowledgeable of genealogies, and he will inform you, so that you do not say words that return upon the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and thus fall into what they fell into." Hassan ibn Thabit replied: "By Allah, I shall draw you out from them as a hair is drawn out from dough," because nothing of the dough adheres to it.

The matter of glorification is similar. It is transcendence (تنزيه), and transcendence is an expression of negation (العدم), not true transcendence. True transcendence is only from every attribute that indicates contingency (الحدوث), because He is characterized by Eternity (القدم), and the attributes of contingency belong only to contingent beings (المحدثات).

It is here that feet slip in the knowledge of what contingent beings are, for there is nothing in Existence but Allah. The existent things (الموجودات) are the Words of God (كلمات الله), and by them, praise is offered to God.

If the glorifier (المنزه) transcends his Lord, and he only transcends Him from what is an attribute of the contingent, and the contingent has nothing of itself, nor does its essence belong to it, but rather to the one who manifested it—then if he transcends the Real from something by which He should be praised, and by its likes, he has abandoned the praise that he ought to have offered Him.

Therefore, when you glorify Him, realize from what you are transcending Him, since there is nothing but Him. For the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) is the substance of the existents. For this reason, the Real described Himself with attributes belonging to contingent beings, which rational, theoretical proofs deem impossible, and transcend Him from.

Beware of glorifying Him with your intellect (عقلك). Let your glorification of Him be through the Quran, which is His Speech (كلامه). Thus, you will be a narrator, not an inventor or innovator. If there is any flaw, you will be innocent of it, since nothing has glorified Him but His own Speech, and He knows Himself better than you do. He praises His Essence with the most complete praises and the greatest commendation, as the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "You are as You have praised Yourself."

He has praised Himself with things that the rational proof says are impermissible for Him and transcends Him from. This is the ultimate dispraise and a denial of the Real in what He attributed to Himself, and an assumption that your knowledge of Him is greater than His own.

Beware of transcending Him from a matter that is established in the Law (الشرع) as His description, whatever it may be. Do not glorify Him even a single glorification based entirely on your intellect. I have advised you, for rational proofs are often in conflict with scriptural proofs in matters of divinity.

So, glorify your Lord with the Speech of your Lord and with His glorification, not with your intellect derived from its reflection and speculation, for it has gained nothing more than ignorance. Guard what has been mentioned to you, for it is a chronic disease in which healing is rare.

Dispraise with the dispraise of God, praise with the praise of God, have mercy with the mercy of God, and curse with the curse of God, and you will succeed in knowledge and fill your hands with goodness.

Glorification (التسبيح) is the praise of every existent thing in the world, nothing else. This is what misled the rationalists, and it is part of the subtle Divine Subtlety (المكر الإلهي الخفي). Their intellects missed His saying, the Exalted: <<بِحَمْدِهِ>> (with His praise), which is what we mentioned. The Exalted said: <<وَإِنْ مِنْ شَيْءٍ إِلَّا يُسَبِّحُ بِحَمْدِهِ>> (There is nothing that does not glorify Him with His praise). He did not say "praises" (*yahmad*), nor "magnifies" (*yukabbir*), nor "declares unity" (*yuhallil*), for these are all praises involving existential affirmation. Glorification (التسبيح) is praise involving negation (العدم).

Thus, the Divine Subtlety entered, affecting the reflective intellects. The Gnostics (العارفون) came and found that God had qualified the glorification of everything with His praise (المضاف إليه). So they glorified Him with what He praised Himself with, and they did not deduce anything contrary to that, unlike those who speculate on divinity with their intellects.

For this reason, He said: <<وَلَكِنْ لَا تَفْقَهُونَ تَسْبِيحَهُمْ>> (But you do not understand their glorification), because they forgot the phrase *bi-Hamdihi* (with His praise). Their argument for this was the proofs of their intellects, since God veiled that from them with the veil of their own thoughts. He did not hold them accountable for this, due to His saying: <<إِنَّهُ كَانَ حَلِيمًا غَفُورًا>> (Indeed, He is ever Forbearing and Forgiving), despite the lack of proper etiquette involved from one perspective.

The intercessor for them with God was their saying: <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like unto Him). And in this, they erred. But God accepted the plea of <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> on their behalf, and forgave them for what they hesitated to affirm or deemed impossible, such as God’s settling (استواء), companionship (معية), being in a place (ظرفية), descent (نزول), and countless other things spoken of by His Books and Messengers.

I have made you understand how to glorify your Lord and have set you upon the path. So remember me before your Lord.

### (Chapter Eight: Concerning the Invocation of Magnification - Takbir)

The Exalted said: <<وَلَذِكْرُ الله أَكْبَرُ>> (And the remembrance of Allah is greater). The remembrance of Allah is the Quran. So remember Him with the Quran, and do not magnify Him with your own magnification.

He commanded you to magnify Him, saying: <<وَكَبِّرْهُ تَكْبِيراً>> (And magnify Him with great magnification)—magnification from having a child, a partner, or a protector (*wali*)—and do not neglect in this magnification His saying: *min al-dhull* (out of humiliation), for He qualified it.

He says: <<إِنْ تَنْصُرُوا الله يَنْصُرْكُمْ>> (If you support Allah, He will support you). We do not support Him out of humiliation. For this reason, He said: <<وَلَمْ يَكُنْ لَهُ وَلِيٌّ من الذُّلِّ>> (And He does not need a protector out of humiliation). He called you to support Him to fulfill the right of the form upon which He created you, because He says: <<أَعْطى‏ كُلَّ شَيْءٍ خَلْقَهُ>> (He gave everything its creation). Part of giving the form upon which He created you its right is that He should ask it for His support, for He is the Helper (الناصر). He said: <<كُونُوا أَنْصارَ الله>> (Be supporters of Allah). And the Helper is the Protector (*Wali*). For this reason, He qualified it.

So, when you magnify Him from having a protector, know from which protector you are magnifying Him. The same applies to a partner in sovereignty (الشريك في الملك).

#### [Does the Servant Possess or Not Possess?]

Upon this issue rests the question of whether the servant possesses or does not possess. Those who see the partnership of causes (الأسباب), without which the effects (المسببات) cannot exist, do not affirm a partner in sovereignty, because the cause is part of the sovereignty and is like an instrument (الآلة). The instrument is used to produce what is the property of the originator, just as the instrument is the property of the originator, and the instrument owns nothing.

For this reason, the magnification is qualified against a partner in *sovereignty* (الملك), not in *creation* (الإيجاد). For Allah, the Exalted, brought things into existence in two ways:

1.  A way He brought into existence with the existence of its causes, such as the crafts of the world—the chest for the carpenter, the wall for the builder, and all the crafts of the world. All of it is His creation, the Exalted, yet the attribution is to the carpenter, even though the carpenter did not act independently in making the chest only with his hand, but with multiple tools of iron and other materials. These are the causes of carpentry. The making of the chest is not attributed to any of them, but the chest is attributed as a craft to its maker, and it was only made with the tool.

Then there is another attribution: if the carpenter made it for himself, the chest is attributed to him because it is his property. This relates to His saying: <<وما خَلَقْتُ الْجِنَّ والْإِنْسَ إِلَّا لِيَعْبُدُونِ>> (And I did not create the jinn and mankind except to worship Me). For <<لَهُ مُلْكُ السَّماواتِ والْأَرْضِ>> (To Him belongs the sovereignty of the heavens and the earth). If the wood belongs to someone else, the chest, in terms of its craftsmanship, is attributed to the carpenter, but in terms of ownership, it is attributed to the owner, not the carpenter.

Allah only negated the partner in *sovereignty*, not the partner in *craftsmanship*. <<أَلا لَهُ الْخَلْقُ والْأَمْرُ تَبارَكَ الله رَبُّ الْعالَمِينَ>> (Unquestionably, to Him belongs the creation and the command. Blessed is Allah, Lord of the worlds).

2.  The second way is what He brought into existence without a cause, which is His creation of the essences of the primary causes themselves.

So, when you magnify your Lord from having a protector or a partner, qualify it with what the Real qualified it, and do not generalize, lest you miss much goodness and great knowledge.

Similarly, His saying: And magnify Him from <<أَنْ يَتَّخِذَ وَلَداً>> (that He should take a son). A child (الولد) is not *taken* (متخذ) by the parent, because the parent has no real action in its creation. Rather, he places water in the womb of his companion, and another cause takes over the creation of the child’s essence. The one who *takes* a child is the adopter, like Zayd when the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, adopted him.

So He said to us: <<وَقُلِ الْحَمْدُ لِلَّهِ الَّذِي لَمْ يَتَّخِذْ وَلَداً>> (And say: 'Praise be to Allah, who has not taken a son'). For if He had taken a son, <<لَاصْطَفى‏ مِمَّا يَخْلُقُ ما يَشاءُ>> (He would have chosen from what He creates whatever He willed). He would have adopted whomever He willed. But He did not act like one who takes a son.

And His saying, the Exalted: <<لَمْ يَلِدْ>> (He neither begets) refers to a biological son (*walad al-sulb*). Thus, He has no son, nor did He adopt anyone. He negated sonship from both aspects, because one group of Jews and Christians claimed they were the sons of God, intending adoption, for they knew their fathers. And they said concerning the Messiah that he was the son of God, since they knew no father for him, nor did he come into being through a father, due to their ignorance of what God said about the angel appearing to Mary as <<بَشَراً سَوِيًّا>> (a man in all respects), and God making him a Spirit (روحاً), since Gabriel was a Spirit. Jesus only came into being from two sources. Gabriel bestowed Jesus upon her in the breathing, but they did not perceive this, just as the spirit is breathed into the form when it is perfected. They did not know the spirit of Jesus nor his form. The form of Jesus is like the embodiment of the Spirit, because it resulted from a representation (تمثل). If you were to reflect upon the creation of Jesus, you would see a tremendous knowledge that the understanding of rationalists falls short of.

So, when you magnify your Lord, magnify Him as He magnified Himself: <<تَعَالَى عَمَّا يَقُولُ الظَّالِمُونَ عُلُوًّا كَبِيرًا>> (Exalted is He far above what the wrongdoers say, with great loftiness). The wrongdoers are those who magnify Him from what He did not magnify Himself from, such as His saying: "He rejoices at the repentance of His servant," and "He smiles upon the one who comes to His House," and "He boasts of the people of the standing (at Arafat) to His angels," and "I was hungry, and you did not feed Me."

He lowered Himself to the level of His servant. If you magnify Him by transcending Him from these stations, you have not magnified Him with His magnification, but rather you have denied Him. These are the wrongdoers in reality. His magnification is only what He magnified Himself with. So stop at your limit, and do not judge your Lord with your intellect.

### (Chapter Nine: Concerning the Invocation of Declaration of Unity - Tahlil)

This is the invocation of Unity (التوحيد) by negating everything other than Him, and there is nothing other than Him. If there is nothing other than Him, and you negate the negation, you have affirmed. For the Exalted says: <<وَقَضَى رَبُّكَ أَلَّا تَعْبُدُوا إِلَّا إِيَّاهُ>> (And your Lord has decreed that you worship none but Him). Thus, nothing is worshipped in what is worshipped except Allah.

#### [What is Meant by Unity (Tawhid)?]

This Unity is based on thirty-six aspects—meaning those mentioned in the Quran, insofar as it is the Speech of God. Part of it is the Unity of the One (توحيد الواحد). For this reason, some theological scholars believe that God is the one who unified the One, and were it not for His unification, there would be no one to be called the One. Thus, His Oneness (وحدانيته) manifested the One. Part of it is the Unity of Allah (توحيد الله), which is the Unity of Divinity (الألوهية). And part of it is the Unity of Identity (توحيد الهوية).

We shall mention all of this in this chapter, along with the Divine Names related to this declaration of Unity (التهليل), and we shall not exceed what is mentioned in the Quran concerning it, which are thirty-six instances. These are ten degrees of the celestial sphere (الفلك) by whose movements God ordained the existence of created beings from the various kinds of existents: the world of spirits, bodies, light, and darkness.

These thirty-six are the right of God concerning the existents in the world, for they come into being in the very articulation of the Quran by man. It is like the tenth part (*‘ushr*) in what the heaven pours down, which is called the Highest (الأعلى) from His saying: <<سَبِّحِ اسْمَ رَبِّكَ الْأَعْلَى>> (Glorify the Name of your Lord, the Most High). The declaration of Unity (التهليل) is the tenth part of the invocation, and it is its purification (زكاته), because it is the right of God. It is the tenth of the three hundred and sixty degrees.

From this:

#### (The First Unity)

This is His saying, the Exalted: <<وَإِلَهُكُمْ إِلَهٌ وَاحِدٌ لَا إِلَهَ إِلَّا هُوَ الرَّحْمَنُ الرَّحِيمُ>> (And your God is one God; there is no god except Him, the All-Merciful, the Compassionate). This is the Unity of the One (توحيد الواحد) through the Name *Al-Rahman* (The All-Merciful), who possesses the Breath (النفس). He began with it because were it not for the Breath, the letters would not have appeared, and were it not for the letters, the Words would not have appeared.

He negated divinity from everyone, and the Real (الحق) unified only His Oneness (أحديته), affirming divinity for it by the Identity (الهوية) which refers back to His Name, the One (الواحد). The first attribute He described Himself with is *Al-Rahman*, because He is the possessor of the Breath.

Such an invocation is called *Tahlil* (declaration of unity) from *Ihlal*, which means raising the voice. That is, when one invokes *La ilaha illa Allah* (There is no god but Allah), the voice—which is the breath (النفس) that exits—is raised above every breath in which something other than this Word appeared. For this reason, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The best thing I and the Prophets before me have said is *La ilaha illa Allah*." And none said it but a Prophet, because none informs about the Real but a Prophet. It is the Speech of the Real.

Raise the Words: *La ilaha illa Allah*. It consists of four words: negation, the negated, affirmation, and the affirmed. The four Divine realities are the origin of the world’s existence (Life, Knowledge, Will, and Command/Power—which is the essence of Power rationally, and Command scripturally). The four natural realities are the origin of bodies’ existence (Heat, Cold, Dryness, and Wetness). The four elements are the origin of generated things (Aether, Air, Water, and Earth). The four humors are the origin of animal existence (Two Biles, Blood, and Phlegm). The four realities are the origin of human existence (Body, Nutrition, Sensation, and Articulation).

When the servant says *La ilaha illa Allah* upon this quaternary structure, he becomes the tongue of the world and the deputy of the Real in articulation. Thus, the world and the Real remember Him through his remembrance.

This Word has twelve letters. It has encompassed the simple numbers of this count, which are twelve: the three decades (tens, hundreds, and thousands), and from one to nine. After this, composition occurs, which does not take you beyond these units to the inexhaustible. Thus, what is finite (these twelve) has encompassed what is inexhaustible (what is composed from them).

Although *La ilaha illa Allah* is confined to this number in existence, its recompense is inexhaustible. By it, the ruling of the inexhaustible occurred. The subsistence of Existence, which is not followed by non-existence, is by the Word of Unity, *La ilaha illa Allah*. This is the act of the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن). For this reason, He began with it in the Quran and made it the Unity of the One (توحيد الأحد), because the world appeared from the One Real.

#### (The Second Unity)

From the Breath of the All-Merciful: <<الله لا إِلهَ إِلَّا هُوَ الْحَيُّ الْقَيُّومُ>> (Allah, there is no god except Him, the Living, the Self-Subsisting). This is the Unity of the Identity (توحيد الهوية), and it is the Unity of the Beginning, because *Allah* is the subject (مبتدأ) in it.

He described it in this verse with the attribute of transcendence (تنزيه) from the ruling of slumber (*sinah*) and sleep (*nawm*), due to the forms He manifests in, which are subject to slumber and sleep. For instance, a person sees his Lord in a dream in the image of a human, whose nature is to sleep. So He transcended and unified Himself in this form, even if He appears in it in a vision, for He is not one whom slumber or sleep overtakes. This is the most specific description of Him in this verse.

He placed *Al-Hayy* (The Living) and *Al-Qayyum* (The Self-Subsisting) first, because sleep and slumber only overtake the living and the standing (i.e., the vigilant), since death only comes upon the living. For this reason, it is said of the Real that He is the Living <<الَّذِي لا يَمُوتُ>> (Who does not die). Similarly, sleep and slumber. Slumber is the beginning of sleep, like a breeze is the beginning of wind, for sleep is vapor, which is air, and the breeze is its beginning, and slumber is the beginning of sleep. It only comes upon one characterized by vigilance. This is the Unity of Transcendence from one whose nature is to accept what this Living, Self-Subsisting Deity is transcended from. Were it not for the length, we would mention the rest of the verse with the Divine Names it contains.

#### (The Third Unity)

From the Breath of the All-Merciful: <<الم اللَّهُ لَا إِلَهَ إِلَّا هُوَ الْحَيُّ الْقَيُّومُ>> (Alif, Lam, Mim. Allah, there is no god except Him, the Living, the Self-Subsisting). This is the Unity of the letters of the Breath (توحيد حروف النفس): the *Alif*, the *Lam*, and the *Mim*. We have mentioned the realities of these letters in the second chapter of this book, which is sufficient.

This Unity is also the Unity of the Beginning. It includes the Names of Acts (أسماء الأفعال): the Sender down of the Book in truth from Allah, who is called the Living, the Self-Subsisting. He clarified that He is the Sender down of the four Books, confirming one another, because most witnessing (الشهود) is fourfold. The Divine Books are the Real’s covenants (وثائق الحق) with His servants. They are books of description and verification concerning what He has a right to from them, and what they have a right to from Him, which He made incumbent upon Himself out of grace and favor.

Thus, He entered into the covenant with them, saying: <<أَوْفُوا بِعَهْدِي أُوفِ بِعَهْدِكُمْ>> (Fulfill My covenant, and I will fulfill your covenant). He included us under the covenant, signaling that we have denied our servitude to Him, for if we were truly servants, He would not have written a covenant upon us, as we would be subject to the Master’s ruling. When we became certain of our departure from our reality and claimed sovereignty, disposal, taking, and giving, He wrote contracts between us and Him, and took a covenant and a pact from us, and included Himself with us in that.

Do you not see that the *mukatab* slave (one who contracts for his freedom) is only contracted with when he is lowered to the status of the free? If the scent of freedom were not imagined, the contract of the slave—while he is a slave—would not be valid. For nothing is written upon the slave, nor is any right due to him, as he only acts by the permission of his Master. If the servant fulfills the reality of his servitude, no covenant or pact is taken from him. Do you not see that the runaway slave has a shackle placed upon him, which is the bond (الوثاق), because of his running away? This is analogous to the documents that contain the covenants and contracts that are not valid between the servant and the Master.

The most astonishing verse that passes by the Gnostics is every verse that contains <<أَوْفُوا بِالْعُقُودِ>> (Fulfill the contracts) or covenants, for these are verses that have removed the servants from their servitude to God.

#### (The Fourth Unity)

From the Breath of the All-Merciful, His saying: <<هُوَ الَّذِي يُصَوِّرُكُمْ فِي الْأَرْحَامِ كَيْفَ يَشَاءُ لَا إِلَهَ إِلَّا هُوَ الْعَزِيزُ الْحَكِيمُ>> (It is He who forms you in the wombs however He wills. There is no god except Him, the Mighty, the Wise). This is the Unity of the Will (توحيد المشيئة).

He described the Identity (الهوية) with Might (*‘Izzah*), which is His saying: <<وَلَمْ يُولَدْ>> (And was not born). He is Mighty in His sanctuary, since He is the one who forms us in the wombs without direct physical involvement. If He had been directly involved, the womb would have contained Him, just as the recipient contains the form. If He were not the Former (المصور), this attribution would not be true, and He is the Truthful One.

He did not attribute the forming to anyone else, saying: <<كَيْفَ يَشَاءُ>> (However He wills), meaning, however He intended. In this *kayfiyyah* (modality), it appeared that His Will accepts modality, along with His description of Might (*‘Izzah*) and then Wisdom (*Hikmah*). The Wise (الحكيم) is the one who arranges things that are placed in their proper stations, and forming requires this, since He is the Former, not the angel, along with the Might that befits His Majesty.

This perplexes sound intellects that recognize His Majesty. As for the people of interpretation (*Ta’wil*), they are neither perplexed nor correct—I mean in their delving into interpretation. Even if they agree with the knowledge, they have committed something forbidden to them, about which they will be questioned on the Day of Resurrection, they and everyone who spoke concerning His Essence, the Exalted, and transcended Him from what He attributed to Himself, preferring his intellect over his faith, and judging his Lord’s knowledge by his speculation, which he ought not to have done. This is His saying, the Exalted: "The son of Adam denied Me, and he ought not to have done so."

He mentioned some of what he denied Him in, not all of it, and left him a degree of hope when He attributed him to Himself in the *Hadith Qudsi* where He says: "My servant." But if He says "the son of Adam," which is the sounder narration, He distances him from Himself and attributes him to the manifest Adam, peace be upon him, because the disobedience occurred through the manifest aspect, which was approaching the tree and eating. And he forgot and did not find in himself firm resolve, which is the action of the inner aspect. Thus, his inner aspect was cleared of it, and he was <<عِنْدَ الله وَجِيهاً>> (honored in the sight of Allah), chosen, as the Exalted said.

#### (The Fifth Unity)

From the Breath of the All-Merciful, His saying: <<شَهِدَ الله أَنَّهُ لا إِلهَ إِلَّا هُوَ والْمَلائِكَةُ وأُولُوا الْعِلْمِ قائِماً بِالْقِسْطِ>> (Allah witnesses that there is no god except Him, and the angels, and those having knowledge, standing firm in justice). This is the Unity of the Identity (توحيد الهوية) and the Testimony (الشهادة) concerning the Name *Al-Muqsit* (The Equitable), which is Justice (*‘Adl*) in the world. This is His saying: <<أَعْطى‏ كُلَّ شَيْءٍ خَلْقَهُ>> (He gave everything its creation).

He described Himself with the establishment of balance in Unity—meaning the Unity of Testimony—by standing firm in justice (*Qist*), and He made that for the Identity (الهوية). God was the Witness to that by virtue of all His Names, for He conjoined it with multiplicity, which is His saying: <<والْمَلائِكَةُ وأُولُوا الْعِلْمِ>> (And the angels, and those having knowledge). We know, since He mentioned Allah without specifying a Name, that He intended all the Divine Names that the world seeks through justice, since He does not weigh against Himself. Thus, nothing enters under this except what enters into the balance.

This is the Unity of Justice (*Qist*). We have narrated a sound *hadith* concerning this:

Yunus ibn Yahya narrated to us, from Abu al-Waqt ‘Abd al-Awwal al-Harawi, from Ibn al-Muzaffar al-Dawudi, from Abu Muhammad al-Hamawi, from al-Farabri, from al-Bukhari, from Abu al-Yaman, from Shu‘ayb, from Abu al-Zinad, from al-A‘raj, from Abu Hurayrah, from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, who said: "Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, said: 'Spend, and I will spend upon you.' And He said: 'The Hand of Allah is full, undiminished by spending, pouring forth night and day.' And He said: 'Do you see what He has spent since He created the heavens and the earth? Indeed, it has not diminished what is in His Hand.' <<وَكَانَ عَرْشُهُ عَلَى الْمَاءِ>> (And His Throne was upon the water), and in His Hand is the Scale (الميزان), He lowers and raises."

Muslim also narrated it from Abu Hurayrah, saying: "His Right Hand," and did not say "His Hand," and said: "and in His Other Hand."

This is a sound *hadith*. When the servant stands firm in justice in his declaration of unity to his Lord, his Lord confirms him and says the like of his saying. This is God’s purification of His servant.

More than one person narrated to us, including Ibn Rustam Makin al-Din Abu Shuja‘ al-Isfahani, the Imam of the Station in the Noble Sanctuary of Mecca, and ‘Umar ibn ‘Abd al-Majid al-Miyanashi, from Abu al-Fath al-Karkhi, from al-Tiryaqi Abu Nasr, from ‘Abd al-Jabbar ibn Muhammad, from al-Mahbubi, from Abu ‘Isa al-Tirmidhi, from Sufyan ibn Waki‘, from Isma‘il ibn Muhammad, from Jahadah, from ‘Abd al-Jabbar ibn ‘Abbas, from al-Agharr Abu Muslim, who said: I bear witness that Abu Sa‘id and Abu Hurayrah both bore witness that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever says *La ilaha illa Allah, wa Allahu Akbar* (There is no god but Allah, and Allah is Greater), his Lord confirms him and says: 'There is no god but I, and I am Greater.' And if he says *La ilaha illa Allah wahdahu* (There is no god but Allah, alone), Allah says: 'There is no god but I, and I am alone.' And if he says *La ilaha illa Allah, lahu al-mulk wa lahu al-hamd* (There is no god but Allah, to Him belongs the sovereignty and to Him belongs the praise), Allah says: 'There is no god but I, to Me belongs the sovereignty and to Me belongs the praise.' And if he says *La ilaha illa Allah, wa la hawla wa la quwwata illa billah* (There is no god but Allah, and there is no might and no power except with Allah), Allah says: 'There is no god but I, and there is no might and no power except with Me.' And he used to say: 'Whoever says it in his illness and then dies, the Fire will not consume him.'"

Whoever gives the Real (الحق) its due from himself to his Lord, to others, and to himself, by establishing the balance upon himself in that, leaving no right upon himself for himself or for others whatsoever, stands in this station with the justice (*Qist*) by which he testified for his Lord. This is a testimony of fulfilling rights: <<مَنْ يَكْتُمْها فَإِنَّهُ آثِمٌ قَلْبُهُ>> (Whoever conceals it, his heart is sinful). And whatever right he had due from others, he waived it and did not demand it, since it was his right, so <<وَقَعَ أَجْرُهُ عَلَى الله>> (his reward is due from Allah).

What confirms what we mentioned about giving the Real its due in this testimony is His saying after <<قَائِمًا بِالْقِسْطِ>> (standing firm in justice): <<لَا إِلَهَ إِلَّا هُوَ الْعَزِيزُ الْحَكِيمُ>> (There is no god except Him, the Mighty, the Wise). God testified to His own Unity, and testified that His angels and those possessing Knowledge testified to His Unity. This is part of His establishment of justice, and it is from the category of favor shown to one who offers testimony before being asked for it. For God testified that His servants testified to His Unity before His servants asked Him for it.

He clarified in this verse that testimony must be based on Knowledge (علم), not on mere conjecture or imitation (تقليد), except for the imitation of an infallible one in what he claims. Then you testify for him that you are upon knowledge, just as we testify concerning the nations that their prophets delivered the message of the Real to them, even though we were not present during the time of the delivery. However, we believed the Real in what He informed us of in His Book concerning Noah, ‘Ad, Thamud, the people of Lot, the dwellers of the wood, and the people of Moses.

The testimony of Khuzaymah is only valid for one whose faith is based on knowledge of the one he believes in, not on imitation or good conjecture. Know this.

#### (The Sixth Unity)

From the Breath of the All-Merciful, His saying: <<اللَّهُ لَا إِلَهَ إِلَّا هُوَ لَيَجْمَعَنَّكُمْ إِلَى يَوْمِ الْقِيَامَةِ>> (Allah, there is no god except Him. He will surely assemble you for the Day of Resurrection). This is also the Unity of the Beginning, and it is the Unity of the Identity (توحيد الهوية) described by the Name *Al-Jami‘* (The Gatherer) for judgment and separation.

It is from the mercy of God that He said: <<لَيَجْمَعَنَّكُمْ>> (He will surely assemble you). We are only assembled in that upon which we do not differ, which is the acknowledgment of His Lordship (ربوبيته), glorified be He. If He gathers us by virtue of our acknowledgment of His Lordship, then this is a verse of good tidings and a mention of goodness concerning us, implying the happiness of all, even if we enter the Fire. For the state of gathering prevents the eternity of retribution without end, though the punishment itself may be eternal, and the states within it vary. When the state of retribution and the finding of pain ends, He grants bliss and the finding of pleasure in the punishment itself, which is fitting for one who acknowledged His Lordship, then associated partners, then unified Him in a place other than the realm of obligation (التكليف).

Obligation was a contingent matter that occurred in the middle between the two testimonies and was not fixed. Thus, the ruling remained for the two origins: the first and the last, which is the cause that gathers us on the Day of Resurrection. He only gathered us in that upon which we agreed.

> When they find pleasure in the punishment, they are relieved
> From the painful punishment, and that is the recompense.

Abu Yazid al-Akbar al-Bistami said:

> All my desires I have attained,
> Except the pleasure of my ecstasy in the punishment.

He did not say "in the pain." We have much poetry on this subject.

#### (The Seventh Unity)

From the Breath of the All-Merciful, His saying: <<ذَلِكُمُ اللَّهُ رَبُّكُمْ لَا إِلَهَ إِلَّا هُوَ خَالِقُ كُلِّ شَيْءٍ فَاعْبُدُوهُ>> (That is Allah, your Lord; there is no god except Him, the Creator of all things, so worship Him). This is the Unity of the Lord (*Rabb*) through the Name *Al-Khaliq* (The Creator). This is the Unity of Existence (توحيد الوجود), not the Unity of Estimation (توحيد التقدير), for He commanded worship, and none commands worship except one described by Existence.

He attributed Existence to the Lord (*Rabb*). He placed that Name between *Allah* and the declaration of Unity (التهليل), and made it a specific attribution to us, to the Lord. This is a specific attribution so that we may unify Him in His Lordship and His Majesty, and in the necessity of His Existence, for He does not accept non-existence as the contingent accepts it, for He is the One whose Existence is fixed for Himself.

We also unify Him in His sovereignty by acknowledging our servitude to Him. And we unify Him as the Benefactor (المنعم) for the blessings He bestowed upon us by nourishing us in the darkness of the wombs and in the life of this world. We also unify Him in the interests He brought into existence, by which we are sustained, such as establishing laws, setting up balances, and pledging allegiance to the Imams who uphold the religion. All these aspects were granted by the Name *Al-Rabb*. We unified Him and negated the lordship of all others. Joseph said to his two prison companions: <<أَ أَرْبابٌ مُتَفَرِّقُونَ خَيْرٌ أَمِ الله الْواحِدُ الْقَهَّارُ>> (Are diverse lords better, or Allah, the One, the Irresistible?).

#### (The Eighth Unity)

The Ninth Unity (التوحيد التاسع) from the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) is His saying, the Exalted: <<اتَّبِعْ ما أُوحِيَ إِلَيْكَ من رَبِّكَ لا إِلهَ إِلَّا هُوَ وأَعْرِضْ عَنِ الْمُشْرِكِينَ>> (Follow what has been revealed to you from your Lord; there is no deity except Him, and turn away from the polytheists). This is the Unity of Following (توحيد الاتباع), and it belongs to the Unity of Identity (توحيد الهوية). It is a unity of imitation (تقليد) in knowledge, because it establishes the secondary causes (الأسباب) while removing the authority of the lords (الأرباب) from them, as when [the polytheists] said: <<ما نَعْبُدُهُمْ إِلَّا لِيُقَرِّبُونا إِلَى الله زُلْفى‏>> (We only worship them that they may bring us nearer to Allah in proximity). If they had said, "We do not take them [as gods]," and maintained servitude (العبودية) solely for the presence of Allah, the Exalted, they would have had a way out by acknowledging the Divine secondary causes established in the cosmos (العالم). Thus, the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) was commanded to turn away from polytheism (الشرك), not from the secondary cause (السبب). Indeed, concerning the interests of this worldly life, He said: <<ولَكُمْ في الْقِصاصِ حَياةٌ>> (And there is for you in legal retribution [saving of] life). He provided a reason, and the *lam* of causation (لام العلة) is frequent in the Quran. This [Unity] also contains what was in the Seventh Unity regarding the Unity of the Name *al-Rabb* (the Lord), generalizing the attribution of all of us to Him. Here, however, it is specified for the caller [Muhammad], as if it were a unity in a court of judgment. Thus, it includes the unity of the Just One (توحيد المقسط) for establishing balance in judgment between adversaries, as indicated by His saying: <<وأَعْرِضْ عَنِ الْمُشْرِكِينَ>> (and turn away from the polytheists). It was specified for the caller because he came with the unity of faith (التوحيد الإيماني), not the rational unity (التوحيد العقلي). This is the unity of the Prophets and Messengers, for they did not affirm Unity through speculation, but rather through the necessity of a knowledge (علم) they found within themselves which they could not repel. Thus, he left the polytheists and their deities and isolated himself in the Cave of Hira, devoting himself to worship without a teacher, save what he found within himself, until the Real (الحق) suddenly came to him, which is His saying: <<اتَّبِعْ ما أُوحِيَ إِلَيْكَ من رَبِّكَ لا إِلهَ إِلَّا هُوَ>> (Follow what has been revealed to you from your Lord; there is no deity except Him). That is, He accepts no partner. So, turn away from them until faith (الإيمان) is firmly established, and establish it with the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن), so that you may make for it helpers, and I command you to fight the polytheists, not merely to turn away from them.

The Tenth Unity (التوحيد العاشر) from the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) is His saying: <<إِنِّي رَسُولُ الله إِلَيْكُمْ جَمِيعاً الَّذِي لَهُ مُلْكُ السَّماواتِ والْأَرْضِ لا إِلهَ إِلَّا هُوَ يُحيِي ويُمِيتُ>> (Indeed, I am the Messenger of Allah to you all, [from Him] to Whom belongs the dominion of the heavens and the earth. There is no deity except Him; He gives life and causes death). This is the Unity of Identity (توحيد الهوية) in the Name *al-Mursil* (the Sender), and it is the Unity of Dominion (توحيد الملك). For this reason, He described Himself as giving life and causing death, since the Sovereign (الملك) is the one who gives life and causes death, gives and withholds, harms and benefits. Whoever gives, gives life and benefits; and whoever withholds, harms and causes death. If the withholding is not due to stinginess, then His withholding is protection, providence, and generosity, though the one deprived may not perceive it. The harm in his case lies in his failure to attain his objective due to his ignorance of the benefit in what the Benefactor protected him from. And this deprived one "died" because his will was not executed, just as the will of the dead is not executed. This, then, is Allah's withholding, harming, and causing death, for He is the Bestower of Grace, the Benefactor. So, He sent the Messengers with Unity (التوحيد) as a reminder of their affirmation in the First Covenant (الميثاق الأول). He said: <<وما أَرْسَلْناكَ إِلَّا رَحْمَةً لِلْعالَمِينَ>> (And We have not sent you except as a mercy to the worlds). Whoever affirms His Unity through the tongue of His Messenger, not from his own tongue, Allah will reward him for his unity with the reward of His Messenger. But if he affirms His Unity not through the tongue of His Messenger, but through the tongue of His Message, He will reward him with a Divine recompense (مجازاة إلهية) that is unknown, falling under His saying: <<ما لا عين رأت ولا أذن سمعت ولا خطر على قلب بشر>> (What no eye has seen, nor ear heard, nor has it occurred to the heart of man).

In the Name of Allah, the All-Merciful, the Compassionate.

The Tenth Unity (التوحيد العاشر) from the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) is His saying: <<وما أُمِرُوا إِلَّا لِيَعْبُدُوا إِلهاً واحِداً لا إِلهَ إِلَّا هُوَ سُبْحانَهُ عَمَّا يُشْرِكُونَ>> (And they were not commanded except to worship one God; there is no deity except Him. Exalted is He above what they associate [with Him]). This is the Unity of the Command to Worship (توحيد الأمر بالعبادة). It is one of the most astonishing matters: how can a command be issued concerning something that is intrinsic (ذاتي) to the commanded one? For worship (العبادة) is intrinsic to creatures (المخلوقين). So, why was the command to worship given? As for the believers, their command is to worship Him from the perspective of the Oneness of the Essence (أحدية العين), as He said concerning a group: <<قُلِ ادْعُوا الله أَوِ ادْعُوا الرَّحْمنَ أَيًّا ما تَدْعُوا فَلَهُ الْأَسْماءُ الْحُسْنى‏>> (Say, "Call upon Allah or call upon the All-Merciful. Whichever [Name] you call upon—to Him belong the Most Beautiful Names [الأسماء الحسنى]"). Who, then, is this group commanded to worship one God? [They are commanded] not to look at the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية) in terms of the different meanings they denote, thereby making them subservient to those meanings. Their worship would then be conditioned (معلولة), as they would see that every reality within them is linked to a Divine Reality (حقيقة إلهية) to which its inherent need relates, and these realities are multiple. For the reality of seeking provision only worships *al-Razzaq* (the Provider), and the reality of seeking well-being only worships *al-Shafi* (the Healer). So, it was said to them: "Worship only one God," meaning that every Divine Name, even if it denotes a meaning different from another, also points to a single Essence (عين واحدة) sought by these various relations.

As for those who interpret worship (العبادة) here as referring to actions (الأعمال), they have no knowledge of the [Arabic] language. Action is the form (صورة), and worship is the spirit (روح) of that practical form established by the responsible individual (المكلف). As for the non-believers, who are the polytheists (المشركون), they are those who attributed divinity (الألوهة) to those who do not deserve it, applied its name to something other than its designated referent, and claimed multiplicity (الكثرة) in it, just as they claimed multiplicity in humanity. Their claim regarding humanity is correct, but they did not recognize its invalidity regarding Divinity (الإلهية). That is why they were astonished by its Unity, saying: <<أَ جَعَلَ الْآلِهَةَ إِلهاً واحِداً إِنَّ هذا لَشَيْ‏ءٌ عُجابٌ>> (Has he made the gods [into] one God? Indeed, this is a curious thing!). They did not realize that making divinity multiple is even more astonishing. So, it was said to them: Even if you only worshipped all those you worshipped because you imagined that divinity was their attribute, and thus you worshipped nothing else—that is not the case. For you yourselves testified that you only worship them <<إِلَّا لِيُقَرِّبُونا إِلَى الله زُلْفى>> (that they may bring us nearer to Allah in proximity). Thus, despite your polytheism (شرك), you affirmed that there is a Great God, and that your service to these deities brings you closer to Allah. This is a claim without proof (برهان), which is His saying: <<ومن يَدْعُ مَعَ الله إِلهاً آخَرَ لا بُرْهانَ لَهُ به>> (And whoever invokes another god alongside Allah, for which he has no proof). This verse offers the greatest hope for the polytheist who, through strenuous speculation (نظر جهد الطاقة) and imagination, believes his doubt (شبهه) to be a proof (برهان), thereby establishing an excuse for him before Allah. Since they confessed that they worshipped the partner (الشريك) to bring them nearer to Allah in proximity, the speaker opened the door for objection against himself, by being asked: "How did you know that these stones or others have such a status with Allah that they should be made objects of worship for you?" As He said: <<فَسْئَلُوهُمْ إِنْ كانُوا يَنْطِقُونَ>> (So ask them, if they can speak). Thus, those who worshipped one who speaks and claims divinity are in a better state than those who worship what neither hears nor sees nor avails them anything. This was the argument of Abraham to his father, concerning which the Exalted said: <<وتِلْكَ حُجَّتُنا آتَيْناها إِبْراهِيمَ عَلى‏ قَوْمِهِ>> (And that was Our argument which We gave to Abraham against his people). His father was one of his people. This and other arguments were given to him by Allah. So, Allah commanded them to worship only one God; there is no deity except Him in the reality of the matter (في نفس الأمر). *Subhanahu* (Exalted is He) means He is far removed from having a partner associated with His Divinity (ألوهته). This, then, is the Unity of the Command (توحيد الأمر).

The Eleventh Unity (التوحيد الحادي عشر) from the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) is His saying: <<فَإِنْ تَوَلَّوْا فَقُلْ حَسْبِيَ الله لا إِلهَ إِلَّا هُوَ عَلَيْهِ تَوَكَّلْتُ وهُوَ رَبُّ الْعَرْشِ الْعَظِيمِ>> (But if they turn away, then say, "Sufficient for me is Allah; there is no deity except Him. Upon Him I have relied, and He is the Lord of the Great Throne [العرش العظيم]"). This is the Unity of Sufficiency (توحيد الاستكفاء), and it belongs to the Unity of Identity (توحيد الهوية). When Allah, the Exalted, said: <<وتَعاوَنُوا عَلَى الْبِرِّ والتَّقْوى‏>> (And cooperate in righteousness and piety), He referred us back to ourselves by His command. We hastened to comply with His command. Some of us said: "Had Allah not known that we have a valid role in establishing the righteousness and piety with which we were charged, He would not have referred us back to ourselves." Others among us said: "The cooperation in righteousness and piety that we were commanded to do is for each of us to refer his companion back to his Lord in that matter and seek sufficiency (يستكفي) in Him concerning what he was charged with." This is His saying: <<اسْتَعِينُوا بِاللَّهِ>> (Seek help through Allah) which is a discourse of realization (خطاب تحقيق), and <<اسْتَعِينُوا بِالصَّبْرِ والصَّلاةِ>> (Seek help through patience and prayer) which is a discourse of trial (خطاب ابتلاء). When the people who claimed that they have a verified role in action, and were therefore commanded to cooperate, heard what was said by those who considered it a discourse of trial, or interpreted it as referring back to Allah in that matter—since we know to say <<وإِيَّاكَ نَسْتَعِينُ>> (And You alone we ask for help) and <<اسْتَعِينُوا بِاللَّهِ>> (Seek help through Allah)—which was the saying of Moses to his people, even though they did not seek Allah's help except with a certain degree of self-assertion, though higher than the people of the first station and closer to the Real (الحق). So, they turned away from them in this speculation and did not adopt it. What, then, is their state with the One whose manifestation is: <<وإِلَيْهِ يُرْجَعُ الْأَمْرُ كُلُّهُ فَاعْبُدْهُ وتَوَكَّلْ عَلَيْهِ>> (And to Him [alone] is the return of all matters, so worship Him and rely upon Him)? The Exalted said to them: <<فَإِنْ تَوَلَّوْا>> (But if they turn away) from what you called them to, <<فَقُلْ حَسْبِيَ الله>> (then say, "Sufficient for me is Allah"), meaning, sufficiency is in Allah. <<لا إِلهَ إِلَّا هُوَ عَلَيْهِ تَوَكَّلْتُ وهُوَ رَبُّ الْعَرْشِ الْعَظِيمِ>> (There is no deity except Him. Upon Him I have relied, and He is the Lord of the Great Throne [العرش العظيم]). If He is the Lord of the Throne (العرش), and the Throne encompasses the world of bodies (عالم الأجسام), and you, in terms of your physicality, are the smallest of bodies, then seek sufficiency in Allah, Who is the Lord of such a Throne. And whoever has Allah as his sufficiency returns <<بِنِعْمَةٍ من الله وفَضْلٍ لم يمسسه سوء>> (with favor from Allah and bounty, no harm having touched them), and he comes with what pleases Allah. And Allah is <<ذُو فَضْلٍ عَظِيمٍ>> (Possessor of great bounty) upon whoever makes Him his sufficiency. *Al-Fadl* (bounty) means increase—that is, what He gives is not merely commensurate with one's action, but more than that, something that is magnified in his sight when he witnesses it through direct experience (ذوقا). One of the most astonishing things I saw was from one of the Shaykhs among the People of Allah (أهل الله), who was similar to Abu Yazid in spiritual state (الحال), and perhaps even surpassed him in it. I sat with this person one day in the Umayyad Mosque in Damascus while he recounted his spiritual state with Allah and the events that transpired between them. He told me that the Real (الحق) mentioned to him the greatness of His Dominion. The Shaykh said: "I replied to Him, 'O Lord, my dominion is greater than Yours!'" He said to me, "How can you say that?"—though He knows best. I said to Him, "O Lord, because Your like is in my dominion, for You answer me when I call You and give me when I ask You, but there is nothing like You in Your dominion." He said: "You have spoken the truth." I have not seen anyone who adopted a doctrine close to this, or identical to it, except Muhammad ibn Ali al-Tirmidhi al-Hakim, for he speaks of this station as the Station of the King of Kings (مقام ملك الملك). We have explained this in the *Questions of al-Tirmidhi* in this book, which were asked by the People of Allah in the book *The Seal of the Saints* (ختم الأولياء). Then this Shaykh wept out of reverence (أدبا) for Allah and said, "O my brother, He rewards me for it and treats me intimately." I used to say to him: "If He rejoices at the repentance of His servant, as His Messenger (peace and blessings be upon him) reported about Him, then how must be His regard for those who possess Gnosis (العارفين) of Him?"

The Twelfth Unity (التوحيد الثاني عشر) from the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) is His saying: <<حَتَّى إِذا أَدْرَكَهُ الْغَرَقُ قالَ آمَنْتُ أَنَّهُ لا إِلهَ إِلَّا الَّذِي آمَنَتْ به بَنُوا إِسْرائِيلَ>> (Until, when drowning overtook him, he said, "I believe that there is no deity except that in whom the Children of Israel believe"). This is the Unity of Seeking Aid (توحيد الاستغاثة), and it is the Unity of Connection (توحيد الصلة). The relative pronoun *al-ladhi* (الذي - that in whom) is used in this Unity, which is one of the relative nouns (الأسماء الموصولة). This was used to remove ambiguity from the listeners, just as the sorcerers did when they believed in the Lord of the Worlds, saying: <<رَبِّ مُوسى‏ وهارُونَ>> (The Lord of Moses and Aaron), to remove ambiguity from the minds of the listeners. For this reason, He threatened them, and then [Pharaoh] completed [his statement] by saying: <<وأَنَا من الْمُسْلِمِينَ>> (And I am of the Muslims), when he knew that the God (الإله) is the one who is submitted to, and who submits to no one. Ali ibn Abi Talib said: "I entered into the state of consecration (أهللت) with what the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) entered into," even though he did not know what the Messenger had entered into. This was accepted from him despite his entering into consecration without verified knowledge (علم محقق). How much more so if it is based on verified knowledge! Pharaoh made this known so that his people would know of his retraction from his claim that he was their Lord Most High. His affair is with Allah, for he believed upon seeing the affliction (البأس), and such faith was of no benefit, though the punishment of this world was lifted from him, <<إِلَّا قَوْمَ يُونُسَ>> (except the people of Jonah). The Hereafter was not addressed. Furthermore, Allah confirmed his faith by His saying: <<آلْآنَ وقَدْ عَصَيْتَ قَبْلُ>> (Now? While you had disobeyed before?). This indicates the sincerity (إخلاصه) of his faith. Had he not been sincere, the Exalted would have said concerning him what He said concerning the Bedouins who claimed, "We have believed": <<قُلْ لَمْ تُؤْمِنُوا ولكِنْ قُولُوا أَسْلَمْنا ولَمَّا يَدْخُلِ الْإِيمانُ في قُلُوبِكُمْ>> (Say, "You have not believed, but say, 'We have submitted,' for faith has not yet entered your hearts"). Thus, Allah testified to Pharaoh's faith, and Allah would not testify to anyone's sincerity in his Unity (توحيده) without rewarding him for it. After his belief, he did not disobey, so Allah accepted him if He accepted him in a state of purity. When a disbeliever embraces Islam, he is required to perform a ritual bath (*ghusl*). Thus, his drowning served as a washing and purification for him, since Allah seized him in that state as <<نَكالَ الْآخِرَةِ والْأُولى‏>> (an exemplary punishment for the Hereafter and the first [life]), and made that a lesson <<لِمَنْ يَخْشى‏>> (for whoever fears). His faith does not resemble the faith of one who is gargling [in the throes of death], for the one gargling is certain that he is departing and is decisive about it. This drowning here was not like that, because he saw the sea dry for the believers, and he knew that this was due to their faith. Thus, he was not certain of death, but rather life was predominant in his thought. Therefore, his station is not the station of one who is facing death and says: <<إِنِّي تُبْتُ الْآنَ>> (Indeed, I have repented now), nor is he among <<الَّذِينَ يَمُوتُونَ وهُمْ كُفَّارٌ>> (those who die while they are disbelievers). His affair is with Allah, the Exalted. When Allah said to him: <<فَالْيَوْمَ نُنَجِّيكَ بِبَدَنِكَ لِتَكُونَ لِمَنْ خَلْفَكَ آيَةً>> (So this day We will save you in body that you may be to those who succeed you a sign), just as the people of Jonah were [a sign]. This is a connected faith (إيمان موصول). The Identity (الهوية) was placed before its two distant pronouns [in the verse] so that it may be attached to the Unity of Identity (توحيد الهوية).

The Thirteenth Unity (التوحيد الثالث عشر) from the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) is His saying: <<فَإِلَّمْ يَسْتَجِيبُوا لَكُمْ فَاعْلَمُوا أَنَّما أُنْزِلَ بِعِلْمِ الله وأَنْ لا إِلهَ إِلَّا هُوَ فَهَلْ أَنْتُمْ مُسْلِمُونَ>> (But if they do not respond to you, then know that what has been revealed was revealed with the Knowledge of Allah, and that there is no deity except Him, so are you Muslims?). This is the Unity of Response (توحيد الاستجابة), and it is the Unity of *Huwa* (He), a strange unity. For His saying <<فَإِلَّمْ يَسْتَجِيبُوا>> (But if they do not respond) refers to the claimants [of prophethood], and <<لَكُمْ>> (to you) refers to the callers [the prophets]. <<فَاعْلَمُوا أَنَّما أُنْزِلَ بِعِلْمِ الله>> (then know that what has been revealed was revealed with the Knowledge of Allah). The pronoun in *fa'lamu* (then know) refers back to the callers, and they already know that it was revealed with the Knowledge of Allah. Had He intended the claimants, He would have said *fa-ya'lamu* (then they know) with the *ya* of the third person, just as He said *yastajibu* (they respond) with the *ya* of the third person. Then He said: <<وأَنْ لا إِلهَ إِلَّا هُوَ>> (and that there is no deity except Him), meaning, "And know that there is no deity except Him," just as you know that it was revealed with the Knowledge of Allah. Then He said: <<فَهَلْ أَنْتُمْ مُسْلِمُونَ>> (so are you Muslims?), even though they were already Muslims. All of this is addressed to the callers if the particle *hal* (هل - are/is) retains its original interrogative meaning. However, if it is used here as it is in His saying: <<هَلْ أَتى‏ عَلَى الْإِنْسانِ>> (Has there come upon man...), relying on the contextual indicator (قرينة الحال), then it is removed from being a question. Otherwise, this would not be addressed to the callers unless it is like the saying:

> إياك أعني فاسمعي يا جارة
> I mean you, so listen, O neighbor.

The address is to Zayd, but the intended party is Amr. [Similarly, verses like] <<ولَئِنْ أَشْرَكْتَ لَيَحْبَطَنَّ عَمَلُكَ>> (If you should associate [anything] with Allah, your work would surely become worthless) and <<فَإِنْ كُنْتَ في شَكٍّ مِمَّا أَنْزَلْنا إِلَيْكَ فَسْئَلِ الَّذِينَ يَقْرَؤُنَ الْكِتابَ من قَبْلِكَ>> (So if you are in doubt concerning that which We have revealed to you, then ask those who have been reading the Scripture before you). It is known that [the Prophet] is forgiven for his past and future sins, and he is <<عَلى‏ بَيِّنَةٍ من رَبِّهِ>> (upon clear evidence from his Lord) concerning his wealth. Thus, we know by contextual indicators that he is the one addressed, but the intended party is someone else, not him. The wisdom behind this is the correspondence of turning away with turning away. Because they turned away from accepting the call of the callers, Allah turned away from them in the address, though they are the intended party, making them hear [the message] through others. As for the benefit of Knowledge (العلم) in this, it is that you might say: "Since Allah knew that a people would not believe, the benefit of addressing them was removed, and their address would be futile." So, Allah, the Exalted, informed them that the revelation of the address of the call to those who will not accept it is, in Allah's Knowledge (علم الله), only revealed by Allah's Knowledge. That is, its revelation was predetermined in Allah's Knowledge, and it must be revealed, because the alteration of the Known (المعلوم) is impossible, as He said: <<ما يُبَدَّلُ الْقَوْلُ لَدَيَّ>> (The word will not be changed with Me). This is because it was predetermined in Allah's Knowledge that there would be five prayers in action but fifty in reward. He continued to reduce the fifty, by Allah's Knowledge, until it reached Allah's Knowledge of establishing the five. He then denied any further reduction, saying: <<ما يُبَدَّلُ الْقَوْلُ لَدَيَّ>>. Thus, Allah's Knowledge concerning things is prior; no new knowledge (علم) arises for Him, but rather the relation (التعلق) arises, not the knowledge. If knowledge were to arise anew, confidence in His promise would be lost, for we would not know what might arise for Him. If you say, "This also applies to the threat (الوعيد)," we reply: "We used to say that, but we learned that He only sent a Messenger with the language of his people and with what they agreed upon as praiseworthy, and He deals with them accordingly in their law (*shari'a*). This is how His Knowledge preceded." This is <<لِسانٌ عَرَبِيٌّ مُبِينٌ>> (a clear Arabic tongue). Among the things praised by the speakers of this language—indeed, it is praise in every nation—is the overlooking of the execution of a threat (الوعيد) against the wrongdoer and pardoning him, while fulfilling the promise (الوعد) which is for good. This is what the Arab poet says about:

> وإني إذا أوعدته أو وعدته *** لمخلف إيعادى ومنجز موعدي‏
> And indeed, when I threaten him or promise him, I break my threat but fulfill my promise.

Thus, the revelation of the threat (الوعيد) was by Allah's Knowledge (علم الله) which preceded its revelation, but its execution concerning a certain people was not in Allah's Knowledge. Had it been in Allah's Knowledge, it would have been executed upon them, just as the promise (الوعد) which is for good is executed, because threatening (*i'wad*) is only for evil, while promising (*wa'd*) is for both good and evil. It is said: "I threatened him (*aw'adtu-hu*) with evil," and "I promised him (*wa'adtu-hu*) with evil and good." The Exalted said: <<وما أَرْسَلْنا من رَسُولٍ إِلَّا بِلِسانِ قَوْمِهِ لِيُبَيِّنَ لَهُمْ>> (And We did not send any messenger except with the language of his people, so that he might make [things] clear to them). Among what the Exalted made clear to them is the overlooking of evil deeds concerning those of His servants who commit evil, and the seizing of evil deeds from whomever He wills among His servants. He did not do this regarding the promise of good. Thus, He informed us of what is in His Knowledge. Just as He is One in His Divinity (ألوهيته), He is One in His Command (أمره). Therefore, nothing is revealed except by Allah's Knowledge, whether it is executed or not.

The Fourteenth Unity (التوحيد الرابع عشر) from the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) is His saying: <<وهُمْ يَكْفُرُونَ بِالرَّحْمنِ قُلْ هُوَ رَبِّي لا إِلهَ إِلَّا هُوَ عَلَيْهِ تَوَكَّلْتُ وإِلَيْهِ مَتابِ>> (And they disbelieve in the All-Merciful. Say, "He is my Lord; there is no deity except Him. Upon Him I have relied, and to Him is my return"). This is the Unity of Return (توحيد الرجعة), and it is the Unity of Identity (توحيد الهوية). He informed that they disbelieve in *al-Rahman* (the All-Merciful) because they treated this Name as foreign, as it was not known to them nor had they heard of it before this. When <<قِيلَ لَهُمُ اسْجُدُوا لِلرَّحْمنِ قالُوا وما الرَّحْمنُ>> (it was said to them, "Prostrate to the All-Merciful," they said, "And what is the All-Merciful?"), and this Name <<وزادَهُمْ هذا الاسم نُفُوراً>> (increased them in aversion). They only knew *Allah*, the One for whom they worshipped partners to bring them nearer to Allah in proximity. When they were told to worship Allah, they did not say, "And what is Allah?" but rather they denied His Unity (توحيده). It has been transmitted that they knew *al-Rahman al-Rahim* (the All-Merciful, the Compassionate) as a single compound name, like Ba'labak or Ramhormuz. When He isolated it and used it without attribution, they denied it, just as in attribution one says *Ba'li*. So, the caller said to them: "The All-Merciful is my Lord," and did not say, "He is Allah," because they do not deny the Lord (*al-Rabb*). Since *al-Rahman* (the All-Merciful) possesses the Breath (النفس), and by the Breath is their life, He interpreted it with *al-Rabb* (the Lord), because He is the Sustainer, and by sustenance is their life. Thus, they do not flee from the Lord, but they flee from Allah. For this reason, they worshipped partners to intercede for them with Allah, since in His hand is the Divine Power (الاقتدار الإلهي) and the severe grasp. He is the Great, the Exalted, in their view, and they acknowledge and affirm Him. So, He was gentle with them by expressing it through the Name *al-Rabb* so that they might return, as it is closer in suitability to *al-Rahman*. He said to Moses and Aaron: <<فَقُولا لَهُ قَوْلًا لَيِّناً لَعَلَّهُ يَتَذَكَّرُ أَوْ يَخْشى‏>> (And speak to him with gentle speech that perhaps he may be reminded or fear). Hope (*al-tarajji*) from Allah is a certainty, just as they said concerning *‘asa* (perhaps), for both are words of hope. He did not say to them, "Perhaps he will be reminded or fear in that assembly, inevitably," nor did He specify it for the future of the Hereafter, for everyone will fear Him in that station. Rather, He used the verb of the present state, which admits possibility between the state of this world and the future delay for the abode of the Hereafter. This would not be specified for the future except with the particles *sa* or *sawfa*. Thus, what was hoped for from Pharaoh occurred, because the hope of the Exalted is a certainty. Pharaoh believed, was reminded, and feared, as Allah informed. The gentleness of the speech of Moses and Aaron had an effect on him, and the Divine hope occurred as He informed. This indicates the acceptance of his faith, because He only specified the hope for remembrance and fear, not the time, except that it was during the time of the call, and that occurred during the time of the call, which is the worldly life. He commanded His Prophet to say, so that they might hear: <<قُلْ هُوَ رَبِّي لا إِلهَ إِلَّا هُوَ عَلَيْهِ تَوَكَّلْتُ>> (Say, "He is my Lord; there is no deity except Him. Upon Him I have relied") concerning your affair, and <<وإِلَيْهِ مَتابِ>> (and to Him is my return), meaning, my reference point concerning your affair, hoping that He may guide you to faith. He did not speak harshly to them; rather, this too is gentle speech, so that the motives of the addressed parties might be abundant for considering what He addressed them with. For if He had addressed them with the Attribute of Compulsion (*al-Qahr*), which is an unseen reality with no immediate manifestation other than mere harshness of speech, their natures would have recoiled, and the zeal of the Age of Ignorance (*Jahiliyya*) would have seized them concerning those whom they had set up as deities. So, He preserved them, which is His saying, the Exalted: <<وما أَرْسَلْناكَ إِلَّا رَحْمَةً لِلْعالَمِينَ>> (And We have not sent you except as a mercy to the worlds), and He did not say "to the believers." The reason for its revelation was that [the Prophet] prayed against the tribes of Ri'l, Dhakwan, and Usayya for a full month in every prayer, asking Allah to seize them. Allah admonished him for this. This serves as a reminder of Allah's Mercy (رحمة) toward His servants, because in any case, they are His servants, acknowledging Him, believing in His Greatness, and seeking proximity to Him. However, they were ignorant of the path to proximity, did not give speculation (النظر) its due, and did not establish a strong doubt (شبهة) in the form of a proof (برهان). Thus, they fell under the meaning of His saying: <<ومن يَدْعُ مَعَ الله إِلهاً آخَرَ لا بُرْهانَ لَهُ به>> (And whoever invokes another god alongside Allah, for which he has no proof). The proof (البرهان) intended here is what the speculator claims to be proof, for it is impossible for there to be evidence in the reality of the matter (في نفس الأمر) for another god. The only remaining possibility is that the doubt appears in the form of a proof, and he believes it to be a proof, and he has no power beyond this.

The Fifteenth Unity (التوحيد الخامس عشر) from the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) is His saying: <<يُنَزِّلُ الْمَلائِكَةَ بِالرُّوحِ من أَمْرِهِ عَلى‏ من يَشاءُ من عِبادِهِ أَنْ أَنْذِرُوا أَنَّهُ لا إِلهَ إِلَّا أَنَا فَاتَّقُونِ>> (He sends down the angels with the Inspiration [الروح] by His command upon whomever He wills of His servants, [saying], "Warn that there is no deity except Me, so fear Me [and be mindful of Me]"). This is the Unity of Warning (توحيد الإنذار), and it is the Unity of Turning Back [to God] (توحيد الإنابة). In this descent of Unity, the human messengers and those sent to them are equal. The angels are the ones who descended with the warning because of Allah's command to them to do so. The Spirit (الروح) here is the warning they descended with, so that whoever accepts it among His servants may be given life by its acceptance, just as bodies are given life by souls (الأرواح). Thus, the human messengers were given life by this revealed Spirit, and they warned with it. This is a tremendous unity, descended from a Mighty Compeller (جبار عظيم) with intimidation and threat, yet containing a subtle kindness in His saying: <<فَاتَّقُونِ>> (so fear Me). That is, "Make Me a shield (وقاية) by which you repel what I have warned you about." This is His kindness. It does not mean "fear Me" [in the sense of terror], because Allah has no absolute, severe threat and grasp (بطش) that contains nothing of mercy (الرحمة) and kindness (اللطف). For this reason, Abu Yazid, upon hearing a reciter read: <<إِنَّ بَطْشَ رَبِّكَ لَشَدِيدٌ>> (Indeed, the grasp of your Lord is severe), said: "My grasp is more severe." For when a creature (المخلوق) grasps, there is nothing of mercy in his grasp. Moreover, he may not be able to inflict upon the seized one the full extent of the vengeance he feels, due to the swift death of that person. Since mercy is removed from his grasp, he said, "My grasp is more severe." The reason for this is the creature's narrowness, for he does not possess the Divine vastness. Although Allah's grasp is severe, there is mercy in His grasp toward the one seized. The creature's grasp is to relieve himself of the distress and constraint he feels within himself by inflicting it upon the seized one, seeking relief for himself in his grasp at that moment, though he may not attain it fully. This is unlike the Real (الحق), the Exalted, whose grasp, due to the precedence of Knowledge (سبق العلم), seizes the one seized only for the cause that necessitates it. And the one who takes vengeance for another is not like the one who takes vengeance for himself.

The Sixteenth Unity (التوحيد السادس عشر) from the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) is His saying: <<فَإِنَّهُ يَعْلَمُ السِّرَّ وأَخْفى‏ الله لا إِلهَ إِلَّا هُوَ لَهُ الْأَسْماءُ الْحُسْنى‏>> (Indeed, He knows the secret and what is more hidden. Allah—there is no deity except Him. To Him belong the Most Beautiful Names [الأسماء الحسنى]). This is the Unity of Substitution (توحيد الأبدال), for He substituted *Allah* for *al-Rahman*. In meaning, this is the substitution of the definite for the indefinite, because they denied *al-Rahman*. In wording, it is the substitution of the definite for the definite. It belongs to the Unity of Identity (توحيد الهوية) which subsists by the rulings of the Beautiful Names (الأسماء الحسنى), not that the meanings of the Beautiful Names subsist by it. Rather, it subsists by the meanings of the Names, just as <<هُوَ قائِمٌ عَلى‏ كُلِّ نَفْسٍ بِما كَسَبَتْ>> (He is Guardian over every soul with what it has earned). Likewise, He subsists by every Name according to what it denotes. This is an obscure knowledge (علم غامض). For this reason, He said in this Unity: <<يَعْلَمُ السِّرَّ وأَخْفى‏>> (He knows the secret and what is more hidden), following His saying: <<وإِنْ تَجْهَرْ بِالْقَوْلِ>> (And if you speak aloud). What is more hidden (*al-akhfa*) from the possessor of the secret is what he does not know, yet what he must necessarily know specifically. He is only named by the rulings of His Acts (أفعاله) through the path of meaning. All of them are Beautiful Names (أسماء حسني), except that some are pronounced, and some are known but not pronounced, due to the customary ruling of applying blame to them. Indeed, He says: <<فَأَلْهَمَها فُجُورَها وتَقْواها>> (And inspired it [with discernment of] its wickedness and its righteousness). He placed wickedness (*fujur*) before righteousness (*taqwa*) out of concern for us regarding the conclusion and the ultimate goal of goodness. Had He placed wickedness after righteousness, it would have been among the hardest things for us to hear. Wickedness exposes one to affliction (*bala'*), while righteousness secures mercy (الرحمة). Since righteousness is mentioned later, it can only be good. The Exalted also said: <<الله يَسْتَهْزِئُ بِهِمْ>> (Allah ridicules them), yet no Name is derived from it for Him, for the reason we mentioned. Thus, <<فَلَهُ الْأَسْماءُ الْحُسْنى‏>> (To Him belong the Most Beautiful Names) according to convention, while the beauty of others is concealed and unknown by convention, except to the Gnostics of Allah (العارفين بالله). Due to the definite article *alif-lam* (ال) which signifies comprehensiveness, everything to which the name "secret" applies, and what is more hidden than that secret, is included in this Knowledge. Among the secrets is marriage (*nikah*). The Exalted said: <<ولكِنْ لا تُواعِدُوهُنَّ سِرًّا>> (But do not promise them secretly), meaning, marriage. Allah also knows this, even though the apparent meaning of the verse points to what a person speaks to himself, due to His saying: <<وإِنْ تَجْهَرْ بِالْقَوْلِ>> (And if you speak aloud). He knows that, and He knows what you speak to yourself, which is His saying: <<ونَعْلَمُ ما تُوَسْوِسُ به نَفْسُهُ>> (And We know what his soul whispers to him). Nevertheless, the *alif-lam* has a ruling concerning the absolute name of the secret, so He knows what marriage produces, which is His saying, the Exalted: <<ويَعْلَمُ ما في الْأَرْحامِ>> (And He knows what is in the wombs), for He is the Creator of what is in them. <<أَ لا يَعْلَمُ من خَلَقَ وهُوَ اللَّطِيفُ>> (Does He who created not know? And He is the Subtle [اللطيف]) due to His knowledge of the secret, <<الْخَبِيرُ>> (the All-Aware) due to His knowledge of what is more hidden. From this Divine Presence (الحضرة) comes the establishment of proofs (الأدلة) for His Gnosis (معرفته). He placed within the souls of scholars the composition of premises (المقدمات) according to a specific aspect (الوجه الخاص) and a specific condition (الشرط الخاص). Thus, the premises resemble the sexual union (*wiqa'*) of a married couple, so that production (الإنتاج) may result from it. The specific aspect that links the two premises is that one element of the two premises is repeated in both to connect them for the sake of production. The specific condition is that the predicate (الحكم) must be more general than the cause (*illa*) or equal to it, so that the desired conclusion falls under the predicate. If the predicate were more specific, it would not produce a result and would be excluded. An example is their saying: "Everything that is not devoid of originated events (*hawadith*) is originated (*hadith*)." Here, *hadith* (originated) is the predicate, and the other premise is: "Bodies are not devoid of originated events." *Hawadith* (originated events) is the specific aspect that unites the two premises, resulting in the necessary conclusion that the body is originated. The predicate is more general because the cause is the originated events subsisting in it, and the predicate is its being originated. Not everything originated is said to be "not devoid of originated events." Thus, this predicate is more general than the cause, and the result is correct. The detailed explanation for correcting the two premises is a known path, but we only intended to provide an example, not to establish the origination of bodies or anything else. If you know that origination (الإيجاد) is only valid according to what we have established—which is analogous to the secret (السر) in marriage—you move on to the knowledge of what is more hidden than the secret. Just as you move from the example I gave you to the fact that the Real (الحق) brought the cosmos (العالم) into existence in this manner, and the cosmos appeared from an Essence (ذات) described by Power (القدرة) and Will (الإرادة). The Will related to the bringing into existence of a specific existent, which is the orientation (التوجه), like the union of the spouses. Then the Power (الاقتدار) was executed, and He brought into existence what He willed. This was more hidden than the secret because of our ignorance regarding the relation of this orientation to this Essence (الذات) and the relation of the Attributes (الصفات) to it, since they are unknown to us and cannot be known. Thus, the orientation and the attribute are known in terms of their specific reality, but the nature of the relation is unknown due to our ignorance of the related-to (the Essence), not the related (the Attribute). This, then, is the Unity of the Originator of things (توحيد الموجد) who is One in multiplicity despite the abundance of relations.
