This knowledge has caused confusion regarding this known reality, except for those from whose eyes Allah has removed the veil of concealment (غطاء الستر), so they perceive the matter as it truly is and judge according to what they witness. Scholars have differed on whether the occurrence of such a thing is permissible or not.

The Seventeenth Unity (التوحيد السابع عشر) from the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) is His saying: <<وأَنَا اخْتَرْتُكَ فَاسْتَمِعْ لِما يُوحى‏ إِنَّنِي أَنَا الله لا إِلهَ إِلَّا أَنَا فَاعْبُدْنِي>> (And I have chosen you, so listen to what is revealed. Indeed, I am Allah; there is no deity except Me, so worship Me). This is the Unity of Listening (توحيد الاستماع), and it is the Unity of Turning Back [to God] (توحيد الإنابة). It is strengthened by the plural reading, for it has been recited as *wa-ana ikhtarnaka* (And We have chosen you), indicating multiplicity. Then He used the singular, saying: <<إِنَّنِي>> (Indeed, I). Although the word *inna* (إن) is for emphasis, the *inniyya* (the "I-ness") is the Reality (الحقيقة). Since the ruling of the pronominal *ya* (ياء المتكلم) affects the form of the Reality, [the Reality] looked for something in Existence (الوجود) that resembled its form and found a *nun* among the *nuns*. It said to it: "Protect me with yourself because of the pronominal *ya*, lest it affect the form of my Reality, causing the observer and listener to witness a change in the Reality, [believing] that the *ya* is the very Essence of the Reality." So, the *nun* of protection (*nun al-wiqaya*) came and intervened between the *ya* and the *nun* of the Reality. The *ya* then caused the adjacent *nun* to take the vowel *kasra*. It was named the *nun* of protection because it protected the Reality with itself, so the Reality remained as it was, untouched by change. Thus, He said: <<إِنَّنِي أَنَا الله>> (Indeed, I am Allah). Had the *nun* of protection not been present, He would have said *inni ana Allah*, thereby changing it. The change of the Reality by the pronoun in the present moment is the station of His Theophany (تجليه) in forms on the Day of Resurrection. There are only two specific forms, with no third: a form that is denied and a form that is recognized. Even if the forms are infinite, they are confined to this ruling: they must either be denied or recognized. If the reading is <<وأَنَا اخْتَرْتُكَ>> (And I have chosen you) [singular], it is more appropriate for the verse, more suitable, and more negating of change, for Unity (التوحيد) accompanies it until the end of the verse in His saying: <<فَاعْبُدْنِي>> (so worship Me). If it is read in the plural (*wa-ana ikhtarnaka*), change appears through the transition in the single Essence (العين الواحدة) from the many to the One. The context of the verse strengthens the reading *wa-ana ikhtarnaka* (We have chosen you) because He enumerated matters that require different Names, necessitating change and Theophany (التجلي) in every form to which He calls. The total number of forms that appeared to Moses in this event, according to tradition, was twelve thousand forms, in each of which He said to him, "O Moses," so that Moses would be alert to the fact that if He had remained in a single form, the speech would not have flowed, and He would not have said "O Moses" in every word. Know this, for this Unity in this verse is one of the most difficult, due to His saying *wa-ana ikhtarnaka* (We have chosen you), using the plural, then the singular, and then enumerating what He spoke to Moses (peace be upon him). This, then, is the Unity of Gathering/Plurality (توحيد الجمع) according to every reading. However, His saying *wa-ana ikhtarnaka* was recited by Hamza to the Lord of Might in a dream, and his Lord said to him, "And We have chosen you." Thus, it is a *Barzakh* (Isthmus/برزخ) reading. For this reason, the plural was used, because it is a formal Theophany (تجل صوري) in a dream, and the reading must necessarily be thus. If you use the singular after the plural, it is solely for the Oneness of the Gathering (أحدية الجمع).

The Eighteenth Unity (التوحيد الثامن عشر) from the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) is His saying: <<إِنَّما إِلهُكُمُ الله الَّذِي لا إِلهَ إِلَّا هُوَ وَسِعَ كُلَّ شَيْ‏ءٍ عِلْماً>> (Your God is only Allah, the One besides whom there is no deity; He encompasses all things in [His] Knowledge). This is the Unity of Vastness (توحيد السعة), belonging to the Unity of Identity (توحيد الهوية). It is a unity of transcendence (*tanzih*) so that one does not imagine His vastness (سعته) to be a container for the cosmos (العالم), due to the Names *al-Batin* (the Inner) and *al-Zahir* (the Outer), the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن), the Words that are inexhaustible, and the Speech. So, He said that His vastness is His Knowledge (علمه) of everything, not that He is a boundary for anything. The reason for this Unity relates to the story of the Samiri and his saying about the calf when he threw into it what he had grasped from the Messenger's trace. The calf thus became a container for what was thrown into it. When the calf lowed, he said: <<هذا إِلهُكُمْ وإِلهُ مُوسى‏>> (This is your god and the god of Moses). So, Allah said: <<إِنَّما إِلهُكُمُ>> (Your God is only) one God, in whom there is no composition (تركيب). <<وَسِعَ كُلَّ شَيْ‏ءٍ عِلْماً>> (He encompasses all things in Knowledge), meaning, He is Knower of everything. He thus refuted the Samiri's statement. Then He established for them the proof of the Samiri's lie, despite the calf having lowed, by saying what Abraham said concerning the idols: <<أَ فَلا يَرَوْنَ أَلَّا يَرْجِعُ إِلَيْهِمْ قَوْلًا>> (Do they not see that it does not return to them a word?), meaning, when asked, it does not speak, whereas Allah is characterized by Speech. And it <<لا يَمْلِكُ لَهُمْ ضَرًّا ولا نَفْعاً>> (does not possess for them [the power of] harm or benefit), meaning, they derive no benefit from it, because [Moses] said: <<لَنُحَرِّقَنَّهُ ثُمَّ لَنَنْسِفَنَّهُ في الْيَمِّ نَسْفاً>> (We will surely burn it and then scatter it into the sea, scattering). How can one who cannot repel harm from himself repel it from others? And when he burned it and scattered it, they could not benefit from it. Had he left it, doubt (الشبهة) would have entered their minds due to the harm and benefit found in living creatures. In the establishment of these proofs are great matters. The Exalted said concerning the Jews that they said: <<يَدُ الله مَغْلُولَةٌ>> (The hand of Allah is chained), and they said: <<إِنَّ الله فَقِيرٌ ونَحْنُ أَغْنِياءُ>> (Indeed, Allah is poor, and we are rich). And He said: <<إِنَّما قَوْلُنا لِشَيْ‏ءٍ إِذا أَرَدْناهُ أَنْ نَقُولَ لَهُ كُنْ فَيَكُونُ>> (Our word to a thing when We intend it is only that We say to it, "Be," and it is). He made us deaf to the perception of this saying except through the path of faith (الإيمان), and He made us blind to its orientation toward the origination of things by establishing secondary causes (الأسباب). So, He sent down the rain, and it fell. The earth was plowed, the seed was sown, the sun spread out, the seed sprouted, it was harvested, ground, kneaded, baked, chewed by teeth, swallowed, digested in the stomach, taken by the liver, cooked into blood, then sent through the veins, distributed throughout the body, and a vapor ascended from it, resulting in the life of that body due to that breath (النفس). These are the primary secondary causes, along with the movement of the celestial spheres, the course of the stars, the casting of rays upon the fields of light, and the counterpart of the Universal Soul (النفس الكلية) by Allah's permission, along with the sustenance provided to it by the Intellect (العقل). All of these are established veils (حجب), primary ones, besides the subtle secondary causes between them. Hearing requires the tearing of all these veils until it hears the saying "Be." So, He created in the believer the power of faith (قوة الايمان), which flowed into his hearing, enabling him to perceive the saying "Be," and flowed into his sight, enabling him to witness the Originator of the secondary causes. He did all of this from the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) so that He might have mercy upon those who worshipped other than Allah, once He has exacted from them the rights of the partners who will disown them on the Day of Resurrection. When He has exacted their rights through punishment and retribution, the matter returns to Him alone, and the days during which the partners were entitled to their rights are concluded. When He is alone and the matter returns to Him, He shows them mercy concerning what is His right, through these veils we mentioned, due to His Knowledge of what He established, and that He made their tongues speak what they said and created in their souls what they imagined. Exalted is He, a Just Judge, Subtle, All-Aware (لطيف خبير), Who does what is fitting, in the manner that is fitting, for the purpose that is fitting. There is no deity except Him, <<فَعَّالٌ لِما يُرِيدُ>> (Doer of what He intends).

The Nineteenth Unity (التوحيد التاسع عشر) from the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) is His saying: <<وما أَرْسَلْنا من قَبْلِكَ من رَسُولٍ إِلَّا نُوحِي إِلَيْهِ أَنَّهُ لا إِلهَ إِلَّا أَنَا فَاعْبُدُونِ>> (And We did not send before you any messenger except that We revealed to him that there is no deity except Me, so worship Me). This is the Unity of Power and Definition (توحيد الاقتدار والتعريف), and it belongs to the Unity of Turning Back [to God] (توحيد الإنابة). It is a strange unity. Such a statement is called allusion (*ta'rid*), meaning, "Be like this." It is similar to His saying: <<ما يُقالُ لَكَ إِلَّا ما قَدْ قِيلَ لِلرُّسُلِ من قَبْلِكَ>> (Nothing is said to you except what was already said to the Messengers before you). He mentioned worship (العبادة) but did not specify particular actions, for He said: <<لِكُلٍّ جَعَلْنا مِنْكُمْ شِرْعَةً ومِنْهاجاً>> (For each of you We have appointed a law [shari'a] and a way [minhaj]). That is the specification of actions, which is where the duration of the ruling ends, expressed as abrogation (*naskh*) in the discourse of the scholars of the Law (*Shari'a*). The only general actions that are continuous in every prophethood are the establishment of the Religion, gathering upon it, and the word of Unity (كلمة التوحيد). This is His saying, the Exalted: <<شَرَعَ لَكُمْ من الدِّينِ ما وَصَّى به نُوحاً والَّذِي أَوْحَيْنا إِلَيْكَ وما وَصَّيْنا به إِبْراهِيمَ ومُوسى‏ وعِيسى‏ أَنْ أَقِيمُوا الدِّينَ ولا تَتَفَرَّقُوا فِيهِ>> (He has ordained for you of religion what He enjoined upon Noah and that which We have revealed to you, and what We enjoined upon Abraham and Moses and Jesus—to establish the religion and not be divided therein). Al-Bukhari titled a chapter on this: "What has been transmitted that the religion of the Prophets is one," and that is nothing but Unity (التوحيد), the establishment of the Religion, and worship (العبادة). In this, the Prophets (peace be upon them) agreed. The specification of this revelation with the "I-ness" (*al-Ananiyya*) indicates that it is Divine Speech (كلام إلهي) with the removal of intermediaries. What was revealed to them was from Him, for only the Speaker says "I." If it is said that He mentioned that the angels descend with the like of this, then it is not unlikely that the Messengers received it in two ways: If the angels descended with it, it would be in the form of a narration (حكاية), as the poet said:

> سمعت الناس ينتجعون غيثا *** فقلت لصيدح انتجعي بلالا
> I heard the people seeking rain, so I said to Saydah, "Seek Bilal."

The *sin* in *al-nas* (the people) is in the nominative case (*rafa'*) due to narration. Had the listener heard them seeking rain directly, the *sin* would have been in the accusative case (*nasb*). Thus, His saying: <<أَنْ أَنْذِرُوا أَنَّهُ لا إِلهَ إِلَّا أَنَا فَاتَّقُونِ>> (Warn that there is no deity except Me, so fear Me) was brought down by the angels. When something like this is transmitted devoid of contextual indicators or explicit text, it is interpreted according to its original principle: only the Speaker says "I." Do you not see what we mentioned in the preceding *hadith*, that Allah confirms His servant in one instance, just as He narrates from him in another? Concerning the confirmation, He said: When the servant says, "There is no deity except Allah, and Allah is Greater," his Lord confirms him, saying, "There is no deity except Me, and I am Greater." Thus, He is the Speaker using the "I-ness" (*al-Ananiyya*), and no other. As for His narration of what [the Prophet] said, it is His saying: <<لا تَحْزَنْ إِنَّ الله مَعَنا>> (Do not grieve; indeed Allah is with us), using this exact wording. If the narration is based on meaning, it is like His saying concerning Pharaoh: <<يا هامانُ ابْنِ لِي صَرْحاً>> (O Haman, build for me a tower). Pharaoh said this in the Coptic language, and the translation of it occurred in the Arabic language, but the meaning is the same. This is narration based on meaning. Thus, matters should be understood when they are transmitted, so that the Speech of Allah (قول الله) is distinguished from the speech He narrates, whether literally or by meaning, with every person being judged by his own state. Thus, Allah's saying: <<وإِذْ أَخَذَ الله مِيثاقَ النَّبِيِّينَ لَما آتَيْتُكُمْ من كِتابٍ وحِكْمَةٍ ثُمَّ جاءَكُمْ رَسُولٌ مُصَدِّقٌ لِما مَعَكُمْ لَتُؤْمِنُنَّ به ولَتَنْصُرُنَّهُ قالَ أَ أَقْرَرْتُمْ وأَخَذْتُمْ عَلى‏ ذلِكُمْ إِصْرِي قالُوا>> (And [recall] when Allah took the covenant of the prophets, [saying], "Whatever I give you of the Scripture and Wisdom, and then there comes to you a messenger confirming what is with you, you must believe in him and support him." [Allah] said, "Have you affirmed and taken upon that My obligation?" They said...), Allah's Speech ends here. Then He narrated the meaning of their saying, translating for them: <<أَقْرَرْنا>> (We have affirmed). Likewise, His saying: <<وإِذا لَقُوا الَّذِينَ آمَنُوا قالُوا>> (And when they meet those who believe, they say...), Allah's Speech ends here. <<آمَنَّا>> (We have believed) is a narration. And <<وإِذا خَلَوْا إِلى‏ شَياطِينِهِمْ قالُوا>> (But when they are alone with their devils, they say...), Allah's Speech ends here. <<إِنَّا مَعَكُمْ إِنَّما نَحْنُ مُسْتَهْزِؤُنَ>> (Indeed, we are with you; we are only mockers) is a narration. So, when you mention, know whose tongue you are mentioning with, and when you recite, know whose tongue you are reciting with, what you are reciting, and from whom you are translating.

The Twentieth Unity (التوحيد العشرون) from the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) is His saying: <<وذَا النُّونِ إِذْ ذَهَبَ مُغاضِباً فَظَنَّ أَنْ لَنْ نَقْدِرَ عَلَيْهِ فَنادى‏ في الظُّلُماتِ أَنْ لا إِلهَ إِلَّا أَنْتَ سُبْحانَكَ إِنِّي كُنْتُ من الظَّالِمِينَ>> (And [mention] the man of the fish [Jonah], when he went off in anger and thought that We would not restrict [him]. Then he called out in the darknesses, "There is no deity except You; exalted are You. Indeed, I have been of the wrongdoers"). This is the Unity of Distress (توحيد الغم), and it is the Unity of the Addressed (توحيد المخاطب). It is the Unity of Relief (توحيد التنفيس), just as the All-Merciful granted relief (*naffasa*) to Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) through the Ansar (Helpers). He said: "Indeed, the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) comes to me from the direction of Yemen." The Ansar were those who were formed from that Breath of the All-Merciful, which are the Words of the Real (كلمات الحق). Similarly, Allah granted relief to Jonah by his emergence from the belly of the fish. He dealt with his people by lifting the punishment from them after they saw it descending upon them, and they believed. Allah made him pleased concerning his nation, and their faith benefited them, which He had not done with any nation before them. This was because his anger was for Allah and on His behalf, and his thought concerning his Lord was that He would not restrict him. And so He did, for Allah relieved him after the distress, so that he might know the measure of the favor Allah bestowed upon him through direct experience (ذوقا), as it was said:

> أحلى من الأمن عند الخائف الوجل
> Sweeter than security to the fearful and anxious one.

This indicates that Jonah was beloved by Allah, as He singled out his people for his sake with what He had not singled out any nation before them. He informed us of this by saying: <<فَلَوْ لا كانَتْ قَرْيَةٌ آمَنَتْ فَنَفَعَها إِيمانُها إِلَّا قَوْمَ يُونُسَ لَمَّا آمَنُوا كَشَفْنا عَنْهُمْ عَذابَ الْخِزْيِ في الْحَياةِ الدُّنْيا ومَتَّعْناهُمْ إِلى‏ حِينٍ>> (Was there not any town that believed and whose faith benefited it, except the people of Jonah? When they believed, We removed from them the punishment of disgrace in the worldly life and gave them enjoyment for a time). He extended their enjoyment in compensation for the pain they endured upon seeing the punishment. It is known concerning human souls that the nights of intimacy and union are short, even if their actual duration is long, and the nights of separation and punishment are long, even if their actual duration is short. This is like what was mentioned in the interpretation of the days of the Dajjal (Antichrist): that the first day will be like a year, due to the severity of the sudden affliction, making it seem long to them; then like a month; then like a week. Once they become accustomed to it, it will be like the rest of the known days, which are neither lengthened nor shortened by any state. Similarly, it is said concerning the Day of Resurrection that its measure is fifty thousand years, due to the horror of the rising and the severity that creation will witness therein. Yet, for the secure ones, <<الَّذِينَ لا يَحْزُنُهُمُ الْفَزَعُ الْأَكْبَرُ>> (those whom the great terror will not grieve), its duration will be like the two cycles of the dawn prayer. And what comparison is there between the time of the two cycles of the dawn prayer and the time of fifty thousand years? When the affliction intensified upon the people of Jonah, and the temporal moment for them at the time of seeing the punishment was like a year or longer, He mentioned that, in compensation for this length they perceived in their souls, He granted them enjoyment for a time (إلى حين). Thus, they remained in the bliss of the worldly life for a long period, which they would not have attained had it not been for this affliction. Observe how beautifully the balance (الوزن) is established in matters. It has been said that the time (*al-hin*) He made the limit of their enjoyment is the Resurrection, and Allah knows best. We saw one who saw a man whose footprint we saw on the shore. He was slightly ahead of me, and I could not catch up to him. I measured the length of his foot in the sand: three spans and two-thirds of a span. He was one of the people of Jonah and sent us a message concerning events that would occur in al-Andalus, where we were, in the year 585 AH and 586 AH. Everything he mentioned, we saw occur exactly as he described. Look, then, at this Divine Providence (العناية الإلهية) toward this Prophet and the confession of Unity (توحيده) that he brought.

The Twenty-First Unity (التوحيد الحادي والعشرون) from the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) is: <<فَتَعالَى الله الْمَلِكُ الْحَقُّ لا إِلهَ إِلَّا هُوَ رَبُّ الْعَرْشِ الْكَرِيمِ>> (So exalted is Allah, the Sovereign, the Real [الحق]; there is no deity except Him, Lord of the Noble Throne [العرش الكريم]). This is the Unity of the Real (توحيد الحق), and it is the Unity of Identity (توحيد الهوية). The Exalted said: <<ما خَلَقْنَا السَّماواتِ والْأَرْضَ وما بَيْنَهُما لاعِبِينَ>> (We did not create the heavens and the earth and what is between them in play). This is also His saying: <<أَ فَحَسِبْتُمْ أَنَّما خَلَقْناكُمْ عَبَثاً>> (Did you think that We had created you in vain?). The phrase "there is no deity except Him" is an attribute of the Real (الحق). The matter in which the existence of the cosmos (العالم) appeared is the Real, and it only appeared in the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن), which is the Cloud (*al-Ama'*). Thus, He is the Real, the Lord of the Throne (العرش) which He gave the encompassing form, because He encompasses everything. The Origin (الأصل) in which the forms of the cosmos appeared encompasses everything in the world of bodies (عالم الأجسام), and this Origin is none other than the Real (الحق) by which creation occurred. Because of this receptivity, it is like a container from which the existence it holds emerges, layer after layer, essence (عين) after essence, according to the ruling order. So, He brought forth what was hidden within it so that He might witness it and affirm His Unity (يوحده) despite its emanation from Him. Thus, one is confused: if one counts them, there is nothing there but Him; yet if one affirms His Unity, one sees that its essence is not Him. So, He originated two extremes and an intermediary (واسطة) for the distinction of the essences (الأعيان) within the single Essence (العين الواحدة). Thus, the forms multiplied, but the wood-ness or the lute-ness did not multiply. The lute-ness is in every form according to its reality without division, and this form is not that form, and there is nothing added to the lute-ness. So, it was said, "There is nothing there." He replied: <<وما خَلَقْنَا السَّماءَ والْأَرْضَ وما بَيْنَهُما باطِلًا ما خَلَقْناهُما إِلَّا بِالْحَقِّ>> (And We did not create the heaven and earth and that between them in vain. We created them not except with the Real [الحق]). It was asked, "Where is He?" He said, "In the very Essence of Distinction (عين التمييز)." Thus, I cannot deny the distinction, nor can I affirm anything other than a single Essence. So, <<لا إِلهَ إِلَّا هُوَ رَبُّ الْعَرْشِ الْكَرِيمِ>> (There is no deity except Him, Lord of the Noble Throne).

The Twenty-Second Unity (التوحيد الثاني والعشرون) from the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) is His saying: <<الله لا إِلهَ إِلَّا هُوَ رَبُّ الْعَرْشِ الْعَظِيمِ>> (Allah—there is no deity except Him, Lord of the Great Throne [العرش العظيم]). This is the Unity of the Hidden (توحيد الخبء), and it belongs to the Unity of Identity (توحيد الهوية). Since the vegetative hidden thing (*al-khab' al-nabati*) is brought forth from the earth by the sun through the heat Allah deposited in the earth, and with the assistance of water through the moisture Allah gave it, combining heat and the passive element of coldness so that the sun does not act independently, life appeared in the elemental living being. The hoopoe, unlike other birds, was singled out by Allah with the perception of water. It saw water as having sovereignty over the rest of the elements, magnifying itself and protecting its station, since it was specialized in its knowledge, so that it might testify to its knowledge of the noblest of things, as the Throne (العرش) upon which the All-Merciful is established was upon water. Thus, it defended its station. It found a people worshipping the sun, which is contrary to the nature of water, from which Allah made every living thing. It knew that were it not for the sun's heat, this hidden thing would not emerge, and that the sun assists the water. So, jealousy overtook it in this rivalry, and it informed Solomon (peace be upon him) about its worshippers. It added, for emphasis, "other than Allah," alerting him to the point of jealousy. Although the sun brings forth the hidden thing of the earth with its heat, it also hides the stars with its radiance and reveals the earthly sensibles with its rising. Thus, it has the state of hiding (*al-khab'*) and revealing (*al-izhar*), and by it, night and day are defined. Thus, it rivaled the One Who <<يُخْرِجُ الْخَبْ‏ءَ في السَّماواتِ والْأَرْضِ ويَعْلَمُ ما تُخْفُونَ وما تُعْلِنُونَ>> (brings forth the hidden [things] in the heavens and the earth and knows what you conceal and what you declare). So, Allah tested the water, and it became sunken, and He tested the sun, and it set. Then He caused the springs to gush forth, revealing the hidden thing of the water, and the oven (*al-tannur*) boiled over, revealing the hidden thing of the sun. Thus, He brought forth the hidden thing in the heavens and the earth. He encompassed <<كُلَّ شَيْ‏ءٍ رَحْمَةً وعِلْماً>> (all things in Mercy and Knowledge). He established Himself upon the Great Throne (العرش العظيم) by ruling over the sphere of the sun with its rotation and over the water with its stability and flow. Thus, in every degree, they are in a state of hiding and revealing. So, He affirmed Unity (وحده) through manifestation by His manifestation, and He affirmed Unity through hiding by the drawing of His curtains. Thus, the Exalted knows <<ما تُخْفُونَ وما تُعْلِنُونَ>> (what you conceal and what you declare). He is Allah; <<لا إِلهَ إِلَّا هُوَ رَبُّ الْعَرْشِ الْعَظِيمِ>> (there is no deity except Him, Lord of the Great Throne).

The Twenty-Third Unity (التوحيد الثالث والعشرون)

(The Twenty-Third Unity)

From the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) is His saying: <<وَهُوَ اللهُ لَا إِلَهَ إِلَّا هُوَ لَهُ الْحَمْدُ فِي الْأُولَى وَالْآخِرَةِ وَلَهُ الْحُكْمُ وَإِلَيْهِ تُرْجَعُونَ>> (And He is Allah; there is no deity except Him. To Him belongs [all] praise in the first [life] and the Hereafter. And to Him belongs the judgment, and to Him you will be returned). This is the Unity of Choice (توحيد الاختيار), and it is part of the Unity of Ipseity (توحيد الهوية). Since the World (العالم) consists of the Words of Allah the Exalted, the relation of these Words to the pure Breath of the All-Merciful (النفس الرحماني) within it is a single relation. This evidence would suggest that there should be no differentiation (تفاضل) in the World, nor anyone chosen by Allah with preference over another. Yet, we see that the matter manifests otherwise in universal Being (الوجود) among all existent things. The Exalted said: <<وَلَقَدْ كَرَّمْنَا بَنِي آدَمَ وَحَمَلْنَاهُمْ فِي الْبَرِّ وَالْبَحْرِ وَرَزَقْنَاهُم مِّنَ الطَّيِّبَاتِ وَفَضَّلْنَاهُمْ عَلَى كَثِيرٍ مِّمَّنْ خَلَقْنَا تَفْضِيلًا>> (And We have certainly honored the children of Adam and carried them on the land and sea and provided for them of the good things and preferred them over much of what We have created, with [definite] preference). And He said: <<تِلْكَ الرُّسُلُ فَضَّلْنَا بَعْضَهُمْ عَلَى بَعْضٍ>> (Those messengers—We preferred some of them over others). And He said: <<وَفَضَّلْنَا بَعْضَ النَّبِيِّينَ عَلَى بَعْضٍ>> (And We preferred some of the prophets over others). And He said: <<وَنُفَضِّلُ بَعْضَهَا عَلَى بَعْضٍ فِي الْأُكُلِ>> (And We prefer some of them over others in [quality of] food), despite the fact that <<يُسْقَى بِمَاءٍ وَاحِدٍ>> (they are irrigated with one water). There is no verse more deserving of reflecting the reality of Being (الوجود) regarding differentiation than this verse, where He said: <<يُسْقَى بِمَاءٍ وَاحِدٍ>> (irrigated with one water). Thus, the difference in taste (الطعم) emerged from the One (الواحد) through the path of preference (المفاضلة). The occurrence of this is frequent in the Quran, concerning the preference of one part of every genus over another, even the Quran itself, which is the Word of Allah, is preferred over all other revealed Books, which are also the Word of Allah. And the Quran itself has parts preferred over others, despite its undisputed relation to Allah as His Word. The Verse of the Throne (آية الكرسي) is the mistress of the verses of the Quran, and it is Quran, and the Verse of Debt (آية الدين) is Quran. How astonishing is this secret! From this, we learned that the wisdom (الحكمة) necessitated by rational consideration (النظر العقلي) is not sound, and that Allah’s Wisdom in all matters is the true Wisdom (الحكمة الصحيحة) which cannot be rationally grasped. Even if it is not unknown, it cannot be determined merely by thought or rational consideration, but rather: <<يُؤْتِي الْحِكْمَةَ مَن يَشَاءُ وَمَن يُؤْتَ الْحِكْمَةَ فَقَدْ أُوتِيَ خَيْرًا كَثِيرًا>> (He gives wisdom to whom He wills. And whoever is given wisdom has certainly been given much good).

I saw, while recording this Unity (توحيد) which yields differentiation, an astonishing occurrence (واقعة عجيبة). I was given an unrolled parchment (رق منشورا) whose width, as far as the eye could see, was no less than twenty cubits, while its length I cannot ascertain. It was in the shape drawn in the margin [of the original text]. It was a single skin, the hide of a ram. When you looked at it while reading, you saw it as white, but when you looked at it without reading, you saw it as green. When I read it, I saw it as leather, but when I did not read it, I saw it as a piece of cloth—I do not know if it was silk or linen. This was the dowry (*sadaq*) of my family (أهلي). It was said to me, "This is a divine dowry for your family." I did not ask about the husband, nor did I know that she had left the bond of my marriage, and I was extremely happy and joyful about this matter. Then, a green silk purse (صرة حرير خضراء) was brought forth, emanating from the Book (الكتاب) as if it had formed from it. Inside it were a thousand gold coins (*dinar*), each coin heavy—I do not know its weight. It was said, "Divide it among her family, five dinars for each person." The first thing I took from it was five dinars, upon which was a brilliant light, greater than the radiance of the brightest star in the sky, possessing rays. I saw that the Book itself was the very essence of my family (عين أهلي); her book was none other than her. I was lying upon her, leaning with my whole body. I looked at the inscription on that Book and found it to be in the handwriting of Zayn al-Din Abdullah ibn al-Shaykh Abd al-Rahman, known as Ibn al-Ustadh, the judge of the city of Aleppo. He wrote it from the dictation of the great judge Baha al-Din ibn Shaddad. The dowry, from beginning to end, was composed in rhymed prose (*saj'*) with a single rhyme scheme, based on the open *ra* and the *ha*. I recorded from it, after the *Basmala*: "Praise be to Allah, Who made His Quran and His Criterion (Furqan), His Torah, His Gospel, and His Psalms the inscriptions and lines of this hidden Book (الكتاب المكنون), and deposited within it every verse and chapter found in the Books, and manifested it in Being (الوجود) in the most beautiful form, and made its declarations famous in the upper and lower worlds (العالم العلوي والسفلي), and its signs (آياته) endless and uncounted, and His Words (كلماته) mentioned by every tongue, in every time and non-time." Thus, it continued in this rhyme scheme to its end—if it had an end—in handwriting like dust motes. When I returned to my senses (حسي), I found myself writing this chapter (فصل) on the types of Unity (التوحيد), and behold, it was the Unity of Choice (توحيد الاختيار). I knew that that vision was the very essence of this chapter, and that my family had the most abundant share and greatest portion of this chapter.

Since we have seen that differentiation and choice occur in the World (العالم), even in the prescribed Divine remembrances (الأذكار الإلهية) as we mentioned, we know that there is a rational matter (أمر معقول) which is neither the essence of the Breath (النفس) nor other than the Breath in which the Words—which are the Fixed Entities (أعيان الكائنات)—are formed. Behold, that is the very essence of the Will (المشيئة), in which this preference appeared in the One (الواحد) and the preference in the Equal (المتساوي). The One is not described by preference, nor is the Equal characterized by preference. Thus, we knew that the Secret of Allah (سر الله) is unknown; none knows it but He. We found it to be the Unity of Choice (توحيد الاختيار) in the Presence of the Secret (حضرة السر): <<لَا إِلَهَ إِلَّا هُوَ لَهُ الْحَمْدُ فِي الْأُولَى>> (there is no deity except Him. To Him belongs [all] praise in the first [life]), which is the praise of generalization (حمد الإجمال), <<وَالْآخِرَةِ>> (and the Hereafter), which is the praise of detail (حمد التفصيل). Thus, the praises were distinguished within the single Essence (العين الواحدة), so that its praise was its very essence. How astonishing is the station of this Unity for one who witnesses it! I was astonished by the name of my family in the occurrence, and her name is Maryam (Mary). The meaning of this name is known in the language in which she was named: she is consecrated to Allah (محررة لله), the bearer of the Spirit of Allah (روح الله), the locus of the Word of Allah (كلمة الله), praised by the Word of Allah, and acquitted by the testimony of the dates that fell when she shook the trunk of the dry palm tree, and by her son speaking in the cradle that he was the servant of Allah. Both are just witnesses (شاهدان عدلان) with Allah. Thus, she was entirely for Allah, by Allah, and from Allah. For this reason, Zachariah, the Prophet of Allah, envied her and wished for a like gift from Allah, so He gave him John (Yahya), who was chaste (*hasur*) like her, and He had not made for him a namesake (سميا) before among the Prophets of Allah, thus singling him out with the primacy of the Names of Allah. Look at the blessing of this name in the Being of Allah among the servants of Allah. This was nothing but the choice of Allah: <<وَرَبُّكَ يَخْلُقُ مَا يَشَاءُ وَيَخْتَارُ مَا كَانَ لَهُمُ الْخِيَرَةُ>> (And your Lord creates what He wills and chooses; they have no choice). Rather, it belongs to Allah, and Allah is <<فَعَّالٌ لِّمَا يُرِيدُ>> (The Doer of what He intends).

(The Twenty-Fourth Unity)

From the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) is His saying: <<وَلَا تَدْعُ مَعَ اللهِ إِلَهًا آخَرَ لَا إِلَهَ إِلَّا هُوَ كُلُّ شَيْءٍ هَالِكٌ إِلَّا وَجْهَهُ>> (And do not invoke with Allah another deity. There is no deity except Him. Everything will perish except His Face [Essence]). This is the Unity of Judgment (توحيد الحكم) through the Unity to which Multiplicity (الكثرة) returns, since it is its very essence, and it is the Unity of Ipseity (توحيد الهوية). He forbade His Being (كونه) from invoking a god alongside Allah, and He made the forbidden object indefinite (نكر المنهي عنه) because there was no such thing there. If it were there, it would be definite, and if it were definite, it would not be indefinite. This indicates that whoever invokes another god alongside Allah has blown into unlit embers and sought fatness from a swelling. His invocation was a flesh upon a bone that has no definite referent nor any clear and manifest reality. Thus, the meaning implied by his invocation was pure non-existence (العدم المحض). Nothing remains except the One who possesses pure Being (الوجود المحض). Everything that is imagined to be a thing (شيء) is perishing in the very essence of its thingness (شيئيته) from the attribution of divinity (الألوهية) to it, not from its thingness itself. The Face (وجه) of the Real (الحق) remains, and He is <<ذُو الْجَلَالِ وَالْإِكْرَامِ>> (Possessor of Majesty and Honor) and of immense bounties. Whoever invokes, invokes only toward what is known. So, what is it that He made indefinite? It is not the essence of what was mentioned. The Pure Real (الحق الخالص) is He who, in His Essence (ذاته), knows and is not ignorant, and is ignorant and cannot be encompassed by knowledge. Thus, He knows from the perspective that He cannot be encompassed by knowledge, and He is ignorant from the perspective that He cannot be encompassed by knowledge. So, knowledge of Him is the very essence of ignorance of Him. There is none who accepts opposites in His description except Allah.

(The Twenty-Fifth Unity)

From the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) is His saying: <<هَلْ مِنْ خَالِقٍ غَيْرُ اللهِ يَرْزُقُكُم مِّنَ السَّمَاءِ وَالْأَرْضِ لَا إِلَهَ إِلَّا هُوَ>> (Is there any creator other than Allah who provides for you from the heaven and earth? There is no deity except Him). This is the Unity of Cause (توحيد العلة), and it is part of the Unity of Ipseity (توحيد الهوية). If He were not unified by Cause, just as He is unified by other things, He would not be God, because it is the nature of God that the existence of nothing should issue forth outside of Him. If anything issued forth outside of Him, He would have no judgment (حكم) over it. Yet He said: <<وَإِلَيْهِ يُرْجَعُ الْأَمْرُ كُلُّهُ>> (And to Him is returned the matter, all of it). Therefore, He must possess the Unity of Cause. This means He is worshipped through this Unity because the worshipper, in the origin of his being, is dependent on a cause (سبب). Thus, he does not depart from his reality. His cause is his sustenance (رزقه), by which his essence (عينه) remains. The veiled person (المحجوب) imagines this sustenance to be in the established secondary causes (الأسباب الموضوعة), and this imagination is correct—it is in the established causes—but by the rule of designation (حكم الجعل), not by the rule of their own essence (ذاتها). The designator of their being sustenance is Allah, Who <<يَرْزُقُكُم مِّنَ السَّمَاءِ>> (provides for you from the heaven) with the sustenance of the spirits (أرزاق الأرواح) that descends from it, and <<وَالْأَرْضِ>> (and the earth) with the sustenance of the bodies (أرزاق الأجسام) that emerges from it. He is the Provider (الرازق) in Whose hand is this sustenance. However, when Allah cast veils (حجب) over the sight of some of His servants, and they perceived only the name of the sustenance (مسمى الرزق) and not the name of the Provider (مسمى الرازق), they said, "This is it." So, it was said to them, "It is not 'this'; rather, it is designated within 'this' by the One Who created you. Just as He created you, He sustained you. So, do not equate with Him that which belongs to Him and comes from Him. You and those upon whom you rely are equal. Therefore, do not rely upon your likes, lest you rely upon Multiplicity (الكثرة). Reliance upon Multiplicity leads to the non-attainment of that upon which reliance was placed, since every one of the many says, 'Someone else will fulfill this for him,' and thus nothing is fulfilled for him." This true state (الحال الصحيح) calls him to detachment and singularity toward the One, knowing that the One is aware of his singularity and detachment from all else. This makes it incumbent upon the One to fulfill his need, leading to the attainment of the desired object—from behind a veil for some people, and through witnessing (الشهود) and Unveiling (الكشف) for others, who are the People of Allah (أهل الله) and His elect.

(The Twenty-Sixth Unity)

From the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) is His saying: <<إِنَّهُمْ كَانُوا إِذَا قِيلَ لَهُمْ لَا إِلَهَ إِلَّا اللهُ يَسْتَكْبِرُونَ>> (Indeed, they used to be arrogant when it was said to them, "There is no deity except Allah"). This is the Unity of Astonishment (توحيد التعجب), and it is the Unity of God (توحيد الله), not the Unity of Ipseity (توحيد الهوية). His saying <<يَسْتَكْبِرُونَ>> means they deem it great and are astonished by it: how can "There is no deity except Allah" be sound in the Cosmos (الكون), when a thing can only exist in one form and one essence, yet the forms are many, differing in definition and reality, and in their hands is prevention and giving, which belongs to Allah? <<أَجَعَلَ الْآلِهَةَ إِلَهًا وَاحِدًا إِنَّ هَذَا لَشَيْءٌ عُجَابٌ>> (Has he made the gods [into] one God? Indeed, this is a curious thing). That is, Multiplicity (الكثرة) within the single Essence (العين الواحد). <<مَا سَمِعْنَا بِهَذَا فِي آبَائِنَا الْأَوَّلِينَ>> (We have not heard of this in the former generations). They did not deny it or reject it, but rather deemed it great and were arrogant about it, astonished at how things could be one single thing. They were also arrogant about such a statement coming from such a person, since they knew he was one of them and had witnessed only what they had witnessed. Where did he get this claim? The senses veiled them from the Gnosis (معرفة) of the Breath (النفس) and the Divine Specialization (الاختصاص الإلهي). Thus, they fulfilled Allah’s command without realizing it, because He is the One Who commands His servants to reflect (*I'tibar*), which is astonishment. He said: <<إِنَّ فِي ذَلِكَ لَعِبْرَةً لِّأُولِي الْأَبْصَارِ>> (Indeed in that is a lesson for those who have vision). And He said: <<فَاعْتَبِرُوا يَا أُولِي الْأَبْصَارِ>> (So take heed, O people of vision). They reflected as they were commanded, so they are among the people of vision. Their saying <<إِنْ هَذَا إِلَّا اخْتِلَاقٌ>> (This is nothing but fabrication) was because the definition of this Unity came to them through one of their own, and they did not recognize the Divine Providence (العناية الإلهية) and the Lordly Specialization (الاختصاص الرباني). The fabrication was not in what they were astonished by, because if they had rejected it entirely, they would not have been astonished. Rather, they attributed fabrication to the one who brought it, since he was of their kind and subject to such a possibility, until the signs were made clear to them through observation. Then they would know that this Messenger had not fabricated it, and that it came to him from Allah, Whom these people worshipped—these so-called deities—for the purpose of drawing closer to the Great, Exalted Allah. They placed them in the position of an argument for the King and gave them His Name, just as the name of governorship (*wilaya*) is given to every governor (*wali*), even though the true Governor is Allah, and the governors are many. It is as if He informed them on behalf of Allah that He did not appoint these whom they worship, but rather their fathers set them up as deities. This God to Whom I call you—you know Him, and you do not deny His Name, Allah. And you are the ones who say: <<مَا نَعْبُدُهُمْ إِلَّا لِيُقَرِّبُونَا إِلَى اللهِ زُلْفَى>> (We only worship them that they may bring us nearer to Allah in position). So, you named Him, and they named their deities. At that point, they realized in whose hand the true matter lay: was it in their hands or in mine, the Messenger says? When they recognized and verified his statement, they knew they were exposed, because when they named those deities, they did not name them Allah, nor did they conceive the meaning of Allah from their names, for they knew their names. So they said what the people of Abraham said: <<لَقَدْ عَلِمْتَ مَا هَؤُلَاءِ يَنطِقُونَ>> (You have certainly known that these do not speak). That was the Divine argument against them, derived from themselves. He only argued against them using themselves. <<وَتِلْكَ حُجَّتُنَا آتَيْنَاهَا إِبْرَاهِيمَ عَلَى قَوْمِهِ>> (And that was Our argument which We gave to Abraham against his people).

(The Twenty-Seventh Unity)

From the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) is His saying: <<ذَلِكُمُ اللهُ رَبُّكُمْ لَهُ الْمُلْكُ لَا إِلَهَ إِلَّا هُوَ فَأَنَّى تُصْرَفُونَ>> (That is Allah, your Lord; to Him belongs the sovereignty. There is no deity except Him. So how are you diverted?). This is the Unity of Indication (توحيد الإشارة). There is nothing in the Cosmos (الكون) that can be indicated except Him. <<فَأَنَّى تُصْرَفُونَ>> (So how are you diverted?)—because the indication (الإشارة) only occurs from the pointer concerning a matter that has newly occurred to him, even if it is not newly occurring in its essence in reality. However, he knows that it occurred newly to him. And a matter only occurs newly to someone when he is necessarily ignorant of its nature at the moment it occurs to him, due to his preoccupation with its occurrence and its effect upon him. So, his companion points it out to him at that time and in that state. This companion is of two types, for he has no companion other than two: either his sound intellect (عقله السليم) or his infallible Law (شرعه المعصوم). There is nothing else, because there is none who says to him regarding this indication, <<ذَلِكُمُ اللهُ رَبُّكُمْ لَهُ الْمُلْكُ لَا إِلَهَ إِلَّا هُوَ>> (That is Allah, your Lord; to Him belongs the sovereignty. There is no deity except Him), except one of these two companions. Anything other than these two companions will say to him the opposite of what these two companions said. One will say to him, "This is Time (الدهر) and its disposition," and another will say, "This is Nature (الطبيعة) and its rulings," and another will say, "This is the ruling of the Cycle (حكم الدور)." Thus, every speaker diverts him to what he sees. So, the saying of these two companions is <<فَأَنَّى تُصْرَفُونَ>> (So how are you diverted?). And <<فَيُضِلُّ اللهُ مَن يَشَاءُ وَيَهْدِي مَن يَشَاءُ>> (And Allah sends astray whom He wills and guides whom He wills) by the Quran, and He <<وَمَا يُضِلُّ بِهِ إِلَّا الْفَاسِقِينَ>> (does not mislead thereby except the defiantly disobedient), those who deviate from the ruling of these two companions. And <<وَاللهُ يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وَهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (And Allah speaks the truth, and He guides to the way).

(The Twenty-Eighth Unity)

From the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) is His saying: <<شَدِيدِ الْعِقَابِ ذِي الطَّوْلِ لَا إِلَهَ إِلَّا هُوَ إِلَيْهِ الْمَصِيرُ>> (Severe in penalty, Owner of bounty. There is no deity except Him; to Him is the [final] return). This is the Unity of Becoming (توحيد الصيرورة), and it is part of the Unity of Ipseity (توحيد الهوية). In reality, it is the station of Faith (مقام الايمان), because the believer is one whose fear and hope are balanced, and his two feet are equal in them. He does not allow His Bounty (فضله) to rule over His Justice (عدله), nor His Justice over His Bounty. Just as He manifests in the Severe in Penalty (شديد العقاب), He manifests in the comprehensive Bounty (الطول الأعم), which is supported by the Forgiver of Sin (غافر الذنب) and the Acceptor of Repentance (قابل التوب). He did not grant the Severe in Penalty such support, and this is due to the claim (الدعوى) inherent in severity. Thus, He entrusted him to what he claimed, so he is not aided. But he who makes no claim is aided. This is a governorship (ولاية) in Creation (الخلق). Because He mentioned severity in penalty but did not mention a similar attribute for Bounty (الطول), He strengthened the support of the Owner of Bounty with the Forgiver of Sin and the Acceptor of Repentance against the Severe in Penalty, thereby alerting His servants of understanding to abandon making claims (ترك الدعوى). If the Severe one knew that there was someone who could resist him, he would not make that claim. Thus, the Exalted warned His servants against making claims, so that the Real (الحق) may personally take charge of their affairs and protect them in their movements and stillness, so that they may stop at that point and know that He is the Real.

(The Twenty-Ninth Unity)

From the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) is His saying: <<ذَلِكُمُ اللهُ رَبُّكُمْ خَالِقُ كُلِّ شَيْءٍ لَّا إِلَهَ إِلَّا هُوَ فَأَنَّى تُؤْفَكُونَ>> (That is Allah, your Lord, Creator of all things. There is no deity except Him. So how are you deluded?). This is the Unity of Bounty (توحيد الفضل), and it is part of the Unity of Ipseity (توحيد الهوية), because it follows His saying: <<إِنَّ اللهَ لَذُو فَضْلٍ عَلَى النَّاسِ>> (Indeed, Allah is the Possessor of Bounty upon the people). Thus, this Unity is a thanksgiving for the bounty that Allah bestowed upon people, along with His saying: <<لَخَلْقُ السَّمَاوَاتِ وَالْأَرْضِ أَكْبَرُ مِنْ خَلْقِ النَّاسِ وَلَكِنَّ أَكْثَرَ النَّاسِ لَا يَعْلَمُونَ>> (The creation of the heavens and earth is greater than the creation of mankind, but most of the people do not know). He meant in rank (المنزلة), for everyone knows the physical mass, but people did not reflect upon His saying <<أَكْبَرُ مِنْ خَلْقِ النَّاسِ>> (greater than the creation of mankind) in terms of their being *people* (ناس), and He did not say greater than Adam or the Caliphs (الخلفاء). For if it were so, He would not have preferred some people over others, nor some Messengers over others. The preference of the Form (فضل الصورة) cannot be resisted by any other preference. His saying <<لَذُو فَضْلٍ عَلَى النَّاسِ>> (Possessor of Bounty upon the people) is because the Bestower of Bounty is also one who bears this Name. What is meant is the general and specific Bounty. So, He unified Him by the tongue of generality and specificity. Thus, the Unity of Bounty (توحيد الفضل) appeared from the Presence of Generosity and Giving (حضرة الكرم والبذل).

(The Thirtieth Unity)

From the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) is His saying: <<هُوَ الْحَيُّ لَا إِلَهَ إِلَّا هُوَ فَادْعُوهُ مُخْلِصِينَ لَهُ الدِّينَ الْحَمْدُ لِلَّهِ رَبِّ الْعَالَمِينَ>> (He is the Ever-Living; there is no deity except Him, so call upon Him, sincere to Him in religion. [All] praise is due to Allah, Lord of the worlds). This is the Unity of Life (توحيد الحياة), and it is the Unity of the All (توحيد الكل), and it is part of the Pure Unity of Ipseity (توحيد الهوية الخالصة). Life is a condition for every breathing thing. Therefore, this World (العالم) is alive, including the vapors rising from it. The Unity of Life is the Unity of the All, for there is nothing but the Living. There is nothing but the Real (الحق), Who glorifies Himself (المسبح نفسه) by the Divine Speech (الكلام الإلهي) that the All-Merciful (الرحمن) bestowed upon His Breath (نفسه). He said: <<سُبْحَانَ رَبِّكَ رَبِّ الْعِزَّةِ>> (Exalted is your Lord, the Lord of Might), <<سُبْحَانَ الَّذِي أَسْرَى بِعَبْدِهِ>> (Exalted is He who took His Servant by night), and <<فَسُبْحَانَ اللهِ حِينَ تُمْسُونَ وَحِينَ تُصْبِحُونَ>> (So exalted is Allah when you reach evening and when you reach morning). There is nothing but the World (العالم), and there is nothing in the World that does not glorify Him with His praise. There is no praise more perfect than the praise of Absolute Oneness (الأحدية), for in it there is no partnership. Thus, Unity (التوحيد) is the best praise, and it is *La ilaha illa Allah*. For this reason, we said that it is the Unity of Life and the Unity of the All, and it is the sincerity of Unity (إخلاص التوحيد) for Allah, from Allah and from the World.

(The Thirty-First Unity)

From the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) is His saying: <<لَا إِلَهَ إِلَّا هُوَ يُحْيِي وَيُمِيتُ رَبُّكُمْ وَرَبُّ آبَائِكُمُ الْأَوَّلِينَ>> (There is no deity except Him; He gives life and causes death, your Lord and the Lord of your first forefathers). This is the Unity of Blessing (توحيد البركة), because it is in the Surah where He mentioned that He sent it down on a <<لَيْلَةٍ مُّبَارَكَةٍ>> (blessed night), which is the Night of Decree (*Laylat al-Qadr*), corresponding to the night of the middle of Sha'ban, which is specified for the determination of fates (*Ajal*). For this reason, this Unity is characterized by <<يُحْيِي وَيُمِيتُ>> (He gives life and causes death), which is His saying: <<فِيهَا يُفْرَقُ كُلُّ أَمْرٍ حَكِيمٍ>> (In that night is made distinct every precise matter), meaning firmly established (محكم). Thus, the wisdoms (الحكم) brought by the Divine Messengers and spoken by the Divine Books appear therein, as a mercy to Allah’s servants, both general and specific. Every existent thing perceives them, but not every existent thing knows whence they originated. Thus, they are general in ruling but specific in knowledge, because the preparedness of the recipients (القوابل) differs. Where is the light of the sun compared to the light of the lamp (السراج) in illumination? Yet, the sun took its name from the lamp and was dependent on it, despite being brighter than it. He made His Prophet in this station a *Sirajan Muniran* (a radiant lamp). And by this, Allah struck the similitude for His Light (نوره) with which He illuminated the heavens and the earth. He likened His Attribute to the attribute of the lamp (المصباح), then mentioned what caused the similitude—things not found in the sun—such as the sustenance (الإمداد) and the equilibrium (الاعتدال), despite the existence of difference, by mentioning the Tree (الشجرة) derived from the contention (*tashajur*) found in the World due to the difference in tongues and colors, which Allah made signs (آيات) in His creation. He mentioned the Niche (المشكاة), and what it is to the sun. For the Light of the heavens and the earth, which is the Light of Allah (نور الله), there is a Niche (مشكاة) known by whoever unifies Him with this Blessed Unity, which is the Unity of Blessing. In this Niche is a Lamp (مصباح), which is the very essence of the Light (عين النور) that this Niche preserves from the difference of desires (اختلاف الأهواء) and their ruling regarding the movement and agitation that occurs in lamps. When desires become strong, it leads to the extinguishing of the lamps. Similarly, the Real (الحق) disappears and is hidden among those who dispute, leading to confusion. When the Night of Decree descended, two men disputed, and it was lifted, for it does not accept contention. Since the Prophets only bring the Truth (الحق), which is the Manifest Light (النور المبين), therefore, the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "There should be no contention in the presence of a Prophet." So, one who possesses light does not contend. Furthermore, this Lamp (مصباح) that was used as a similitude has a Glass (زجاجة). For the Divine Light (النور الإلهي) there is a Glass, and this Unity informs you what that Glass is. This is not the case for the sun. The Glass resembles a brilliant star (الكوكب الدري). If the locus in which the Lamp appeared is likened to the brilliant star, which is the sun, then what is the rank of the Lamp, which is the owner of the locus? Then He said in this Lamp that it <<اسْتَوْقَدَ>> (is kindled), meaning it ignites and illuminates, from a <<شَجَرَةٍ مُّبَارَكَةٍ زَيْتُونَةٍ>> (blessed olive tree). Thus, the Divine Light must have a reality (حقيقة) by which the similitude with the Tree occurs, just as it came in the difference of the Divine Names, such as the Harmful and the Beneficial, the Exalter and the Abaser, the Giver of Life and the Giver of Death, and the Names of Opposition. Furthermore, this Tree is <<لَّا شَرْقِيَّةٍ وَلَا غَرْبِيَّةٍ>> (neither eastern nor western). Thus, He described it with equilibrium (الاعتدال). For this reason, the mentioned Lamp, which was used for the similitude, is the Lamp within the Niche and the Glass. Thus, it is protected from movement and agitation because the Tree is neither eastern nor western. All of this is not found except in the Lamp, and all of this must be considered in the Divine Light.

(The Thirty-Second Unity)

From the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) is His saying: <<فَاعْلَمْ أَنَّهُ لَا إِلَهَ إِلَّا اللهُ وَاسْتَغْفِرْ لِذَنبِكَ وَلِلْمُؤْمِنِينَ وَالْمُؤْمِنَاتِ وَاللهُ يَعْلَمُ مُتَقَلَّبَكُمْ وَمَثْوَاكُمْ>> (So know that there is no deity except Allah and ask forgiveness for your sin and for the believing men and believing women. And Allah knows your movement and your resting place). This is the Unity of Remembrance (توحيد الذكرى), and it is the Unity of God (توحيد الله). Know that when Allah molded man upon heedlessness (الغفلات) as a mercy to him, he becomes heedless of the Unity of Allah due to the constant observation of secondary causes (مشاهدة الأسباب) where creation (التكوين) appears. There is no perception (إدراك) by which the very Face of the Real (عين وجه الحق) is witnessed in the causes from which creation proceeds. Due to the dominance of heedlessness and this veil (الغطاء), he imagines that creation originates from the essence of the causes. When Remembrance (الذكرى) comes to him, in whatever form it comes, he knows by its arrival that it indicates in its essence that there is no deity except Allah, and that those causes, were it not for the aspect of the Divine Command (وجه الأمر الإلهي) within them, or were they not the very essence of the Divine Command, nothing would have been formed from them at all. Since this Unity came after a veil (ستر) that Remembrance lifted, it resulted in him asking for Allah’s covering (ستر الله) for the believing men and women. For the lifting of the veil and the presence of Unveiling (الكشف) upon the lifting—or the knowledge that it is the very essence of the veil and nothing else—is a pleasure whose measure cannot be estimated. It is one of Allah’s favors (منن) upon His servant.

(The Thirty-Third Unity)

From the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) is His saying: <<هُوَ اللهُ الَّذِي لَا إِلَهَ إِلَّا هُوَ عَالِمُ الْغَيْبِ وَالشَّهَادَةِ هُوَ الرَّحْمَنُ الرَّحِيمُ>> (He is Allah, other than whom there is no deity, Knower of the unseen and the witnessed. He is the Most Merciful, the Bestower of Mercy). This is the Unity of Knowledge (توحيد العلم), and it is part of the Unity of Ipseity (توحيد الهوية). It is His unification from the perspective of differentiation (التفرقة), because He distinguished between the Unseen (الغيب) and the Witnessed (الشهادة), and combined Knowledge (العلم) and Mercy (الرحمة). This only occurs in Ladunni Knowledge (العلم اللدني), which is the knowledge that benefits its possessor. He said concerning His servant Khidr: <<آتَيْنَاهُ رَحْمَةً مِّنْ عِندِنَا>> (We had given him mercy from Us)—which is His saying <<هُوَ الرَّحْمَنُ الرَّحِيمُ>> (He is the Most Merciful, the Bestower of Mercy)—then He said: <<وَعَلَّمْنَاهُ مِن لَّدُنَّا عِلْمًا>> (and taught him from Us knowledge)—which is His saying <<عَالِمُ الْغَيْبِ وَالشَّهَادَةِ>> (Knower of the unseen and the witnessed). The knowledge of Mercy (علم الرحمة) is accompanied by gentleness and compassion (اللين والعطف), and it is that which comes from His Presence (*ladun*). The soft branch (*ghusn ladin*) is the tender one. And <<وَيُؤْتِ مِن لَّدُنْهُ أَجْرًا عَظِيمًا>> (and He will give from His presence a great reward). He magnified it. And <<وَمَا أَرْسَلْنَاكَ>> (And We did not send you)—and He only sent him with Knowledge—<<إِلَّا رَحْمَةً لِّلْعَالَمِينَ>> (except as a mercy to the worlds). Thus, He made His sending a mercy. It is knowledge that grants felicity (السعادة) in gentleness: <<فَبِمَا رَحْمَةٍ مِّنَ اللهِ لِنتَ لَهُمْ>> (So by mercy from Allah, [O Muhammad], you were lenient with them). Although Knowledge is noble, it has sources, the noblest of which is that which comes from His Presence (*ladun*), for Mercy is coupled with it, and it possesses the Breath (النفس) by which Allah relieves His servants of the severity they experience.

(The Thirty-Fourth Unity)

From the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) is His saying: <<هُوَ اللهُ الَّذِي لَا إِلَهَ إِلَّا هُوَ الْمَلِكُ الْقُدُّوسُ>> (He is Allah, other than whom there is no deity, the Sovereign, the Holy). This is the Unity of Attributes (توحيد النعوت), and it is part of the encompassing Unity of Ipseity (توحيد الهوية المحيطة). All attributes belong to Him, including the attributes of Majesty (نعوت الجلال), for the attributes of Transcendence (صفات التنزيه) do not imply affirmation (الثبوت), yet the matter is existent and affirmed (وجودي ثابت). For this reason, He placed the Ipseity (الهوية) first and last, so that when the attributes of negation (نعوت السلب) arrive and confusion arises in the heart of the listener, the encompassing Ipseity prevents the listener from departing into non-existence (العدم) by saying, "Then there is nothing existent," since it has departed from the existence of the intellect and the senses, thus equating it with non-existence. The Ipseity prevents this, for the pronoun (الضمير) must necessarily refer back to an established matter. Understand this.

(The Thirty-Fifth Unity)

From the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) is His saying: <<اللهُ لَا إِلَهَ إِلَّا هُوَ وَعَلَى اللهِ فَلْيَتَوَكَّلِ الْمُؤْمِنُونَ>> (Allah—there is no deity except Him. And upon Allah let the believers rely). This is the Unity of Calamities (توحيد الرزايا) and the return to Allah concerning them, so that their pain may vanish, since the afflicted person sees that what struck him occurred by the hand of the One Who preserves his existence. For this reason, Allah praised those who say, when a calamity strikes them: <<إِنَّا لِلَّهِ وَإِنَّا إِلَيْهِ رَاجِعُونَ>> (Indeed we belong to Allah, and indeed to Him we will return). They belong to Allah in their present state, and they return to Him upon leaving that state. Whoever has his existence preserved by Him, and what was taken from him was preserved by Him, and what he possessed was a trust (*amana*) until its time, then he has not been afflicted or suffered loss. The Unity of Calamities is the most beneficial medicine to use. Therefore, He informed them of what they receive from Him in this regard, saying: <<أُولَئِكَ عَلَيْهِمْ صَلَوَاتٌ مِّن رَّبِّهِمْ وَرَحْمَةٌ>> (Those are the ones upon whom are blessings from their Lord and mercy). And mercy is not accompanied by pain. And <<وَأُولَئِكَ هُمُ الْمُهْتَدُونَ>> (And those are the [rightly] guided), meaning those for whom the matter became clear as it is in itself. It is called a calamity (*musiba*) in his case because it descended upon him, and in the case of one who lacks this spiritual taste (*dhawq*) because its pain descends into his heart, causing him to be discontent, thereby depriving him of its goodness.

(The Thirty-Sixth Unity)

From the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) is His saying: <<رَبُّ الْمَشْرِقِ وَالْمَغْرِبِ لَا إِلَهَ إِلَّا هُوَ فَاتَّخِذْهُ وَكِيلًا>> (Lord of the East and the West; there is no deity except Him, so take Him as a Trustee). This is the Unity of Agency (توحيد الوكالة), and it is part of the Unity of Ipseity (توحيد الهوية). In this Unity, Allah granted the human world ownership of all that He created for its benefit, and commanded it to appoint Allah as Agent (*Wakil*) in that, so that man may devote himself to what he was created for: the worship of his Lord, as stated in His saying: <<وَمَا خَلَقْتُ الْجِنَّ وَالْإِنسَ إِلَّا لِيَعْبُدُونِ>> (And I did not create the jinn and mankind except to worship Me). How far is this station from His saying: <<وَأَنفِقُوا مِمَّا جَعَلَكُم مُّسْتَخْلَفِينَ فِيهِ>> (And spend from that over which He has made you successors)? He placed the spending in their hands, yet the ownership belongs to Allah. In this amount that He commanded them to spend, He commanded them to take Him as an Agent. Thus, there is no contradiction between the two stations. Ownership belongs to Allah, and spending belongs to the servant, based on the matter and what was permitted to him therein. In spending, Allah commanded them to appoint Him as Agent, due to His Knowledge of the places of expenditure and the channels that satisfy the Lord of the wealth in spending. Thus, the revealed Laws clarified for him the channels of wealth, so he spends with insight, guided by the view of the Agent. Whoever spends on what the Agent did not command him to spend on, the spender owes the value of what he consumed of the wealth of the one who appointed him successor. He has nothing, for he is bankrupt by original ruling, so there is no judgment against him. This Unity grants him the lifting of the judgment concerning what he destroyed of the wealth of the one who appointed him successor. This is the last *Tahlil* (utterance of *La ilaha illa Allah*) mentioned in the century that reached us, consisting of thirty-six stations, which we have mentioned in their entirety, clarified as Divine and Quranic, by which Allah mentioned Himself and commanded us to mention Him. We complied. When we mentioned Him by them, we received knowledge from His Presence (*ladun*), and the mention of them was a mercy from Him toward us. We have thus rendered the obligatory tenth (العشر الواجب), complete, and it has fallen into the Hand of the Real (يد الحق), Who will undertake its nurturing until the time of the Encounter (اللقاء) and the return of the trusts to their owners. And <<وَاللهُ يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وَهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (And Allah speaks the truth, and He guides to the way).

(Chapter Ten: Concerning the Remembrance by the *Hawqala*)

This is the saying: *La hawla wa la quwwata illa billah* (There is no power nor strength save in Allah). It is the remembrance of every bearer according to the measure of what he bears. Those who remember by it are in classes, just as they are in form in classes. Whoever has the greatest entry (أكثر دخولا) is the most diligent in this remembrance. The one who attained perfection in it is conditioned not to cease this remembrance verbally, just as he does not cease it by the witnessing of the state (شاهد الحال). This applies to every responsible being (*mukallaf*) in the World. The entire World is responsible. Part of the World is compelled (مجبور) regarding the burden it was commanded to carry—this is expressed as the individual obligations (*fara’id al-a’yan*) and the communal obligations (*fara’id al-kifaya*), where if one person performs it, the obligation falls from the rest. And part of the World was not compelled to carry the burden, but it was offered to it. If it accepted it, it only accepted it due to its ignorance of the measure of what it carried, like man when the Trust (الأمانة) was offered to him and he carried it. He was <<ظَلُومًا>> (unjust) to himself and <<جَهُولًا>> (ignorant) of its measure. When the heavens, the earth, and the mountains were offered it, they <<أَبَيْنَ أَن يَحْمِلْنَهَا وَأَشْفَقْنَ مِنْهَا>> (refused to bear it and feared it) because of their knowledge of the measure of what they would carry. Thus, they did not wrong themselves, but <<وَلَكِنَّ النَّاسَ أَنفُسَهُمْ يَظْلِمُونَ>> (but mankind wrongs themselves). No creature was described as wronging itself except man. Thus, the creation of the heavens and the earth was <<أَكْبَرُ مِنْ خَلْقِ النَّاسِ>> (greater than the creation of mankind) in rank (المنزلة), for they were more knowledgeable of the measure of the Trust than man. By this, they were also greater than the creation of mankind in the rank of Knowledge (العلم), for they were not described by ignorance as man was. Similarly, when they were commanded to come, it was a command of obligation. If they had not responded willingly, they would have been brought unwillingly. So, <<قَالَتَا أَتَيْنَا طَائِعِينَ>> (They said, "We have come obediently"), knowing that the One Who commanded them was capable of bringing them unwillingly. So they said, "We have come obediently." The coming occurred, and the willingness is subject to the possibility that they spoke the truth in their claim. If the Speaker was the Real (الحق), then they did not lie, but spoke the truth. If the saying was through an intermediary, then what we said is possible. When the knower (*alim*) among us says *La hawla wa la quwwata illa billah*, he says it in compliance with the Divine Command and in imitation. The imitation is His saying: <<وَإِيَّاكَ نَسْتَعِينُ>> (And You we ask for help), when the Real is the Speaker. This is seeking help through the secondary causes (الأسباب) that cannot be removed, and the effect cannot exist except through their existence. The Command is His saying: <<اسْتَعِينُوا بِاللهِ وَاصْبِرُوا>> (Seek help through Allah and be patient) in bearing these hardships, with *La hawla wa la quwwata illa billah*. End of the One Hundred and Twentieth Part.

In the Name of Allah, the All-Merciful, the Bestower of Mercy.

(Chapter Eleven: Concerning the Divine Name Al-Badi' [The Originator])

And its orientation toward every originated thing (*mubda'*) and toward the creation of the First Intellect (العقل الأول), which is the Pen (القلم). And its orientation toward the creation of the *Hamza* (glottal stop) among the letters and their levels. And its orientation toward the creation of the two conditions (*shartayn*) among the lunar mansions. And its orientation through the Divine Breath-like Sustenance (الإمداد الإلهي النفسي)—the essential (الذاتي) and the supplementary (الزائد) sustenance—and the reason for its supplementation.

[The First Thing Allah Created]

Allah the Exalted said: <<بَدِيعُ السَّمَاوَاتِ وَالْأَرْضِ>> (Originator of the heavens and the earth), because they were not created according to a pre-existing model (مثال متقدم). The first thing Allah created was the Intellect (العقل), which is the Pen (القلم). It is the first originated effect (*maf'ul ibda'i*) that appeared from Allah the Exalted. Every creation without a pre-existing model is an originated thing (*mubda'*), and its Creator is its Originator (*mubdi'*). If Knowledge (العلم) were merely the conceptualization of the known thing as some define it, that created thing would not be an originated thing (*mubda'*), because it would be based on a model existing in the self of the one who originated it, created according to that model and corresponding to it. That which exists in the Self of the Real (نفس الحق), according to the proponent of this definition of Knowledge, has always been necessarily existent in the Self of the Real. Thus, He did not originate it within Himself as the temporal originator does when he originates, nor did it exist in the external entity (العين) except in the form that arose in the self of the Former (المصور) as a likeness of it, not as the thing itself, since He is not a locus for what He creates. So, He is not an Originator (*badi'*) [in the sense of creating from nothingness], yet He is an Originator. For there is no form of what He originated within His Self, nor did He conceptualize it. This is a problematic issue, for some known things accept conceptualization, and some do not, yet they are known. Thus, the definition of Knowledge is not merely the conceptualization of the known thing. Likewise, the Knower may be one who conceptualizes, because he possesses the imaginative faculty (قوة متخيلة), or he may be one who knows but does not conceptualize, because representation (التمثل) is not permissible for Him. Thus, conceptualization comes from outside, and He does not accept the form within Himself for what He forms from outside, yet He knows it.

[That Origination is Specific to Forms]

Know first that origination (الإبداع) occurs only in forms (الصور) specifically, because they are what accept creation, and thus accept origination. As for meanings (المعاني), none of them are originated, because they do not accept creation, and thus do not accept origination. They are rationally grasped as Fixed Entities (ثابتة الأعيان). This is the Presence of Verified Meanings (حضرة المعاني المحققة). There are forms that accept creation and origination, indicated by words that are names for them. It is said that under this speech, or for this word, there is a meaning (معنى) that it indicates. That meaning contained within the word may be a form (صورة) with an external existence (وجود عيني) possessing shape and measure, such as the word *Zayd*. This is a word that indicates a meaning understood from it, for which it was designated: a person among mankind, possessing an upright stature, length, width, and directions. Such a thing is called a meaning for this word. This meaning accepts creation. However, by meanings (المعاني), we only intend that which does not accept creation. Everything that does not accept creation does not accept likeness (المثل). Only the form accepts likeness, specifically the material and non-material forms. By material, I mean the composite (المركبة), which are bodies of all types. By non-material, I mean the simple entities (البسائط) that have no part other than their essence, but they accept juxtaposition (المجاورة), and thus accept composition, leading to the emergence of various forms ad infinitum. The first of these, even though it is a form, is the originated (*mubda'*). The second is not originated, for it is based on its model, but it is created (*makhluq*). Thus, by the first creation, He is the Originator (*Badi'*), and by the second creation, which is similar to the first creation, He is the Creator (*Khaliq*). The first thing Allah created was the Intellect (العقل). He manifested it in the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) in the Cloud (*al-Ama'*) at its first degree, which is in the self of man, who is created upon the form of the *Hamza* (الهمزة). It is the first originated thing among the letters of man's exhalation (تنفس الإنسان). It has aspects and rulings, just as the Intellect has in the Breath. Among these is the Divine Breath-like Sustenance (الإمداد الإلهي النفسي), which is in His saying: <<لَئِن شَكَرْتُمْ لَأَزِيدَنَّكُمْ>> (If you are grateful, I will surely increase you), and in His saying: <<لِّلَّذِينَ أَحْسَنُوا الْحُسْنَى وَزِيَادَةٌ>> (For those who have done good is the best [reward] and extra). The increase (*ziyada*), wherever it occurs, whether in good or evil, cannot be rationally grasped except after grasping the origin (الأصل). When its measure is known, the increase is known, lest the increase be imagined to be the origin. The minimum increase is equal to the origin, up to the fourth degree, and there is no increase beyond it. Every increase that exceeds the increase is equal to the origin. An example of this is the origin being the existence of the essence of the Intellect (عين العقل), and the increase being the existence of the Soul (النفس), which is equal to the Intellect, then Nature (الطبيعة), which is equal to the Intellect, then the Hyle (*al-Haba'*) which is equal to the Intellect, then the Total Body (الجسم الكل), which is the fourth, and there is nothing beyond it except the forms. Likewise, the natural lengthening (*al-madd al-tabi'i*) is in the position of the Intellect, such as the lengthening of the *Alif* in *qala* (قال) and its like. This runs through every existent thing. It has sustenance (إمداد) from the Real (الحق) by which its subsistence (بقاؤه) occurs. What is added beyond that by which its subsistence and the manifestation of its essence occur is due to another cause. Since the Intellect was the first existent thing, it was made the cause for every Divine sustenance in Being (الوجود). Similarly, the *Hamza* in the human self necessitates sustenance in the sound, whether it comes later or earlier. The increase in this extends up to four levels beyond the natural lengthening, with each increase being equal to the origin, which is the natural *Alif* in every lengthened sound. Examples of this are *a'amana* (أامن) in the recitation of Abu Amr, *aa'amana* (أاامن) in the recitation of Ibn Amir and al-Kisa'i, *aaa'amana* (أااامن) in the recitation of Asim, and *aaaa'amana* (أاااامن) in the recitation of Warsh and Hamza. Likewise, *ja'a* (جاء), *jaaa'a* (جااء), *jaaaa'a* (جاااء), and *jaaaaa'a* (جااااء) occur as we mentioned. This Divine sustenance, both before and after the cause that necessitates it, is according to the Gnosis (المعرفة) of Allah. Whoever does not know Allah through the evidence of the World (العالم) upon Him, the sustenance precedes the knowledge of Allah without the servant knowing it. He is turning over in Allah’s favor without knowledge of who the Bestower is specifically. Whoever knows the World through Allah, the sustenance is subsequent, because he knew Allah and saw Him before His sustenance, even though his knowledge of Him is from His sustenance—but that is the natural lengthening. The sustenance in the Breath of the All-Merciful (النفس الرحماني) is the creation of favors with multiplication by increase: <<وَاللهُ يُضَاعِفُ لِمَن يَشَاءُ>> (And Allah multiplies for whom He wills), just as in the human self, the lengthening of the sound is a request to reach the necessitating cause, or an emergence from the necessitating cause, through the Divine sustenance for the very essence of the desired letter, which is the essence intended by that favor among the existent things, just as one seeks to reach the letter *Mim* by lengthening in *a'amana* and the letter *Dal* in *Adam*. Know this.

[The Orientation of Al-Badi' toward the Creation of the Two Conditions of the Lunar Mansions]

Likewise, this Name (البديع) is oriented toward the creation of the two conditions (*shartayn*) among the lunar mansions (المنازل), to clarify thereby the very essence of the determined constellations (البروج المقدرة) in the Atlas Sphere (الفلك الأطلس), since they have no sign by which they are known. So, He made these mansions a sign for those measures that the hidden, sweeping, running stars (الجواري الخنس الكنس) traverse in this Atlas Sphere. By the mansions, it is known how much they have traversed of that Sphere. Every star in the Starry Sphere (الفلك المكوكب) also traverses this Atlas Sphere, but the lifespan of a single person is not enough to perceive it. It has been transmitted to us that the date of construction of some of the pyramids of Egypt was found when the Vulture (النسر) was in Leo (الأسد), and today it is in Capricorn (الجدي). Look at the years that have passed over it! The masters of planetary motion say that these fixed stars traverse one degree of the Sphere every sixty years, and some have transmitted one hundred years. When will the senses perceive its movement, just as they perceive the movement of the hidden, sweeping, running stars?

Then we return to our discussion of the First Intellect (العقل الأول) and its rank in the Breath of the All-Merciful (النفس الرحماني) as the *Hamza* is among the letters of man. We say that when Allah created the angels, who are the Intellects created from the Cloud (*al-Ama'*), and the Divine Pen (القلم الإلهي) was the first creature among them, Allah chose it, advanced it, and appointed it over the register of the creation of the entire World. He entrusted it with the consideration of its interests, and made that its obligatory worship (*ibadat taklif*) that brings it closer to Allah. It has no consideration except for that. He made it simple (بسيط) so that it would not be heedless, nor sleep, nor forget. Thus, it is the most retentive of the originated existent things and the most precise in recording the types of knowledge that Allah taught it. It wrote all of them, inscribed in the Preserved Tablet (اللوح المحفوظ), safe from alteration and distortion. Among what was written and affirmed therein is the knowledge of alteration (علم التبديل)—that is, the knowledge of what is altered and distorted in the world of change—otherwise, its state is upon the form of Allah’s Knowledge, accepting no alteration. When Allah appointed it to what He appointed it, He gave it from His Names the Disposer (المدبر) and the Detailer (المفصل), without thought or deliberation. In man, this is thought and reflection. When it is alone in this within itself, it has one ruling, and when it disposes with another, it has another ruling, which is called consultation (*mushawara*) in the human world. The Exalted said to His Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him), commanding him: <<وَشَاوِرْهُمْ فِي الْأَمْرِ فَإِذَا عَزَمْتَ فَتَوَكَّلْ عَلَى اللهِ>> (And consult them in the matter. And when you have decided, then rely upon Allah). The ruling of disposition (التدبير) by which it governs its authority is of several types, whether it disposes alone or seeks partnership through consultation. The reason necessitating consultation is that the Real (الحق) has a specific Face (وجه خاص) in every existent thing that is not found in any other existent thing. The Real, the Glorified, may cast into it concerning a matter something that He does not cast into one who is higher in rank than it, such as the knowledge of the Names given to Adam, even though the Highest Assembly (الملإ الأعلى) of angels is nobler than him in Allah’s sight. Despite this, Adam possessed what they did not.
