We have mentioned in this Book the evidence for the preference of the Highest Assembly of angels over the highest of mankind, which the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) gave me in a vision I saw. Before that vision, I did not hold a single, unified view on the matter. If this is the case, then the Intellect may act alone in matters it established in the World, as the Disposer and Detailer, not based on thought, for it is not among the people of thoughts. Another intellect may share in its disposition, such as the Universal Soul (النفس الكلية), which I shall mention in the chapter following this, if Allah wills. Such a partnership is the portion of consultation in the world of creation. The reason for this is to fulfill the Divinity (الألوهة) what it deserves, since it is known that Allah the Exalted has a specific Face in every existent thing, from which He casts to it whatever He wills, which is not given to other Faces. From that Face, every existent thing is dependent on Him, even if it is through a cause. If you say, "Allah already taught it His Knowledge concerning His creation when He said to it, 'Write My Knowledge concerning My creation until the Day of Resurrection,'" we reply in two ways. The first way is that even though it knew what would be, among what He informed it of concerning existence was its consultation and the participation of others in its disposition, just as we know that Allah knows what will be from His creation, yet He said: <<وَلَنَبْلُوَنَّكُمْ حَتَّى نَعْلَمَ>> (And We will surely test you until We know). And He is more knowing than Allah, so this cannot be. Something similar to this has come concerning Allah. The second way in the answer is that we have known that Allah has a specific Face for every existent thing, and that Divine Face is not characterized by creation. He said to the Pen, "Write My Knowledge concerning My creation," and He did not say to it, "Write My Knowledge concerning the Face that is from Me for every creature individually." So, the Glorified gives through a cause, which is what the Pen wrote of Allah’s Knowledge concerning His creation, and He gives without a cause, which is what He gives from that Face, by which neither the causes nor the creation are known. Thus, consultation occurred so that a matter might emerge from it that could be part of the knowledge of that Face, and the one consulted in the disposition might cast to the Intellect knowledge that he received from Allah through that Face, whose knowledge was neither written nor contained in His creation. For this reason, Allah said to His Messenger: <<فَإِذَا عَزَمْتَ فَتَوَكَّلْ عَلَى اللهِ>> (And when you have decided, then rely upon Allah)—meaning, rely on carrying out what you agreed upon in consultation, or what you decided upon alone without them. His saying <<فَتَوَكَّلْ عَلَى اللهِ>> (then rely upon Allah) in such a case is before the action occurs, for the decision precedes the action. He was told to rely upon Allah because it is not known, before the action occurs, what Allah will cast into your self from that specific Divine Face which is outside of creation—that is, the Divine Command (الأمر الإلهي). For to Him belongs the Creation (الخلق) and the Command (الأمر). What comes from that Face is the Command, and what comes from other than that Face is the Creation. The matter proceeds similarly in the movements of the stars. Each star in a celestial degree gives a ruling individually that it does not give when another star or more joins it in that degree. Their conjunction is like consultation, and their non-conjunction is like acting alone. What results from the conjunction is not what results from the isolation. <<أَوْحَى فِي كُلِّ سَمَاءٍ أَمْرَهَا>> (He revealed in every heaven its command), including what it acts upon alone and what it does not act upon alone. That which arises from the conjunction is outside the command that each heaven acts upon alone. Furthermore, there are different states in the conjunctions, so what arises depends on the difference in states. The states there are like the intentions (*aghrad*) here in the conjunctions. Everyone speaks according to his intention and perspective: <<قُلْ كُلٌّ يَعْمَلُ عَلَى شَاكِلَتِهِ>> (Say, "Each works according to his manner"). Then the Command descends to the human self, so the ruling of a single letter is different from its ruling when it is joined with another. The letter *Qaf* (ق) alone indicates the command for protection (*wiqaya*). If it joins with *Lam* (ل), a form called *Qul* (قل - Say) emerges, and a command for speech arises for the *Qaf*. How far is that from the command for protection? Likewise, if it joins with the letter *Mim* (م), the form *Qum* (قم - Stand up) emerges from this conjunction, and a command for standing arises for the *Qaf*. This is how it proceeds with more than one letter, whether connected to produce a word or separated to produce words. Matters arise due to the occurrence of these words. The master says to his servant, "Say (*Qul*)," and speech occurs in the servant, so he speaks. Or, "Stand up (*Qum*)," and he stands up. A movement called standing appears from the commanded person due to the appearance of the form of that conjunction. In this way, existent things (الكائنات) arise in the Breath of the All-Merciful (النفس الرحماني). The essences of the Words (أعيان الكلمات) appear. This is what is expressed as the World (العالم). The manifestation of the Word is in the Breath, and the manifestation of the Cosmos (الكون) is in the Cloud (*al-Ama'*). What is in the Breath is called a Word (كلمة) and a Command (أمر), and what is in the Cloud is called a Cosmos (كون), a Creation (خلق), and the manifestation of an essence (ظهور عين). The word *Kun* (كن - Be) was used because it is a word of existence, substituting for all Divine Commands, just as the letters *Fa*, *Ayn*, and *Lam* (فعل - verb) substitute for all measures and all measured things among the nouns and verbs. They are the letters that measure the Word and measure the essence of the existent thing. *Kun* stands in place of *Qul*, *Qum*, *Khudh* (Take), *Quss* (Relate), *Ukhruj* (Exit), *Udkhul* (Enter), *Iqtarib* (Approach), and all that by which the Command occurs. If it is a command for standing, standing occurs; if it is a command for sitting, sitting occurs, and so on for all essences. The Word occurs in the Breath, and the Cosmos occurs in the Cloud, based on the connection (صلة) in the measure. This connection is found in the types of things produced by disposition, whether alone or through consultation, in the Cosmos.

As for what arises from disposition alone, this occurs when two Divine Names rule the Disposer, or two thoughts (*khatiran*) in the case of the people of thoughts—which, in Divine matters, is hesitation (التردد). This Disposer, in this state and others, is necessarily under the ruling of a Divine Name from the seven Names that control the Breath and the Words that appear in it. These are the Comprehensive Name (الاسم الجامع), the Beneficial (النافع), the Protector (العاصم), which is the Preserver (الواقي), the Swift (السريع), and the Veiler (الستار). These five Names grant the station of Servitude (*Ubudiyya*) in the World. And the Seer (البصير) and the Maker (البارئ), which grant the station of Freedom (*Hurriyya*).

The Comprehensive Name (الاسم الجامع): From it comes the sustenance (الإمداد) for the people of virtues, who persevere in noble character. Concerning this Name, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "I was sent to perfect noble character." It also sustains the people of gathering (الجمع), Being (الوجود), protection, and the abandonment of accountability for crimes. They defend the perpetrators from what the Avenger (المنتقم) and the Punisher (المعاقب) intend for them. It is the Giver of Security, which is His saying: <<يَا عِبَادِيَ الَّذِينَ أَسْرَفُوا عَلَى أَنفُسِهِمْ لَا تَقْنَطُوا مِن رَّحْمَةِ اللهِ>> (O My servants who have transgressed against themselves [by sinning], do not despair of the mercy of Allah). Its action is always only in those who are in the station of Servitude.

The Beneficial Name (الاسم الإلهي النافع): From it comes the sustenance for the Gnostics of Allah (العلماء بالله) according to their ranks. Most of its sustenance is found in the scholars of the Spirits (علماء الأرواح), which is His saying: <<أَوْحَيْنَا إِلَيْكَ رُوحًا مِّنْ أَمْرِنَا مَا كُنتَ تَدْرِي مَا الْكِتَابُ وَلَا الْإِيمَانُ وَلَكِن جَعَلْنَاهُ نُورًا>> (We revealed to you a Spirit [Ruh] of Our command. You did not know what the Scripture was or [what] faith [was], but We made it a light)—meaning a light of guidance. It also sustains the people of generosity (أهل الجود) among the various noble ones specifically, who bestow gifts before being asked, of everything that benefits the recipient. This is specific giving. The sustenance of this Name is for those whom Allah established in the station of Servitude (*Ubudiyya*) and Worship (*Ubuda*). For the men of Allah are in one of two states: either the state of Servitude or the state of Freedom. The chapter on Servitude and the chapter on Freedom have already preceded in this Book.

The Protecting Name (الاسم الواقي): This is the Preserving Name (الاسم العاصم) from the Command of Allah. From it comes the sustenance for the Truthful (الصديقين), the people of secrets (أصحاب الأسرار), and the people of contemplation and thoughts (أهل النظر والأفكار) in their investigations and debates, for extracting benefits in the gatherings of the People of Allah, without contention. This Name only sustains the masters of the station of Servitude and the people of seeking sufficiency in Allah (أهل الاستكفاء بالله), who rely upon Allah with the reliance of a servant upon his master, not the reliance of a son upon his father, nor the dead upon his washer, nor the hired worker upon his employer, nor the reliance of the principal upon his agent.

The Swift Name (الاسم السريع):

For it [the Name] is like the Protector (الواقي) in that it only provides aid (إمداد) to the people of this specific reliance (التوكل) and those who are in the station of Servitude (العبودية). Its aid to those who spend is through replacement, which is His saying, the Exalted: <<وَمَا أَنْفَقْتُمْ مِنْ شَيْءٍ فَهُوَ يُخْلِفُهُ>> (And whatever thing you spend, He will replace it). It also aids the people of Subsistence (البقاء) for the people of Annihilation (الفناء). From Him they take, and to Him they resort.

As for the Name the Veiler (الستار)—which is the Forgiving (الغفار), the Pardoner (الغفور), and the Absolver (الغافر)—in providing aid (الإمداد), it is like the Swift (السريع) and the Protector (الواقي) for the servant and those who rely [on God] (المتوكلين). From this Name comes the aid for the people of acquisition (الاكتساب) and those who affirm secondary causes (الأسباب) while relying upon Allah, except that even though they rely upon Allah, outwardly they do not manifest sufficiency in Allah (الاكتفاء بالله). Thus is everyone who affirms secondary causes, even if they are among those who rely [on God]; not every reliant person outwardly manifests sufficiency in Allah. This Name also aids the people of the spiritual stations (المنازل) and their spiritual journeys (المنازلات). They have chapters in this book, numbering around two hundred, which will follow, God willing.

As for the Name the Originator (الباري), from Him comes the aid for the intelligent engineers, the masters of deduction (الاستنباطات), the inventors of crafts, and the designers of strange forms. From this Name they take, and He is the Provider of aid to the image-makers (المصورين) regarding the beauty of the form in the balance (الميزان). The most astonishing thing I saw concerning this was in Konya, in the lands of Rum, involving a painter who was with us. We tested him and benefited him in his craft regarding the soundness of imagination (صحة التخيل) in a way he had not possessed before. One day he painted a partridge and concealed a flaw in it that could not be perceived, bringing it to us to test us in the balance of depiction (ميزان التصوير). He had painted it on a large platter, corresponding to the size of the partridge in bulk. We had a falcon with us, and when it saw the image, the person holding it released it toward the painting. The falcon struck it with its leg, imagining it to be a real partridge due to its form and the colors of its feathers. Those present were astonished by the beauty of his craft. He asked me, "What do you say about this image?" I replied, "It is of the utmost perfection, except that it contains a hidden flaw." (He had mentioned this flaw to those present privately.) He asked me, "And what is it? Its proportions are correct." I said, "The length of its legs, compared to the balance of the image, is the width of a barley grain too long." He stood up and kissed my head, saying, "I did that intentionally to test you." The attendees confirmed this, saying that he had mentioned it to them before showing it to me. I was astonished by the falcon's reaction and its pursuit of the image. This Name also aids the masters of Generosity (أرباب الجود), specifically during times of famine (المسغبة), not those who spend unconditionally without restriction. This Name only regards those men who are established in the station of Freedom (الحرية); the aid provided is distinct from that given to those established in Servitude (العبودية).

As for the Name the All-Seeing (البصير), for it aids the people of Freedom and Servitude (العبودة), though the aid to the people of Freedom is greater, and His regard for them is mightier. This Name and the Name the Originator (الباري) aid the people of eloquence (الفصاحة) and expression (العبارات). To them belongs the inimitability of the Qur'an (إعجاز القرآن) and the beautiful composition of exquisite speech. This Name, the All-Seeing, aids the people of the spiritual stations and journeys in their insights (بصائرهم). These are those who strove to acquire them, those who ate from *beneath their feet*, meaning they did not receive them through the paths of Divine Care (العناية) without effort. For the people of this station are of two types: one group attained these stations through striving and acquisition, and another group attained them through Divine bestowal (الإنزال الإلهي) as an act of care, without striving or prior effort, but through Divine selection (اختصاص إلهي). This Name also aids the people of differentiation (أهل التفرقة), who distinguish what the Fixed Entities (أعيان المظاهر) bestow upon the outward manifestation according to their preparedness (استعداداتها). This is an astonishing station that most people of differentiation do not know. Most of the knowledge of the people of differentiation is the knowledge of the meanings of the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية) in terms of their significance, not in terms of their indication of the Essence (الذات). This is the limitation of what these Names bestow and the limitation of those to whom they bestow it. The ultimate extent of the world in this chapter, which we witnessed through Unveiling (كشفا), is a thousand worlds, no more than that. That which we witnessed through direct experience (ذوقا), keeping pace with them step by step, racing them and surpassing them, was sixteen worlds across eight Presences (حضرات): the Presence of Union (حضرة النكاح) and the Presence of Doubts (حضرة الشكوك). The rest of the world was known through Unveiling and definition, not through direct experience. Thus, we entered into everything we mentioned concerning these Divine aids through direct experience, along with the general body of the People of Allah (أهل الله). We surpassed them through a Divine Name, which is the Last (الآخر), from which we took leadership, and the Spirit of Allah (روح الله) attained by the Foremost (المقربون), based on His saying, the Exalted: <<فَأَمَّا إِنْ كَانَ مِنَ الْمُقَرَّبِينَ فَرَوْحٌ وَرَيْحَانٌ وَجَنَّةُ نَعِيمٍ>> (But if he is of the Foremost, then [for him is] rest and provision and a Garden of Bliss). I attained these stations upon entering this Path (الطريقة) in the year 580 AH, in a short period: in the Presence of Union with the people of Purity (أهل الصفاء), and in the Presence of Doubts with the people of Compulsion and Dominance (أهل القهر والغلبة), due to the breach of conditions—which are the covenants taken upon the world by Allah. Some of us betrayed, and some of us fulfilled, and we were among those who fulfilled, praise be to Allah. These are strange sciences and precious direct experiences. We met men who possessed them in the Maghreb, men in Alexandria, two or three men in Damascus, and one man in Sivas who lacked a small part of this station. He presented it to us, and we completed it for him until he realized it in a short time. He was a stranger, not from that land, but from Akhlat. Every group we mentioned, who are under the encompassment of these Divine Names, has distinction in three Presences: a High Presence, a Middle Presence, a Low Presence, and a Shared Presence.

### [The Opposing or Proximate Names]

These governing intellects (العقول المدبرة) are necessarily in one of these Presences during the passage of thoughts (الخواطر) over them, or [under the influence of] the opposing Names (الأسماء المتقابلة) or the proximate Names (المتقاربة). The opposing Names are like the Harmer (الضار) and the Benefiter (النافع), or the Honorer (المعز) and the Humiliator (المذل), or the Giver of Life (المحيي) and the Giver of Death (المميت). Examples of the proximate Names are the All-Knowing (العليم) and the All-Aware (الخبير), or the All-Powerful (القدير) and the Dominant (القاهر), or the Great (الكبير) and the Magnificent (العظيم), and whatever follows this course in the world of Creation (الخلق) and Command (الأمر). Now, God willing, I shall mention the effect of the ruling of all that in the World (العالم).

As for the detail of what we mentioned, we say—after you know that all these classes we mentioned are specifically the People of the Breaths (أهل الأنفاس) among the People of Allah, and no others—that when the governor from the world of Breaths (عالم الأنفاس) desires to execute a certain matter of the Isthmus (برزخي), its execution requires two rulings, though the matter is one. The Name the Comprehensive (الجامع), the Benefiter (النافع), the All-Seeing (البصير), and those who affirm Generosity during famine, look to the easier ruling and judge the matter accordingly. The Gnostics of Allah (العلماء بالله) establish Unity (التوحيد) between the two rulings and judge by the easier of the two. As for the Originator (الباري), the Swift (السريع), the Protector (الواقي), and the Forgiving (الغفور), they follow the path of Verification (التحقيق) in this, giving each ruling its due right, without favoring one side over the other. Only the Perfected Ones (المكملون) among the Men of Allah judge by this. If one of the two rulings is of the Isthmus (برزخيا) and the other is lower (سفليا), the Name the Comprehensive, the Benefiter, and the All-Seeing judge by what involves the removal of constraint (رفع الحرج). However, the Name the All-Seeing and the people of Generosity establish Unity between the two rulings so that they remove association (الاشتراك). The remaining seven Names and all classes outside the classes of these three Names follow the path of moderation (الاعتدال), fulfilling rights according to what the Levels (المراتب) bestow. An example of the first, the Isthmus, is when you see the Real (الحق) in a form perceived by the senses. The Verifiers (المحققون) give the Divinity (الألوهية) its due right and give the Presence (الحضرة) in which the Real appeared in this form its due right. The other group judges the Real by the form and says, "Had He not been upon a reality that accepts it, it would not have been valid for Him to appear in it, since it was not other than Him at the time of the Theophany (التجلي)." As for those who established Unity between the two rulings, they said: "The Real is upon what He is in Himself, and this form appeared *by* the Real, not that the Real appeared *by means of* it." They made Unity a separator between the Real and the form. And similarly in the second case. The example of the second case is the Theophany of one who says, upon seeing all existents (الأكوان), "I saw nothing but Allah," given that forms in the Isthmus (البرزخ) are only determined from the world of Nature (الطبيعة), which is the sensible world. The ruling is as we established. If the matter is between a ruling of the Isthmus and a high form, such as seeing the Real in the form of an angel, then the Comprehensive, the All-Seeing, and the Benefiter remove the constraint regarding the resemblance (التشبيه) that occurred, and they fulfill the right of one of the two rulings, which is the ruling pertaining to the side of Might (العزة). The people of Divine Generosity (الجود الإلهي) consider Unity and manifest it along with the removal of constraint. Unity is like His saying: <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like unto Him), and the removal of constraint is the completion of the verse: <<وَهُوَ السَّمِيعُ الْبَصِيرُ>> (And He is the All-Hearing, the All-Seeing). Another level: If two Divine matters appear in two different forms, and both matters are of the Isthmus, the Divine ruling in this is that you see the form of the Real in the Isthmus and the form of the angel in the Isthmus in the image of two humans, such as the form of Moses and Aaron, for example. Or you see the Real in the form of two persons simultaneously in one vision in the world of the Isthmus, such as seeing the Real in the form of a youth and an old man at the same time, and there is no doubt that it is the Real and nothing else. The ruling of knowledge from the Gnostics of Allah and the people of Divine Generosity in this occurrence is that this is Divine aid for the form in which the Real appeared. The people of Generosity, too, and the virtuous ones, the masters of additions (الزيادات) in Divine Knowledge, along with the Divine Name the All-Seeing, remove the Real by [affirming] <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like unto Him) and interpret the form in a manner befitting it. The remaining Divine Names and classes of the People of Allah, the masters of the Stations (المقامات) and Verification (التحقيق), leave the Real as the Real, in a manner befitting Him, and the form as the form, in a manner befitting it. This is the preferable view to me. Another level: A Prophet among the Prophets, like Jesus (عيسى), the Spirit of Allah (روح الله) and His Word (كلمته), appears as the Real by virtue of being the Word of Allah, and appears as an angel by virtue of being the Spirit of Allah. The ruling in this occurrence, according to the Gnostics of Allah and the people of Generosity among the People of Allah, is that they attach the angel to that Prophet and declare the Real transcendent (ينزهون) from that form. As for those firmly rooted in Knowledge (الراسخون في العلم), who are the people of additions, and whom the people of Divine Generosity also agree with, they say that the Divine Presence (الجناب الإلهي) is more accepting of forms than the World. They attach [the appearance] to the form of that Prophet and leave the form of the angel as it is, without interpreting it, especially concerning Jesus, for he appeared to his mother as a perfect man when He gave her Jesus. As for the Divine Name the All-Seeing, it drops the form of the Real from that, out of transcendence (تنزيها), and leaves what remains as it is. Another level: An angel among the angels appeared in a sensible form and appeared in a station of the Real (مقام حق), saying, "I am the Real," just as Moses heard the address from the tree: <<إِنَّنِي أَنَا اللَّهُ لَا إِلَٰهَ إِلَّا أَنَا>> (Indeed, I am Allah; there is no god except Me). The ruling of the Gnostic scholars (العلماء العارفون) and the people of Divine Generosity is that they say concerning the sensible form that it is an angel, and concerning the station of the Real that it is the Real. As for the people of additions among the Gnostics of Allah and the people of Divine Generosity, they also agree with their ruling, but they judge the Real by the angelic nature. The Divine Name the All-Seeing, by its ruling, drops the Real because of the resemblance (التشبيه) that entered into it, and leaves what remains as it is. All the People of Allah say that since the Real accepts forms, it is not far-fetched for the forms to claim Him and say, "I am the Real." What is relied upon in this matter is to give the Real His due right from the perspective of the Sacred Law (الشرع), not from the perspective of the Intellect (العقل); to give the sense its due right, and to give the angel its due right. Despite this, those who are not Verifiers must accompany Unity between the two rulings for fear of association (الاشتراك). The Verifier (المحقق) does not care, for he knows what is there. Another level: If one of the two forms is high (علوية) and the other is of the Isthmus (برزخية), the three Names—the Comprehensive, the All-Seeing, and the Benefiter—remove the constraint in the form of the Isthmus and others, and they do not give each of the two forms its due right.

### [That the Matter is Real and Creation, and that it is Pure Being that has ever been and ever shall be]

Know that all that we have mentioned is the ruling of the Intellect (العقل) concerning matters. Sometimes it imposes strictness, sometimes it grants ease, and sometimes it gives every possessor of a right his due right. Thus, in every ruling, it is according to how the Real (الحق) manifests Himself to it, whether that is in Divine matters (الإلهيات), natural matters (الطبيعيات), or what is composed of both, in terms of Gathering (الجمع) and Separation (الفرق), Annihilation (الفناء) and Subsistence (البقاء), Sobriety (الصحو) and Intoxication (السكر), Absence (الغيبة) and Presence (الحضور), Effacement (المحو) and Affirmation (الإثبات).

Clarification of what the Matter is upon: Know that the Matter (الأمر) is the Real and Creation (خلق). It is Pure Being (وجود محض) that has ever been and ever shall be, and Pure Possibility (إمكان محض) that has ever been and ever shall be, and Pure Non-existence (عدم محض) that has ever been and ever shall be. Pure Being does not accept non-existence, eternally and forever. Pure Non-existence does not accept Being, eternally and forever. Pure Possibility accepts Being due to a cause and accepts non-existence due to a cause, eternally and forever. Pure Being is Allah, none other than Him. Pure Non-existence is that whose existence is impossible, none other than it. Pure Possibility is the World (العالم), none other than it. Its level (مرتبته) is between Pure Being and Pure Non-existence. By what aspect it looks toward non-existence, it accepts non-existence; and by what aspect it looks toward Being, it accepts Being. From it comes darkness, which is Nature (الطبيعة), and from it comes light, which is the Breath of the All-Merciful (النفس الرحماني) that grants existence to this possible thing (الممكن). The World is both carrier (حامل) and carried (محمول). Insofar as it is a carrier, it is form, body, and agent (فاعل). Insofar as it is carried, it is spirit, meaning, and recipient (منفعل). There is no sensible, imaginative (خيالية), or intelligible form (معنوية) except that it has a leveling (تسوية) and adjustment (تعديل) from the side of the Real, as befits it, its station, and its state. This is before composition (التركيب)—meaning its joining with the carried thing it bears. When the Lord leveled it with what He willed—whether by word, hand, two hands, or hands (أيد)—there are no more than these four, because Existence (الوجود) is established upon the square (التربيع) and adjusted it. This leveling is the readiness and preparedness for composition and bearing. The All-Merciful received it and directed His Breath (نفسه) upon it. This is the Spirit of the Real (روح الحق) in His saying: <<فَإِذَا سَوَّيْتُهُ وَنَفَخْتُ فِيهِ مِنْ رُوحِي>> (So when I have proportioned him and breathed into him of My Spirit). This very Breath (النفس) was accepted by that form. The acceptance of forms varied according to their preparedness (الاستعداد). If the form was elemental (عنصرية) and its wick was ignited by that Breath, it was called an animal (حيوان) at that ignition. If no ignition appeared, but movement appeared to the eye, and it was elemental, it was called a plant (نبات). If neither ignition nor movement appeared (meaning to the sense), and it was elemental, it was called a mineral or inanimate object (معدنا وجمادا). If the form was acted upon by celestial movement (حركة فلكية), it was called a pillar (ركنا), and it is of four levels. Then, a leveled and adjusted form was acted upon by these pillars, and it was called a heaven (سماء), and it is of seven layers. The All-Merciful, Mighty and Majestic, directed His Breath upon these forms, and they lived a life that the sense does not perceive, nor does faith or the soul deny. Therefore, they did not accept ignition. Every place in these heavens that accepted ignition was called a star (نجما). Thus, the stars appeared, and their spheres (أفلاكها) moved by them. They were like the animal in what ignited from them, and like the plant in what moved from them. If the form resulted from intelligible movement (حركة معنوية), practical power (قوة عملية), and psychic direction (توجه نفسي), it was called a total body (جسما كلا), the Throne (عرشا), the Footstool (كرسيا), and a sphere—the sphere of the constellations (فلك برج) and the sphere of the lunar mansions (فلك منازل). The All-Merciful directed His Breath upon these forms. What accepted ignition was called stars, which are to Him like the pupils in the face of a human. What did not accept ignition was called a sphere. If the form was intellectual (عقلية), emanating intrinsically (انبعاثا ذاتيا) from a pure intellect, seeking by its preparedness what it would carry, the All-Merciful directed His Breath upon it during the leveling that its Lord leveled it with His Breath. What ignited from it was called the light of knowledge (نور علم). What moved from it but did not ignite was called action (عملا). The essence (الذات) carrying these two powers is called a soul (نفسا). If the form was Divine, it must either be comprehensive, in which case it is the form of the Human (الإنسان), or non-comprehensive, in which case it is the form of the Intellect (العقل). When the Lord leveled the intellectual form by His Command and fashioned the human form with His two Hands, the All-Merciful directed His Breath upon them both and breathed into them a spirit from His Command. As for the form of the Intellect, in that breathing, it carried all the sciences of the cosmos until the Day of Resurrection. He made it the origin of the World's existence and gave it priority in possible existence (الوجود الإمكانى). As for the form of the First Human, created with the two Hands, in that breathing, he carried the knowledge of the Divine Names (علم الأسماء الإلهية), which the form of the Intellect did not carry. Thus, he came forth upon the form of the Real, and in him the ruling of the Breath (النفس) terminated, for there is nothing more perfect than the form of the Real. The World revolved, and possible Existence appeared between light and darkness, Nature and Spirit, the Unseen (غيب) and the Witnessed (شهادة), concealment (ستر) and Unveiling (كشف). Whatever aspect of all that we mentioned faced Pure Being was light and spirit. Whatever aspect of all that we mentioned faced Pure Non-existence was darkness and body. By the combination of both, a form comes into being. If you look at the World from the perspective of the Breath of the All-Merciful, you say, "There is nothing but Allah." If you look at the World from the perspective of what is leveled and adjusted, you say, "The creatures." You did not throw, by virtue of your being creation, when you threw, by virtue of your being the Real, <<وَلَكِنَّ اللَّهَ رَمَىٰ>> (But Allah threw), because He is the Real. By the Breath, the entire World was breathing. The Breath manifested it. It is the inner aspect (باطن) for the Real and the outer aspect (ظاهر) for Creation. The inner aspect of the Real is the outer aspect of Creation, and the inner aspect of Creation is the outer aspect of the Real. By the combination of both, the cosmos (الكون) is realized. By abandoning the combination, it is said: Real and Creation. The Real belongs to Pure Being, and Creation belongs to Pure Possibility. Whatever perishes from the World and whose form departs is from the side facing Non-existence. Whatever remains of it and in which non-existence is not valid is from the side facing Being. These two matters remain ruling the World perpetually. Creation is new in every breath, in this world and the Hereafter. The Breath of the All-Merciful is perpetually directed, and Nature perpetually forms images for this Breath, so that the Divine Command is not suspended, for suspension is not valid. Forms are generated, and forms appear according to the preparedness to accept the Breath. This is the clearest possible explanation regarding the origination of the World. <<وَاللَّهُ يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وَهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (And Allah speaks the Truth, and He guides to the Way).

(Chapter Twelve) of this Section, concerning the Divine Name the Resurrector (الباعث) and its direction toward the creation of the Preserved Tablet (اللوح المحفوظ). This is the Universal Soul (النفس الكلية), which is the Spirit breathed into the leveled forms after their adjustment is complete. By that breathing, Allah grants them whatever form He wills, based on His saying: <<فِي أَيِّ صُورَةٍ مَّا شَاءَ رَكَّبَكَ>> (In whatever form He willed, He assembled you). And its direction toward the creation of the letter *Ha* (الهاء) among the letters and the pronominal *Ha* (هاء الكنايات), and its direction toward the creation of *Al-Butayn* (The Belly) among the determined lunar mansions (المنازل المقدرة).

Know that this Soul (النفس) is the Preserved Tablet (اللوح المحفوظ). It is the first emanated existent (أول موجود انبعاثي) and the first existent found *at* a cause, which is the First Intellect (العقل الأول). It exists from the Divine Command and the cause. It has a specific face toward Allah, which is the face before existence. Every existent in the World has that face, whether its existence has a created cause or not.

### [Causes are either Creative or Intelligible/Relative]

Know that causes (الأسباب) are either creative (خلقية) or intelligible/relative (معنوية نسبية). Creative causes are like the existence of a creature preceded by the existence of a creature before it, which has a certain relation to its existence, in whatever way—either by an active relation or a relation by property. This is necessary, and then it is a cause; otherwise, it is not a cause. That effect may occur in something other than a creature, such as His saying: <<أُجِيبُ دَعْوَةَ الدَّاعِ>> (I answer the call of the caller). The request is a cause for the existence of the answer, whatever the answerer may be. From this reality descends His saying, the Exalted: <<مَا يَأْتِيهِمْ مِنْ ذِكْرٍ مِنْ رَبِّهِمْ مُحْدَثٍ>> (No reminder comes to them from their Lord that is newly produced), meaning that some of these matters were newly produced by the requests. As for the intelligible cause (السبب المعنوي), it is from the perspective of the caused (المُسَبَّب) and from the perspective of the causer (المُسَبِّب). From the perspective of the caused (passive participle), it is its preparedness (استعداده) to accept the effect within it. For if there were no preparedness in it, the effect would not occur in it. That preparedness is more resistant than the impossible (المحال), which does not exist. Yet, the impossible has a preparedness to accept being hypothesized within it. Therefore, we hypothesize the impossible in some issues, even though it does not accept existence, in order to extract knowledge from that hypothesis that we did not possess. Were it not for its preparedness to accept the hypothesis, the Intellect would not be able to hypothesize it. The possible (الممكن) is more accepting of the essence of Being. The cause from the perspective of the causer (active participle) is what Allah mentioned: <<إِنَّمَا قَوْلُنَا>> (Indeed, Our word), thus affirming His Essence, and His saying: <<إِذَا أَرَدْنَاهُ>> (When We intend it), thus affirming the Will (الإرادة) and the relation to the willed object. It is necessary for one whose affair is thus to be All-Knowing, Living, and possessing power over what He wills to bring into existence. All these are relative, intelligible preparednesses, except for the Essence (العين) which is the Causer (المسبب), for He is an existential cause (سبب وجودي) that is not an ultimate cause (*'illa*), but rather a necessary condition. When Allah created this First Intellect (العقل الأول), the Pen (قلما) sought, by its reality, a place for the trace of its writing, because it was a Pen. From this seeking, the Preserved Tablet (اللوح المحفوظ), which is the Soul (النفس), emanated. Therefore, it was the first emanated existent. Since it emanated from the seeking inherent in the Pen, and the intellectual power did not possess the independence to bring this Tablet into existence, it was supported by the Name the Resurrector (الباعث) and by the specific face from which this Soul emanated. The Intellect cast upon it everything it possessed until the Day of Resurrection, inscribed and ordered. This is a third existent, whose level is between the Tablet and the Pen, and whose existence is after the Tablet. Allah placed in the Pen the casting of what He created within it, and placed in the Tablet the acceptance of what is cast upon it. What was cast upon it, and what the Tablet contained of the words created in the essence of the Pen and the Tablet after the completion of the writing, was two hundred thousand verses, sixty-nine thousand verses, and two hundred verses. This is what will occur in Creation until the Day of Resurrection, from the perspective of what the Soul casts into the World through secondary causes. As for what occurs from the specific Divine Faces (الوجوه الخاصة الإلهية) in the existents, that happens at the time of its existence. No one knows it but Allah, and it has no existence except in the Knowledge of Allah. This is all that the Intellect acquired from the Breath of the All-Merciful, in terms of what its Lord, the Exalted, spoke to it, just as He spoke to Moses with twelve thousand words, in every word saying to him, "O Moses." The form of the Divine reception by the Intellect is a Theophany (تجلي) of the All-Merciful, arising from love between the Manifestor and the recipient of the manifestation.

### [Allah established Affection and Mercy between Spouses]

From this station, Allah established affection (المودة) and mercy (الرحمة) between the spouses so that one may find tranquility in the other. He made the wife created from the very essence (عين) and soul (نفس) of the husband, as He said: <<وَمِنْ آيَاتِهِ أَنْ خَلَقَ لَكُمْ مِنْ أَنْفُسِكُمْ أَزْوَاجًا لِتَسْكُنُوا إِلَيْهَا وَجَعَلَ بَيْنَكُمْ مَوَدَّةً وَرَحْمَةً إِنَّ فِي ذَلِكَ لَآيَاتٍ>> (And among His signs is that He created for you from yourselves mates that you may find tranquility in them; and He placed between you affection and mercy. Indeed in that are signs)—meaning a mark and a proof—<<لِقَوْمٍ يَتَفَكَّرُونَ>> (for a people who reflect). They know that He is the Real. The benefit of this reflection is that when a person marries a woman and finds tranquility in her, and Allah establishes affection and mercy between them, he knows that Allah desires their union. If the tranquility is lifted from one of them toward the other, or from both, and the affection—which is the permanence of this tranquility (and for this reason love is called *wudd* [affection] due to its permanence, and He is called *al-Wadud* [the Loving One] due to the permanence of His love for those of His servants whom He loves)—is removed, and the mercy is removed from between them or from one of them toward the other, so that he turns away from her, then he knows that Allah has willed their separation. He should hasten to that, thereby achieving success with Allah in this station. If he persists and resists, he is deprived of Divine Proximity (القرب الإلهي), for the Divine Presence does not accept persistence and resistance. What is established in the Sacred Law is established. Only the people of reflection among Allah's servants know what we have said, for Allah only made it a sign for them. The Exalted made the cause for the acquisition of these sciences in the essence of the Intellect to be the Theophany.

### [That the Cause of the World's Existence is Love]

From it, the Intellect received that. The cause of the Theophany was Love, for it is the fundamental cause of the World's existence, and Hearing (السماع) is the cause of its being. We have explained this in the Chapter on Hearing and Love. As for the form of the Soul's reception of the sciences it possesses, it is in two ways—for it and every existent that arises from a cause—and it varies according to the diversity of causes. The first way: If the reception for every existent at a cause is from its own specific face, it only occurs through a Divine Theophany, whether the recipient of the manifestation knows it or not. If he knows it, he is among the Gnostics of Allah. If he does not know it, he is among the people of Divine Care (أهل العناية), and he is unaware that he is cared for. For most people do not know the discourse of this specific face, nor do they recognize it, as it is a special knowledge that Allah grants only to those whom He has chosen and fashioned for Himself among His servants.

### [The Causes are Different]

As for the second way of reception, it is what is gained from the cause, and its paths are innumerable, for the causes are diverse. How does the causality of the Intellect, in what appears upon the Soul from its direction and reception, compare to the causality of the heaven, in what appears upon the earth from plants, from its direction upon the earth with the rain it casts into it, and the earth's reception of that? Every celestial movement, the gaze of a star in the higher world, and the aid of Nature—all of this constitutes causes for the existence of a flower that appears on the face of the earth. How does this compare to the direction of the Intellect's causality? Therefore, we said that its causes are not confined, even though they are confined in the matter itself. From the Soul to the last pillar in the World, and some generated things between the Soul and the last pillar of the spheres, stars, and movements, in the existence of the essence of that flower and leaf, there is a trace and a ruling from a Divine Command. The generated cause may know it or may not know it. All of these are intrinsic causes (أسباب ذاتية). Some are accidental (عرضية), such as a teacher delivering a lesson to a group. This is among the accidental causes, which is everything in which the cause has a will (إرادة). Everything else is intrinsic. The relationship between causes and effects (المسببات) is never severed, for it preserves the fact that this is a cause and that is caused by it. When Allah brought this Universal Soul (النفس الكلية) into existence from the Breath of the All-Merciful after the Intellect, like the existence of the letter *Ha* after the *Hamza*, or the *Hamza* after the *Ha* in the human soul created upon the Form, it is a Universal Soul in the Breath of the All-Merciful, and in the human soul, it is the letter *Ha*, a pronoun (ضمير), and an allusion (كناية). Insofar as it is a pronoun, it refers back to the One who brought it into existence, for it is the very essence of the indication (الدلالة) toward Him. Understand this, for the indication only occurs in the second, as the second seeks the first, but the first does not seek the second by the ruling of indication. For this reason, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever knows his soul knows his Lord." This [the soul] is the second, for it is the locus of indication. Concerning the first [the Lord], He said: <<فَإِنَّ اللَّهَ غَنِيٌّ عَنِ الْعالَمِينَ>> (Indeed, Allah is free from need of the worlds), thus declaring Him transcendent from indication. For this reason, it is not valid for Him to be an ultimate cause (*'illa*). The indication toward Him is through His saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "Allah was, and there was nothing with Him." At this level, Allah brought into existence *Al-Butayn* (The Belly) among the lunar mansions, which are occupied by the slow-moving planets and stars.

### [That the Soul has Two Powers]

Allah granted this Soul two powers: a cognitive power (قوة علمية) and a practical power (قوة عملية). By the cognitive power, the essences of the forms (أعيان الصور) appear. By the practical power, the measures (المقادير) and weights (الأوزان) are known. From the specific face comes the Divine Decree (*al-Qada'*) and Predetermination (*al-Qadar*) for this, and this is not known until after its occurrence, except by one whom Allah informs of it. The ruling of the Divine Decree and Predetermination is only known from what we mentioned, unlike the measures and weights, for that is in the knowledge of the Soul. The relation of this Soul to every form in the World is a single relation, without differentiation, except that the forms accept from that according to their preparednesses, which are high in their essence. Thus, differentiation appears. But there [in the Soul itself], there is no differentiation except between it and the Intellect. Since I have clarified for you the confinement of the verses (الآيات) in the Divine Speech (الكلام الإلهي) that appear in the Breath of the All-Merciful—like the verses in the Noble Qur'an and in the revealed Books and sent Scrolls—they have chapters (سور) that gather those verses and separate some from others, just as the chapters of the Qur'an came, which are its known mansions (منازله) that gather the verses, just as the verses gather the words, just as the words gather the letters, just as the letters are the vessels of the meanings. The chapters of these verses are ten chapters, neither more nor less. Among them is the Chapter of the Origin (سورة الأصل), which is the chapter that includes every verse indicating an essence (عين) subsisting by itself in the World, which carries others. The second chapter is the Chapter of the Carried (سورة المحمول), which includes every verse indicating an essence that does not subsist by itself but requires a locus and an essence for its existence to appear in that locus. That essence may be necessary or accidental, according to what its reality bestows. The third chapter is the Chapter of Time (سورة الدهر). The fourth is the Chapter of Leveling/Equilibrium (سورة الاستواء), which has two origins: the first origin is the vessel of the Cloud (*al-Ama'*) and the second origin is the vessel of the Throne (*al-Arsh*). The first is the vessel of meanings, and the second is the vessel of chapters. The fifth chapter is the Chapter of States (سورة الأحوال). The sixth is the Chapter of Measure (سورة المقدار). The seventh is the Chapter of Relations (سورة النسب). The eighth is the Chapter of Connection, Rulings, Expressions, Indications, and Gestures (سورة التوصيل والأحكام والعبارات والإشارات والإيماء)—that by which understanding occurs between speakers, which is the speech of the World and the saying of every speaker. These are the Divine Names that Allah taught Adam. Some of them the angels knew, but Adam was distinguished only by the totality, and nothing of the named things was presented except what the angels were ignorant of. The ninth chapter is the Chapter of Existential Traces (سورة الآثار الوجودية). The tenth chapter is the Chapter of Existents (سورة الكائنات), which are the Divine and cosmic reactions (الانفعالات). These ten encompass these verses. Whoever knows them through Unveiling (كشفا) knows the Real and Creation. Whoever knows them through indication (دلالة) does not attain the perfection of knowledge achieved by the people of Unveiling. Do not say this is symbolic (رمز); rather, all of this is explicit statement and clarification. Every rational person who verifies the contemplation of it knows that all the verses, ancient and modern, are confined within these chapters. The Universal Soul (النفس الكلية) is that through which the knowledge of these chapters appeared, because it was the locus of the Divine Pen's casting upon it. Thus, it is the first thing married by a cosmic spouse. Everything below it belongs to the world of generation (التولد). The Intellect is its father, and the Soul is its mother. Understand this, and do not join those concerning whom Allah said: <<إِنَّهُمْ لَفِي لَبْسٍ مِنْ خَلْقٍ جَدِيدٍ>> (Indeed, they are in confusion concerning a new creation), who are those who turn away from every <<مَا يَأْتِيهِمْ مِنْ ذِكْرٍ مِنْ رَبِّهِمْ مُحْدَثٍ>> (reminder that comes to them from their Lord that is newly produced).

I am in a new creation,
Every day in increase.
And I, by virtue of my love,
Am between finding and Being.
Grateful, with the gratitude of a lover,
Saying, "Is there any more?"
So I am the unique one of my time,
In my Being and my Witnessing.
O Exalted in Degrees,
In the mansions of felicity,
O Allah, lift from me,
In the ascents of rising,
Every veil on my path,
In my descent and my ascent.
And make, O Allah, my portion,
In Your Name, Allah, the Loving One (الودود).

(Chapter Thirteen) concerning the Divine Name the Inner (الباطن) and its direction toward the creation of Nature (الطبيعة), and what it bestows of the breaths of the World, confining them to four realities, their separation and combination, and its direction toward the creation of the letter *Ayn* (العين المهملة) among the letters, and the creation of *Al-Thurayya* (The Pleiades) among the determined lunar mansions.

### [That Nature is in the Third Level of the Existence of the First Intellect]

Know that Nature (الطبيعة) is, according to us, in the third level (المرتبة الثالثة) of the existence of the First Intellect. It is intelligible in existence (معقولة الوجود) but not existent in essence (غير موجودة العين). Thus, the meaning of our saying "created" (مخلوقة) is "measured/determined" (مقدرة), because *al-Khalaq* (creation) is determination. Not everything determined necessarily exists. The poet said:

For you cut out what you determined,
While some people determine but do not cut out.

This is from the triliteral root [of *khalaqa*], because he intended praise. It is not from the quadriliteral root, for the quadriliteral is only used in the context of blame and satire. Not everyone who determines a matter brings it into existence. From this Divine reality, the hypothesis of the impossible (فرض المحال) appeared in theoretical existence among scholars in the sciences. He determines what is not valid to exist, and he may determine what is valid to exist but does not exist. Similarly, this Arab said: "Some people promise good but do not do it, but you, O King, see no benefit except that you do it." The Creator (الخالق) has two meanings: the Determiner and the Bringer into Existence. Whoever creates has either determined or brought into existence. The Exalted determined the level of Nature such that if it had existence, it would be below the Soul. Thus, even though it is not existent in essence, it is witnessed by the Real. For this reason, He distinguished it and specified its level. For natural existents, it is like the Divine Names: it is known, intelligible, and its effects appear, and it is not unknown, yet it has no external essence whatsoever. Similarly, Nature bestows what is in its power of sensible forms added to it existentially, yet it has no external existence. How astonishing is its level, and how high is its effect! It is an intelligible essence (ذات معقولة), a collection of four realities. The effect of these four in created natural bodies is called heat (حرارة), dryness (يبوسة), coldness (برودة), and moisture (رطوبة). These are the effects of Nature in bodies, not its essence, just like Life, Knowledge, Will, and Speech in the Divine relations, where there is only one Essence (ذات واحدة) in existential Being. Life looks toward heat, Knowledge looks toward coldness, Will looks toward dryness, and Speech looks toward moisture. For this reason, He described it with softness, saying: <<فَقُولَا لَهُ قَوْلًا لَيِّنًا>> (And speak to him a gentle word). Thus, it accepts softness and roughness. Will is dryness, for He says: <<فَإِذَا عَزَمْتَ فَتَوَكَّلْ>> (So when you have decided, then rely [upon Allah]). And [the Prophet] said: "I found the coldness of his fingertips, so I knew." For this reason, we assigned Knowledge to coldness in Nature, and similarly Life to heat, for the natural living being must possess heat.

### [Intellectual Life]

As for what it bestows of the breaths of the World, it is that by which life occurs in natural bodies, such as growth and sensation, and nothing else. Every breath other than this is not from Nature; rather, its ultimate cause (*'illa*) is another matter, which is Intellectual Life (الحياة العقلية), the life of Knowledge, which is the very essence of the Divine Light (النور الإلهي) and the Breath of the All-Merciful. Then know that the designation of the Soul (النفس) from this existential reality only occurs when it belongs to the All-Merciful (الرحمن) and similar Divine Names. It may be a reality for other Names that necessitate the opposite, and in that case, it is not a soul in the sense of relief (التنفيس) for the existent that arises from it. Although it is a reality, its being a soul is due to a specific consideration by which relief occurs, either for those existents from whom Allah removes the constriction and constraint they find, or for the one whose attribute it is, in terms of the penetration of his will. But if it is not viewed from this perspective, it is merely an expression of the life of the one described by it, in terms of its reality, nothing more. Do you not see that the animal soul (النفس الحيواني) removes the name of death from the existence in which it resides? By this, it is called a soul, for death is a disliked attribute from the perspective of familiar companionship, since death is a separator, and thus disliked by the soul. But if one looks at the One he meets in that death, which is Allah, then it becomes a gift, and the name *Nafs* (Soul/Breath) is more appropriate for it in this Witnessing (الشهود). Since it possesses the existence of the essences of forms (أعيان الصور), it was assigned the letter *Ayn* (العين المهملة) among the letters, because the natural form has no spirit from the perspective of Nature, but it is a spirit for the natural forms derived from the Divine Spirit (الروح الإلهي). It was also assigned the existence of *Al-Thurayya* (The Pleiades), which are seven stars, because Nature is in the third level and consists of four realities, as previously mentioned. The total was seven, and *Al-Thurayya* appeared from it, being seven stars. Just as the Intellect had three relations and faces, from which the multiplicity (الكثرة) arose—which some speculative thinkers mentioned as the cause of multiplicity emanating from the First Intellect despite its oneness—so *Al-Sharatayn* (The Two Signs) were three stars. The Soul is like the Intellect in this, so *Al-Butayn* (The Belly) was three stars. And because the Soul is second, *Al-Butayn* was in the second level after *Al-Sharatayn*. From these seven that appeared in Nature, the septenaries (المسبعات) appeared in the World, which are also the seven days of the week. Muhammad ibn Sirin, may Allah have mercy on him, considered this. A woman came to him and said, "Last night I saw the moon in *Al-Thurayya*." He said, "I am the moon of this time in this land, and *Al-Thurayya* is seven stars. After seven days, I will be buried." For *Al-Thurayya* (The Pleiades) is derived from *al-Thara* (moist earth), which is a name for the earth. He died within seven days. Look how astonishing this is. While I was recording this issue concerning Nature, I dozed off and saw my mother wearing beautiful white clothes. She lifted her skirt until her private parts (فرجها) were exposed to me. I looked at them, then said, "It is not lawful for me to look at my mother's private parts," so I covered them while she laughed. I found that I had unveiled an aspect in this matter that ought to be concealed, so I concealed it with beautiful expressions after having unveiled it before seeing this incident. My mother was Nature, and the private parts were that aspect which ought to be concealed. The Unveiling (الكشف) was its manifestation in this chapter, and the covering with the beautiful white garment was its concealment with beautiful words and expressions. Then, also, while I was speaking about Nature in this chapter, I was overcome by drowsiness and saw myself upon a magnificent horse. I came to a shallow pool of water whose ground was small stones. I wanted to cross it, and I saw a man ahead of me on a gray horse crossing. There was a deep ditch in the water, like an irrigation channel, covered with those stones, so that one would not notice it until drowning in it. That rider's horse sank into it, and he struggled until the water reached the horse's flank, then he escaped to the other side. I looked for where to cross and found a passage built over it, with steps on both sides for pedestrians, which the horse could not ascend. It ascended with very close steps, and its top was the width of a span. It descended on the other side with steps. I spurred my horse, and people were astonished, saying, "No horse can cross that!" I did not speak to them. The horse understood what I wanted from it and ascended gently. When it reached the top and wanted to descend, it stopped, and I feared for it and myself from falling. I dismounted and crossed, holding its bridle, and it did not leave my hand. The horse crossed, and we escaped to the other side, and the people were astonished. I heard some people saying, "If faith (الإيمان) were in *Al-Thurayya*, men from Persia would attain it." I said, "Even if Knowledge (العلم) were in *Al-Thurayya*, the Arabs would attain it. Faith is imitation (تقليد). How great is the difference between a scholar and one who imitates a scholar!" They said, "He speaks the truth." Thus, the Arab possesses Knowledge and Faith, while the non-Arabs (العجم) are witnessed to possess Faith specifically in the religion of Allah. I returned to myself and found that I was dealing with an issue concerning Nature that corresponded to this vision. I was astonished by these two incidents in this chapter. I looked at the stars of the lunar mansions: from one star, like *Al-Sarfa* (The Change), to two, like *Al-Dhirā'* (The Arm), to three, like *Al-Butayn* (The Belly), to four, like *Al-Jabhah* (The Forehead), to five, like *Al-Awwā'* (The Howler), to six, like *Al-Dabarān* (The Follower), to seven, like *Al-Thurayya* (The Pleiades), to nine, like *Al-Na'ā'im* (The Ostriches). I did not see the number eight existing among the stars of the mansions. I knew that because the number eight had no form in the stars of the mansions, a child born in the eighth month dies and does not live, or is afflicted and cannot benefit himself. This is a month in which coldness and dryness dominate the fetus, which is the nature of death. Its corresponding planet is Saturn (كيوان), which is cold and dry. Therefore, I did not see the existence of eight in the mansions. Then I knew that the wandering stars (السيارة - planets) have no descent or rest; rather, they are perpetually traversing. Their passage may be exactly upon the stars of the mansion, or above or below them, depending on the definition of the mansion. Thus, it is called a mansion (*manzila*) metaphorically, for the one who alights in it has no stability; rather, he is swimming, just as he was swimming before reaching it. The designation respects what the sight perceives of that, for sight does not perceive movement until after separation. To that extent, it is called a mansion, because it is the portion of sight, and sight prevailed.

### [That Nature Cannot Remain in One State]

Know that this is the ruling of Nature (الطبيعة) concerning forms: it cannot remain fixed in one state, so there is no rest with it. For this reason, equilibrium (الاعتدال) in elemental natural bodies does not exist; it is intelligible but not existent. If Nature accepted the balance (الميزان) equally, the existence of anything would not be valid from it, nor would any form appear from it. Furthermore, the generation of natural forms below the elemental ones, when they appear, also does not occur while Nature is perpetually in equilibrium. Rather, some of its realities must prevail over others for the sake of bringing into existence. Were it not for that, no sphere would move, no angel would swim, Paradise would not be described with eating, drinking, and appearing in different forms, nor would the breaths in the World change entirely. The origin of this in Divine Knowledge is His being, the Exalted: <<كُلَّ يَوْمٍ هُوَ فِي شَأْنٍ>> (Every day He is in [new] affair). The "day" is the singular time, and the "affair" (الشأن) is what Allah brings into existence within it. How, then, can it be valid for Nature to be moderate in its ruling over things when it has no support in Divine matters? Thus, I have clarified for you the existence of Nature. *End of the one hundred and twenty-first section.*

(Chapter Fourteen concerning the Divine Name) the Last (الآخر) and its direction toward the creation of the Haba'ic Substance (الجوهر الهبائي) in which the forms of bodies appeared, and what resembles this substance in the world of composites, and its direction toward the creation of the letter *Ha* (الحاء المهملة) among the letters, and the creation of *Al-Dabarān* (The Follower) among the lunar mansions.

### [Nature Has No Essence in Existence; rather, the Form Manifests It]

Know that this Substance (الجوهر) is like Nature: it has no essence (عين) in existence; rather, the form manifests it. It is intelligible but not existent in essential Being (الوجود العيني). It is in the fourth level (المرتبة الرابعة) of the levels of Existence, just as the letter *Ha* (الحاء المهملة) is in the fourth level of the articulation points of the letters in the human soul. However, the letter has a verbal form in speech, sensible to hearing, and this Haba'ic Substance (الجوهر الهبائي) does not have such an existence. This Name, by which it is distinguished, is transmitted from Ali ibn Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him. As for us, we call it the Phoenix (*al-Anqa'*), for its mention is heard, and it is intelligible, but it has no existence in essence. It is not known in reality except through parables (الأمثلة المضروبة). Just as the Real's being <<نُورُ السَّمَاوَاتِ وَالْأَرْضِ>> (the Light of the heavens and the earth) is not known in its reality. Rather, we knew the Real through it by striking a parable, for He said: <<مَثَلُ نُورِهِ كَمِشْكَاةٍ>> (The example of His light is like a niche...) [Q 24:35]. He mentioned the things necessary for the lamp, which is the similitude for the Light of the heavens and the earth—that by which the higher intellects were illuminated (which is His saying "the heavens") and the natural forms (which is His saying "and the earth"). Likewise, this intelligible Haba'ic thing is not known except by the parable struck for it, which is every matter that accepts, by its essence, the different forms that befit it, and it is in every form by its reality. The philosophers call it *Hayūlā* (Prime Matter), which is a disputed issue among them. We are not among those who relate their sayings concerning a matter, nor the sayings of others. Rather, we present in this book and all our books what Unveiling (الكشف) grants and what the Real dictates. This is the method of the People [Sufis]. For example, Al-Junayd was asked about Unity (التوحيد) and he answered with words that were not understood. He was asked, "Repeat the answer, for we did not understand." He gave another answer. He was told, "This is more obscure to us than the first. Dictate it to us so we may examine it and know it." He replied, "If I were the one who caused it to flow, I would dictate it." He indicated that he had no personal effort in it, but that it was according to what was cast upon him, necessitated by his time, and the casting varies according to the variation of times.

### [From Divine Knowledge]

From Divine Knowledge, one knows that nothing is repeated in Existence (الوجود).

And whoever knows the Divine Expansion knows that nothing is repeated in Existence (الوجود). Rather, the existence of similitudes (الأمثال) in forms is imagined to be the essences (الأعيان) of what has passed, but they are their similitudes, not their essences. And the similitude of a thing is what is its essence.

Know that this Fourth Intelligible (المعقول الرابع) is where the entity (العين) appears from the existence of the Intellect within it, which accepts the ruling of Nature (الطبيعة). This is the Universal Body (الجسم الكل) which accepts the subtle and the dense, the turbid and the transparent. It is that which will be mentioned in the second chapter following this one. We only restricted its level (مرتبة) as the Fourth Intelligible because we considered its acceptance of the form of the body specifically. But when considering its Reality (حقيقة), this is neither its level nor is that name its name. Rather, its name which befits it is the Universal Reality (الحقيقة الكلية), which is the spirit (روح) of every reality (حق); and whenever a reality is devoid of it, it is not a reality. For this reason, the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "For every reality, there is a reality (حقيقة)." So he came with the word that necessitates comprehensiveness when stripped of restrictive qualifiers, which is the word 'every' (كل).

Like the concept of Knowledge (العلم), Life, and Will (الإرادة): they are fundamentally one intelligible concept (معقولة واحدة). When a specific matter is attributed to it due to a specific relation, a name arises for it. Then, if that specific matter is attributed to an Essence (ذات) whose existence is known, even if its reality is unknown, that specific matter is attributed to it according to what that particular Essence necessitates. If that Essence is described by Pre-eternity (القدم), this matter is described by Pre-eternity; and if it is described by Origination (الحدوث), this matter is described by Origination.

And the matter in itself is not described by Existence, since it has no entity, nor by Non-existence, because it is intelligible (معقول). Nor is it described by Origination, because the Pre-eternal does not accept being described by it, and the Pre-eternal cannot be a locus for originated things (الحوادث). Nor is it described by Pre-eternity, because the originated accepts being described by it, and the originated is not described by the Pre-eternal, and the Pre-eternal cannot subsist (حالاً) in the originated. Thus, it is neither Pre-eternal nor originated. So when the originated is described by it, it is called originated; and when the Pre-eternal is described by it, it is called Pre-eternal. And it is truly Pre-eternal in the Pre-eternal, and truly originated in the originated.

This is because in its essence, it corresponds to everything described by it, such as Knowledge (العلم), which The Real (الحق) and Creation (الخلق) are described by. So it is said concerning the Knowledge of The Real that it is Pre-eternal, for the one described by it is Pre-eternal, and His Knowledge of the known things is Pre-eternal, having no beginning. And it is said concerning the knowledge of Creation that it is originated (محدث), for the one described by it was not, and then came to be; thus, its attribute is like it, since its ruling only appeared in it after the existence of its entity, so it is originated like it. And Knowledge in itself does not change from its reality relative to itself. It is in every Essence with its reality and entity, and it has no existential entity (عين وجودية) other than the entity of the one described; thus, it remains in its original state: intelligible (معقول), not existent (موجود).

Its example in the sensory realm is whiteness in every white thing, and blackness in every black thing—this is concerning colors. Likewise concerning shapes: squareness in every square, circularity in every circle, and octagonalness in every octagon. And the shape in itself is in every shaped thing, and it remains in its reality of intelligibility (المعقولية). What the sense perceives is the shaped thing, not the shape, for the shape is intelligible. For if the shaped thing were the essence of the shape, it would not appear in another shaped thing like it, and it is known that this shaped thing is not the other shaped thing.

This is a parable set forth for the Universal Realities (الحقائق الكلية) by which The Real and Creation are described. They are Names (أسماء) for The Real, and they are existents (أكوان) for Creation. Thus, this Fourth Intelligible, for the forms of Nature, accepts the forms through its substance (جوهر), while remaining in its original state of intelligibility. What is perceived is the form, and nothing else. And the form subsists only in this Intelligible. There is no existent thing (موجود) except that it is intelligible when considering that in which its form appeared, and existent when considering its form.

Do you not see that The Real, Exalted is He, has not named Himself with a Name, nor described Himself with an affirmative Attribute (صفة ثبوتية), except that Creation is also described by it? And it is attributed to every described entity according to what the reality of that described entity yields. They are only prior in The Real due to the priority of The Real in Existence (الوجود), and they are posterior in Creation due to the posteriority of Creation in Existence. So it is said concerning The Real that He is an Essence described as Living, Knowing, Powerful, Willing, Speaking, Hearing, Seeing. And it is said concerning the created human that he is Living, Knowing, Powerful, Speaking, Hearing, Seeing, without dispute from anyone. And Knowledge, Speech, and all Attributes are fundamentally one reality (حقيقة واحدة) in the Intellect. Yet, the difference between them in ruling is not denied, for the effect of Power (القدرة) differs from the effect of other Attributes, and so on for every Attribute, though the entity (العين) is one. Furthermore, the reality of the single Attribute is one in terms of its essence (ذات), but its definition (حد) differs relative to The Real being specified by it, and relative to Creation being described by it. And this Reality remains perpetually intelligible; the Intellect cannot deny it, and its ruling remains existent and manifest in every existent thing.

> For every existent thing has a form of it
> Within it, yet it has no form in its essence (ذات).
> Its ruling is nothing but its essence,
> And that ruling is one of its signs.
> Opposites gather in its description,
> For its negation is in the very entity of its affirmation.

Thus, the meaning (المعنى) that accepts the form of the body is what is mentioned and sought in this chapter, and it is that which is prepared for it. And the body that accepts shape is the Haba' (هباء) [Cosmic Dust], because it is that which accepts shapes by its essence, so every shape appears in it, yet nothing of the Haba' is in the shape, nor is it the essence of the shape. And the Elements (الأركان) are the Haba' for the generated things (المولدات). This is the Natural Haba' (الهباء الطبيعي). And iron and its likes are the Haba' for everything formed from it, such as a knife, a sword, a spearhead, an axe, and a key—all of which are forms of shapes. And this kind is called the Industrial Haba' (الهباء الصناعي).

These are four according to the rationalists (العقلاء), and the origin is the Whole (الكل), which is what we dedicated this chapter to. And we added the Reality of Realities (حقيقة الحقائق), which we mentioned in this chapter, which encompasses Creation and The Real. No one among the masters of speculative thought mentioned it except the People of Allah (أهل الله), although the Mu'tazila noticed something close to it. They said that Allah is a Speaker by virtue of 'Speaker-ness' (القائلية), and Knowing by virtue of 'Knower-ness' (العالمية), and Powerful by virtue of 'Powerful-ness' (القادرية), because they fled from affirming an attribute supplementary to the Essence of The Real, in order to uphold the transcendence (تنزيه) of The Real. They took this approach and came close to the matter.

All this—I mean what pertains to this chapter concerning the ruling of the other Manifest Name, which is the Word of the Breath of the All-Merciful (كلمة النفس الرحماني)—is that which is directed toward Al-Dabaran among the Lunar Mansions (المنازل). Its stars are six, and it is the first perfect number, thus it is the origin of every perfect number. Every hexagon (مسدس) in the world has a share of this perfection, and upon it the bees build their house so that no void (خلاء) enters it. Some of the People of Allah consider it the best of shapes, for it approaches circularity while having visible angles. They made it superior because the hexagonal shape, like beehives, does not accept gaps (خلل) despite multiplicity, thus preventing emptiness. The circular shape is not like this, even if others resemble it in not accepting gaps, such as the square, which is far from circularity. And circularity (الاستدارة) is the first of the shapes that the body accepted, and some were placed inside others, because the Void is circular. If it were not so, the body would not be circular, because it only filled the Void, and thus it does not accept another circularity from the outside, for there is no Void other than that which the body has occupied. If only part of the Void were occupied, it would only accept the hexagonal shape. It is only described by perfection because it manifests from its half, its third, and its sixth, thus subsisting from the very entity of its parts.
