Thus, <<يُولِجُ اللَّيْلَ فِي النَّهَارِ>> (He causes the night to enter the day) when the day is female, and <<يُولِجُ النَّهَارَ فِي اللَّيْلِ>> (He causes the day to enter the night) when the night is female. We have explained this in the book *Kitāb al-Sha'n*. Everything that manifests of knowledge and effects in the generated entities on Sunday originates from this heaven and its inhabitant—indeed, this applies every day and throughout the entire Cosmos under its encompassing influence. Its star does not hide (*lā yakhnis*).

***

### Chapter Twenty-Five: Concerning the Name *al-Muṣawwir* (The Fashioner)

The orientation of this Divine Name was toward the creation of the Fifth Heaven, its sphere, and its star. Its manifestation occurred in the lunar mansion *al-Ghafr*. He revealed within it the manifestation of the forms (صور) of spirits, bodies, and sciences in the elemental world (العالم العنصري). It was specifically associated with the complete effect, by way of delegation (*al-tawliyah*), on Friday. He settled Joseph (peace be upon him) therein, and the letter *Rā'* (ر) appeared from it.

***

### Chapter Twenty-Six: Concerning the Name *al-Muḥṣī* (The Reckoner)

The Exalted said: <<وَأَحْصَى كُلَّ شَيْءٍ عَدَداً>> (And He has enumerated all things in number), meaning existing things. The orientation of this Divine Name was toward the creation of the Sixth Heaven, its star, and its sphere on Wednesday, in the lunar mansion *al-Zubānā*. He settled Jesus (peace be upon him) therein. Everything that manifests on Wednesday in the elemental world, whether sensory or subtle effects, and whatever the Gnostics receive in their hearts thereof, originates from the revelation of this heaven. From it appeared the undotted letter *Ṭā'* (ط).

***

### Chapter Twenty-Seven: Concerning the Name *al-Mubīn* (The Manifest/Clear)

The orientation of this Name was toward the creation of the Lowest Heaven (السماء الدنيا), its star, and its sphere on Monday, in the lunar mansion *al-Iklīl*. From the movement of this sphere appeared the undotted letter *Dāl* (د). To it belongs every ruling that manifests in the Cosmos on Monday, spiritually and physically. This applies entirely to the daytime of that day, not its night. The night of every day is neither the night preceding that day nor the night following its sunset on that day. We have mentioned this in *Kitāb al-Sha'n*. Rather, the night belonging to that day is the first hour of the night that governs the first hour of the day. That is the day of that night, and that night is the night of that day. This is what I mean.

### The Human is Swiftly Changing in His Inner Being, Full of Inner Thoughts

Know that Allah revealed His command within this Lowest Heaven (السماء الدنيا) and settled Adam therein, who is the Singular Human (الإنسان الفرد), the origin of this species. This is referred to in His saying: <<خَلَقَكُمْ مِنْ نَفْسٍ وَاحِدَةٍ>> (He created you from a single soul). However, Allah made him—meaning the human—swiftly changing in his inner being (باطنه) and full of inner thoughts (خواطر), transforming in his inner being at every moment with different transformations, because he is upon the Divine Form (الصورة الإلهية), and He, the Glorified, is "every day in [new] affair" (*kull yawmin fī sha'n*). It is impossible for the Cosmos to remain fixed in one state for two moments. Rather, states and accidents change upon it in every single moment, and these are the Divine Affairs (*al-Shu'ūn*) in which the Real (الحق) is present, for those who know what Allah has said.

The dominion of this only manifests in the inner being of the human. He continuously transforms in every breath into forms called inner thoughts (الخواطر). If these were visible to the eyes, you would see wonders. The fastest of the celestial movements is the movement of this sphere with its star, the Moon. It is the swiftest in traversing the Sphere of the Lunar Mansions (فلك المنازل) compared to the other wandering stars. It occupies one mansion every day, traversing the sphere in twenty-eight days. Thus, the manifestation of effect in the created world was swift due to the speed of the movement. This suited Adam in the swiftness of his inner thoughts, so Allah settled him in this heaven. He placed the souls (*nasam*) of his descendants to his right and left as dark figures, whose forms are seen by the People of Unveiling (أهل الكشف). To his right is *'Illiyyūn* (The Highest), and to his left is the lower realm (*al-Sufl*). Nothing concerning the states of his descendants is hidden from him.

### Indeed, Adam (peace be upon him) Varies in His States According to the Diversity of the Divine Names

Know that this Reality (الحقيقة) that caused him to be called the Singular Human (إنسانا مفردا) exists in every human being, but it was more complete in Adam because he existed without a likeness. Thereafter, likenesses originated from him, manifesting in his form, just as he originated from the Cosmos (العالم) and the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية), manifesting in the form of the Cosmos and the Form of the Real (صورة الحق). Thus, mankind shares certain things, while each individual is distinguished by something unique to him, just as the Cosmos is. By what distinguishes him, the human is called the Singular Human, and by what he shares, he is called the Great Human (الإنسان الكبير). Since Adam was the father of humanity, there was a subtle connection (*raqīqah*) and relation from him to every human. Since his relation to the Cosmos and the Real was like the relation of his descendants to him, he possessed a subtle connection from every form in the Cosmos extending to him to preserve his form, and a subtle connection from every Divine Name extending to him to preserve his rank and his Vicegerency (خلافته). Thus, he varies in his states according to the diversity of the Divine Names and transforms in his existences according to the transformation of the entire Cosmos. He is small in size, subtle in body, and swift in movement.

When he moves, he moves the entire Cosmos and, by that movement, calls forth the orientation (توجه) of the Divine Names upon him, so that they may see what he intended by that movement, and they rule concerning it according to their Realities (حقائقها). There is no sphere smaller than the sphere of the Lowest Heaven, so Allah settled him therein due to this suitability. Because of the smallness of this sphere, it is the fastest in rotation, which suited the swiftness of the inner thoughts in the human. Thus, He settled him therein specifically in his capacity as the Singular Human, not in his capacity as the shared human.

Furthermore, Allah placed one of his descendants in every heaven: Jesus, Joseph, Idris, Aaron, John (Yaḥyā), Moses, and Abraham (peace be upon them). He looks upon them every day in his capacity as their father, and they look upon him in their capacity as inhabitants of specific stations, not in their capacity as his sons. This Singular Human (الإنسان المفرد) confronts the Divine Presence (الحضرة الإلهية) with his very Essence (ذاته). Allah created him, in terms of his shape and limbs, upon six directions that manifested in him. He is in the Cosmos like the point within the circumference. In relation to the Real (الحق), he is like the Inner (الباطن); in relation to the Cosmos, he is like the Outer (الظاهر). In terms of intention (القصد), he is like the First (الأول); in terms of origination (النشء), he is like the Last (الآخر). Thus, he is First by intention and Last by origination, Outer by form and Inner by spirit. Likewise, Allah created him, in terms of his nature (طبيعته) and the form of his body, from four elements. He possesses the quaternary aspect from his nature, as he is the totality of the four elements (الأركان). He originated his body with three dimensions: length, width, and depth. Thus, he resembles the Divine Presence (الحضرة الإلهية) in Essence (ذاتاً), Attributes (صفاتاً), and Acts (أفعالاً). These are three levels (مراتب): the level of his shape, which is the very essence of his directions; the level of his nature; and the level of his body.

Furthermore, Allah gave him a likeness (مثل) and an opposite (ضد), and there is nothing beyond these five. He is distinguished by the five because no number possesses the Name *al-Ḥafīẓ* (The Preserver) except them. They preserve themselves and others by their own essence. This is His saying: <<وَلَا يَؤُودُهُ حِفْظُهُمَا>> (And the preservation of both does not weary Him), where He used the dual form, which corresponds to our statement that they preserve themselves and others. As for his being an opposite, it is in his capacity as one who is incapable, ignorant, deficient, dead, blind, mute, deaf, poor, abased, and non-existent. As for his being a likeness, it is in his manifestation through all the Divine and Cosmic Names. Thus, he is a likeness of the Cosmos (العالم) and a likeness of the Presence (الحضرة). He combines the two likenesses, which is not granted to any other creature. He is Living, Knowing, Willing, Powerful, Hearing, Seeing, Speaking, Mighty, Rich, and possesses all the Divine Names and the Cosmic Names. He has the capacity to embody the character traits of the Names (*al-takhalluq bi al-asmā'*). He has five states by which he confronts everything other than himself, according to how they view him, since he is the Comprehensive Word (الكلمة الجامعة).

Allah granted him such power that in a single glance, he looks upon the two Presences (الحضرتين): he receives from the Real (الحق) and imparts to the Creation (الخلق). Among those who look upon him, some view him in terms of his shape, and he sustains them from that station with specific matters related to shape. Others view him in terms of his nature, and he sustains them from that station with specific matters related to nature, just as the Real sustains him in his shape from His Name *al-Muḥīṭ* (The All-Encompassing), and in his nature from His Life, Knowledge, Will, and Power. Others look upon him in terms of his body, and he sustains them from that station with specific matters related to the body, just as the Real sustains him from His Presence with what manifests in His Essence, Attributes, and Acts. Others look upon him as an equal, in a state of contention, and he sustains them from that station with specific matters related to confrontation, just as the Real sustains him from His Name *al-Ba'īd* (The Distant), and *al-Mu'izz* (The Honorer) if he is abased, or *al-Mudhill* (The Humiliator) if he is mighty. Others look upon him in terms of his being a likeness to Him in rank, for by rank he was a Vicegerent (خليفة), a rank in which he was shared, as He said: <<هُوَ الَّذِي جَعَلَكُمْ خَلَائِفَ فِي الْأَرْضِ>> (It is He who has made you successors [vicegerents] upon the earth), and He said: <<يَا دَاوُودُ إِنَّا جَعَلْنَاكَ خَلِيفَةً فِي الْأَرْضِ>> (O David, indeed We have made you a vicegerent upon the earth). They are the deputies of the Real among His servants. He sustains them from that station with specific matters related to that likeness, just as the Real sustains him from His Form with all His Names. There are no other aspects than these.

### Indeed, Allah Divided His Creation into Wretched and Blessed

Allah divided His creation into wretched (*shaqī*) and blessed (*sa'īd*). He made the dwelling place of His servants two abodes: the abode of Hell (جهنم), which is the abode of every wretched person, and the abode of Gardens (جنان), which is the abode of every blessed person. They were called wretched because they were established in what is difficult for them, which is opposition (المخالفة). They were called blessed because they were established in what is easy for them, which is assistance and conformity (الموافقة). Whoever is with Allah, conforming to Allah's Will concerning himself and His creation, nothing that occurs in the Cosmos is difficult for him. It is related concerning Rābi'ah (may Allah be pleased with her) that the corner of a wall struck her head and drew blood, but she did not turn around. When asked about it, she said, "My preoccupation with conforming to His Will in what occurred distracted me from feeling what you see of the present state." What happened was not difficult for her; had it been difficult, she would have suffered torment from it within herself.

The wretched have no torment except from themselves, because they were established in the station of objection and rationalization concerning Allah's Acts among His servants: "Why was it thus? If it had been otherwise, it would have been better and more fitting." They contended with Lordship (الربوبية) and opposed Allah and His Messenger. Their wretchedness (*shaqā'*) is their opposition (*shiqāq*). Thus, Hell is the abode of the wretched by their entering it in this state. But when the duration becomes long for them, the state changes, because a long duration has a ruling, based on His saying: <<فَطَالَ عَلَيْهِمُ الْأَمَدُ فَقَسَتْ قُلُوبُهُمْ>> (But the duration seemed long to them, and their hearts hardened). When the duration becomes long for the wretched, and they realize that their objection is not beneficial, they say, "Conformity is better." Their forms are thus transformed, and this transformation affects the ruling, so the opposition ceases, and the torment is lifted from their inner beings. They find rest in their abode and experience a pleasure therein that only Allah knows, because they chose what Allah chose for them. They realize then that their torment was only from themselves. They praise Allah in every state, and this leads them to praise Allah, the Bestower of Grace and Favor.

### Degrees of the Gardens and Levels of the Fire

Furthermore, this Singular Human (الإنسان المفرد), Adam, and every human established in his unique aspect, has another perspective on the stations of the blessed, which are defined by the Starry Sphere (الفلك المكوكب). These are the stations of the Gardens and the stations of the Fire. Paradise has one hundred degrees (درجة), and the Fire has one hundred levels (درك), corresponding to the number of the Divine Names. By the ruling of shared participation, ninety-nine Names are attained by every human in his capacity as sharing with others. The Name that completes the hundred is the Singular of the Unseen (وتر الغيب), just as the ninety-nine are the Singular of the Witnessed (وتر الشهادة), because Allah is Singular (*Witr*) and loves the Singular. The Name that completes the hundred is Singular. Through it, the Real (الحق) performs a Theophany (يتجلى) to the Singular Human when he is aligned with the matter by which he is called the Singular Human. When he is aligned with this Singular Name, his stations are twenty-eight, because the letters of his self (*nafs*) are twenty-eight letters. From these letters, signs indicating the Real manifested in the station of Gathering (الجمع) and Existence (الوجود), totaling 5,838 signs. All of these are stations within these stations.

### Read and Ascend

It will be said to the reciter of the Quran on the Day of Resurrection: "Read and ascend (اقرأ وارق), for your station is at the last verse you recite." For this reason, Abū Yazīd was praised for not dying until he had memorized the entire Quran. It is incumbent upon the reciter of the Quran, if he is not among the People of Unveiling (أهل الكشف) or the People of Divine Instruction (التعليم الإلهي), to research and ask the scholars of external knowledge (*'ulamā' al-rusūm*) what they have established or seen to have been Quran whose wording was abrogated (*nuskha lafẓuhu*) from this Uthmanic codex. He should not worry if they tell him such-and-such, whether the path to that knowledge is sound or unsound. He should memorize it, for by doing so, he increases his degrees. The codices have differed. This benefits him and does not harm him, for what we have in our hands is undoubtedly Quran, yet we know that much of it has been omitted. If the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) had been the one to compile it, we would have stopped at it and said, "This alone is what we recite on the Day of Resurrection when the reciter of the Quran is told, 'Read and ascend.'" Caution lies in what we have stated, but I do not mean that he should pray with it; rather, he should memorize it specifically, as it is not transmitted by continuous chains (*mutawātir*) like the current text. None of the Companions disputed that the Uthmanic codex is Quran.

When a human being attains, through his unique aspect, a station among these stations, that station grants him the Reality (حقيقة) of what it is, concerning the manifest matters that Allah established for it in the acts of the servants—in their movements, stillness, and dispositions. What prevented me from specifying these matters is only what might occur to weak hearts and the misplacement of wisdom, for those who preserve the secrets of Allah are few. When the Singular Human (الإنسان المفرد) fulfills the knowledge of these matters, enters the eight Gardens, sees the White Dune, witnesses the degrees of people in the Vision (الرؤية), distinguishes their ranks and stations therein, and observes the formations of the Gardens and the subtle connections (*raqā'iq*) extending to them from the Sphere of the Zodiacal Signs, he knows that Allah has secrets in His creation. Allah desired to make him know the effects of this, so he ascended with his self to this Sphere and circled with it one revolution for each sign until he completed twelve revolutions. By his dwelling in each revolution, he observed the effect it imparts in the Gardens of Bliss, in Hell, in the world of this life (عالم الدنيا), in the Isthmus (البرزخ), on the Day of Resurrection, and in the states of the accidental beings in the Cosmos, specifically those related to the human body, his spirit, and the generated entities. We may refer to some of these secrets scattered throughout this book in its various mansions, if Allah wills.

### Every One of These Divine Names Has a Kingly Spirituality That Preserves It and Sustains It

All the Divine Names specific to this human being, described by this attribute, by which he descends into these stations, are known and enumerated. They are: *al-Rafī' al-Darajāt* (The Exalter of Ranks), *al-Jāmi'* (The Gatherer), *al-Laṭīf* (The Subtle), *al-Qawī* (The Strong), *al-Mudhill* (The Humiliator), *Razzāq* (The Provider), *Azīz* (The Mighty), *Mumīt* (The Giver of Death), *Muḥyī* (The Giver of Life), *Ḥayy* (The Living), *Qābiḍ* (The Withholder), *Mubīn* (The Manifest), *Muḥṣī* (The Reckoner), *Muṣawwir* (The Fashioner), *Nūr* (The Light), *Qāhir* (The Dominant), *'Alīm* (The All-Knowing), *Rabb* (The Lord), *Muqaddir* (The Determiner), *Ghanī* (The Rich), *Shakūr* (The Appreciative), *Muḥīṭ* (The All-Encompassing), *Ḥakīm* (The Wise), *Ẓāhir* (The Outer), *Bāṭin* (The Inner), *Bā'ith* (The Resurrector), and *Badī'* (The Originator).

Every one of these Names has a kingly spirituality (روحانية ملك) that preserves it and sustains it. These spiritualities have forms in the human soul (النفس الإنساني) called letters (حروف) in the points of articulation when spoken, and in the script when written. Their forms differ in writing but do not differ in numerical value. These spiritual angels (الملائكة الروحانيات) are named in the World of Spirits (عالم الأرواح) by the names of these letters. Let us mention them according to the order of their points of articulation so that their rank may be known. The first is the Angel of *Hā'* (ه), then *Hamzah* (ء), the Angel of undotted *'Ayn* (ع), the Angel of undotted *Ḥā'* (ح), the Angel of dotted *Ghāyn* (غ), the Angel of dotted *Khā'* (خ), the Angel of *Qāf* (ق)—which is a mighty angel, and I have seen those who met with him—the Angel of *Kāf* (ك), the Angel of *Jīm* (ج), the Angel of dotted *Shīn* (ش), the Angel of *Yā'* (ي), the Angel of dotted *Ḍād* (ض), the Angel of *Lām* (ل), the Angel of *Nūn* (ن), the Angel of *Rā'* (ر), the Angel of undotted *Ṭā'* (ط), the Angel of undotted *Dāl* (د), the Angel of dotted *Tā'* (ت) with two dots above it, the Angel of *Zāy* (ز), the Angel of undotted *Sīn* (س), the Angel of undotted *Ṣād* (ص), the Angel of dotted *Ẓā'* (ظ), the Angel of dotted *Thā'* (ث) with three dots, the Angel of dotted *Dhāl* (ذ), the Angel of *Fā'* (ف), the Angel of *Bā'* (ب), the Angel of *Mīm* (م), and the Angel of *Wāw* (و).

These angels are the spirits (أرواح) of these letters, and these letters are the bodies (أجساد) of those angels, both in utterance and in script, regardless of the pen used. The letters act through these spirits, not through their essences—meaning their forms perceptible to hearing and sight, and conceived in the Imagination (الخيال). One should not imagine that the letters act through their forms; rather, they act through their spirits. Every letter has a glorification (*tasbīḥ*), magnification (*tamjīd*), declaration of oneness (*tahlīl*), exaltation (*takbīr*), and praise (*taḥmīd*), by all of which it magnifies its Creator and its Manifestation (مظهره). Its spirituality (روحانيته) never leaves it. By these Names, these angels are called in the heavens, and there is not one of them who has not benefited me.

Likewise, these stars that you see are merely forms that have kingly spirits (أرواح ملكية) managing them, just as the human form has a spirit. The human acts through his spirit; similarly, the star and the letter—were it not for the spirit, no act would manifest from them. For Allah, the Glorified, does not fashion a perceptible form in Existence (الوجود) by the hand of anyone—be it a human or the wind when it blows, creating shapes in everything it affects—even the snake or worm walking in the sand, leaving a path. That path is a form created by Allah through the movement of that worm or other creature. Allah breathes into it a spirit (روحاً) from His command, and that form, with its shape and spirit, continuously glorifies Him until it vanishes, and its spirit transfers to the Isthmus (البرزخ). This is His saying: <<كُلُّ مَنْ عَلَيْهَا فَانٍ>> (Everyone upon the earth will perish). Likewise, aerial and aquatic forms—were it not for their spirits, no effect would manifest from them, neither in their isolation nor in their composition.

Whenever someone creates a form, and it ceases to exist, vanishes, and its spirit transfers to the Isthmus, its spirit—which is that angel—glorifies and praises Allah. That merit returns to the one who brought that form into existence, whose spirit was this angel. Only the People of Unveiling (أهل الكشف) and Witnessing (الوجود) among the People of Allah (أهل الله) know the Realities of things. For this reason, Allah alerted the hearts of the heedless so that they might pay attention to the disconnected letters (الحروف المقطعة) at the beginning of the Surahs, for they are the forms and names of angels. When the reciter pronounces them, it is like calling out to them, and they answer him. The reciter says *Alif Lām Mīm*, and these three angels reply, "What are you saying?" The reciter then recites what follows these letters. If it is good, they say, "You have spoken the truth." They say, "This is a true believer; he spoke the truth and informed of the truth," and they seek forgiveness for him.

They are fourteen angels: *Alif, Lām, Mīm, Ṣād, Rā', Kāf, Hā', Yā', 'Ayn, Ṭā', Sīn, Ḥā', Qāf, Nūn*. They appeared in different stations of the Quran. In some stations, one appeared, such as *Qāf* (ق) and *Nūn*. In some stations, two appeared, such as *Ṭā' Sīn* (طس), *Yā' Sīn* (يس), and *Ḥā' Mīm* (حم)—which are seven, meaning the *Ḥawāmīm*—and *Ṭā' Hā* (طه). In some stations, three appeared: *Alif Lām Mīm* (in Al-Baqarah and Āl 'Imrān), *Alif Lām Rā'* (in Yūnus, Hūd, Yūsuf, Ibrāhīm, and Al-Ḥijr), and *Ṭā' Sīn Mīm* (in Al-Shu'arā', Al-Qaṣaṣ, Al-'Ankabūt, Luqmān, Al-Rūm, and Al-Sajdah). Among them are stations where four appeared: *Alif Lām Mīm Ṣād* (in Al-A'rāf) and *Alif Lām Mīm Rā'* (in Al-Ra'd). And stations where five appeared: *Kāf Hā' Yā' 'Ayn Ṣād* (in Maryam) and *Ḥā' Mīm 'Ayn Sīn Qāf* (in Al-Shūrā). The total number of Surahs is twenty-eight, exactly the number of the lunar mansions of the heaven. Some of these letters are repeated in the mansions, and some are not. Their forms, including repetitions, total seventy-nine angels. In the hand of every angel is a branch of faith, for "Faith has seventy-odd branches, the highest of which is *Lā ilāha illā Allāh* (There is no god but Allah), and the lowest is removing harm from the road."

The *bid’* (البضع) is from one to nine, and it has fulfilled the limit of the *bid’*. Whoever looks into these letters [الحرف] through this door that has been opened for him will see wonders. These angelic spirits [الأرواح الملكية], whose bodies are these letters, will be under his command. By means of the branches of faith [شعب الايمان] that are in their hands, they sustain him and preserve his faith. All of this is from the Breath of the All-Merciful [النفس الرحماني] by which Allah relieves His creation.

Know that these fourteen letters found at the beginning of the Surahs—each letter has an outward aspect, which is its form [صورته], and an inward aspect, which is its spirit [روحه]. For every letter, there is a night of the month, meaning the month known by the moon. When the moon travels and completes fourteen mansions [منزلة] in its course, it grants to each of these letters, in terms of their forms, two powers: one from its own Essence [ذاته] and one from its light [نوره]. And it grants it two other powers: one from the mansion in which it descends, and one from the zodiacal sign [البرج] corresponding to that mansion, but only to the extent that the mansion holds sway over the sign. Thus, that letter acquires four powers, and its operation becomes stronger than the operation of any single possessor of these powers. Its operation is effective in the manifestation of the essences [أعيان] of the desired object.

When the moon begins to wane, it begins to enter the spirituality [روحانية] of these letters until it completes them with the full complement of the mansions, which are twenty-eight. The powers are the same as the previous powers, except that the operation is different. The manifest operation is for benefits, and the second operation is for repelling harms.

In the power of the moon’s light [النور القمري] for this letter, there are degrees [مراتب] according to the mansion and the sign in which the sun is located, and the moon’s conjunctions [اتصالات] with the mansion—its sextile, quartile, trine, opposition, and conjunction. Thus, the rulings [الأحكام] vary according to these differences. This is what the letter receives from the power of the lunar light. Therefore, working with the letters requires precise knowledge [علم دقيق]. These powers accrue to the letter from the moon’s course. We have already mentioned the letter corresponding to each mansion.

As for *Lam-Alif* (لام ألف), its level [مرتبته] is the level of the Jawzahar (the Dragon’s Head and Tail), and it is one of the compound letters. They assigned it the status of a single letter to complete the genesis of the letters. This letter corresponds to the night of concealment (*laylat al-sirar*) for the moon. If the moon eclipses the sun, that is the most fortunate and powerful state for working with *Lam-Alif*. If it does not eclipse it, its operation is weakened to the extent that it falls short of that state. Likewise, the moon’s conjunctions with the five planets have an effect on the letter, according to the five rulings [الأحكام الخمسة] that result from its conjunction with that planet, just as was the case with the sun.

The practitioner must also consider the moon’s exaltation [شرف], its fall [هبوطه], its being void of course [خالي السير], its being far from light, its being with the Head (Rahu), and its being with the Tail (Ketu). For Allah did not appoint the moon mansions <<حَتَّى عَادَ كَالْعُرْجُونِ الْقَدِيمِ>> (until it returns like the old date stalk) and single it out for mention in vain. Rather, this is due to a Divine Wisdom [حكمة إلهية] known only to him who has been granted Wisdom, which is the abundant Divine Good [الخير الكثير الإلهي]. The remaining six planets also have mansions in the reality of the matter (*fi nafs al-amr*), but they were not singled out for mention. Since the moon was included in the mention, it possesses a Divine Power [القوة الإلهية], honor in vicegerency (*wilaya*), and Divine Ruling [الحكم الإلهي] that others do not. For it was mentioned only through the letters, and through them the Remembrance (the Quran) descended to us. Thus, its relation to the letters is more complete than the relation of others. Therefore, its sustenance (*imdad*) to the letters is twofold: a sustenance of reward and gratitude, because through them it achieved mention; and a natural sustenance, like the sustenance the other six planets provide to these letters.

We only mentioned what pertains specifically to the moon, excluding the other six, because we are in the lowest heaven (*sama’ al-dunya*), which is the moon’s station. On the night of concealment (*laylat al-sirar*), it is cold and moist, and on the night of the full moon (*laylat al-ibdar*), it is hot and moist due to the light it contains. Thus, it is watery and airy. In between these states, it varies according to the light it holds, for light possesses honor. Since fire and light combine in burning and in the strength of action upon the remaining elements [العناصر], this is why Iblis boasted over Adam and showed arrogance toward him. Fire does not accept cooling, unlike the other elements [الأركان]. Air can be heated, as can water and earth. Thus, fire has an effect on the elements themselves, while none of them has an effect on fire. Likewise, water has an effect on air and earth: it cools the air and increases its moisture, and it moistens the earth and increases its coldness. Air and earth have no effect on these two elements. Therefore, the strongest of the elements is fire, followed by water. Heat belongs to fire, and coldness to water. For this reason, He made them active agents, and the other two—the moisture of air and the dryness of earth—passive. Glory be to the All-Aware, the All-Knowing, the Creator, the Arranger and Determiner of all affairs. There is no god but He, the Almighty, the Wise.

On the night I recorded this chapter—the fourth night of the month of Rabi’ al-Akhir in the year 627 AH, corresponding to the night of Wednesday, the twentieth of February—I saw in a spiritual vision (*al-waqi’a*) the outward and inward aspects of the Divine Identity [الهوية الإلهية] with a verified witnessing [شهود محققا], something I had never seen before in any of our spiritual stations [مشاهدنا]. From witnessing this, I gained knowledge, delight, and joy that none can know except one who has tasted it. How excellent was that vision! <<لَيْسَ لِوَقْعَتِهَا كَاذِبَةٌ خَافِضَةٌ رَافِعَةٌ>> (There is no denial of its occurrence, lowering [some], raising [others]). Its form is illustrated in the margin as it appeared, so whoever draws it should not alter it. The form is a white light on a red carpet, which also has light, in four layers of form. And its spirit [روحها] is also on that carpet, on the other side, in four layers. Thus, the totality of the Identity [الهوية] is eight, in two different sides of a single carpet. The edges of the carpet are neither the carpet itself nor other than the carpet. I have never seen, known, imagined, or had cross my heart a form like what I saw in this Identity. Furthermore, it possesses a subtle movement within its Essence [ذاتها], which I see and know, without transition, change of state, or attribute.

(Chapter Twenty-Eight) Concerning the Divine Name *Al-Qabid* (The Restrainer)

And its orientation [توجهه] toward bringing into existence what appears in the Aether [الأثير]—namely, comets (those with tails) and combustions—and the existence of the letter *Ta* (ت) with two dots above it among the letters. It corresponds to the mansion of *al-Qalb* (the Heart). The Aether is the element [ركن] of Fire.

The existence of these elements precedes the existence of these spheres [الأفلاك], in terms of what you call heavens, but not in terms of what they are as spheres. It is connected to the Air, and Air is hot and moist. Due to the moisture in the Air, when it connects with this Aether, the Aether affects it, causing ignition in some moist parts of the Air. Thus, comets (stars with tails) appear. Due to their rapid propulsion, those tails become visible to the eye.

### [The Devils Ascend to the Lowest Heaven to Steal Hearing]

If you wish to verify this, look at the sparks of fire when the air strikes the fire with a fan or otherwise; sparks fly out like threads to the eye, and then they extinguish. These stars are similar. And Allah made them, from the time of the Prophet’s mission, <<رُجُومًا لِلشَّيَاطِينِ>> (missiles for the devils). For the devils, who are the disbelievers among the Jinn, ascend to the lowest heaven [السماء الدنيا] to steal hearing [يسترقون السمع]—that is, what the angels in heaven say and discuss concerning what Allah has revealed therein. If the devil attempts to pass, Allah sends upon him <<شِهَابًا رَصَدًا ثَاقِبًا>> (a piercing, observing flame). This is why it gives off that great light you see, and that light remains as a path in its wake.

I once saw its path, where its light remained for an hour or more than an hour, while I was circumambulating the Kaaba. I and a group of circumambulators saw it, and people were astonished by that. We never saw a night with more comets than that one, throughout the entire night until morning. Due to their abundance and overlapping, like the overlapping of fire sparks, those stars obstructed our vision of the other stars. We said, "This must be due to a great matter." A little later, news reached us that a major event had occurred in Yemen at the very time we saw this: a wind brought them a great quantity of dust resembling tutty (zinc oxide), covering their land and rising above the ground up to the knees. People were afraid, and the atmosphere darkened over them so much that they walked in the streets during the day with lamps. The accumulation of clouds intervened between them and the light of the sun. They heard a tremendous roaring sound in the sea near Zabid. This was in the year 600 AH or 599 AH—the doubt is mine, as I did not record it when I saw it, and I only recorded it in this place in the year 627 AH, which is why I am uncertain due to the passage of time. However, it is well known among the elite and the common people of the Hijaz and Yemen.

We saw many wonders in that year. In that same year, a plague struck Ta’if until no resident remained there. It afflicted them from the beginning of Rajab until the beginning of Ramadan in the year 599 AH, according to verification. The plague that descended upon them was such that if its sign appeared on their bodies, they would not survive more than five days before perishing. Whoever survived five days did not perish. Mecca became filled with the people of Ta’if, and their homes remained open, their goods and livestock in their pastures. During that period, if a stranger passed through their land and took any of their food, goods, or livestock—since there was no guardian to protect it—he was immediately afflicted by the plague. But if he passed through without taking anything, he was safe. Thus, Allah protected their wealth during that period for those who remained and for their heirs. They repented and inherited the daughters that year, and the conflicts that had been among them ceased. But when Allah saved them from that and removed it, and security was restored to them, they returned to their former state of turning away [from God].

These comets do not occur *in* the Aether [الأثير]; rather, the Aether causes them to occur *in* the Air, igniting it. Therefore, it is truly burning air, not flaming air—this is the Aether. It is like thunderbolts [الصواعق], which are burning airs without a flame. They affect anything they pass by. Nothing occurs in this element [ركن] other than what we have mentioned, except that, in the reality of the matter (*fi nafs al-amr*), it is a noble angel [ملك كريم] that has a specific glorification (*tasbih*) and a powerful dominion (*sultan*).

The lowest heaven is extremely cold. Were it not that Allah placed this fire between the Air and the Heaven to separate us from the coldness of this heaven, no animal, plant, or mineral would exist on Earth due to the intensity of the cold. Thus, Allah heated the world of Earth, Water, and Air by means of the rays that the stars cast toward the Earth, mediated by this Aether. The world was heated, and life flowed through it. This is by the decree of the Almighty, the All-Knowing. There is no god but He, the Lord and Sovereign of everything.

(Chapter Twenty-Nine) Concerning the Divine Name *Al-Hayy* (The Living)

And its orientation [توجهه] toward bringing into existence what appears in the element of Air [ركن الهواء]. It corresponds to the letter *Zay* (ز) among the letters, and the mansion of *al-Shawla*. Allah the Exalted said: <<فَسَخَّرْنَا لَهُ الرِّيحَ تَجْرِي بِأَمْرِهِ رُخَاءً حَيْثُ أَصَابَ>> (So We subjected to him the wind, running by his command, gently, wherever he directed). Thus, He made it commanded, informing us that it possesses intellect. Air is not called *rih* (wind) unless it moves and undulates. If its movement is intense, it is a violent wind (*za'za'*); if it is not intense, it is gentle (*rukha’*), meaning a soft wind. The wind possesses a spirit [روح] and intellect, like all other bodies in the cosmos [العالم]. Its blowing is its glorification (*tasbih*). By it, ships sail, lamps are extinguished, fires are ignited, waters and trees are moved, seas undulate, the earth is shaken, branches are played with, and clouds are driven.

### [The Human is the Strongest Existent Due to the Strength of the Form Upon Which He Was Created]

It is an element stronger than Water, and Water is stronger than Fire, and Fire is stronger than Iron, and Iron is stronger than Mountains, and Mountains are stronger than Earth. And there is nothing stronger than Air except the Human [الإنسان], in that he is able to suppress his lower desire (*hawa*) with the intellect [عقله] that Allah created within him. Thus, his intellect manifests in its ruling over his desire. For due to the strength of the form [الصورة] upon which he was created, leadership (*ri’asa*) is intrinsic to him; and due to his being contingent (*mumkin*), poverty and lowliness (*dhilla*) are intrinsic to him. If his poverty overcomes his leadership, and he manifests through his servitude (*‘ubudiyya*), and the effect of the Lordship (*rububiyya*) inherent in his form does not appear, then there is no creature stronger than him.

And thus the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, informed us, according to what was narrated to us by Muhammad ibn Qasim ibn Abd al-Rahman ibn Abd al-Karim al-Tamimi al-Fasi, who said: Umar ibn Abd al-Majid al-Miyanishi narrated to us, who said: Abd al-Malik ibn Qasim al-Harawi narrated to us, who said: Mahmud ibn al-Qasim al-Azdi narrated to us, who said: Abd al-Jabbar ibn Muhammad al-Jarahi narrated to us, who said: Muhammad ibn Ahmad al-Mahbubi narrated to us, who said: Abu Isa Muhammad ibn Isa ibn Sawra al-Tirmidhi narrated to us, who said: Muhammad ibn Bashshar narrated to us, who said: Yazid ibn Harun narrated to us, who said: Al-Awwam ibn Hawshab narrated to us, from Sulayman ibn Abi Sulayman, from Anas ibn Malik, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, who said: "When Allah created the Earth, it began to shake. So He created the mountains and fixed them upon it, and it became stable. The angels were astonished by the strength of the mountains and said, 'O Lord, is there anything in Your creation stronger than the mountains?' He said, 'Yes, Iron.' They said, 'O Lord, is there anything in Your creation stronger than Iron?' He said, 'Yes, Fire.' They said, 'O Lord, is there anything in Your creation stronger than Fire?' He said, 'Yes, Water.' They said, 'O Lord, is there anything in Your creation stronger than Water?' He said, 'Yes, Wind.' They said, 'O Lord, is there anything in Your creation stronger than Wind?' He said, 'The son of Adam who gives charity with his right hand, concealing it from his left.'"

This is a rare hadith. In this hadith is the knowledge of the human limbs concerning things. For this reason, Allah the Exalted described them as bearing witness on the Day of Resurrection, saying: <<يَوْمَ تَشْهَدُ عَلَيْهِمْ أَلْسِنَتُهُمْ وَأَيْدِيهِمْ وَأَرْجُلُهُمْ بِمَا كَانُوا يَعْمَلُونَ>> (On the Day when their tongues, their hands, and their feet will bear witness against them as to what they used to do).

Air is a mighty existent [موجود عظيم], and it is the element closest in relation to the Breath of the All-Merciful [نفس الرحمن]. Thus, it is most deserving of this chapter. Air is the very breath of the Great World [العالم الكبير] and its life. It possesses power and capability. It is the necessary cause for the existence of melodies [النغمات] by moving instruments, the movements of the spheres [الأفلاك], the branches of trees, and the intersection of sounds. Natural hearing affects the spirits [الأرواح], causing rapture (*hayaman*), intoxication (*sukr*), and delight (*tarab*) within them. When Air moves, it is the strongest of the natural influences on bodies and spirits. Allah has made this element the origin of life for the natural world, just as He made Water the origin of natural forms. The form of Air is from Water, and the spirit of Water is from Air. If the Air were to cease moving, every breather would perish, and everything in the cosmos breathes, for the origin is the Breath of the All-Merciful [نفس الرحمن].

Allah made it subtle so that it might readily accept rapid movement, for the breathing cosmos requires much breath at one time and little breath at another. Do you not see that in summer, when a person’s body is hot, he moves the air with a fan to cool the heat he feels, due to the coolness of Water present in the Air by virtue of its form? Although Air has a subtle movement, it is not sufficient for the overheated person. Similarly, when the Air becomes excessive to the point of harming a person, he seeks shelter from it, because it is not within the power of the animal to diminish the Air, unless the human is the one initiating the air’s movement; in that case, he can diminish it by weakening the movement of the cause by which he initiated it. But if the cause is outside human control, he cannot diminish it. Air is what drives the spirits [الأرواح] to the nostrils, whether pleasant or foul. In it, the forms of letters and words appear. Were it not for the Air, no speaker would speak, and no sounder would sound.

### [That the Creator’s Knowledge of the Cosmos is His Knowledge of Himself]

Since the Creator is a Speaker and described Himself with Speech, He also described Himself as having a Breath (*nafs*), even though <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (there is nothing like Him). However, He alerted His Gnostic servants [عباده العارفين] that His Knowledge of the cosmos is His Knowledge of Himself. And He described Himself, glory be to Him, as breathing the spirits [الأرواح] and thus giving life to the perfected forms. He used the term *nafkh* (breathing/blowing), which indicates *nafs* (breath). Thus, the life of the cosmos is through the Divine Breath (*al-nafkh al-ilahi*) in the sense that He has a Breath. Therefore, among the forms of the cosmos, none is more deserving of this life than the Air, for it is what emerged in the form of the Breath of the All-Merciful [النفس الرحماني], by which Allah relieves His servants of the distress and grief caused by Nature.

After informing you of the status of Air in the cosmos, let us mention what occurs within it. Among what occurs are the forms of the embryo in intercourse and the fruit in pollination. Allah the Exalted said: <<وَأَرْسَلْنَا الرِّيَاحَ لَوَاقِحَ>> (And We sent the winds as fertilizers). This is known by observation in the pollination of fruits. The Air fertilizes by carrying masculine scents. The barren wind is that which is not fertilizing. Fertilizing winds are not exclusive to fruit; rather, they are every wind that gives forms, and the barren wind is every wind that removes forms. The air that ignites fire is among the fertilizing winds, and the wind that extinguishes lamps is among the barren winds. Although they are one in essence, they are not one to those who witness the renewal of the cosmos in every breath, for they are in confusion regarding a new creation. The origin of this in Divine Knowledge [العلم الإلهي] is that the fertilizing winds are what Lordship (*Rububiyya*) grants in the existence of the essences [أعيان] of the creatures ruled, and the barren winds are the splendors of the Face [سبحات الوجه] that remove the essences of the existent things from His creation.

Among what is found in the Air are hail, snow, and ice, when the coldness of Water overcomes it. Hail takes its form from its roundness, and ice from the dryness imparted by the coldness of Earth. Snow is less dry than ice. Rain comes from its moisture and the moisture that Water adds to it, increasing its quantity. In this Air, in the mountains whose matter Allah mentioned in His saying: <<وَيُنَزِّلُ مِنَ السَّمَاءِ مِنْ جِبَالٍ فِيهَا مِنْ بَرَدٍ>> (And He sends down from the sky, from mountains therein, hail). We have explained this earlier in this book. Moisture prevails in the Air due to the moisture added by Water, and Fire imparts heat that increases the quantity of the Air’s heat. This causes putrefaction (*ta’affin*) in the atmosphere within these mountains, because these elements are compounded from the four natural realities [الحقائق الطبيعية], each element being one of them. This is the reason they accept the forms of existent things within them; otherwise, the generated things (*al-muwalladat*) would not be accepted.

When putrefaction occurs, Allah forms aerial, atmospheric animals [حيوانات هوائية جوية] within that putrefaction, in the forms of white snakes and spherical animals. We have seen the spherical ones, and we have seen those who saw the white snakes. We have come across mention of them in some books on weather phenomena (*anwa’*). The falcons of Valencia, when they soar high in the atmosphere at certain times and encounter one of these, descend with it in sight of their owners. Among those who saw this was my father, when a falcon descended with one from the atmosphere during the time of Sultan Muhammad ibn Sa’d, the ruler of Eastern Al-Andalus. This spherical type that we witnessed from that formation is called the Salamander (*al-Shalamandar*) in Al-Andalus. It mostly descends into braziers (*kawaneen*) with the rain. It possesses properties if licked by the tongue, but the knowledge of those properties has escaped me at this moment. It is tested and known among us.

Among what occurs in this element, adjacent to the element of Fire, are thunderbolts [الصواعق], which are burning air, and lightning [البروق], which is flaming air caused by intense movement, and thunder [الرعود], which is the blowing of the air that cracks the bottom of the clouds when they accumulate. This is a glorification (*tasbih*), for every sound in the cosmos is a glorification of Allah the Exalted, even the sound of an ugly word—it is ugly, yet it is a glorification in a way known to the People of Allah [أهل الله] through their spiritual tastes (*adhwaq*), for those who understand from Allah. This angel [ملك] called Thunder is created from Air, just as we are created from Water. That sound we call thunder is the glorification of that angel. At that moment, Allah brings it into existence, so its essence is its very sound, and it vanishes just as lightning and comets vanish. These are the occurrences of this element in the elemental world [العالم العنصري]. It corresponds to the letter *Zay* (ز), which is one of the sibilant letters (*huruf al-safir*), making it suitable, because sibilance is air with intensity and constriction. It corresponds to *al-Shawla*, which is hot. Understand this.

(Chapter Thirty) Concerning the Divine Name *Al-Muhyi* (The Giver of Life)

And its orientation [توجهه] toward bringing into existence what appears in the element of Water [ركن الماء]. It corresponds to the undotted letter *Sin* (س) among the letters, and the appointed mansion of *al-Na’a’im*. Allah the Exalted said: <<وَجَعَلْنَا مِنَ الْمَاءِ كُلَّ شَيْءٍ حَيٍّ>> (And We made from water every living thing). And the Exalted said: <<وَيُنَزِّلُ عَلَيْكُمْ مِنَ السَّمَاءِ مَاءً لِّيُطَهِّرَكُم بِهِ وَيُذْهِبَ عَنكُمْ رِجْزَ الشَّيْطَانِ وَلِيَرْبِطَ عَلَىٰ قُلُوبِكُمْ وَيُثَبِّتَ بِهِ الْأَقْدَامَ>> (And He sends down upon you from the sky water to purify you thereby and remove from you the defilement [rijz] of Satan and to strengthen your hearts and make firm thereby your feet). The pronoun *bihi* (thereby) referring to the feet is directed back to the rain.

### [What is Meant by *Rijz* (Defilement)]

The word *rijz* (رجس) with the letter *sin* (س) means filth according to the reciters. Here, it means spiritual filth, because it is attributed to Satan, indicating only the doubts (*shubah*), ignorances, and matters of skepticism that he casts to defile the locus of the heart. Allah removes that by means of the scientific life [الحياة العلمية] contained in the descending water, through proofs and Unveiling [الكشف]. When that doubtful filth is removed by this water sent down from Allah, the filth of ignorance vanishes, and the veil is lifted from the heart. It then looks with its own eye upon the dominion (*malakut*) of the heavens and the earth. Thus, it binds its essence to what Knowledge has granted it, knowing what is intended for it in every breath and time. It deals with it according to the revealed Knowledge that manifested through that water, whose descent in the outward realm He made a sign of His action in the inward realm. One of its applications was facing enemies. What he witnessed and what bound his heart to it led to his foot being firm on the day of battle when meeting enemies, so they did not turn their backs in retreat. And Allah sent down His victory, which is the firming of the feet.

This is the Divine Power [القوة الإلهية] that Allah granted to Water, raising it to the status of the angels, indeed, more complete than the angels. We said "indeed, more complete" because Allah made Water the cause for the firming of the feet of the believing strivers (*mujahidin*), saying: <<وَيُثَبِّتَ بِهِ الْأَقْدَامَ>> (and make firm thereby your feet). Thus, He assigned it the status of an assistant in what He wills. Regarding the angels, He said: <<إِذْ يُوحِي رَبُّكَ إِلَى الْمَلَائِكَةِ أَنِّي مَعَكُمْ>> (When your Lord revealed to the angels, "Indeed, I am with you"). Knowing their weakness, He informed them that Allah is with them by virtue of His I-ness (*Aniyya*) so that their courage might be strengthened in what they cast into the hearts of the believing strivers: that they should stand firm, endure the enemy, and not flee. This is from the angelic inspirations (*lammat al-mala’ika*). Then He said to them: <<فَثَبِّتُوا الَّذِينَ آمَنُوا>> (So make firm those who have believed)—meaning, place in their hearts the resolve to stand firm. Then He assisted them, saying: <<سَأُلْقِي فِي قُلُوبِ الَّذِينَ كَفَرُوا الرُّعْبَ>> (I will cast terror into the hearts of those who disbelieve). He informed them of this so that they might cast this word into the souls of the strivers, for it is part of the Revelation (*wahy*). The striver then finds that casting within himself, which is the angel’s revelation in his inspiration.

### [Water is from the River of Natural Life that is Above the Elements]

Look at the difference between the level [مرتبة] of Water and the level of these angels. Although Water is from the angels, it is an elemental angel [ملك عنصري]. Its origin in the element is from the River of Natural Life [نهر الحياة الطبيعية] that is above the elements. This is the river in which Gabriel immerses himself once every day, and in which the people of the Fire immerse themselves when they exit it through intercession. This elemental water is from that Water which is the River of Life. And these angels who strengthen the hearts of the strivers, make them firm, and reveal to them the saying: <<سَنُلْقِي فِي قُلُوبِ الَّذِينَ كَفَرُوا الرُّعْبَ>> (We will cast terror into the hearts of those who disbelieve)—they are the angels who enter the Frequented House (*al-Bayt al-Ma’mur*) in the seventh heaven, created from the drops of the water of the River of Life when the Trustworthy Spirit (Gabriel) shakes himself after his immersion. For this reason, Allah coupled the angels with the strivers in firming them, along with the descending Water, so that we may make firm the feet thereby. In this, Allah has clarified the level of Water among the levels of the angels, so that the knowing servants of Allah may understand it. <<وَمَا يَعْقِلُهَا إِلَّا الْعَالِمُونَ>> (And none will understand them except those who have knowledge).

Allah made from water every living thing. This element is what grants forms throughout the cosmos, and its life is in its movements. Furthermore, Allah made this element salty due to the benefits it holds for the cosmos. By means of its saltiness, it purifies the atmosphere from the heaviness and putrefaction that occur in it from the vapors of the Earth and the breaths of the cosmos. This is because the Earth, by its nature, does not cause putrefaction, as it is cold and dry. Accidental moistures occur in it from Water and increase. When they increase, the rays of the stars, such as the sun and others, heat them by passing through the Aether, and then by the movements of compressed Air in the Earth’s atmosphere. Movement is a necessary cause for the appearance of heat, which is evident in the hot springs in sulfurous lands. When the quantity of heat multiplies upon these moistures, it causes them to ascend high as vapor. From there, putrefaction occurs in the atmosphere. The saltiness in the sea removes that putrefaction, purifying the atmosphere. This is from Allah’s mercy toward His creation, and only the knowledgeable among His servants perceive it.

### [That Allah Established a Ruling for Places Regarding Water]

Furthermore, Allah established a ruling [حكما] for places regarding Water, and the origin of that ruling is from the Water itself—this is the wonder. He made some lands saline (*sibakh*) that yield salty water when the salinity is great, and they yield bitter, acrid, and brackish water, just as they also yield sweet, palatable water. All of this is by the making of Allah the Exalted. The origin of all this is from the moistures that Water granted to the Earth, and the heat that Air and movements granted to it. The temperaments (*amzija*) of the Earth vary. Some water is sweet and palatable, for the benefit of servants in what they use for drinking and other purposes. And some is salty and bitter, for the benefit of servants in removing the putrefaction of the Air. There is no element that Allah has not made both an active agent and one acted upon. The origin of this is in Divine Knowledge [العلم الإلهي]: <<وَإِذَا سَأَلَكَ عِبَادِي عَنِّي فَإِنِّي قَرِيبٌ أُجِيبُ دَعْوَةَ الدَّاعِ إِذَا دَعَانِ>> (And when My servants ask you concerning Me, indeed I am near. I respond to the invocation of the supplicant when he calls upon Me). Every agent acted upon in the cosmos is part of the Divine Response (*al-ijaba al-ilahiyya*). As for the active agent (*ism al-fa’il*) of that, it is known to everyone. We only draw attention to what most people might overlook, just as He said concerning certain things: <<وَلَكِنَّ أَكْثَرَ النَّاسِ لَا يَعْلَمُونَ>> (But most people do not know).

Furthermore, Allah the Mighty and Majestic did not place the formations that are the creatures of the sea in the salty sea, except specifically in the sweet parts of it. Were it not for the presence of Air and sweet Water in it, no animal would be formed there. Do you not see the vapor rising from rivers and seas, especially in cold weather? That is the breath (*nafs*) rising from the Earth and the Sea, just as breath exits a breather. It seeks its greatest element, transforms into water, and joins its element according to what was predetermined in Allah’s Knowledge concerning it. Thus, it is a revolving wheel: from it, it emerges, and to it, some of it returns. Its origin in Divine Knowledge [العلم الإلهي] is that Allah was, and there was nothing else. He brought things into existence and manifested claims within them by causing some of them to transform into others, and by granting them the powers by which they act. After all this, He said: <<وَإِلَيْهِ يُرْجَعُ الْأَمْرُ كُلُّهُ>> (And to Him is returned the whole affair). Thus, He made the rising of vapor from Water—which is water that transformed into air—called vapor, to distinguish between the original Air and the transformed Air. Then it becomes accumulated clouds, and then it descends as water, just as it was the first time. Thus, it returns to the origin from which it emerged, and the cycle repeats. For this reason, we likened it to a wheel and said that it returns. This is by the decree of the Almighty, the All-Knowing. End of the 123rd Part.

(In the Name of Allah, the Most Merciful, the Grantor of Mercy)

(Chapter Thirty-One) Concerning the Divine Name *Al-Mumit* (The Giver of Death)

And its orientation [توجهه] toward bringing into existence what appears in the Earth [الأرض]. It corresponds to the undotted letter *Sad* (ص) among the letters, and the mansion of *al-Bulda*. Allah the Exalted said: <<خَلَقَ الْأَرْضَ فِي يَوْمَيْنِ>> (He created the Earth in two days). And He said: <<وَقَدَّرَ فِيهَا أَقْوَاتَهَا>> (And determined therein its provisions). It is the first of the elements [الأركان] created, followed by Water, then Air, then Fire, then the Heavens.

The Exalted informed us of matters concerning it that necessitate that it possesses intellect. He described it with speech and refusal, saying that He spoke to it and it spoke to Him, and He characterized it by obedience and taking the most cautious path, thereby indicating its knowledge and intellect. He made it the locus for the formation of minerals, plants, animals, and humans. He made it the Presence [حضرة] of Vicegerency (*Khilafa*) and governance (*tadbir*). Thus, it is the place of the gaze of The Real [الحق]. He subjected all the elements, spheres [الأفلاك], and angels [الأملاك] for its sake. And He caused to grow therein <<مِن كُلِّ زَوْجٍ بَهِيجٍ>> (of every beautiful pair)—of every male and female. Nothing was gathered before Him, glory be to Him, for any creature except for what was created from it, which is the clay of Adam, peace be upon him, which He fermented with His two Hands, while <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (there is nothing like Him). He established it in the station of servitude (*‘ubudiyya*), saying: <<الَّذِي جَعَلَ لَكُمُ الْأَرْضَ ذَلُولًا>> (He who made the earth subservient to you). He assigned it the level [مرتبة] of the Universal Soul [النفس الكلية] from which the cosmos manifested. Likewise, the generated things (*al-muwalladat*) of the cosmos manifested from this Earth up to the concave surface of the sphere of the Mansions. This element does not transform into anything, nor does anything transform into it. Although the other elements are similar in this regard, this ruling is more manifest in this element than in others.

### [Mental Existence and External Existence]

Know that everything known [معلوم] that admits division necessarily enters into Mental Existence [الوجود الذهني]. This thing that enters Mental Existence may be one that accepts External Existence [الوجود العيني], or it may be one that does not accept External Existence, such as the impossible. That which accepts External Existence is either self-subsistent (*qa’im bi-nafsihi*), which is predicated as "not in a subject," or it is not self-subsistent. As for the category of what is self-subsistent, it is either spatially delimited (*mutahayyiz*) or non-spatially delimited (*ghayr mutahayyiz*). As for the category of "not in a subject" and "non-spatially delimited," it is either Necessary Existence by virtue of its Essence [واجب الوجود لذاته], which is Allah the Exalted, or it is necessary by virtue of another, which is the contingent (*mumkin*). This contingent existent is either spatially delimited or non-spatially delimited. The division concerning the self-subsistent contingent existents is: the non-spatially delimited, such as the rational souls [النفوس الناطقة] governing the essence of the luminous, natural, and elemental cosmos; and the spatially delimited. The spatially delimited is either composite, possessing parts, or it does not possess parts. If it does not possess parts, it is the indivisible substance (*al-jawhar al-fard*). If it possesses parts, it is the body (*al-jism*). As for the category that is "in a subject"—that which is not self-subsistent and is spatially delimited only by virtue of dependence—it is either necessary for the subject or not necessary, in the view of the eye. However, in the reality of the matter (*fi nafs al-amr*), nothing that is not self-subsistent remains in existence beyond the time of its existence. But some of it is followed by its likes, and some is followed by what is not its like. That which is followed by its likes is what is imagined to be necessary, such as the yellowness of gold or the blackness of the Ethiopian. That which is not followed by its likes is called the accident (*al-‘arad*). The necessary one is called an attribute (*sifa*). The known things that possess External Existence are none other than what we have mentioned.

### [That the Cosmos is One in Substance, Multiple in Form]

Know that the cosmos [العالم] is one in substance (*jawhar*) but multiple in form (*sura*). If it is one in substance, then it does not transform. Likewise, the form does not transform, because that would lead to the inversion of realities [قلب الحقائق]. Heat does not become coldness, dryness does not become moisture, whiteness does not transform into blackness, and triangularity does not become squareness. However, the hot may be found cold, except during the time it is hot; likewise, the cold may be found hot, except during the time it is cold; and the white may be black, similar to what we mentioned; and the triangular may be square. Thus, transformation is nullified. Earth, Water, Air, the spheres [الأفلاك], and the generated things [المولدات] are forms in the substance. Forms are bestowed upon it, and it is named by them according to its configuration—this is *kawn* (coming-to-be). And forms are removed from it, and that name vanishes with their removal—this is *fasad* (passing-away). There is no transformation in existence such that the essence of one thing transforms into the essence of another; rather, it is as we have mentioned.

The cosmos is an individual that comes-to-be and passes-away in every moment. The essence of the cosmos’s substance would not subsist were it not for its acceptance of coming-to-be within it. Thus, the cosmos is perpetually in need. The need of the forms is due to their emergence from non-existence to existence. The need of the substance is for the preservation of existence upon it, since a condition of its existence is the existence of the coming-to-be for which it is the subject—this is necessary. The ruling concerning the self-subsistent contingent existent that is non-spatially delimited is similar: it is the subject for the spiritual attributes [الصفات الروحانية] and perceptions it bears, without which its essence would not subsist. These are renewed upon it just as accidents are renewed upon bodies. The form of the body is an accident in the substance. As for definitions (*hudud*), their locus is only the forms; they are what are defined. The substance in which the form appears must be included in its definition. To this extent, they call the forms "substance," because they include the substance in the definition of the form.

In summary, contemplation of these matters without the path of Divine Unveiling [الكشف الإلهي] does not lead to the reality of the matter as it truly is. It is inevitable that <<لَا يَزَالُونَ مُخْتَلِفِينَ>> (they will remain differing). For this reason, the blessed group, supported by the Holy Spirit, turned to stripping themselves of their thoughts and freeing themselves from the constraint of their powers. They connected with the Greatest Light [النور الأعظم] and witnessed the matter as it is in itself, since The Real [الحق], Mighty and Majestic, was their sight. Thus, they witnessed nothing but The Real. As the Veracious One (*al-Siddiq*) said, "I have not seen a thing except that I saw Allah before it." Thus, he sees The Real, and then he sees His effect in existence, which is the understanding of the manner of emanation (*sudur*). It is as if he witnessed the contingent existents [الممكنات] in their state of immutability [ثبوتها] when the Greatest Light was sprinkled upon those that were sprinkled, and they became characterized by Existence [الوجود] after having been described by non-existence. For whoever reaches this station, the veil of blindness and confusion is lifted from him: <<فَكَشَفْنَا عَنكَ غِطَاءَكَ فَبَصَرُكَ الْيَوْمَ حَدِيدٌ>> (Then We removed from you your covering, and your sight, this Day, is sharp). ... <<إِنَّ فِي ذَلِكَ لَذِكْرَىٰ لِمَن كَانَ لَهُ قَلْبٌ أَوْ أَلْقَى السَّمْعَ وَهُوَ شَهِيدٌ>> (Indeed, in that is a reminder for whoever has a heart or lends an ear while he is a witness). Knowledge [العلم] is only established in Witnessing [الشهود]. The judge rules by the preponderance of his opinion, while the witness testifies based on knowledge, not opinion. Know then that the bodies of the cosmos are divided into subtle and dense, transparent and turbid, dark and illuminated, large and small, visible and invisible. All Existence [الوجود] is a gift.

> There is no withholding with Allah;
>
> everything from Him is a gift.
>
> So if withholding is mentioned,
>
> it is nothing but a gift.
>
> For we are between two things:
>
> a covering and a bedding.
>
> And I am the vessel for all the good in the cosmos.

### [The Following of the Man Who Saw The Real as Real and Suppressed His Desire]

The man who saw The Real [الحق] as The Real and followed Him, and governed and suppressed his lower desire (*hawa*): when he feels the hunger of necessity and the most desirable foods are presented before him, he partakes of them with his intellect, not his appetite, thereby repelling the dominion of his necessity. Then he abstains from the excess out of self-sufficiency and nobility of aspiration. That is the Master of the Time (*Sayyid al-Waqt*), so follow him. That is the form of The Real [صورة الحق] that Allah established as a physical form of far reach, whose extent cannot be attained, and whose path of guidance is not hidden. This is the nature of the Earth: it is the subservient one that does not accept transformation.

The rulings [أحكام] of the elements appear within it, but it has no ruling that appears in anything else. It grants all benefits from its own essence. It is the most honored of bodies. It does not compete with moving things through its movement, because it does not leave its spatial location. Every element manifests its dominion within it. It is the patient, accepting, firm, and stable one. Its shaking was calmed by its mountains, which Allah made its pegs (*awtad*). When it moved out of fear of Allah, Allah secured it with these pegs, and it settled with the stillness of the certain ones (*al-muqinin*). From it, the People of Certainty [أهل اليقين] learn their certainty, for it is the Mother from which we were brought forth, to which we return, and from which we will be brought forth again. To it belongs submission (*taslim*) and delegation (*tafwid*). It is the most subtle of the elements in meaning. It only accepted density, darkness, and hardness to conceal the treasures that Allah deposited within it. Because Allah placed jealousy (*ghayra*) within it, the seekers were confused by it; they could not penetrate it or reach the height of its mountains. He granted it the attribute of sanctification (*taqdis*) and made it a purifier (*tahur*) in the most noble of states, which is in times of necessity, because He established it in His own station. Like the thirsty person who sees a mirage and thinks it is water, <<فَإِذَا جَاءَهُ لَمْ يَجِدْهُ شَيْئًا>> (when he comes to it, he finds it nothing)—meaning, no water—<<وَوَجَدَ اللَّهَ عِندَهُ>> (but finds Allah with him). Allah is only found in necessity. Likewise, the purification by Earth (*taharat al-ard*) only occurs for one who lacks water, whatever the circumstances. Look at how noble its station is!

Then He assigned it the status of the point in the circumference [المحيط]. It faces every part of the circumference with its essence, and every part of the circumference looks toward it. Every line emerging from it reaches the circumference equally and moderately, because it only grants according to its form. And every line from the circumference aims toward it. If it were removed, the circumference would vanish; but if the circumference were removed, its removal would not be necessary. Thus, it is the enduring, subsisting one in this world and the Hereafter. It resembles the Breath of the All-Merciful [نفس الرحمن] in creation.

### [That Allah Made This Earth Like a Single Body]

Know that Allah the Exalted made this Earth, after it was a single mass (*ratq*), like a single body, just as the Heaven was. He split its mass and made it seven layers (*atbaq*), just as He did with the heavens. He gave each earth a readiness to be acted upon by the effect of the movement of one of the celestial spheres [أفلاك السموات] and the ray of its star. The first Earth, which is the one we are upon, corresponds to the first sphere from there. Then they descend until they reach the seventh Earth and the lowest heaven [السماء الدنيا]. For this reason, the Prophet, peace be upon him, said concerning whoever usurps a span of land, "Allah will encircle him with it from seven earths." Because if he usurps something from the Earth, what is beneath that usurped portion is usurped down to the end of the Earth. If they were not layers, one above the other, the meaning of this report would be nullified. Likewise, the report concerning the servant’s prostration on the Earth: Allah purifies with his prostration down to seven earths. And the Exalted said: <<أَنَّ السَّمَاوَاتِ وَالْأَرْضَ كَانَتَا رَتْقًا>> (That the heavens and the earth were a joined entity)—meaning, each of them was a joined entity. Then He said: <<فَفَتَقْنَاهُمَا>> (and We separated them)—meaning, He separated parts of them from others until each was distinguished from its companion, just as He said: <<خَلَقَ سَبْعَ سَمَاوَاتٍ طِبَاقًا وَمِنَ الْأَرْضِ مِثْلَهُنَّ>> (He created seven heavens in layers and of the earth, the like thereof). The apparent meaning is layers. Then He said: <<يَتَنَزَّلُ الْأَمْرُ بَيْنَهُنَّ>> (The command descends between them)—meaning, between the heavens and the earths. If there were only one earth, He would have said "between them" (dual). This is the apparent meaning, and it is what Unveiling [الكشف] grants. The command descending between them is this Divine Command [الأمر الإلهي] that exists between the lowest heaven and the Earth we are upon. It descends from the heaven and then seeks its earth, which is His saying: <<وَأَوْحَىٰ فِي كُلِّ سَمَاءٍ أَمْرَهَا>> (And He revealed in every heaven its command). That command is what descends to its earth, carrying what Allah revealed within it concerning the forms and spirits [الأرواح] that inhabit that earth.

He made this Earth seven regions (*aqalim*) and chose from His believing servants seven whom He named the Substitutes (*al-Abdal*). For each Substitute, there is a region whose existence Allah maintains through him. The first region receives the command from the first heaven from there, and the spirituality of its star looks toward it, and the Substitute who preserves it is on the heart of Abraham (Ibrahim), peace be upon him. The second region receives the command from the second heaven, and the spirituality of its star looks toward it, and the Substitute who preserves it is on the heart of Moses (Musa), peace be upon him. The third region receives the Divine Command from the third heaven, and the spirituality of its star looks toward it, and the Substitute who preserves it is on the heart of Aaron (Harun) and John (Yahya), peace be upon them, with the support of Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him. The fourth region receives the command from the heart of all the spheres, and the spirituality of its Greatest Star looks toward it, and the Substitute who preserves it is on the foot of Idris (Enoch), peace be upon him, and he is the Pole (*al-Qutb*) who has not died until now, and the Poles among us are his deputies. The fifth region receives the command from the fifth heaven, and the spirituality of its star looks toward it, and the Substitute through whom Allah preserves that region is on the heart of Joseph (Yusuf), peace be upon him, and Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, supports him. The sixth region receives the command from the sixth heaven, and the spirituality of its star looks toward it, and the Substitute who preserves it is on the heart of Jesus (Isa), the Spirit of Allah, and John (Yahya), peace be upon them. The seventh region receives the command from the lowest heaven [السماء الدنيا], and the spirituality of its star looks toward it, and the Substitute who preserves it is on the heart of Adam, peace be upon him.

I met these seven Substitutes in the sacred precinct of Mecca, behind the *Hatīm* of the Hanbalis. I found them bowing there. I greeted them, and they greeted me, and I conversed with them. Among all I have seen, I have never seen anyone better in demeanor or more preoccupied with Allah than them. I have only seen their like in Saqīt al-Rifraf, the son of Saqit al-Arsh, in Konya, and he was Persian.

Know that the difference between the temperament [مزاج] of a single element and its mixture [امتزاج] with itself, or its mixture with another element—such as the mixture of Water with Earth, which produces the name "mud" (*tin*), which is neither Earth nor Water. The mixture within a single element is like indigo (*nil*) and white lead (*isfidaj*) when they are mixed by grinding. Their parts mingle and mix in a way that separation is impossible, producing another color that belongs to neither of them. This mixture produces a ruling in the final natural acts. And like sweet water and salty water when mixed, a different taste results, which is neither salty nor sweet. This is what the mixture within a single element grants. Likewise, Water, which is cold, when Fire imparts heat to it such that it is neither left cold nor raised to the degree of Fire’s heat, it becomes lukewarm—neither hot nor cold. This is a mixture that resembles neither the mixture of parts of a single element nor the mixture of two elements.

As for the temperament [المزاج], it is that by which the essence [عين] of the element exists, and it is called the nature (*tab’*). Thus, the nature or temperament of Water is said to be cold and moist; Fire, hot and dry; Air, hot and moist; and Earth, cold and dry. The essences of these elements only appeared through this natural temperament. Every temperament is natural, but mixture is not. Through the mixture we mentioned in the element of Water, we know with certainty that the parts of salty water are adjacent to the parts of sweet water, and the parts of indigo are adjacent to the parts of white lead—adjacent intellectually, not perceivable or separable by the senses. However, in mixture, Nature establishes a ruling in these forms resulting from the mixture, such as the compounding of medicines. Each drug within it has a separate benefit, but when the whole is mixed, it is in this state, and Nature necessarily has a ruling over the totality. If the whole is placed in one vessel and a single water is poured over all of it, each drug imparts a power to every substance (*jawhar*) of that water. Thus, the single substance of water contains the power of every single drug, provided the powers do not conflict. Although this is a mixture, it is not like the previous mixture, nor does its ruling reach the ruling of temperament. This is an intelligible state between temperament and mixture, which is called neither temperament nor mixture. Likewise, although the Earth consists of seven layers, it may be difficult for the senses to distinguish between them, even though we know that no layer is in the same state as another, just as one substance is not in the same state as another substance, and its accident is in the same state as its subject and carrier. Thus is the coming-to-be and passing-away of things, and the changes that affect them. End of the 123rd Part.

(In the Name of Allah, the Most Merciful, the Grantor of Mercy)

As for the natural consequences that affect elemental bodies, they are many. Among them is the movement and rest of the element. Is it contrary to the movement and rest of the sphere [الفلك], if its rest were assumed? Or is its rest like the rest of the heaven, which only the specialists among us affirm? As for the movement of the sphere, which is one of the natural bodies, it moves by a mover that is not itself. Likewise, every moving and resting thing in the cosmos is neither moving by its own essence nor resting by its own essence, but by a mover and a restrainer. That mover must either move it by its own essence or move it by virtue of what it intends to move. As for those who hold that its mover moves it by its own essence, they are the ones who affirm the creation of movement in the body. Movement, by its own essence, imparts motion to that in which it subsists; thus, it is the mover of the moving thing by its own essence. Rest is similar. If the mover moves it by virtue of what it intends to move, it may move it through a means or without a means. That is, through a means that is not characterized by the intention to move it, even if it possesses will—like the compelled person in the case of one who possesses will—or the movement of a branch by the movement of the wind, which is caused by the movement of the hand of the person fanning with it. Without a means, such as a person shaking a stick in his hand, causing it to vibrate. Or the moving thing may be moving by will in its own essence, such as the voluntary movement of a human in directions.

The sphere [الفلك], in our view, moves with the movement of a human in directions, because it possesses intellect, is charged with responsibility, and is commanded, just as the Prophet, peace be upon him, said concerning his she-camel, that she was commanded. And he said concerning the sun, peace be upon him, that it seeks permission to rise, and then it rises, and permission is granted to it. When the time comes for it to rise from its setting place, it will be told, "Return from whence you came," and it will rise from its setting place.
