That is the time when <<لَا يَنفَعُ نَفْسًا إِيمَانُهَا>> (no soul will benefit from its faith).

The sphere moves by will [الإرادة] to impart the Divine Command [الأمر الإلهي] contained in its heaven, which causes things to occur in the elements and the generated things [المولدات]. Through those celestial movements, Time [الزمان] appears. Time does not rule over its manifestation, but only over what is below it. Time has no ruling over the movements of the sphere, because the sphere is the very manifestation of Time. The manifest and accidental occurrences in the spheres, the heavens, and the higher cosmos have causes other than Time. The movements of the sphere are ordered, with successive parts following a single pattern, like the movement of a millstone; every part does not leave its neighbor. The movement of the elements is not like that, for the movement of the element is interpenetrating; every part leaves the part that was adjacent to it and occupies spatial locations other than those it was in.

The causes of the element’s movement differ from the causes of the sphere’s movement. The movement of the sphere knows nothing except what it imparts to the elements in terms of motion, and the rays of its stars, by virtue of the intellect, spirit, and knowledge that Allah deposited within them, impart to the individuals of every generated species—mineral, plant, animal, jinn, and angel created from an act or a soul—by means of glorification (*tasbih*), remembrance (*dhikr*), or recitation. This is due to their knowledge of what Allah deposited with them, which is His saying: <<وَأَوْحَىٰ فِي كُلِّ سَمَاءٍ أَمْرَهَا>> (And He revealed in every heaven its command). Whoever lacks Unveiling [كشف] sees that all that comes into being through their flow is merely them being subjected in their movements to bring these matters into existence, like a craftsman moving tools to create a form he wishes to create, such as a form in wood or otherwise. The tools know nothing of this, nor of what emanated from them, even though those forms only appear through these tools. This is the claim of those who hold a view contrary to ours and that of the People of Allah [أهل الله] who possess Unveiling and Witnessing [الكشف والوجود].

We say that the carpenter’s tool may know more than the craftsman who uses it, for it is living, speaking, knowing its Creator, glorifying its Lord’s praise, and knowing for what purpose it was created, according to the People of Unveiling. When Allah unveils the sight and hearing of the one who receives Unveiling (*al-mukashif*), the trees of the Earth and its stars call out to him with their benefits and harms. Just as the stones spoke to David, peace be upon him. Every stone said, "O David, take me, for I will kill Goliath." And another stone said to him, "Take me, for I will cause a break in the right flank of his army." Thus, every stone knew what it was created for. David took those stones, and the matter occurred just as they mentioned.

When some people do not reach this degree or are not informed of it through direct vision, they deny it. This should not be the case, for there is nothing moving in the World (العالم) except that it knows what it moves toward, except for the two weighty ones (humans and jinn), who may be ignorant of what they move toward—indeed, they are ignorant, save those whom Allah wills among the People of Unveiling (أهل الكشف), whether they be disciples or otherwise. Allah said to the heavens and the earth: <<Come willingly or unwillingly. They said: We come willingly>> (Qur’an 41:11). The coming of the earth is a movement and a transition toward that to which it was called, and it came willingly. Thus, every part of the cosmos is aware of what is desired of it; it acts with insight, even the parts of the human body. The only part that is ignorant is the subtle essence (لطيفته) that is charged with responsibility (المكلفة), entrusted to employ its thought or to look with the light of faith until that light appears upon its sight, thereby unveiling what was previously mere information (خبر) to it.

Since the movement of the element (العنصر) differs from the movement of the celestial sphere (الفلك) due to interpenetration (التداخل) and the rest (السكون) that occurs in some parts of the element, but not in its entirety, we know definitively that the law governing movement in the element differs from the law governing the movement of the celestial sphere. The law governing the movement of the element—whichever element it may be—if it is between two elements, like air and water, or if it is not between two elements, like fire and earth: the movement of the elemental air manifests an effect according to what it directly contacts above it and below it. The same applies to the element of water. As for the movement of fire, only air affects it, and the movement of earth is affected only by water and air. In this, the earth element differs from the fire element. When fire affects other pillars (الأركان) by heating, it takes two paths: either through the mediation of the ray of the Greatest Star, which is the sun—for its ray passes through the Aether (الأثير) and gains an increase in its quantity of heat—or through the mediation of fire carried in charcoal or wood. These effects that appear in an element from another element, if the affected element does not receive sustenance (إمداد) from the element from which the effect originated, and the law of the element in which the effect appeared prevails over it and corrupts it—this is one of the types of Generation and Corruption (الكون والفساد) apparent in elemental bodies.

[The Relation of Movement and Rest]

Then know that the verification (التحقيق) regarding Movement (الحركة) and Rest (السكون) is that they are two relations (نسبتان) belonging to natural essences (الذوات الطبيعية) that occupy space (المتحيزة المكانية) or are capable of occupying space, if they are in the realm of possibility (الإمكان). This is because a spatial entity (المتحيز) must necessarily have a locus (حيز) that it occupies with its Essence (ذاته) during the time of its existence therein. It must either pass through a second time, or times, while remaining in that very locus—which is what is expressed as Rest (السكون)—or it must be in the second time in the locus adjacent to it, and in the third time in the locus adjacent to the second locus. Its appearance and occupation of these loci, locus after locus, can only occur through transition (الانتقال) from one locus to another. This transition can only be by means of a mover (منقل). If this transition is called Movement, while we understand that there is nothing there except the essence of the spatial entity and the locus, and its occupation of the other locus adjacent to the locus it occupied first—this is not prevented. But whoever claims that there is an existing entity called Movement subsisting in the spatial entity, which necessitates its transition from locus to locus, must provide proof. It only transitions by means of a mover. If it possesses will (إرادة), it moves by its will; otherwise, it moves by another mover that transfers it from locus to locus.

Likewise, Conjunction (الاجتماع) and Separation (الافتراق) are two relations of spatial entities. Conjunction is the state of two spatial entities being adjacent in two loci, such that no third locus can be conceived between them. Separation is when a third locus or more can be conceived between them. Know this. Furthermore, Time (الزمان) and Place (المكان) are also concomitants (لواحق) of natural bodies. However, Time is an imagined concept (أمر متوهم) that has no existence in reality (لا وجود له), made manifest by the movements of the celestial spheres or the movements of spatial entities when the question "When?" (متى) is associated with them. The Locus (الحيز) and Time also have no existence in reality (في العين). Existence belongs only to the essences (ذوات) of the moving and resting things. As for Place (المكان), it is that upon which the established things (المتمكنات) settle, not that *in* which they settle. If they were *in* it, those would be loci, not Place. Thus, Place is also a relative concept (أمر نسبي) in an existing entity upon which the established thing settles, or which it traverses through transitions, but not *in* it. If spatial entities are connected by way of adjacency (مجاورة) in a specific sequence without interpenetration (تداخل), that is Connection (الاتصال). If the transitions follow one another moment after moment, that is Succession (التتابع) and Continuity (التتالي) without any interval (فترة) interrupting them. If some enter into others and the entering entity does not separate the connected ones, that is Cohesion (الالتحام). Whatever enters into Existence is described as finite (متناهي), and whatever does not enter is said to be infinite (لا يتناهى) if it is hypothesized to be continuous forever. If these transitions result in transformation (استحالة), that is Generation and Corruption (الكون والفساد). The transition of a thing from non-existence (العدم) to existence is called Generation (كون), and the removal of the form of generation that appeared from it is called Corruption (فساد). If it transitions from one existence to another existence, it is called moving (متحرك).

As for the concomitants (لواحق) that adhere to these bodies—such as colors, shapes, lightness, heaviness, subtlety (لطف), density (كثافة), turbidity (كدورة), clarity (صفا), softness (لين), hardness (صلابة), and similar things—they revert to different causes. Colors are of two types: colors that subsist in the colored object itself, and colors that appear to the viewing observer but are not in the essence of the colored object, due to the variation in shapes and what light imparts to that body, for perception (الإدراك) occurs through light. Likewise, shapes, like colors, revert to two things: the bearer of the shape and the sense of the perceiver. As for the rest of the concomitants of bodies we mentioned, they revert to the perceiver of that quality, not to the bodies themselves, nor to the described Essence (الذات الموصوفة) which is the natural body—this is our view. For a subtle entity like air does not retain the form of light, while a dense body manifests it. We have seen those for whom dense objects (الكثائف) do not veil, and the form of the dense object is, for them, the form of the subtle object in the penetration of perception. Thus, they are only dense objects to those who lack this penetration. Among us are those whom walls do not veil, and nothing weighs them down. Therefore, the reality of these descriptions belongs to the perceiver. If they belonged to the essences of the bodies, there would be equality in that, just as there is equality in their being bodies. Thus, the law of the concomitants does not revert to the essences of the bodies, in our view. As for the natural philosophers (الطبيعيين), even if they differ, they are not upon our path in this knowledge.

[That when a single Essence manifests diverse effects, this is due to the Receptacles]

Know that when a single Essence (الشيء الواحد العين) manifests diverse effects (الآثار المختلفة), this is due to the Receptacles (القوابل), not to its Essence. From this perspective, if you verify this issue, the saying of the Wise Man (الحكيم)—"Only one proceeds from the One (لا يصدر عن الواحد إلا واحد)"—is invalidated. The illustration of this in the element we are discussing is that fire, insofar as it is fire, its law does not change from the perspective of its Essence (ذاتها), yet you find its effects having different laws: it illuminates some bodies but not others, even though its illumination is by combustion; air assists it; it solidifies some things and melts others; it blackens and whitens; it heats and burns; it ripens and dissolves solids. Yet, it remains upon a single reality, and the preparedness of the Receptacles (استعداد القوابل) manifests the difference in the laws of its effects.

> The Essence is one, but the law is diverse, *** And Knowledge perceives what sight does not grasp.

[That things, by virtue of being things, have a law]

Know that things, individually, have a law, and through their mixtures (امتزاجاتها), laws arise for them that belonged neither to the individual components nor to any one of them. It is not truly known which of the two mixed components is the active agent (المؤثر)—is it one, or does each one have a power in it? What has arisen cannot be denied, for we know that the blackness of ink came into existence after it was not, through the mixing of vitriol (الزاج) and gallnut (العفص). Did the vitriol dye the gallnut, making it the active agent and the gallnut the object acted upon? If that were the case, the vitriol would remain unchanged if it were not mixed, and the gallnut water would be dyed. What is witnessed is contrary to this. The same applies to the gallnut. Thus, nothing remains but the reality of the mixing (حقيقة المزج), which brought forth the blackness, and it does not belong truly to one specific component. This is the reality of what we stated regarding the Divine matters: <<We shall attend to you, O you two weighty ones>> (Qur’an 55:31). And Allah comes on the Day of Resurrection for separation and judgment, holding the Balance (الميزان) in His Hand, lowering and raising. Allah is not described by the occurrence of this act, and there is no world (عالم) that is described by it. Thus, something appeared through the World that did not appear, and there is no world. Therefore, the law is not equal.

The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Allah was, and there was nothing with Him."

He did not say: "And He is now as He was." How could he say that, peace and blessings be upon him, when he is the most knowledgeable of creation concerning Allah, and he is the one who brought from Allah His saying: <<Every day He is engaged in some affair>> (Qur’an 55:29) and <<We shall attend to you, O you two weighty ones>> (Qur’an 55:31)? Your Lord has finished such and such, and our Lord descends to the heaven, yet He was when there was no heaven. And is there a world? Was He described by descending to whom, or from where, or where? Then He brought things into existence, and relations (النسب) came into existence. So He settled (استوى), and He descended, and He took the Balance, and He lowered and raised. The reports that sound intellects, free from passions, do not reject have come down with this, and belief in them is obligatory, though the modality (الكيف) is inconceivable. He is the One (الواحد), the Finder (الواجد), the Unique (الأحد), the Glorious (الماجد), <<There is nothing like unto Him>> (Qur’an 42:11).

Were it not for the existence of the breath (النفس) and the preparedness of the points of articulation (المخارج) in the breather (المتنفس), the letters (الحروف) would have no essence (عين). Were it not for composition (التأليف), the words (الكلمات) would have no essence. Existence is interconnected, part with part. Were it not for the distress (الحرج) and constriction (الضيق), the Breath of the All-Merciful (النفس الرحماني) would have no law, for the act of breathing out (التنفيس) is the removal of the essence of distress and constriction. Non-existence (العدم) is the very distress and constriction, for it is possible that this non-existent thing may come into existence. When the possible thing knows its possibility while in the state of non-existence, it is in the anguish (كرب) of longing for the Existence that its reality grants it, so that it may take its share of goodness. So the Breath of the All-Merciful breathed out (نفس) this distress from it and brought it into existence. Thus, His breathing out for it was the removal of the law of non-existence within it. Every existent thing other than Allah is possible (ممكن), so it possesses this attribute. The Breath of the All-Merciful is the giver of the forms of the possible things (الممكنات) to Existence, just as the breath gives existence to the letters. The World (العالم) is the Words of Allah (كلمات الله) from the perspective of this Breath, as He said: <<and His Word which He cast unto Maryam>> (Qur’an 4:171), which is the essence of Jesus, peace be upon him. And He informed us that the Words of Allah shall not be exhausted (لا تنفد), so His creatures continue to be brought into existence, and He continues to be the Creator.

Likewise, when we observe in these elemental bodies matters of diverse forms, diverse shapes, and diverse temperaments (المزاج), yet this difference does not remove them from the reality of their being gathered by a single definition (حد واحد) and a single reality—like the individuals of the animal kingdom, despite the diversity of their types and shapes—a bird, for example, is not removed from its being a bird by the diversity of measures, shapes, and colors that appear in it. We therefore know that this difference is not due to its being human or its being a bird. For humanity exists in every single one of its individuals despite the appearance of difference. Thus, there must be other intelligible realities (حقائق أخر معقولة) that necessitated this difference for them. We searched for this in the Divine Knowledge (العلم الإلهي), which is our goal, since Existence is connected to it. We found that He, the Exalted, does not repeat a Theophany (تجلي), and He appears in a form in which He is denied and in a form in which He is known. He is Allah, the Exalted, in both forms, the First and the Last, and in every form of Theophany. Thus, the forms of Theophany in the Godhead (الألوهة) stand in the place of the difference in the states of the forms of the individuals of the species (النوع). We knew that the change in the individuals of the species stems from this Divine Reality. We knew that we only know of the Real (الحق) what He makes us witness. And Allah disclosed Himself (تجلى) to the species insofar as it is a species, so it did not change from its species-ness, just as He never ceases to be God in His Godhead. Then He appears to that species in forms necessitated by His Essence, the Exalted. Consequently, differences in forms appeared in the individuals of the species, according to their measure and quantity.

Were it not for His presence in the preparedness of this species, which changes by individual in shapes, colors, and measures that do not remove it from its species-ness, it would not accept this change and would remain in a single form. Since the dense object, despite its density, is prepared to accept different forms through the craft of the maker—like wood and the forms conceived from it according to the different forms subsisting in the soul of the maker—the subtle object is more receptive to difference, like water and air. The subtler a thing is, the faster it is inherently in accepting difference. It is thus clear to you that the difference in the forms of the World, from its highest subtlety to its lowest density, does not remove every form in which it appears from being the Breath of the All-Merciful. The Exalted said: <<And Allah has caused you to grow from the earth, a growth>> (Qur’an 71:17). The earth is one, yet where is the form of the star/herb (نجم) compared to the form of the tree (شجر) with its diverse types, compared to the form of the human, compared to the forms of the animal? All of this stems from an elemental reality (حقيقة عنصرية) whose elementality has not ceased due to the difference that appeared within it. The difference of the entire World does not remove it from being one Essence (واحد العين) in Existence. Zayd is not Amr, yet they are both human. They are the essence of humanity, nothing else. From this, you know what the World is and the nature of the matter within it, if you possess sound insight. <<And in yourselves, do you not see?>> (Qur’an 51:21). There is nothing there but the rational soul (النفس الناطقة), which is the intellective, the thinking, the imaginative, the preservative, the formative, the nutritive, the growing, the attractive, the repulsive, the digestive, the retentive, the hearing, the seeing, the tasting, the smelling, and the touching—and the perceiver of these matters. The difference in these faculties (القوي) and the difference in the names applied to them are not something added to the soul; rather, they are the very Essence (عين) of every form. You find this same principle in the forms of minerals, plants, animals, celestial spheres, and angels. Glory be to Him who manifested things, while He is their very Essence.

> My eye has not gazed upon other than His Face, *** Nor has my ear heard anything contrary to His Speech.
> Every existence contained His Existence, *** And every individual has remained in its sleep.
> The interpretation of our visions belongs to them in our sleep, *** So whoever blames, let him join them in their blame.

Related to this chapter and the chapter on the pillar of water is what appears in them of heat (السخانة) from the luminous rays (الشعاعات النورية) emanating from the Essence of the sun—where is its origin in Divine Knowledge? When terrestrial and aquatic bodies are connected to the rays of solar and stellar lights, some bodies are seen to heat up when the ray spreads upon them, while other bodies remain cold and do not accept heating, even though the rays penetrate that body—like the sphere of intense cold (دائرة الزمهرير) and what is above the sphere of Jupiter (الجولا), where the heat of the rays has no effect.

[That the Divine Face has burning Sublimities which, were it not for the veils, would incinerate the World]

Know that the Divine Face (الوجه الإلهي) has burning Sublimities (سبحات محرقات) which, were it not for the veils (الحجب), would incinerate the World. These veils must either be from the World or not. There is no doubt that if the Sublimities did not spread upon the veils, they would not be veils against them. If the Sublimities necessitated incineration, the veils would be incinerated. Furthermore, the veils must either be dense (كثيفة) or subtle (لطيفة). If they are subtle, they do not veil, just as air does not veil the connection of the sun's ray to terrestrial bodies. If they are dense, like walls and similar things, it is clear that the wall heats up from the sun's ray if its parts are compacted and not porous. Moreover, darkness (الظلمة) does not veil light because light repels it, so they do not gather together. Rather, darkness is adjacent to light from behind the veil that creates the darkness which directly contacts the light. Thus, darkness is adjacent to the ray, and the creator of the darkness accepts the spreading of the ray upon it. Therefore, darkness is not a veil in this consideration. Yet, its being a veil is established, as is the fact that light is a veil upon the light of the Face. Light is strengthened by light; it does not veil it. Understand the reality of the Sublimities of the Face: they are essential indications (دلائل ذاتية) which, when they appear, incinerate relations (نسب) but not essences (أعيان). It is thus clear that they are the very essence of those essences—meaning the Face. The ignorance whose fruit was that the World is not the essence of the Face has vanished. The World thus remains in its form; the Sublimities did not destroy it, but rather established it and made manifest what the Face of the Real (وجه الحق) is. Thus, the veil was conceptual (معنويا), and the relation was incinerated.

(Chapter Thirty-Two) Concerning the Divine Name Al-Aziz (The Mighty/The Precious) and its orientation toward the creation of minerals. It is associated with the letter Ẓā’ (الظاء المعجمة) and the lunar mansion Sa‘d al-Dhābiḥ.

[The Reversion of all Attributes and Names to the Essence of the Creator, Exalted is He]

Know that since the Essence (الذات) is distinguished by seven relations (نسب) called Attributes (صفات), to which all Names and Attributes revert—we have mentioned their reversion in the book *Inshā’ al-Jadāwil*, just as those before us mentioned it, except that I added the Name Al-Mujib (The Responder) along with the Name Al-Shakur (The Appreciative) to the Attribute of Speech (صفة الكلام). Those before us did not attach the Name Al-Mujib to the Name Al-Shakur. Since the heavens are seven, the planets (السيارة) are seven, the earths are seven, and the days are seven, Allah made the formation of minerals (المعادن) in this earth occur through the swimming (سباحة) of these seven planets (الدراري) in their seven celestial spheres within the encompassing sphere. Thus, He brought into existence seven minerals.

Since the Name Al-Aziz (The Mighty) was oriented toward their creation, and they had no witness other than Him at the time of their existence, He imprinted upon them might (عزة) and prevention (منعا). Thus, the dominion of transformation (سلطان الاستحالة)—which governs the generated things (المولدات) and the mothers (الأمهات) among the elements, ruling them with rapid transformation from one form to another, as it rules the rest of the generated things—was not strong enough to affect them. Transformation quickly affects them, and its dominion appears in them through increase, decrease, and the removal and imposition of forms. This law is far removed from the minerals, for stones do not change over the passage of time and ages except after a great distance, and that is due to their might (عزتها) which they acquired from the Divine Name Al-Aziz, which was oriented toward their creation from the Divine Presence (الحضرة الإلهية).

Furthermore, this Name sought, through their creation, the rank of perfection (رتبة الكمال) for them, so that they might be realized by might (عزة), such that no Divine Name other than Al-Aziz affects them—out of preciousness (نفاسة) for their relation to Him and the knowledge of scholars that their existence is attributed to Him. The intention was only for a single form containing the essence of perfection, which is gold (الذهبية). However, accidents (عوارض) intervened on the path from the Name Al-Darr (The Harmer) and its brethren, which sickened their essences and diverted them from their path. The rank (المرتبة) they passed through imposed this upon them, for no Name can have a law in the rank of another. The owner of the station (صاحب المنزل) has the greatest right to the station, and they are the masters of Divine etiquette (أرباب الأدب الإلهي) and the teachers of etiquette.

Thus, the Name Al-Aziz remained in this rank, preserving the essence (جوهر) of the mineral, while the Name associated with the rank controls its form, but not the essence of its substance. The Divine Names have servants (سدنة) in the generated things and the elements, consisting of the natures (الطبائع) and the elements, who manage these matters according to the law of the owner of the rank, who is the Divine Name. These servants are the mineral itself, its heat, the cold of winter, the heat of summer, absolute heat, coldness, moisture, and dryness. Each of these mentioned has a specific law that appears in the substance of the generated things and the elements: it thins and thickens, cools and heats, moistens and dries. The rank of perfection is that in which these laws are balanced and resist each other, such that none of them is strong enough to remove the law of its counterpart. When the substance (الجوهر) is purified from being affected, removing its form from itself and preventing itself from that, that is the law of the rank of perfection, and it is nothing but gold among the minerals. As for the other forms, ailments (أمراض وعلل) afflicted them, diverting them from the path of perfection. Thus appeared mercury (الزئبق), lead (الأسرب), tin (القزدير), iron, copper, and silver, just as yellow and dusky ruby (الياقوت الأصفر والأكهب) appeared in the substance of the ruby. When they left the mineral, which is their homeland in the pillar of earth, they remained upon their sickness, always appearing in the form of ailment.

The skillful expert (الحاذق النحرير) among the scholars of the Craft, when he knows this and wishes to attach that mineral to the rank of perfection—and this can only be by removing the sickness—and the sickness is nothing but an increase or decrease in the substance, and medicine (الطب) is nothing but an increase that removes the law of decrease, or a decrease that removes the law of increase—the physician (الطبيب) is only one who increases the deficient or decreases the excessive. The skillful expert among the people of insight in the medicine of minerals looks at what made it iron or copper or whatever it was, and what stood between it and goldness (الذهبية) from reaching its station and manifesting its form within it.

He will then attain the degree of perfection and acquire the attribute of might and prevention from being affected. This physician is aided by the swimming of the seven lights (الأنوار السبعة) in their celestial spheres—meaning the planets: the Moon, Mercury (الكاتب), Venus (الزهرة), the Sun, Mars (الأحمر), Jupiter (المشتري), and Saturn (كيوان)—by the power within them, due to the variation in time that some of them impart. The law of each time differs from the law of the time adjacent to it in one respect, agrees with it in another, and differs from it in all respects. It is impossible for it to agree with it in all respects, for if it agreed, it would be the same entity, and they are undoubtedly two. Complete agreement in all respects is impossible. The recurrence of these times and the succession of the two new moons (الجديدين) have an effect on the pillars (الأركان) and an effect on the essence of the offspring (الولد) in balancing and moderating its substance. When He balances and moderates it, He makes it a substance capable of accepting any form the Real (الحق) wishes to compose it in. Since the forms are diverse, the minerals differed, just as plants differed in form, and animals differed in form, while their natural substance (الجوهر الطبيعي) is one Essence. For this reason, a single definition encompasses them from the perspective of their substance, and definitions only differ due to the form. The same applies to fathers and mothers. Rather, the substance of the entire World is one in substantiality (بالجوهرية), and the Essence differs by forms and the accidents that befall it. It is the Conjoined Separated (المجتمع المفترق) and the One Many—the image of the Divine Presence (الحضرة الإلهية) in Essence and Names. The skillful expert restores the ailing substance, which its ailment diverted from the path of perfection, back to its path so that he may manage it and preserve the continuity of its health, guarding it from the remaining stations of transforming changes on its path that stand between it and the rank of perfection.

Allah only did this to this substance on the path, and He empowered those who would ail and sicken it, thereby preventing it from reaching the rank of Edenic perfection (الكمال العدني), for the benefit of the human species. This is because He knew that humanity needs tools and necessities, and these tools can only exist through the presence of these ailments in this substance and its deviation from the path. Allah, the Glorified, intervened between physicians and the knowledge of removing these ailments from this substance, except for the trustworthy ones (الأمناء) among them, of whom Allah knew that they would preserve the wisdom as Allah placed it in the World. Thus, iron remains iron because of the benefits it contains that are not found in gold or other minerals. As the Exalted said: <<And We sent down iron>> (Qur’an 57:25), meaning He lowered it from the rank of perfection because of the benefits it holds for people. If it were cured of its sickness, it would become arrogant and elevated, and those benefits would not be found. And humanity, which is the intended Essence, would be deprived of the benefits related to iron that are found only in it. For in it, as Allah said, is <<mighty force and benefits for mankind>> (Qur’an 57:25). The same applies to all other minerals; they contain benefits for people, which have appeared and which humanity uses.

Look at how intense Allah’s care is for this human species, even though it is heedless of Allah, ungrateful for His blessings, and exposed to His vengeance. Since Allah knew that among the human world there are those whom Allah has deprived of trustworthiness and granted the spreading of Divine secrets, and it was predetermined in His Knowledge that this untrustworthy person would have his provision in the science of management (علم التدبير), He provided him with stinginess toward his fellow humans out of avarice, envy, and preciousness, lest anyone else be like him. So he abandons working with it, receiving neither reward nor Divine approval.

Furthermore, Allah multiplied the minerals and did not grant this person an effect except in what he possessed of them, and whatever little he might own of that. In that limited amount, his management and craft appear, so that the wise intellectuals may know that he is untrustworthy in what Allah gave him, for he was not granted permission for that by Allah. Then Allah instilled in kings a desire for that knowledge. If someone untrustworthy appears to them with it, they ask him for the knowledge. If he withholds it from them, they kill him out of envy and rage. If he gives them the knowledge of it, they kill him out of fear and jealousy. Since the knowledgeable person knows that he has no recourse with kings other than this, he does not reveal it to them or to the common people, lest news of him reach them—not out of trustworthiness, but out of fear for himself. Thus, no one who is completely knowledgeable in this craft has ever appeared, nor will they appear, due to Divine jealousy (غيرة إلهية), even if Allah has granted him trustworthiness in himself.

From this Divine Name (Al-Aziz) comes the existence of precious stones (الأحجار النفيسة) like rubies (اليواقيت) and pearls (اللآلي), such as chrysolite (زبرجد), emerald (زمرد), coral (مرجان), pearl (لؤلؤ), and spinel (بلخش). Allah placed in the power of man the ability to create all of this—meaning he is capable of forming the like of this from himself. This is called, among the saints (الأولياء), the breaking of habit (خرق عادة), and the stories regarding this are numerous. However, reaching this through the path of cultivation (التربية) and management (التدبير) is greater in rank in Divine matters than reaching it instantaneously through one's spiritual aspiration (همته) and sincerity. For the high honor lies in the knowledge of formation (التكوين), not in the formation itself, because formation only serves as an indication that the one from whom this formation occurred through management is knowledgeable. The one who performs the breaking of habit has no knowledge of the form that came into existence from him, nor of the modality of its formation in a short time, whereas the knowledgeable person knows that.

(Chapter Thirty-Three) Concerning the Divine Name Al-Razzaq (The Provider) and its orientation toward the creation of plants among the generated things. It is associated with the letter Thā’ (الثاء المعجمة بالثلاث) and the lunar mansion Sa‘d Bul‘. The Exalted said: <<Indeed, Allah is the Provider (الرَّزَّاقُ), Possessor of Strength, the Firm (ذُو الْقُوَّةِ الْمَتِينُ)>> (Qur’an 51:58). And He said: <<Have you considered the fire which you kindle? Is it you who produced the tree thereof, or are We the Producer? We have made it a reminder and a provision (مَتاعاً) for the travelers (لِلْمُقْوِينَ)>> (Qur’an 56:71-73). Thus, He made it a reminder for the knowledgeable.

[Due to the difference of the provided, the provisions differed]

The Name Al-Razzaq (The Provider) came in this intensive form (بنية للمبالغة) due to the diversity of provisions (الأرزاق). Despite their multiplicity and diversity, they originate from Him and not from another. The recipients of provision (المرزوقين) differ in their acceptance of provisions. What nourishes one animal may not be suitable for another, because the purpose of consuming provision is the survival of the recipient. If one eats what causes its death, it has not been nourished by it, nor is it provision for it, even if it sustains another. For this reason, the Name is designated with the intensive form. This Provider is described as Possessor of Strength, the Firm (ذُو الْقُوَّةِ الْمَتِينُ). If it were describing Allah (the Name *Allah*), it would be in the accusative case (ذا القوة المتين), but it is not possible to describe the Name *Allah* from the perspective of its indication, for it is comprehensive of opposites. Even though it appears in the wording, the intention is only a specific Name derived from it, which the context requires according to the reality of what is mentioned afterward, for the sake of which the Divine Name came. Thus, when the seeker of provision who is in need says, "O Allah, provide for me," and Allah is also the Withholder (المانع), he only seeks by his state the Name Al-Razzaq. In meaning, he only said, "O Provider, provide for me." Whoever desires a response from Allah in any matter should only ask Him by the specific Name related to that matter. He should not ask by a Name that implies both what he desires and its opposite, nor should he ask by the Name from the perspective of its indication of the Essence of the Named, but rather he should ask from the perspective of the meaning (المعنى) upon which the Name stands, for the sake of which it came and by which it is distinguished from other Names—a distinction of meaning, not a distinction of wording.

[Provisions are either conceptual or sensory]

Know that provisions are either conceptual (معنوي) or sensory (حسي). The recipients of provision are either intelligible (معقول) or sensible (محسوس). The provision of every recipient is that by which its survival and its enjoyment are maintained, if it is one who enjoys, and its life, if it is one described as living. Provisions do not belong to the one who gathers them, but to the one who is nourished by them. It is recounted that a moving man and a resting man met. The moving man said, "Provision is only obtained through movement." The resting man said, "Provision is obtained through movement and rest, and by what Allah wills, for Allah has already finished decreeing it." The moving man said, "Then I will move, and you stay still, so I can see who is provided for." The moving man moved, and when he opened the door, he found a grape. He said, "Praise be to Allah! I have defeated my companion." He entered upon the resting man joyfully and said to him, "O resting one, I moved and was provided for." He threw the grape to the resting man. The resting man took it, ate it, and praised Allah, saying, "O moving one, I rested and ate. Provision belongs to the one who is nourished by it, not to the one who brings it." The moving man was astonished by this and returned to the opinion of the resting man. The purpose of this story is that provision belongs to the one who is nourished by it.

The first provision that appeared from Al-Razzaq was that by which the Names were nourished—the manifestation of their effects in the World—and in which lay their survival, enjoyment, happiness, and joy. The first recipients of provision in Existence were the Names. Thus, the effect of the Names in the generated things (الأكوان) is their provision, by which they are nourished, and the survival of the Names depends on them. This is the meaning of their saying that Lordship (الربوبية) has a secret which, if revealed, Lordship would be invalidated. For the relation (الإضافة) is the survival of its essence in the two related things (المتضايفين), and the survival of the two related things, insofar as they are related, is only through the existence of the relation. Thus, the relation is the provision of the two related things, and by it is their nourishment and their survival as related things. This is part of the conceptual provision (الرزق المعنوي) bestowed by the Name Al-Razzaq.

Al-Razzaq is one of the recipients of provision; He is the first to be nourished by what He provided—He first provided for Himself, then He provided for the Names related to provision that is suitable for each Name, which is its effect in the intelligible and sensible World. Then, in the Divine Breath (النفس الإلهي), after the Names, He found the angelic spirits (الأرواح الملكية) and provided them with glorification (التسبيح). Then He descended to the First Intellect (العقل الأول) and nourished it with Divine Knowledge and the knowledge related to the World below it. Thus, He continued to descend from the essence of what is sought—that by which its survival and life are maintained—to an essence, until He encompassed the entire World with provision, thus becoming Al-Razzaq.

When He reached the plant kingdom and saw what it needed of specific provision, He gave it what nourishes it. He saw that most of its nourishment was in water, so He gave water to it and to every living thing in the World, making it provision for it. Then He made it provision for other animals. Thus, the plant and the animal are both provision and recipient of provision: it is provided for, so it is a recipient of provision, and it provides, so it is provision. Likewise, all animals are nourished and are nourished by others. All are provision and recipient of provision.

He only gave water as provision for every living thing because it is cold and moist, while the World, in its essence, is dominated by heat and dryness. The reason for this is that the World is held in a grip (قبض) from which it cannot escape, because it is a necessary Divine grip upon every possible thing, so it must be this way. Constriction (الانقباض) in the grasped thing is undoubtedly dryness. Thus, dryness dominates it. Due to the dominance of dryness, it inherently seeks what will soften and moisten it. You see it, from the perspective of its dryness, needing moisture. As for its need for coldness, the World is created upon the Image (الصورة), and it saw that whoever is created upon His Image is absolute Existence (مطلق الوجود) and does what He wills. So the World desired to be of this status and to escape the grip upon it, to be free-flowing (مسرح العين), not grasped in generation and possibility. Possibility rejects this, but the Image gives it the power for this seeking. When it does not attain what it seeks, frustration (الغبن) overtakes it, and it heats up. Heat dominates it, and it suffers. It fears annihilation (الانعدام), so it inclines toward seeking coldness to soothe the pain of the heat it finds and to revive itself. The dryness of the grip upon it seeks moisture.

The Name Al-Razzaq looked for nourishment by which the World could live, which would be cold, to counteract the heat and its dominion, and moist, to counteract the dominion of dryness. He found water to be cold and moist, so He made from it every living thing, in every category, according to what suits it. The Exalted said: <<And We made from water every living thing. Will they not then believe?>> (Qur’an 21:30). That is, will they not affirm this? Faith (الإيمان) is only coupled with it because of the rational possibility of the opposite of what is real: that if the opposite of what dominates it were to dominate it, it would destroy it. Therefore, its life must be in the opposite of what dominates it. Do you not see that if coldness and moisture dominated it, it would perish, and its life would only be through heat and dryness? In that case, it would be said, "And We made from fire every living thing." If coldness and dryness dominated it, its life would be through air, and it would be said, "And We made from air every living thing." If heat and moisture were excessive in it, its life would be through earth, and it would be said, "And We made from earth every living thing." This is what the division allows in this case, if it were to happen. Since the reality in the World is the dominance of heat and dryness, for the reason of the Image and the Grip we mentioned, the dominion of heat and dryness arose against it. Thus, its life was only possible through something cold and moist, which was water. So He said: <<And We made from water every living thing. Will they not then believe?>> (Qur’an 21:30). They should look into our saying "from water" and know the nature of water and its effect, and upon whom it acts, and what it repels, so that they know that the World is described by the opposite of what water necessitates, and He judges it by that. The observer thus knows the nature of the medicine (الدواء) with which to counteract the nature of the illness that has afflicted this patient. The Breath of the All-Merciful relieved him of what this patient was suffering. This is from the Breath of the All-Merciful.

All provisions, according to the verifier (المحقق), are medicines, because the entire World fears destruction (التلف) for itself, since its essence appeared from non-existence and has fallen in love with Existence. If something arises in it which, if it dominates, could return it to non-existence, it quickly seeks what will ensure its survival and remove the law of its sickness or the expectation of its sickness. That is its provision by which it lives, and its medicine in which is its healing, whatever type of individual it may be. Everything that accepts growth is a plant, and that by which it grows is its provision.

[Provision is either lawful or unlawful]

Provision is of two types in the Balance (الميزان) established in the World for the establishment of justice, which is the Divine Law (الشرع). One type is called unlawful (حرام), and the other is called lawful (حلال), which is the remainder of Allah (بقية الله) explicitly mentioned in the Qur’an. The Exalted said: <<The remainder of Allah is better for you, if you are believers>> (Qur’an 11:86). This is what remained for the believers from His saying: <<He created for you all that is on earth>> (Qur’an 2:29). Faith (الإيمان) only occurs through the Divine Law, and this saying came in the story of Shu‘ayb, the master of the Balance and the Measure. This is knowledge derived from Divine information.

Al-Razzaq is the one who holds this key. Provision, according to some scholars, includes everything by which nourishment occurs, whether lawful or unlawful, for Allah says: <<There is no creature on earth except that its provision is due from Allah>> (Qur’an 11:6)—this is apparent, not explicit text. And He said: <<So leave it to eat in Allah’s earth>> (Qur’an 7:73), and <<Allah provides for whom He wills without reckoning>> (Qur’an 2:212). Yet, He forbade us from consuming the unlawful. If Allah’s provision included the unlawful, He would not have forbidden it to us. Therefore, the unlawful is not Allah’s provision. Rather, it is provision, but Allah’s provision is the lawful (الحلال), which is the remainder of Allah that He left for us after the imposition of restriction (التحجير) and the prohibition of certain provisions upon us.

You should know, from the perspective of reality, that the address (الخطاب) relates only to the act of the responsible agent (فعل المكلف), not to the essence of the thing whose disposal is prohibited. Everything is Allah’s provision, but the consumer (المتناول) is the one restricted, not the consumed (المتناول). For Al-Razzaq only gives you your provision, and what Al-Razzaq gives cannot be faulted. For this reason, blame is attached to the act of the responsible agent, not to the essence whose consumption was restricted. For the Owner of the essence did not restrict its consumption, and the unlawful is not owned. This is an issue that has been greatly confused among the scholars of external forms (علماء الرسوم). As for His saying: <<So eat of what Allah has provided for you, lawful and good>> (Qur’an 16:114)—the active agent (العامل) in the state is apparent in the Divine Law to be "He provided for you" (رزقكم). For the word *min* (مِنْ) in His saying *mimmā razaqakumu Llāh* (مِمَّا رَزَقَكُمُ الله) is for clarification (التبيين), not for partiality (التبعيض), because partiality is useless here, as it is realized by the intuition of the intellect that it is not within ordinary capacity to eat all provision. Since it is for clarification and relates to "eat" (كلوا), it clarifies that Allah’s provision is the lawful and good. If one eats what is forbidden to him, he has not eaten Allah’s provision. Reflect upon this.

Look at what sustains your life; that is necessarily your provision, and no restriction can apply to it, whether it is owned by another or not. This is a hint summarizing the issue, which the Name Al-Razzaq seeks. For the one who is compelled (المضطر) has no restriction upon him. As for anyone other than the compelled, he has not consumed the provision for the survival of life, but rather for enjoyment. Provision is only that by which his life is sustained. I have alerted your mind to a decisive point that cannot be rejected by any scholar of the Divine Law, for Allah says: <<But whoever is compelled, neither desiring [it] nor transgressing>> (Qur’an 2:173) after the restriction, and He said: <<Except what you are compelled to [eat]>> (Qur’an 6:119). That is the provision we are discussing, and it is what Al-Razzaq gives. May Allah make us among the recipients of provision who are not provision themselves, for Allah caused us to grow from the earth.

Then know that movements in plants are of three types. The head of the plant is what seeks movement. Wherever it turns among the directions, it is attributed to them. If it faces the opposite direction, it is considered inverted (نكسا) in its regard. Scholars considered the directions based on the existence of man, making straightness (الاستقامة) in his formation and movement toward his head. They called his movement straight (مستقيمة). Every plant moves toward the direction of its head. Every movement that opposes the movement of man in its direction is called inverted (منكوسة)—that is the movement of trees. If the movement is between the two, such that the moving thing faces the horizon with its head, its movement is horizontal (أفقية).

The plant that has no sensation (حس) but has growth (النمو), all its movement is inverted, unlike the trees of Paradise, for the movement of the plants of Paradise is straight (مستقيمة) due to the manifestation of their life, for Paradise is the Abode of Life (دار الحيوان). The plant that has sensation is of two types: one that has straight movement, like man, and one that has horizontal movement, like the animal. Between them are intermediaries, being the beginning of man and the end of the animal, such that it does not possess the full strength of man nor does the law of the animal remain upon it, like the ape and the wild man (النسناس). Likewise, between the animal and the plant is an intermediary, like the palm tree, and between the mineral and the plant is an intermediary, like the truffle (الكمأة). The movement of the plant is inverted, and it is either formed (مخلقة) or unformed (غير مخلقة). The formed is called a tree (شجر), which is every plant that stands upon a stalk. The unformed is called a star/herb (نجم), which is every plant that does not stand upon a stalk but merely emerges and appears upon the surface of the earth. This is His saying: <<And the star and the tree prostrate>> (Qur’an 55:6)—meaning what stands upon a stalk among plants and what does not stand upon a stalk. The completion of creation in the plant is standing upon a stalk. Therefore, the star/herb is unformed, just as it came in the creation of man, concerning creation from a drop of sperm, in His saying: <<then from a piece of flesh, formed (مُخَلَّقَةٍ) and unformed (غَيْرِ مُخَلَّقَةٍ)>> (Qur’an 22:5). All of this falls under the law of "He gave everything its creation" (أعطى كل شي‏ء خلقه). So He gave the unformed its creation just as He gave the formed its creation, just as the existence of deficiency is part of the perfection of Existence.

When scholars judged the movement of the plant according to what we established—as inverted—they did not give insight its due. Rather, its movement, in our view, is straight, for it only moves for growth (النمو). No animal or human moves with this movement for growth except by virtue of its being a plant. It is not said of the plant that its movements are diverse insofar as it is a plant. Movements only differ when they are for something other than growth, such as movements in directions. Movements in directions by a moving entity are only a relation of the will to move that body from the mover. The mover may be the moving entity itself, such as voluntary movement (حركة الاختيار), or the movement in the moving entity may be from another mover, and that other mover has another, until it ends at the Mover or the one moving with intention (بالقصد) for what appeared from these movements.

As for movement for increase in bodies, it stems from the body being a plant, whether in an animal or otherwise. It is a single movement, which is the movement originating from the seed (البزرة) from which the body appeared, through the movement of growth (النماء). It expands in all directions according to the sustenance (الإمداد) provided in that direction. Its movement toward the right may yield less growth than its movement upward, and so on for the rest. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, informed us that the formation (النشأة) stands upon the coccyx (عجب الذنب). What appears as the leg, shank, thigh, and buttocks is from inverted movement. What appears from the coccyx up to the head is from straight movement. What appears in expansion toward the right, left, back, and front is from horizontal movement. All of this, in our view, is straight movement.

The only inverted movement, in our view, is every movement in a moving entity that contradicts what its nature necessitates. This only occurs in compulsory movement (الحركة القهرية), not in natural movement (الحركة الطبيعية). When every body moves toward its greatest part, that is its natural, straight movement, like the movement of the flame toward the Aether (الأثير) and the body of the stone toward the earth. If the fiery body moves toward the earth and the lower regions, and the stone moves toward the upper regions, the movement is inverted, and it is compulsory movement (الحركة القسرية). When growth ends in a body such that the body no longer accepts it in the direction it does not accept, and then that body moves in that direction, its movement is not a movement of planting or growth—like a body that has reached its maximum length in a specific direction. It has no movement of growth in that direction. If it moves in the direction of length, it moves with its entirety, not for length, but for transition from its place to the place of length, downward or upward. Look at what we verified regarding the movement of the plant: that it is not inverted movement. For the seed extends branches upward and extends branches downward. The plant does not take its nourishment from the branches below, called roots (أصولا). Rather, the plant takes nourishment from the seed from which these branches appeared. For this reason, dryness occurs in some lower branches, just as it occurs in the visible branches that bear leaves and fruit, while growth and life exist in the remaining veins and branches, just as blood is divided from the liver into the rest of the organs, upward and downward.

What should be said regarding conceptual and sensory movements is that they are three movements: Movement from the Center (حركة من الوسط), which imparts what appeared from the origin (الأصل) from which natural bodies arise; Movement toward the Center (حركة إلى الوسط), which is the Divine Sustenance (الإمداد الإلهي); and Movement in the Center (حركة في الوسط), which is the survival of the essence of the origin. There is no plant except that it is both medicine (دواء) and poison (داء)—meaning it contains benefit and harm according to the acceptance of bodily temperaments (الأمزجة البدنية) and their state of preparedness. What is harmful to some temperaments is the very thing that is beneficial to the temperament of others. If the effect were due to the essence of the plant, its law would not differ. Rather, the effect is due to the recipient (القابل), and the recipient is a plant, just as the plant itself is a plant. It only affects itself with harm or benefit insofar as it is a plant, even if its individuals are numerous and distinguished by individuality. We have alerted you by this to the essences of the individuals of the World and how some affect others, while the Essence is one by its essential definition (بالحد الذاتي) but multiple by accidental forms. I have informed you elsewhere who the manifest Essence of the World is, and that its substance is unchanging, and to whom belongs the law by which change appeared in this Essence—it is like the appearance of change in the forms of the mirror due to the change in the postures of the viewer, or it may be due to the change of the Theophanies (المتجليات) themselves, and the mirror is the locus of that manifestation for the eye of the viewer. The Cloud (العماء), which is the Divine Soul (النفس الإلهي), is the Receptacle for all these forms. Know that. <<And Allah speaks the Truth, and He guides to the Way>> (Qur’an 33:4).

(Chapter Thirty-Four) Concerning the Divine Name Al-Mudhill (The Humiliator/Subduer) and its orientation toward the creation of animals. It is associated with the letter Dhāl (الذال المعجمة) and the lunar mansion Sa‘d al-Su‘ūd. The Exalted said: <<And We have subdued them (ذَلَّلْناها) for them, so from them is their riding and from them they eat>> (Qur’an 36:72). And He said: <<And He has subjected to you whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth—all from Him>> (Qur’an 45:13). Thus, the animal kingdom is included in that.

[Allah made the animal kingdom subservient to man by the Name Al-Mudhill]

This is the law of the Name Al-Mudhill (The Subduer) in the World through subjugation (التسخير), even within the subjugated entity itself. Allah made some parts of it subservient to others, stemming from the Name Al-Mudhill. For the origin of all things is created from the earth, which is submissive (الذلول) by Divine decree, just as it is mighty (العزيزة) by its origin. He made the reason for the subjugation of some to others, despite the World being subjugated to us, the elevation of some of us above others in degrees, which the subjugated entity needs. The Exalted said: <<And We have raised some of them above others in degrees, so that some may take others into service (سُخْرِيًّا)>> (Qur’an 43:32).

Know, may Allah support you with a spirit from Him, that I only speak about these existent things in this Divine Breath (النفس الإلهي) from the perspective of the law of the Divine Name I mention, specifically concerning that existent thing in the World, and some of the effect that Name has within it.

[That subjugation may be humiliation, or it may be for the fulfillment of the immediate needs of the subjugated]

Know that subjugation (التسخير) may be a form of debasement (إذلال) or it may be for the fulfillment of the immediate need (بالحال) of the one for whom the subjugation is enacted. This is the distinction between the two types of subjugation, based on the reality (حقيقة) of the subjugator and the subjugated.

The servant, who is the human, is subjugated to his horse and beast, in that he must attend to its watering, feeding, and checking its conditions, which ensures its well-being, health, and life. Conversely, the beast is subjugated to him by way of debasement (إذلال) for carrying his burdens, for riding, and for his utilization of it for his own interests.

The same applies within the human species through the elevation of degrees (الدرجات) among them. By virtue of rank, some subjugate others. The rank of the king necessitates that he subjugates his subjects to his will by way of debasement (إذلال) for the fulfillment of his interests, due to his need for them. Conversely, the rank of the subjects and common people necessitates that they subjugate the king for their protection, defense, fighting their enemies, and judging disputes and seeking rights among them. This latter is a subjugation of fulfillment (سخرية قيام), not a subjugation of debasement (سخرية إذلال), necessitated by the rank of the common people and the rank of the king. The Abaser (المذل) among the Divine Names (الأسماء) is the Ruler (الحاكم) in both instances.

Then the Unveiling (الكشف) concerning this matter brings forth a marvelous thing, which the Quran speaks of and direct witnessing (العيان) confirms. He said: <<وَهُوَ اللهُ فِي السَّمَاوَاتِ وَفِي الْأَرْضِ>> (And He is Allah in the heavens and in the earth). And He said: <<وَسَخَّرَ لَكُمْ مَا فِي السَّمَاوَاتِ وَمَا فِي الْأَرْضِ جَمِيعًا مِنْهُ>> (And He has subjected to you whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth—all from Him). And Luqman said to his son: <<يَا بُنَيَّ إِنَّهَا إِنْ تَكُ مِثْقَالَ حَبَّةٍ مِنْ خَرْدَلٍ فَتَكُنْ فِي صَخْرَةٍ أَوْ فِي السَّمَاوَاتِ أَوْ فِي الْأَرْضِ يَأْتِ بِهَا اللهُ>> (O my son, indeed if it should be the weight of a mustard seed and should be in a rock or in the heavens or in the earth, Allah will bring it forth). For He is in the earth, and He is in the heaven, and He is in the rock, and He is with us wherever we are. The Creator (الخالق) does not separate from the created (المخلوق), and the Abaser (المذل) does not separate from the act of debasement (الإذلال), for if He were to separate from it, this description would leave Him, and that Name (الاسم) would cease to exist.

And the Exalted said: <<وَمَا خَلَقْتُ الْجِنَّ وَالْإِنْسَ إِلَّا لِيَعْبُدُونِ>> (And I did not create the jinn and mankind except to worship Me)—meaning, that they should humble themselves (يتذللوا) to Me. And they do not humble themselves to Me unless they know My station and My might. Thus, He created them by the Name The Abaser (المذل) because He created them for His worship. He described Himself as The Self-Subsisting (القيوم), the One who stands <<عَلَىٰ كُلِّ نَفْسٍ بِمَا كَسَبَتْ>> (over every soul by what it has earned). And He said: <<وَلَا يَئُودُهُ حِفْظُهُمَا>> (And the preservation of both [the heavens and the earth] does not weary Him). Thus, He described Himself as preserving what is in the heavens and the earth. By virtue of rank (الدرجة), He is the Preserver of the Existence (الوجود) that the Cosmos (العالم) requires to be maintained upon it, and by virtue of rank, the Cosmos is preserved for Him.

If you know that the master subjugates his slave by rank (الدرجة), and the slave subjugates his master by immediate need (الحال), and that the master does what he does for the slave not by way of compulsion or debasement (الإذلال) from the slave, but rather for the confirmation of his own mastery over him—then he only subjugated himself to the slave for his own benefit. Do you not see that the Name "Master" (السيد) is removed from the master if he sells his slave or if the slave perishes? Look then at the marvelous ruling of this Name (الاسم).

This Name (المذل) was specified for the animal because the ruling of intention (القصد) is manifest in it, and because it is ready to refuse due to the will (الإرادة) it possesses. When the Name The Abaser (المذل) was directed toward it, its rule fell under the rule of one who has neither will nor power (in relation to the animal), due to the might (العزة) that these two attributes (will and power) grant to the one who possesses them. Thus, Allah made whomever He willed possess the attribute of need (الافتقار), destitution (الفاقة), and want (الحاجة), so that he is humbled before every humble thing in which he sees a need that he requires and for which he descends from the rank of his might. Allah bound Existence (الوجود) upon this principle, and through it came the well-being (صلاح) of the World (العالم). There is no Name among the Names (الأسماء) that grants general well-being in the World, nor one that holds sway in the Divine Presence (الحضرة الإلهية), like this Name, The Abaser (المذل). Its ruling is perpetually active in this world and the Hereafter. The gnostic (العارف) whom the Real (الحق) establishes in the witnessing (مشاهدة) of this Name, and to whom He discloses Himself through it and from it, is the happiest of Allah’s servants in Allah and the most knowledgeable of Allah’s secrets through Unveiling (الكشف). This much allusion in this chapter is sufficient for the knowledge of Divine and cosmic subjugation (التسخير), for it links the master to the servants and the servants to the master. <<وَاللهُ يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وَهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (And Allah speaks the Truth, and He guides to the way).

***

### Chapter Thirty-Five: Concerning the Divine Name The Strong (القوي)

Its direction is toward the creation of the Angels. It is associated with the letter Fāʾ (ف) and the lunar mansion Saʿd al-Akhbiya. Allah the Exalted said: <<عَلَيْهَا مَلَائِكَةٌ غِلَاظٌ شِدَادٌ>> (Over it are angels, stern and severe). And concerning the angels, He said: <<وَيَفْعَلُونَ مَا يُؤْمَرُونَ>> (And they do what they are commanded). And He said: <<لَا يُكَلِّفُ اللهُ نَفْسًا إِلَّا وُسْعَهَا وَإِلَّا مَا آتَاهَا>> (Allah does not charge a soul except [with that within] its capacity and except with what He has given it). The command (*al-amr*) is an imposition (تكليف). Thus, strength appeared in the angels through the aid of the Name The Strong (القوي), for He supplied them with His strength.

There is nothing in the created World (العالم) possessing greater strength than the woman, due to a secret known only to those who know how the World came into existence, by what movement the Real (الحق) brought it forth, and that it arose from two premises, being a result. The one who marries (the male) is the seeker (طالب), and the seeker is needy (مفتقر). The one who is married (the female) is the sought (مطلوب), and the sought possesses the might (عزة) of being needed, and desire (الشهوة) is overwhelming. Thus, the station of the woman among existing things has become clear to you, as well as what aspect of the Divine Presence (الحضرة الإلهية) looks upon her, and by what means her strength is manifest.

Allah drew attention to the strength He specifically granted her in His saying concerning Aisha and Hafsa: <<وَإِنْ تَظَاهَرَا عَلَيْهِ>> (And if you cooperate against him)—meaning, if you assist one another against him—<<فَإِنَّ اللهَ هُوَ مَوْلَاهُ وَجِبْرِيلُ وَصَالِحُ الْمُؤْمِنِينَ وَالْمَلَائِكَةُ بَعْدَ ذَلِكَ ظَهِيرٌ>> (Then indeed Allah is his Protector, and Gabriel and the righteous among the believers and the angels, moreover, are his supporters). All this is in opposition to two women! And He mentioned none but the strong ones who possess severity and power. Indeed, the righteous believers act by spiritual resolve (الهمة), which is the strongest of actions. If you have understood this, you have been cast upon the path. Thus, He placed the angels, after mentioning Himself, Gabriel, and the righteous believers, in the rank of helpers. <<وَلَا قُوَّةَ إِلَّا بِاللهِ>> (And there is no power except with Allah). This indicates that the regard of the Name The Strong (القوي) toward the angels is stronger in establishing power in them than in others, for He brought them into existence from Himself. Whoever is sought for aid is stronger in the matter for which aid is sought than the one who seeks aid. Therefore, every angel whom Allah created from the breaths of women is the strongest of the angels, for he originates from the breath of the strongest. Thus, the direction of the Divine Name The Strong (القوي) in establishing power upon the creation of the angels of women’s breaths granted them greater strength than all other angels.

### Angels are distinguished by strength because they are Lights

The angels were distinguished by strength because they are lights (أنوار). There is nothing stronger than light, for it is the means of manifestation (الظهور), and through it is manifestation. Everything is in need of manifestation, and there is no manifestation for anything except through light in the higher and lower Worlds (العالم). The Exalted said: <<اللهُ نُورُ السَّمَاوَاتِ وَالْأَرْضِ>> (Allah is the Light of the heavens and the earth). It is related that when the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was asked, "Did you see your Lord?" he replied: "A Light (نوراني); how could I see Him?" And he said: "The splendors (سبحات) of His Face would burn up everything reached by His sight of His creation." The splendors (السبحات) are the lights (الأنوار); they are what manifest things and enrich them. Since the shadow (الظل) cannot remain before the light, and the World (العالم) is a shadow and the Real (الحق) is Light, the World therefore undergoes annihilation (الفناء) of its self when the Theophany (التجلي) occurs. For the Theophany is Light, and the witnessing (شهود) of the self is a shadow. Thus, the viewer to whom the Theophany is granted is annihilated (يفنى) from witnessing his own self upon seeing Allah. When the Veil (الحجاب) is lowered, the shadow appears, and the enjoyment of the witnessed object occurs. This chapter contains a great knowledge that cannot be spoken, nor can its secret be divulged—the knowledge of the emanation of the World, the knowledge of modality. <<وَاللهُ يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وَهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (And Allah speaks the Truth, and He guides to the way).

***

### Chapter Thirty-Six: Concerning the Divine Name The Subtle (اللطيف)

Its direction is toward the creation of the Jinn. It is associated with the letter Bāʾ (ب) and the lunar mansion Muqaddam min al-Dālī. Allah the Exalted said concerning the Jinn: <<إِنَّهُ يَرَاكُمْ هُوَ وَقَبِيلُهُ مِنْ حَيْثُ لَا تَرَوْنَهُمْ>> (Indeed, he sees you, he and his tribe, from where you do not see them). Thus, He described them with subtlety (اللطافة). Allah created them from <<مَارِجٍ مِنْ نَارٍ>> (a smokeless flame of fire). *Al-Marj* (the blending) is the mixing; thus, they are composed of fire mixed with the moisture of materials, which is why they manifest a flame, which is the ignition of air, making them hot and moist. The devils (الشياطين) among the Jinn are the wretched ones (الأشقياء) specifically distanced from Allah’s mercy. The fortunate ones retain the Name Jinn. They are a creation between the angels and mankind (الإنسان), who is elemental (*ʿunṣurī*). This is why [Iblis] was arrogant; had he been purely natural without the ruling of the element, he would not have been arrogant and would have been like the angels. The Jinn possess a nature of the Isthmus (برزخي النشأة); they have a face toward the luminous spirits (الأرواح النورية) due to the subtlety of the fire within them, which grants them concealment (الحجاب) and transformation (التشكل). They also have a face toward us, by which they are elemental and blended (*mārij*).

The Name The Subtle (اللطيف) granted the Jinn the ability to flow through the son of Adam like blood, without him perceiving it. Were it not for the warning of the Lawgiver (الشارع) regarding the touch of the devil (لمة الشيطان) and his whispering (*waswasa*) in the breasts of people, none but the People of Unveiling (أهل الكشف) would know that a devil exists. Among the rulings of this Name The Subtle (اللطيف) concerning the devils among the Jinn is the saying of the Exalted to Iblis: <<وَاسْتَفْزِزْ مَنِ اسْتَطَعْتَ مِنْهُمْ بِصَوْتِكَ وَأَجْلِبْ عَلَيْهِمْ بِخَيْلِكَ وَرَجِلِكَ وَشَارِكْهُمْ فِي الْأَمْوَالِ وَالْأَوْلَادِ وَعِدْهُمْ>> (And incite [to senselessness] whoever you can among them with your voice and assault them with your cavalry and infantry and share with them in [their] wealth and [their] children and promise them). Iblis said: <<فَبِعِزَّتِكَ لَأُغْوِيَنَّهُمْ أَجْمَعِينَ إِلَّا عِبَادَكَ مِنْهُمُ الْمُخْلَصِينَ>> (By Your might, I will surely mislead them all, except Your sincere servants among them)—meaning those whom the Real (الحق) has chosen for Himself. Thus, out of His Subtlety (لطفه), He made for Iblis a point of attachment by which he may cling in a specific station known to the Gnostics of Allah (العارفون بالله).

### The Devil Promises Them Poverty

Then Allah informed us that the devil promises them poverty, based on His saying: <<وَعِدْهُمْ>> (And promise them). Thus, He included Mercy (الرحمة) in a way that Iblis did not perceive. Had Iblis perceived this Rahmanic gradual enticement (الاستدراج الرحماني), he would not have sought mercy from the source of the Divine Favor (المنة). However, the circumstances of the states (قرائن الأحوال) veiled him from considering the Real (الحق) as the attribute of the Divine Command (الأمر الإلهي). The Name The Subtle (اللطيف) bequeathed to the Jinn concealment (الاستتار) from the eyes of people, so that sight does not perceive them unless they materialize. It also made their hearing of the Quran, when recited to them, better than the hearing of mankind, for the human came into existence through the Comprehensive Name (الاسم الجامع) and was not created exclusively by the Divine Name The Subtle (اللطيف) apart from its corresponding Names.

When the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, recited Surah Ar-Rahman to them, they did not hear the verse <<فَبِأَيِّ آلَاءِ رَبِّكُمَا تُكَذِّبَانِ>> (Then which of the favors of your Lord will you deny?) without saying, "We deny none of Your favors, our Lord." Then, the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, recited it afterward to the humans among his Companions, but no such utterance emerged from them during the recitation as emerged from the Jinn. So the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said to his Companions, "I recited this Surah to the Jinn, and they were better listeners to it than you," and he mentioned the rest of the Hadith. Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, commands: <<وَإِذَا قُرِئَ الْقُرْآنُ فَاسْتَمِعُوا لَهُ وَأَنْصِتُوا>> (And when the Quran is recited, listen to it and pay attention). And He informed us about the Jinn, saying: <<وَإِذْ صَرَفْنَا إِلَيْكَ نَفَرًا مِنَ الْجِنِّ يَسْتَمِعُونَ الْقُرْآنَ فَلَمَّا حَضَرُوهُ قَالُوا أَنْصِتُوا فَلَمَّا قُضِيَ وَلَّوْا إِلَىٰ قَوْمِهِمْ مُنْذِرِينَ قَالُوا يَا قَوْمَنَا إِنَّا سَمِعْنَا كِتَابًا أُنْزِلَ مِنْ بَعْدِ مُوسَىٰ مُصَدِّقًا لِمَا بَيْنَ يَدَيْهِ يَهْدِي إِلَى الْحَقِّ وَإِلَىٰ طَرِيقٍ مُسْتَقِيمٍ يَا قَوْمَنَا أَجِيبُوا دَاعِيَ اللهِ وَآمِنُوا بِهِ يَغْفِرْ لَكُمْ مِنْ ذُنُوبِكُمْ وَيُجِرْكُمْ مِنْ عَذَابٍ أَلِيمٍ>> (And [mention, O Muhammad], when We directed to you a group of the Jinn, listening to the Quran. And when they attended it, they said, "Listen quietly." And when it was concluded, they went back to their people as warners. They said, "O our people, indeed we have heard a Scripture revealed after Moses, confirming what was before it, guiding to the truth and to a straight path. O our people, respond to the caller of Allah and believe in Him; He will forgive you your sins and protect you from a painful punishment). Allah neither said nor was it narrated that any human said such a thing. Thus, the Name The Subtle (اللطيف) produced these effects in the believers among them and the devils.

Has it been narrated that any human disbeliever made a statement like that of Iblis, which is his saying: <<بِمَا أَغْوَيْتَنِي لَأُزَيِّنَنَّ لَهُمْ فِي الْأَرْضِ وَلَأُغْوِيَنَّهُمْ أَجْمَعِينَ إِلَّا عِبَادَكَ مِنْهُمُ الْمُخْلَصِينَ>> (Because You have put me in error, I will surely make [evil] attractive to them on earth and I will surely mislead them all, except Your sincere servants among them)? This was after Allah said to him: <<إِنَّ عِبَادِي لَيْسَ لَكَ عَلَيْهِمْ سُلْطَانٌ>> (Indeed, My servants—you have no authority over them). This cut off his despair of having authority and rule over them. They are the protected (المعصومون) and preserved, inwardly and outwardly, from intentionally violating Allah’s sanctity. The thoughts (*khawāṭir*) of the protected and preserved are either Lordly (ربانية), angelic (ملكية), or psychic (نفسية). The sign of this in the protected person is that he finds no hesitation (تردد) between performing or abandoning an obligatory duty (*wājib*), though he may find hesitation between the recommended (*mandūb*) and the disliked (*makrūh*), but not in abandoning an obligatory duty—he finds no hesitation in that. This is because hesitation in these two matters (obligatory duty and its abandonment) comes from the thought of the devil. Whoever finds this sign in himself knows that he is protected. Iblis’s saying, "I will surely mislead them," stems from his characterization of Allah’s saying, "Because You have put me in error." And the beautification (*tazyīn*) he brought forth comes from the command, "And promise them," for it is implied therein. Thus, in his actions concerning the servants, he did not depart from the Subtle Command (الأمر اللطيف) which the circumstances of the states (قرائن الأحوال) render as a threat and warning. The manifest aspect (الظاهر) is connected to the ruling due to the establishment of the All-Merciful (الرحمن) upon the Throne and the vastness and universality of Mercy (الرحمة), which rules over everything. And from its ruling was His saying: <<وَاسْتَفْزِزْ مَنِ اسْتَطَعْتَ>> (And incite whoever you can), and the rest of the verses. Ponder, O friend, the ruling of this Name (الاسم) concerning the Jinn, both their believers and their disbelievers. If you are not among the People of Unveiling and Existence (أهل الكشف والوجود), then follow what Allah mentioned in the Quran regarding their news and the accounts of their actions and sayings, both their believers and their disbelievers.

Among the effects of the Name The Subtle (اللطيف) was the subtlety of Iblis toward Adam in his saying: <<هَلْ أَدُلُّكَ عَلَىٰ شَجَرَةِ الْخُلْدِ وَمُلْكٍ لَا يَبْلَىٰ>> (Shall I guide you to the tree of eternity and a kingdom that will not fade?). Adam believed him, though Iblis was the liar. His only lie was in his saying, <<أَنَا خَيْرٌ مِنْهُ>> (I am better than him), which he then justified by saying, <<خَلَقْتَنِي مِنْ نَارٍ>> (You created me from fire). Thus, he combined ignorance and falsehood, for he is not better than Adam, neither in the sight of Allah nor in the nature of existence (النشأة). He made a distinction between the elements, though there is no distinction between them in their realities (الحقائق). Thus, he was subtle in misleading, with the subtlety of one who gradually entices, the cunning one in his cunning, and the deceiver in his deception.

> The Subtle (اللطيف) among the Names is known,
> And His Subtlety is manifest, marked upon creation.
> He is The Subtle, yet He does not appear to our gaze,
> And how can the subtlety of the Essence (الذات) be grasped, being non-existent [to the senses]?
> The Subtlety of The Subtle toward us is an attribute for Him and for us,
> So Subtlety is decreed upon Him in His very Essence.

### The Form of the Fiery Spirit is Unknown to Humans

Know that the fiery spirits (الأرواح النارية), in their corporeal form, are closer in suitability for the Divine Theophany (التجلي الإلهي) in the forms witnessed by the eye than the human body. And whatever is closer in relation to that Divine Presence is stronger in subtlety (اللطافة) than what is further away. Thus, the form of the fiery spirit remains unknown to humans; it is known only through Divine information (إعلام إلهي), for that is information into which nothing that removes it from truthfulness can enter.
