The same applies to information from the angelic spirits (الأرواح الملكية). However, if the information came from the Jinn, we would not trust it because they are elemental (عنصري) in origin, and every elemental existent accepts transformation (الاستحالة) like its origin. But the existent that arises directly from Nature (الطبيعة) without mediation does not accept transformation; therefore, falsehood does not enter its reports. Their subtlety (لطافته) concealed them until their form became unknown. If you ask, "Why were the angelic spirits assigned the Divine Name The Strong (القوي) despite the subtlety they possess from the Divine Name The Subtle (اللطيف)?" We reply: You speak truly, so that you may know that I only intended the specific Divine Name (الاسم الإلهي) in the creation of a certain class of contingent beings (الممكنات) because that Name is the most dominant (الأغلب) over it, and its ruling is the most effective therein. Nevertheless, there is no contingent being that comes into existence except that the Divine Names related to the cosmos (الأكوان) have an effect in it, but some are stronger than others and have a greater ruling in that specific contingent being. For this reason, we attribute it to that Name, just as Saturday is attributed to the lord of the Seventh Heaven, and Sunday to the lord of the Fourth Heaven, and so on, each day to the lord of a heaven. Despite this, the lord of every heaven has a ruling and effect on every day, but the lord of the day to which we attribute it has a greater and stronger ruling therein than others. Know this. <<وَاللهُ يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وَهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (And Allah speaks the Truth, and He guides to the way).

***

### Chapter Thirty-Seven: Concerning the Divine Name The Comprehensive (الجامع)

Its direction is toward the creation of Man (الإنسان). It is associated with the letter Mīm (م) and the lunar mansion Al-Farʿ al-Mu’akhkhar. The Comprehensive Name (الاسم الجامع) is Allah. For this reason, Allah gathered for the creation of Adam’s body between His two Hands, saying: <<لِمَا خَلَقْتُ بِيَدَيَّ>> (To that which I created with My two hands). As for Allah creating the heaven with *ayd* (أيد), that refers to strength, for *al-ayd* (الأيد) means strength. The Exalted said: <<دَاوُودَ ذَا الْأَيْدِ>> (David, the possessor of strength), not the plural of *yad* (hand). It is mentioned in the Hadith of Adam that he said, "I chose the right hand of my Lord, and both of my Lord’s hands are blessed right hands."

When Allah willed the perfection of this human existence (النشأة الإنسانية), He gathered for it between His two Hands and granted it all the realities (حقائق) of the World (العالم). He disclosed Himself to it through all the Names (الأسماء), so it acquired the Divine Form (الصورة الإلهية) and the Cosmic Form (الصورة الكونية). He made it the spirit (روح) for the World, and He made the classes of the World like the limbs of a body for the spirit that governs it. If this human were to depart from the World, the World would die. Just as when a part of the body is departed from, that departure is like numbness (*khadar*) for that limb of the body, and that limb becomes useless because the sensitive, growing spirit has left it. Similarly, the world (الدنيا) becomes useless upon the departure of Man. The worldly abode (الدار الدنيا) is a limb among the limbs of the body of the World, of which Man is the spirit. Since Man possesses this Comprehensive Name (الاسم الجامع), he is able to face both Presences (الحضرتين) with his Essence (ذاته), thus validating his Vicegerency (الخلافة), the governance of the World, and its detailed arrangement. If a human does not attain the rank of perfection (الكمال), he is merely an animal whose outward form resembles the human form. Our discussion here is about the Perfect Human (الإنسان الكامل).

### Allah Created the Human Species Perfect

Indeed, Allah did not create the first of this species except as the Perfect One, who is Adam, peace be upon him. Then the Real (الحق) made clear the rank of perfection (الكمال) for this species. Whoever attains it is the Human (الإنسان) whom He intended. Whoever falls short of that rank possesses humanity only according to what remains for him. Among all existing things, there is none that contains the Real (الحق) except him, and he contained Him only by accepting the Form (الصورة). Thus, he is the locus of Theophany (مجلى الحق), and the Real is the locus of manifestation for the realities of the World through His spirit, which is Man. He was given the lunar mansion Al-Mu’akhkhar (The Last) because he was the last species to appear. His priority (أوليته) is the Real (الحق), and his posteriority (آخريته) is creation (الخلق). Thus, he is the First from the perspective of the Divine Form (الصورة الإلهية) and the Last from the perspective of the Cosmic Form (الصورة الكونية), manifest by both forms, and hidden (باطن) from the Cosmic Form by virtue of the Divine Form he possesses. The ruling of this was evident in the angels’ lack of knowledge of his station, even though Allah had told them he was a Vicegerent (خليفة). How much less would they have known had He not told them? This was only due to his hiddenness (بطونه) from the angels, who belong to the Higher World (العالم الأعلى), which knows what is in the Hereafter and some of the First World. Had they known what would be in the First World, they would not have been ignorant of Adam’s rank despite the definition given. None in the World knew him except the Preserved Tablet (اللوح) and the Pen (القلم), who are the exalted ones, and they cannot deny him. When the Pen inscribed him, it inscribed his rank and what would proceed from him, and the Tablet knew the knowledge of tasting (علم ذوق) what the Pen wrote upon it. Allah the Exalted said to Iblis: <<أَسْتَكْبَرْتَ أَمْ كُنْتَ مِنَ الْعَالِينَ>> (Did you show arrogance, or were you among the exalted ones?), using an interrogative of confirmation regarding what Iblis already knew, so that he might establish testimony against himself by what he uttered. So he said: <<أَنَا خَيْرٌ مِنْهُ>> (I am better than him). Thus, he showed arrogance toward Adam, not toward Allah’s command, and he was not among the exalted ones. So Allah seized him for his saying, and he <<وَكَانَ مِنَ الْكَافِرِينَ>> (was among the disbelievers) of the favor Allah bestowed upon him when He commanded him to prostrate to Adam and included him in the address to the Highest Assembly (الملإ الأعلى). Thus, Allah deprived him due to the ill-omen of his elemental nature. Had Allah the Exalted not gathered for Adam in his creation between His two Hands, so that he acquired the two Forms, he would have been merely one of the animals that walk on two legs. For this reason, the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Many men achieved perfection, but none among women achieved perfection except Asiya, the wife of Pharaoh, and Maryam, the daughter of Imran." The Perfect Ones (الكمل) are the Vicegerents (الخلائف). Allah utilized the entire World for him. There is no formal reality (حقيقة صورية) in the Higher or Lower World except that it looks upon him with a gaze of perfection, entrusted with a secret that Allah deposited in it to convey to him. My saying "formal" (صورية) means that it has a specific form in the World that occupies its place and station. This much allusion to the ruling of this Divine Name The Comprehensive (الجامع) in this species is sufficient for achieving the purpose derived from the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن), for he encompassed the entire Cloud (العماء). For this reason, the letter Mīm (م) belongs to him, based on his form, and it is the last of the letters, followed only by Wāw (و), which is for the Levels (المراتب), encompassing the Real (الحق) and Creation (الخلق) due to the universality of the rank. We shall mention it in the chapter that follows this one, and which Name belongs to it.

***

### Chapter Thirty-Eight: Concerning the Divine Name Exalter of Ranks, Possessor of the Throne (رفيع الدرجات ذو العرش)

Its direction is toward the specification of the Levels (المراتب), not their creation, because they are relations (نسب) that are not characterized by Existence (الوجود), as they have no existent entity (عين). It is associated with the letter Wāw (و) and the lunar mansion Al-Rishāʾ (the Cord), which is the rope for the bucket handle.

### The Manifestation of the Highest Divine Levels in Man

Know that all Levels (المراتب) are fundamentally Divine, and their rulings have appeared in the Cosmos (الكون). The highest Divine Level appeared in the Perfect Human (الإنسان الكامل). The highest of all Levels is the rank of Independence (*al-ghinā*) from everything, and that rank belongs only to Allah by virtue of His Essence (ذاته). The highest rank in the World (العالم) is Independence *by* everything—or, if you wish, you may say, need (*al-faqr*) *for* everything—and that is the rank of the Perfect Human. For everything was created for him and on his behalf, and was subjugated to him because Allah knew his need for it. Thus, he has no independence from it. Need (الحاجة) can only be directed toward the one who holds the power to fulfill it, and that is none other than Allah, <<الَّذِي بِيَدِهِ مَلَكُوتُ كُلِّ شَيْءٍ>> (in whose hand is the dominion of all things). Therefore, He must disclose Himself (يتجلى) to this Perfect Human in the form of everything, so that He may convey to him, through the form of that thing, what he needs and what sustains him. Since Allah characterized Himself to His servants with jealousy (*ghīra*), He manifested its ruling and made clear to them that He is the One who discloses Himself in the form of everything, so that they should not be needy except of Him specifically. Thus, the Mighty and Majestic said: <<يَا أَيُّهَا النَّاسُ أَنْتُمُ الْفُقَرَاءُ إِلَى اللهِ>> (O mankind, you are the needy ones toward Allah). Understand and realize the reliance of people upon the forms of the causes (الأسباب) and their need for them. Allah established the need of people for Him, not for others, to make clear to them that He is the One who discloses Himself in the forms of the causes, and that the causes, which are the forms, are a veil (حجاب) from Him, so that the scholars may know this due to their knowledge of the Levels (المراتب).

### Every Name Among the Names Has a Level That No Other Has

Know that every Name among the Names (الأسماء) has a Level (مرتبة) that no other has, and every form in the World has a rank that no other form has. The Levels are inexhaustible; they are the Degrees (الدرجات), and among them are the high (*rafīʿ*) and the higher (*arfaʿ*), whether they are Divine or cosmic, for the cosmic ranks are Divine. Thus, there is no rank that is not high, and differentiation occurs in the degree of elevation. From this, you know the destination (*māl*) of the two weighty ones (mankind and jinn) through the gnosis of tasting (*ʿirfān dhawq*), for their destination must be toward a Divine Level. The destination of those other than the two weighty ones is known to the Divine scholars (العلماء الإلهيين), but the rank of the destination of the two weighty ones is known only to the elite among the Gnostics of Allah (العلماء بالله). The letter Wāw (و) was assigned to this Name because Wāw represents the six levels of number, and it is the first perfect number. Perfection in the World is only achieved through rank, so we assigned Wāw to it. Among the lunar mansions is Al-Rishāʾ (the Cord), which is the rope. The rope signifies connection (*al-waṣl*), and through it comes holding fast (*al-iʿtiṣām*), just as it is with Allah. Thus, He placed the rope in its rank. Had the rank of the rope not granted this, His saying <<وَاعْتَصِمُوا بِحَبْلِ اللهِ>> (And hold fast to the rope of Allah) would not have been established, just as He said: <<وَاعْتَصِمُوا بِاللَّهِ>> (And hold fast to Allah). Understand where He placed the rank of the rope, with which Name He coupled it, and to which Name He attributed it.

### Forms are the Cause of Distinguishing Entities

Know that were it not for the Forms (الصور), the Entities (الأعيان) would not be distinguished, and were it not for the Levels (المراتب), the measures of things (مقادير الأشياء) would not be known, nor would every form be placed in its proper station, as Aisha said, "Place people in their proper stations." By rank, the superior and the inferior are known, and by it, distinction is made between Allah and the World (العالم), and by it, the realities of the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية) are revealed, concerning their general and specific relation. Let us mention in this chapter the suitability of the Divine Names we have discussed for the letters we specified and the lunar mansions we presented, so that the whole may be linked together. Just as the Cloud (العماء) gathered the forms of existing things, which is the Divine Breath (النفس الإلهي), so too do the letters gather the human psyche (النفس الإنساني), just as the celestial sphere gathers the determined lunar mansions for the descent of the planets, which clarify the measures of the constellations in the Atlas Sphere. We say that my intention in this sequence was not to arrange the chronological order of the World’s creation—for the order of creation has already been mentioned in this book, and it is contrary to what the philosophers assert. Rather, our intention was to know the effect (أثر) that the Divine Names have exerted upon the contingent beings (الممكنات), in each contingent being individually, whether it preceded or succeeded the one mentioned before it. The rank of existing things is according to their current description and limitation. We mentioned the lunar mansions according to their current placement, and the arrangement of the letters according to their points of articulation (*makhārij*). This does not necessitate their arrangement in the words composed of them. A word may begin with letters from the middle articulation points, such as the word *Kun* (Be!), while letters whose articulation points precede it exist. Thus, you look for the Divine Name that necessitates having the initial effect in the World, and you find it to be The Originator (البديع), because no world preceded this World that could serve as its example. Thus, The Originator (البديع) has the ruling in the beginning of the World without precedent. The Initiator (المبدئ) is not like this, and The Restorer (المعيد) seeks what The Initiator seeks, just as The Initiator seeks what The Originator seeks. The Originator (البديع) has the ruling in the Hereafter existence (النشأة الآخرة) for us, just as He had the ruling in the worldly existence (النشأة الدنيا), for it is without the example of this existence. This is His saying, the Exalted: <<وَلَقَدْ عَلِمْتُمُ النَّشْأَةَ الْأُولَىٰ>> (And you had already known the first creation)—meaning that it was without a preceding example. And He said: <<كَمَا بَدَأَكُمْ تَعُودُونَ>> (As He created you, you will return)—meaning, without example. Since the ruling of The Originator (البديع) is the manifest negation of example, and whatever is negated of example is first, we assigned to Him the beginning of the daily time cycle, which appeared with the presence of the sun in Aries, and its beginning is the two conditions (al-Sharṭayn). We assigned to Him the letter Hāʾ (ه), for it is the first letter that appears in the first articulation point. The Name granted the existent entity (العين الموجودة), and through the existent entity appeared Time (الزمان), which is the concomitance of one event with another, about which one asks "When?" If the existent possesses a soul (*nafs*) in matter, the letter is assigned. The arrangement of the lunar mansions is by the sun’s placement to manifest the entities of the seasons, which sustain the generated things (المولدات). Thus, the letters rule over the words, the planets rule over the seasons of time, and the Names rule over existing things. The entities (الأعيان) are divided between active and passive, substance and accident, place, time, relation, and other divisions of things within it. If you understand this, you will attribute every Divine Name to its related object predominantly, even if another Name has a ruling in it. We have already discussed such matters. Its related object is a specific existent or a ruling in an existent. Then Existence (الوجود) is linked, part to part, between active and passive, substance and accident, place and time, relation, and other divisions of things within it. <<وَاللهُ يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وَهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (And Allah speaks the Truth, and He guides to the way).

***

### Chapter Thirty-Nine: Concerning the Transfer (النقل) in the Breaths (الأنفاس)

### What is Meant by the Transfer

Know that what is meant by the Transfer (النقل) is that the ruling (حكم) of the Last (الآخر) is transferred to the First (الأول), and its station in the First is made the Last, though it was the First in the Last. It also removes from the Last the very entity (عين) in which this ruling appeared, yet the Identity (الهوية) is one, for He said: <<هُوَ الْأَوَّلُ وَالْآخِرُ>> (He is the First and the Last), and the Identity is one Entity. The ruling is transferred from the Last to the First in a single Entity. This specific Transfer in this chapter only occurs when an existent is moved from a state of hardship (شدة) to a state of ease (رخاء), and from difficulty (عسر) to facility (يسر). Thus, the Transfer is the facilitation of a path toward the realization of Mercy (الرحمة). This Transfer appears in three Levels (مراتب). The First Level is that it appears in represented forms (الصور الممثلة) resembling the sensible, so they possess the ruling of sensible things, yet they are not sensible, though in one respect they are sensible. That ruling is transferred to them so that it may be known that the manifestation in a form belonging to the Existent, who is transcendent above influence, carries the ruling of the form in which He appeared. Thus, the ruling was transferred to that which previously did not accept it, due to its manifestation in the form to which this ruling belongs. Just as the ruling of humanity was transferred to the Spirit (الروح) when it appeared in the form of a human, resulting in the child, who is Jesus—this is not the nature of spirits, but the ruling of the form was transferred to it by its acceptance of the form. Whoever appears in a form possesses its ruling. From this, you know the rank of the Perfect Human (الإنسان الكامل) whom Allah created upon His Form (صورته), and that Form has a ruling. The ruling followed the Form. No one among Allah’s creation claimed divinity for himself except the human who manifested the rulings of the Names (الأسماء) and the Vicegerency (النيابة), becoming an obeyed king, like Pharaoh and others. The ruling of the Transfer may also appear in the Level of Gnosis (المعرفة), which is the Second Level. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever knows his self knows his Lord." This is by transferring the ruling that belonged to his self to his Lord, when he knows that there is nothing in Existence (الوجود) but Allah. The Third Level is the transition in all Levels (المراتب). The ruling of the station is transferred to the one who occupies it, whatever that station may be, whether praiseworthy or blameworthy. When the ruling is transferred, the ruling within it is transferred according to what is established by custom, ordinary usage, and religious law (الشرعي). Do you not see that if the Jinn spirit (الروح الجني) assumes the form of a snake, and the ruling concerning it for us is killing, we kill it because of its form? Had we known it was a Jinn, we would not have killed it. Thus, the ruling of the form was transferred to the Jinn, and since we judged it to be a snake, we treated it accordingly, and we ruled based on that form. We narrated a Hadith about a person from the Jinn delegation of Nasibin who came to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said to this delegation of Jinn, since they had the ability to appear in any form they wished, He ruled concerning them that whoever assumes a form other than his own and is killed, there is no blood money (*ʿaql*) or retaliation (*qawd*) for him. For whoever kills a snake or a scorpion is not killed for it, nor is blood money taken for it. Thus, whoever appears in a form whose ruling is this, that ruling is applied to him.

***

### Chapter Forty: Concerning the Manifest (الجلي) and the Hidden (الخفي) in the Breaths

The Manifest (الجلي) is what appears, and the Hidden (الخفي) is what is concealed. Concealment (الاستتار) and hiddenness only occur in similitudes (الأمثال), but not in non-similitudes, because a non-similitude does not accept the form of what is not like it. Do you not see his saying, peace be upon him, when he related that Allah said on the tongue of His servant, "Allah hears the one who praises Him"? This is because He said concerning him that He created him upon His Form (صورته), thus making him a similitude (مثلاً). Then He negated the likeness of that similitude, saying: <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like unto Him)—meaning, there is nothing like His similitude. Thus, He negated the likeness of the similitude. The Real (الحق) was concealed in the form of the servant in the saying, "Allah hears the one who praises Him." For the one being translated (the object, *ism mafʿūl*) is concealed by the manifestation of the translator (the subject, *ism fāʿil*) in the matter of likeness to Him concerning the affairs that have no form for those being translated, in the way that the one being translated knows them on his tongue. Thus, the one being translated manifests in the spiritual form of the one being translated and in the sensible form of those being translated, appearing in both forms. For He called him a servant (*ʿabd*), and he is a servant speaking from the Real (حق). Thus, his tongue was the tongue of the Real in his saying, "Allah hears the one who praises Him," and he did not cease to be a servant in that. Allah the Exalted sometimes manifests us and conceals Himself in what belongs to Him, and sometimes manifests Himself and conceals us, according to the stations, out of His wisdom. The Perfect One (الكامل) among the People of Allah (أهل الله) observes Allah’s will in events: whichever entity (عين) Allah wills to manifest, He manifests, and whichever entity He wills to conceal, He conceals. Propriety (الأدب) dictates a universal rule: whatever is good according to custom and religious law (شرعاً) is attributed to the Real (الحق), and the Real manifests and reveals Himself in it to insights and sights. Whatever is ugly according to custom and religious law, He attributes it to Himself if He wills, manifesting and revealing Himself in it, or He attributes it to the devil if He wills, manifesting and revealing the entity of the devil in it. Thus, its inward aspect is the Real, based on His saying: <<فَأَلْهَمَهَا فُجُورَهَا وَتَقْوَاهَا>> (And inspired it [with discernment of] its wickedness and its righteousness), and <<وَكُلٌّ مِنْ عِنْدِ اللهِ>> (And all is from Allah). However, despite all this, if it is not a similitude, He must make it a similitude, and then He conceals it; otherwise, it is not concealed. For there is no similitude except Man, and he accepts concealment. Everything other than Man does not accept it, for it is not a similitude. So, if you wish to conceal it in the Real, you make it a similitude, and then it accepts concealment through this transformation. All causes (الأسباب) are difference, except Man. Allah the Exalted said: <<مَنْ يُطِعِ الرَّسُولَ فَقَدْ أَطَاعَ اللهَ>> (Whoever obeys the Messenger has obeyed Allah). Thus, He adorned him with His Name, and he was manifest, so He concealed Him. <<إِنَّ الَّذِينَ يُبَايِعُونَكَ إِنَّمَا يُبَايِعُونَ اللهَ>> (Indeed, those who pledge allegiance to you are actually pledging allegiance to Allah). He manifested Him with the address pronoun, then concealed Him. <<وَمَا رَمَيْتَ إِذْ رَمَيْتَ وَلَكِنَّ اللهَ رَمَىٰ>> (And you did not throw when you threw, but it was Allah who threw). Just as He distinguished, specified, and separated, saying: <<أَطِيعُوا اللهَ وَأَطِيعُوا الرَّسُولَ وَأُولِي الْأَمْرِ مِنْكُمْ فَإِنْ تَنَازَعْتُمْ فِي شَيْءٍ فَرُدُّوهُ إِلَى اللهِ>> (Obey Allah and obey the Messenger and those in authority among you. And if you disagree over anything, refer it to Allah) as a ruling (حكما), and <<وَإِلَى الرَّسُولِ>> (and to the Messenger) as an entity (عينا). Among the People of Allah (أهل الله), there are those who establish this when they encounter an existence possessing a spirit and a body: they conceal the action of the spirit by the sensible movement (sight), and they conceal the action of the body by the mover (insight). In this, Man is a creator, and the Real is <<أَحْسَنُ الْخَالِقِينَ>> (the Best of creators). Among the People of Allah, there are those who see nothing but Allah, so they have no concealment. And among the People of Allah, there are those who see nothing but creation, so they have no manifestation. All are correct. But the People of Propriety (أهل الأدب) are the Perfect Ones (الكمل), and they rule in this matter according to what Allah has ruled concerning concealment, Theophany (تجل), hiding, and manifestation, as we have presented. <<وَاللهُ يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وَهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (And Allah speaks the Truth, and He guides to the way).

***

### Chapter Forty-One: Concerning Moderation (الاعتدال) and Deviation (الانحراف) of the Soul (النفس)

### The People of Allah are of Divisions

Know that the People of Allah (أهل الله) in this matter are of three divisions. A division that holds that the Real (الحق) neither inclines nor is inclined toward Him; these are the ones who define love as the permanent inclination of the lover toward the beloved. A division that holds that the creation of Man upon the Form (الصورة) grants moderation (الاعتدال), and if there is no moderation, then he is not upon the Form. They incline where the Real inclines, such as His saying, the Exalted: <<وَأَنَّ هَٰذَا صِرَاطِي مُسْتَقِيمًا>> (And that this is My path, straight), in a specific law (شرع خاص), <<فَاتَّبِعُوهُ وَلَا تَتَّبِعُوا السُّبُلَ فَتَفَرَّقَ بِكُمْ عَنْ سَبِيلِهِ>> (So follow it and do not follow [other] ways, for they will separate you from His way). Then He said: <<ذَٰلِكُمْ وَصَّاكُمْ بِهِ>> (That has He instructed you to observe). Thus, He made this definition a commandment to be acted upon. This is the very essence of inclination, contrary to His saying: <<وَإِلَيْهِ يُرْجَعُ الْأَمْرُ كُلُّهُ>> (And to Him is returned the affair, all of it), and His saying: <<مَا مِنْ دَابَّةٍ إِلَّا هُوَ آخِذٌ بِنَاصِيَتِهَا>> (There is no creature except that He holds its forelock). The People of Moderation (أهل الاعتدال) are those who stand between the two deviations. The People of Deviation (أهل الانحراف) from this moderation are those who affirm in cosmic acts, high and low, the Real (حق) without creation (خلق)—and they are one faction—and another faction who affirm them as creation without the Real—literally, not metaphorically, from both factions. These are the ones who say that only one thing emanated from the Real. Regarding the preference in removing criticism and observing the Divine Address: in whatever place He assigns the ruling to one of the two deviations, we assign it; and in whatever place He turns toward moderation, we turn. This is the characteristic of the People of Propriety (الأدباء) with Allah. <<وَاللهُ يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وَهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (And Allah speaks the Truth, and He guides to the way).

***

### Chapter Forty-Two: Concerning Reliance on the Imperfect and Inclination Toward It

This chapter concerns reliance (الاعتماد) upon all causes (الأسباب) except the Perfect Human cause (السبب الإنساني الكامل). For whoever relies upon him has not relied upon the imperfect, due to his manifestation in the Form (الصورة). Everything other than him among the causes is imperfect compared to this rank, just as the woman is imperfect compared to the man due to the degree (الدرجة) between them. Even if the woman achieves perfection, her perfection is not the perfection of the man because of that degree. Some hold that this degree is due to Eve being created from Adam, so she had no manifestation except through him, giving him the degree of causality (السببية), which she can never attain. This is a specific case concerning one entity. We contrast this with Maryam in the existence of Jesus. In that case, the degree is not due to her manifestation from him. Rather, the woman is the locus of passivity (محل الانفعال), and the man is not. The locus of passivity does not possess the rank of acting. Thus, she has imperfection. Despite this imperfection, reliance is placed upon her and inclination is shown toward her because she accepts passivity in and through herself. Allah did not establish the causes in vain, but so that we might speak of them and rely upon them with a Divine reliance (اعتماداً إلهياً) that Divine Wisdom (الحكمة الإلهية) granted, while still observing the Face (الوجه) in every passive thing acted upon by them, whether the cause is aware of that Face or not. The wise Divine man of propriety (الحكيم الإلهي الأديب) is the one who places the causes where Allah placed them. Whoever witnesses the specific Face in every passive thing says that Allah acts *at* them (عندها), not *by* them (بها). Whoever does not witness the specific Face says that Allah performs things *by* them, treating the causes like tools, affirming them but not attributing the action to them, like the carpenter who cannot produce the form of a chest or a chair except with the tools of the adze, the saw, and other instruments, whose action is completed *by* them, not *at* them. Thus, you affirm them but do not attribute the craft of the chest to them; rather, you attribute it to the carpenter, the possessor of governance and knowledge of what appeared from him. <<وَاللهُ يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وَهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (And Allah speaks the Truth, and He guides to the way).

***

### Chapter Forty-Three: Concerning Reiteration (الإعادة)

Reiteration (الإعادة) is the repetition of similitudes (الأمثال) or the entity (العين) in Existence (الوجود). The latter is permissible but not actual—I mean the repetition of the entity—due to the Divine Vastness (الاتساع الإلهي). However, Man is in <<لَبْسٍ مِنْ خَلْقٍ جَدِيدٍ>> (confusion regarding a new creation). Thus, they are similitudes (أمثال) that are difficult to distinguish due to the strength of the resemblance. Reiteration is only in the ruling (الحكم), such as a ruler appointing a governor, then dismissing him, then reappointing him after his dismissal. The reiteration is in the governorship, and governorship is a relation (نسبة), not an existent entity (عين وجودي). Do you not see that the Reiteration on the Day of Resurrection is only in the governance (التدبير)? For the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, distinguished between the worldly existence (نشأة الدنيا) and the Hereafter existence (نشأة الآخرة). The spirit that governed the worldly existence returns to govern the Hereafter existence. Thus, it is a reiteration of a ruling and a relation, not a reiteration of an entity that was lost and then found. How can the temperament of one who urinates, defecates, and blows his nose be the same as the temperament of one who does not urinate, defecate, or blow his nose? The entities (الأعيان), which are the substances (الجواهر), were not lost from Existence (الوجود) so that they might be returned to it; rather, they have never ceased to be existent entities. There is no reiteration in Existence for an existent, for it is already existent. Rather, they are relative dispositions (هيأت) and mixtures (امتزاجات نسبية). As for our assertion of the permissibility of reiteration in the disposition and temperament that has vanished, it is based on His saying: <<ثُمَّ إِذَا شَاءَ أَنْشَرَهُ>> (Then, when He wills, He resurrects him)—and He willed it. The one who informs about Allah distinguished between the worldly existence and the other existence, and distinguished between the existence of the People of Bliss (أهل السعادة) and the existence of the People of Wretchedness (أهل الشقاء). The existence of the People of Bliss possesses subtlety (اللطف) and tenderness (الرقة), especially for those who adhere to the Law (المتشرعين), whose hearts are broken, and who look upon the Messenger always with the eye of truth while witnessing his humanity and that he is of their species. It is the custom of the species to envy when superiority appears, but this has been removed from these people. For them is the opening of blessings (فتح البركات) from heaven and earth, just as for the People of Wretchedness is the opening of punishment and increase, due to the increase of sickness in their hearts here when the Divine verses arrived to establish the laws. Both are people of opening, but with what? Know this, for it is subtle knowledge in the science of the Breaths (الأنفاس). <<وَاللهُ يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وَهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (And Allah speaks the Truth, and He guides to the way).

***

### Chapter Forty-Four: Concerning the Subtle (اللطيف) of the Soul (النفس)

The subtle returns to the dense, and what causes this, and the dense returns to the subtle, and what causes this, like the melodist raising and lowering his voice. Know that it is impossible for subtlety (اللطف) to return to density (كثافة), for realities (الحقائق) do not invert. However, the subtle returns to the dense, just as the hot returns to the cold, and the cold to the hot.

### Spirits Become Dense When They Materialize

Know that spirits (الأرواح) possess subtlety (اللطافة). When they materialize and appear in the form of bodies, they become dense in the eye of the observer. Bodies possess density (الكثافة), whether transparent or opaque. If they transform into forms in the eye of the viewer, or become concealed while present, they have become spiritualized (*tarawḥanat*)—meaning they have acquired the ruling of spirits in concealment. Forms vary upon them, just as accidents vary upon them, such as the redness of shame and the yellowness of fear. This is a model indicating that they possess the power of transformation into forms when the causes for that arise in them. As for the cause of the density of spirits, which belong to the World of Subtlety (عالم اللطف), it is because they were created from Nature (الطبيعة), even if their bodies are luminous—they are from the light of Nature, like the light of a lamp. For this reason, they accepted density and appeared in the forms of dense bodies. Similarly, contention (الخصام) affected them due to the ruling of Nature, which contains opposition and contradiction, and the opponent and the contradictory contend with their counterpart, as in the saying of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, relating what Allah recounted about him: <<مَا كَانَ لِيَ مِنْ عِلْمٍ بِالْمَلَإِ الْأَعْلَىٰ إِذْ يَخْتَصِمُونَ>> (I had no knowledge of the Highest Assembly when they disputed). Thus, He described them with disputation. From this reality that bequeathed them disputation, they materialized in the forms of dense bodies. As for the dense returning to the subtle, its cause is analysis (التحليل). Dense things belong to the World of Transformation (عالم الاستحالة), and everything that accepts transformation accepts different and contradictory forms. This is most evident in the people of melody (أهل التلحين). Sound, as sound, does not change its form, but the melodist thickens it in one place and thins it in another, according to the rank he intends, so that he may affect the nature of the listeners with whatever joy, happiness, and expansion, or grief, worry, and contraction he wishes. For this reason, they established this in music in four modes: *al-Bamm*, *al-Zīr*, *al-Muthannā*, and *al-Mutallath*. The locus that these sounds are intended to affect is composed of corresponding humors: bile, blood, and phlegm. Hearing this sound excites the corresponding humors present in the listener. Thus, the ruling occurs due to a specific intention of the melodist, so that this becomes a means for knowing the origin in His saying, the Exalted: <<إِنَّمَا قَوْلُنَا لِشَيْءٍ إِذَا أَرَدْنَاهُ>> (Indeed, Our word to a thing when We intend it)—which is the intention of the melodist—<<أَنْ نَقُولَ لَهُ كُنْ>> (is only that We say to it, "Be!"). Thus, He brought forth speech, which is the sound, extended and interrupted at the articulation points (*makhārij*), to manifest the entities of the letters by which benefit occurs to the listener. Do you not see the sound of cats? Although they do not have letters that are interrupted in themselves, they change their sounds according to the change in their states, to inform the listener of what they intend by that sound. When hungry, the cat’s voice becomes thin, hidden, and subtle. When agitated, it becomes thick, loud, and continuous. Thus, one knows from its sound whether it is agitated or hungry. This affects the listener’s soul according to his acceptance, either with tenderness and compassion, so he feeds it, or otherwise. Furthermore, in this chapter, the Theophany (تجلي) of the Real appears in the forms in which He is denied or seen in sleep, where the Real is seen in the form of creation, due to the Presence of Imagination (حضرة الخيال). For the Presences (الحضرات) rule over those who descend into them and clothe them with whatever robes they wish. How does this Theophany relate to <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like unto Him) and <<سُبْحَانَ رَبِّكَ رَبِّ الْعِزَّةِ عَمَّا يَصِفُونَ>> (Exalted is your Lord, the Lord of Might, above what they describe)? The ruling belongs to the Presence and the Station, because the ruling of realities (الحقائق) and meanings necessitates their rulings for whoever possesses them. If this ruling exists in Divine Knowledge (العلم الإلهي), then its manifestation in the entities of contingent beings (المحدثات) is the closest means of Existence (الوجود) through possible suitability. <<وَاللهُ يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وَهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (And Allah speaks the Truth, and He guides to the way).

***

### Chapter Forty-Five: Concerning Reliance on the Origin of Contingent Beings (المحدثات)

The origin of contingent beings (المحدثات) is that to which they return after completing their self-reflection, which is expressed in the saying of the Lawgiver (الشارع): "Whoever knows his self knows his Lord." The Gnosis (المعرفة) of Allah achieved after the knowledge of the self may be the knowledge of the inability (*al-ʿajz*) to attain Him. Thus, they gain the knowledge that there is One who cannot be known. The abandonment of the sign is itself a sign. He is thus distinguished from His creation by negation (*salb*), not by affirmation (*ithbāt*). Gnosis may also be achieved by knowing Him as God (إلها), so one knows what the rank (المرتبة) deserves, and they make that an attribute of the one who possesses that rank and manifests in it. Thus, their knowledge of what the rank necessitates is their knowledge of its possessor, since He is described by it, and He is described by everything appropriate for that rank to be described by. In reality, it is known that this is knowledge of the rank, not of Him, but it is known that the contingent being (الممكن) cannot achieve more than this through speculation and establishing proofs. If Allah unveils the sight of the contingent being through a Theophany (تجلي) by which the Real (الحق) appears to him, he then knows what the matter truly is, and his state is according to what he knows. Among the people of speculation, there are those who seek this ruling attained by the possessor of the Theophany, but they are not strong enough in it because they fear error due to the lack of tasting (الذوق). Thus, they seek it but do not manifest it. Those who rely on this Origin are of classes, due to the differences in their states. Some rely upon Him in everything when that thing appears. Some rely upon Him in things before the things appear. And some are returned to Him by things, so they rely upon Him after having relied on the things. All of this reverts to their preparedness (استعداداتهم).

### The Science of Rest (السكون) and Movement (الحركة)

Know that this chapter includes the science of Rest (السكون) and Movement (الحركة)—that is, the science of permanence (الثبوت) and establishment, and the science of change and transition. The Exalted said: <<وَلَهُ مَا سَكَنَ>> (And to Him belongs what rests)—meaning, what is permanent (ما ثبت). For the attribute of the Eternal (القديم) is permanent, and the attribute of contingent beings (المحدثات) is established by their establishment and vanishes by their vanishing, and the attribute changes upon them because they accept change. This is because they were non-existent and then came into existence, so they accepted Existence (الوجود) and did not remain fixed in the state of non-existence. Since their origin is the acceptance of transition from one state to another, the attributes changed upon them, so they are only permanent upon change, not upon a specific attribute. Rest (السكون), since it is the absence of movement, cannot be accompanied by a claim (*daʿwā*), so the Real attributed it to Himself. As for Movement (الحركة), since a claim accompanies it—meaning, it accompanies the one who manifests it—the Exalted did not say that to Him belongs what moves. This is because claims enter into it from the movers. The aspect is permanence (الثبوت), not non-existence. Thus, permanence belongs to Him, and vanishing (الزوال) belongs to the World (العالم). Even if it is permanent, that is not from itself, but from the One who makes it permanent. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, when the saying of Labīd reached him:

> Behold, everything besides Allah is vain (باطل)

He said: "This is the truest verse spoken by the Arabs."

Even if things exist, they are in the category of non-existence (العدم) due to the possibility of their non-existence, even if that non-existence does not occur. As for reliance (الاعتماد), we do not doubt that it is a settling upon the one relied upon; this is necessary. Reliance is only placed upon that which possesses the stability of Existence (ثبوت الوجود) and does not accept change or transition from the state of stability. Whoever knows that something accepts transition from stability does not rely upon it, because it betrays the reliance placed upon it due to its connection with that which has no stability. Therefore, one does not rely upon a contingent entity (محدث) except through an unveiling (كشف) and a divine notification (إعلام إلهي).

Thus, our reliance upon that which possesses the attribute of stability is like our reliance upon the Divine Laws (الشرائع) concerning what must be believed. Were it not for the divine definition (التعريف الإلهي) through the signs (الآيات) He manifested confirming its truth, we would not be stable upon it, just as we are not stable upon a ruling (الحكم) with the stability of that which does not transition, due to the possibility of abrogation (النسخ). All of this is Divine Law (شرع) that must be believed. For when abrogation is merely the expression of the termination of the duration of that ruling, it is succeeded by another ruling; it is not that the first ruling became impossible, but rather that it expired due to the expiration of its term, since it was originally linked to a specific duration known to Allah, even if we do not know it.

Therefore, we do not rely upon an ordinary contingent cause (سبب محدث عادي) except by a notification from Allah that He will establish its ruling, such as faith (الإيمان) with which felicity (السعادة) is established, and thus reliance is placed upon it. We say that felicity is linked to faith in Allah and in what came from Him, due to the notification of The Real (الحق) concerning this. However, reliance is not placed upon its persistence in the person whom we see as a believer, for an accidental matter (أمر عارض) may arise in him that intervenes between him and the faith that grants felicity, and thus felicity is negated from him due to the negation of faith.

This is unlike Knowledge (العلم), for Knowledge possesses stability, and heedlessness (الغفلات) does not affect it. It is not necessary for the knower (العالم) to be present with his knowledge at every moment (نفس), because he may be preoccupied with managing what Allah has entrusted him with, and thus he becomes heedless of his state of being a knower of Allah. This does not remove him from the ruling of his attribute as a knower of Allah, even with the existence of the opposite (الضد) in the locus, such as heedlessness or sleep. There is never ignorance after knowledge, unless that knowledge was acquired through rational speculation (نظر في دليل عقلي). Such knowledge is not considered knowledge by us, because doubt (الشبه) can assail its possessor, even if it aligns with true knowledge. True Knowledge is that which its possessor cannot accept doubt, and that is none other than the Knowledge of Tastes (علم الأذواق). That is what we call Knowledge. And Allah says the Truth, and He guides to the Way.

### Chapter Forty-Six: Concerning Reliance upon the World (العالم) [as a Sign]

Because it is the Inscribed Book (الكتاب المسطور) upon the parchment of Existence (رق الوجود), spread out in the cosmos of bodies (عالم الأجرام), originating from the Manifest Name of Allah (الاسم الله الظاهر).

### [Reliance upon the Possessor of Divine Knowledge]

Know that this reliance is only valid if its possessor is a possessor of Knowledge (علم) through divine definition (تعريف إلهي). We use the word *al-’ālam* (العالم, the world/cosmos) to signify that we intend it to be a sign (*‘alāmah*). Since it is established that Existence (الوجود) is the very Essence of The Real (عين الحق), and the manifestation of the diversity of forms within it is a sign of the rulings of the Fixed Entities (الأعيان الثابتة) of the possibles, those manifest forms, by their ruling in the Essence of The Real, were named *‘ālam* (world/sign), like the manifestation of the Book upon the parchment. The Manifest Divine Name (الاسم الإلهي الظاهر) manifested them; rather, He manifested *by* them.

This is a chapter where The Real (الحق) is distinguished from Creation (الخلق), and where the diversity of forms did not affect the Essence (العين) in which these forms appeared, just as the substance (الجوهر) does not change from its substantiality due to the states and accidents (الأعراض) that appear upon it. That manifest aspect is the ruling of the hidden meaning (المعنى المبطون), which has no existence except by its ruling in the eye of the beholder. Thus, its rulings are neither existent nor non-existent, even though they are fixed (ثابتة).

Therefore, reliance is placed upon the World (العالم) as a sign (علامة), not upon Allah, for Allah is independent of the worlds (غني عن العالمين). Rather, it is a sign of the stability of the meanings (المعاني) that possess these rulings, which are manifest in the Essence of The Real (عين حق). The World is a sign of itself, and so is everything. Nothing is a clearer indicator of a thing than the thing itself, for this is an indication that does not vanish. External indications (الدلالات الغريبة) vanish and are not followed.

Thus, whoever relies upon the World from this perspective has relied upon a sound matter that does not change. True reliance (الاعتماد على الحقيقة) can only be upon it in this manner. For if The Real is engaged in a State (شأن) every day, and one does not know what that State will be, one cannot rely upon Him who does not know what is in His own Essence (نفسه). The Perfect One (الكامل) among the people of Allah is he who diversifies according to the diversification of the States (الشئون), for The Real does not appear in Existence except in the forms of the States. Thus, the reliance of this person is a divine reliance, meaning that he is characterized by the attribute of The Real in his acceptance of the States that are manifested to the World through Him. This is part of the Knowledge (العلم) that is guarded from those who are not worthy of it. Know this. And Allah says the Truth, and He guides to the Way.

### Chapter Forty-Seven: Concerning Reliance upon the Promise before its Occurrence

Which is reliance upon the non-existent (المعدوم) due to the truthfulness of the Promise.

### [The True Report, if it is not a ruling, is not subject to abrogation]

Know that this chapter is what Allah used to relieve (نفس) His servants, and it is the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن). For a true report, if it is not a ruling (حكم), is not subject to abrogation (نسخ). The Promise (الوعد) and the Threat (الوعيد) have come by way of report. The Breath of the All-Merciful came with the establishment and execution of the Promise, and hesitation regarding the execution of the Threat concerning specific individuals. This is because the Divine Law (الشريعة) was revealed in the language of the Prophet’s people, addressing them according to what they agreed upon. Among what they agreed upon regarding one characterized by generosity and perfection is the execution of the Promise and the removal of the ruling of the Threat. The masters of the language said concerning this, by way of praise:

> And when I threaten or promise,
> I break my threat, but fulfill my promise.

It is reported in the *Sahih* collection that nothing is more beloved to Allah than to be praised. Praise through overlooking the faults of the wrongdoer is the ultimate praise, and Allah, Exalted is He, is most worthy of it. Truthfulness in the Promise is also a matter of praise. Allah, the Exalted, said: <<فَلا تَحْسَبَنَّ الله مُخْلِفَ وَعْدِهِ رُسُلَهُ>> (So never think that Allah will fail in His promise to His messengers). He mentioned the Promise and informed of the Threat at the end of the verse by saying: <<إِنَّ الله عَزِيزٌ ذُو انتِقامٍ>> (Indeed, Allah is Exalted in Might, Owner of Retribution). He spoke of the Threat being conditional upon His Will (المشيئة), but the Promise is necessarily executed and was not conditioned upon His Will concerning the righteous person. However, concerning the wrongdoer, He conditioned His Will upon forgiveness and punishment.

Thus, reliance is placed upon Allah’s Promise, which has no manifestation except through the existence of what He promised, even though it has not yet come into existence. Reliance upon it is necessary due to what the linguistic convention dictates and the truthfulness of the divine report supported by evidence. Allah is according to the assumption (ظن) of His servant concerning Him, so let him assume good. Here, *al-ẓann* (الظن, assumption) should be understood in the sense of Knowledge (العلم), as is evident in His saying concerning the three who were left behind: <<وظَنُّوا أَنْ لا مَلْجَأَ من الله إِلَّا إِلَيْهِ>> (And they became certain that there is no refuge from Allah except in Him)—meaning, they knew and were certain. The masters of the language said concerning this:

> I said to them, assume (ظنوا) that the heavily armed one will reach me.

### [The Level of Assumption is Barzakhic]

Know that since the level (مرتبة) of assumption (الظن) is an Isthmus (برزخية), having one face toward Knowledge (العلم) and another toward its opposite, when the circumstantial evidence points toward the face of Knowledge within it, we judge it by the ruling of Knowledge and assign it the status of certainty (اليقين), while retaining the name *ẓann* but not its ruling. Assumption only occurs with a type of preponderance (ترجيح) that distinguishes it from doubt (الشك), for doubt has no preponderance. Assumption contains a type of preponderance toward the side of Knowledge.

Similarly, He said: "I am according to the assumption of My servant concerning Me, so let him assume good." This shows that assumption necessarily involves a preponderance, either toward the side of good or toward the side of evil. Allah is according to the assumption of His servant concerning Him. But He did not stop there, because His Mercy precedes His Wrath, so He said, instructing us: "Let him assume good," as a command. Whoever does not assume good concerning Him has disobeyed Allah’s command and is ignorant of what Divine Generosity (الكرم الإلهي) necessitates. If there were equality without preponderance, like doubt, he would be among those who say that His Justice does not affect His Grace, nor His Grace His Justice. Since assumption admits preponderance, The Real commanded us to give preponderance to the side of good concerning ourselves, so that He may be according to our assumption of Him, for He is Merciful. Whoever assumes evil concerning a matter, the consequence that returns to him is only his own evil assumption, nothing else. May Allah make us among the people of Knowledge (أهل العلم), and if He decrees assumption upon us, may we assume good concerning Allah. And this we have done, praise be to Allah. And Allah says the Truth, and He guides to the Way.

### Chapter Forty-Eight: Concerning Reliance upon Allusions (الكنايات)

And the unveilings (الفتوح) that appear from them, which are expressed as the I-ness (الإنّية) on the Path, and how the sound becomes ailing and the ailing becomes sound.

### [Everything other than Allah is ailing by Essence and sound by Accident]

Know, may Allah support you, that everything other than Allah is ailing by Essence (معتل بالذات) and sound by Accident (صحيح بالعرض). Soundness is an accident that occurs to the contingent entity (المحدث) when Allah loves him with a love of cause, such as His love for those who draw near through supererogatory acts (النوافل). Thus, The Real (الحق) becomes their hearing and their sight, and the illness and ailment depart from them, and they become sound. Their sight penetrates every visible thing and their hearing every audible thing.

As for that which is sound by Essence (صحيح بالذات) but ailing by Accident (معتل بالعرض), it is that which sees that Existence (الوجود) is nothing but the very Essence of The Real (عين الحق). From the perspective of its Essence, ailments do not affect it. However, when it appears in the eyes of those who behold it in different forms, the rulings of the Fixed Entities (أحكام أعيان الممكنات) judge it accordingly, and it appears ailing by the ruling of the accident (العرض) that occurred, not by the Essence of those who behold it. In itself, it remains as it is, just as the forms of colors appear to the beholder in the eye, while the light itself is uncolored. Thus, the sound has become ailing.

As for reliance upon Allusions (الكنايات), this is because they are the most known of all known things, and reliance can only be placed upon a known thing for the sake of designation (التعيين). If it were unknown, it would not be distinguished or designated, and reliance would be placed upon something unreliable. The Names (الأسماء) do not possess the strength of the Allusions. The one who relies upon Allusions is never disappointed, but the one who relies upon the Names may be disappointed, because they do not possess the strength of the Allusions in Gnosis (المعرفة). The people of the Known (أهل المعروف) in this world are the people of the Known in the Hereafter, because it does not change. But the Names may transition or be borrowed. Whoever relies upon a Name while it is borrowed or transitioned will be disappointed in his reliance.

The borrowed is like *ishtighāl* (اشتعال, blazing), which is a specific name, an attribute of the states of compounded fire, but it was borrowed for gray hair in His saying: <<واشْتَعَلَ الرَّأْسُ شَيْباً>> (And the head flared up with gray hair). As for transition, it is like His saying: <<جِداراً يُرِيدُ أَنْ يَنْقَضَّ>> (A wall intending to collapse), where the name of the intender (*murīd*) is transferred to that which is not naturally capable of intending. If reliance is placed upon this Name during its transition, the one relying will be disappointed. Allusions are not like this. They possess the unveilings (فتوح) of direct vision (المكاشفة بالحق) and the unveilings of sweetness in the inner being (الباطن), just as the Names possess the unveilings of expression (العبارة).

### Chapter Forty-Nine: Concerning what is annihilated and what is brought into existence

Of that which exceeds the Foundations (الأصول), like the supererogatory acts (النوافل) compared to the obligatory duties (الفرائض). Know that that which the Essence (الذات) seeks for the perfection of its reality is not called supererogatory (الزائد). That which exceeds <<أَعْطى‏ كُلَّ شَيْءٍ خَلْقَهُ>> (He gave everything its creation) is supererogatory. If it is annihilated, the annihilated thing is not affected by its non-existence, and if it exists, it does not add anything to the essence of the existent that was not already there. This is like the Spiritual States (الأحوال) for the people of the Spiritual Stations (المقامات): if they exist in them, it does not increase their status, and if they cease to exist, their non-existence does not diminish their status. For this reason, they are gifts (مواهب).

### Chapter Fifty: Concerning the Comprehensive Matter (الأمر الجامع)

Of the rulings that appear in the soul (النفس) in every breath—as The Real (الحق) who is likened, and as Creation (الخلق), life, and speech—and what Allah used to relieve (نفس) through the Divine Oaths (الأقسام الإلهية).

### [Allah continuously pours forth upon existent things]

Know that the Divine Sustenance (الإمداد الإلهي) for existent things is never cut off. If there is a deficiency, it comes from the recipient (القابل), not from the Sustainer (الممد). If the lack of sustenance in a specific matter is attributed to The Real (الحق), then that deficiency is the sustenance of expediency (*maṣlaḥah*) for the one who is denied, for He is the Knower of the expediencies of the creatures. For this reason, those who know Allah should not specify a particular need when asking, but should ask for what is good for them without specification. How many petitioners specified a need, and when it was fulfilled due to a wisdom known only to Allah, they later regretted what they had specified and wished they had not specified it.

Sustenance (الإمداد) is the Breath of the All-Merciful (تنفس رحماني). Divine Sustenance in existent things is of two types: natural (طبيعي) and superadded (مزاد). The natural is what is urgently needed for the subsistence of the essence and the removal of pain that affects it. The superadded is what exceeds this, which is not inherently needed by the essence itself. This is the case if one is among the people of Allah who speak of quenching thirst upon drinking. But for those who do not speak of quenching thirst, there is no superadded sustenance; rather, all of it is natural.

The superadded is of two kinds: that with which The Real sustains the servant, which is needed by others, and concerning this Allah commands His Prophet: <<وقُلْ رَبِّ زِدْنِي عِلْماً>> (And say, "My Lord, increase me in Knowledge"). This superadded sustenance may be due to the request of another, which necessitates the increase, such as what is in the soul of the reciter in the words *fī’* (shade), *āmana* (he believed), and *ādama* (Adam). Or it may be sustenance from Allah to this servant so that he may sustain others whom Allah knows are in need, thereby honoring the intermediary. In this case, the servant finds in himself a knowledge that his own state does not necessitate, and he knows that the intention is instruction and sustenance for others. An example of this in the soul of the reciter is *jā’a* (he came), *shā’a* (He willed), *dābbah* (creature), and *ṭāmmah* (calamity), which necessitate the increase in sustenance. *Dābbah* and *ṭāmmah* are two forms governed by a single spirit, which is doubling (التضعيف). The hamza (ء) is half a letter according to some, and it is the Manifest Name (الاسم الظاهر), and the *alif* (ا) is half a letter, and it is the Hidden Name (الاسم الباطن). The total is one letter, and it is the cause necessitating the increase in sustenance, due to the Sustainer’s knowledge of the need for it or due to the request. In any case, the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) is present in it. The increase in sustenance is according to the need or the request, so some parts are favored over others. The less favored is a shortening and an ebb (جزر) from the flow (مد), except for the length of the more favored. Know this. The flow (*madd*) is a manifest, sensible sustenance, and the ebb (*jazr*) is an intelligible sustenance to which the name of the opposite is applied. Know this.

If two Gnostics (*‘ārifān*) meet in a Presence of Witnessing (حضرة شهودية) with Allah, what is their ruling? This is a question my Shaykh, Yusuf ibn Yakhluf al-Kūmī, asked me in the year 586 AH. I replied to him: "My master, this is a hypothetical question that does not occur unless the Theophany (التجلي) is in the Presence of Similitude (حضرة المثل), like the vision of a sleeper or the state of a spiritual occurrence (*wāqi‘ah*). But in reality, it does not occur, because the Presence (الحضرة) does not accommodate two such that one witnesses another alongside it. Rather, one does not even witness one's own essence in that Presence, much less witness an additional essence. However, this can be conceived in the Theophany of Similitude (تجلي المثال).

If they meet, each of them must either be united by a single Station (مقام)—higher, lower, or intermediate—or not united by one. If they are united by a single Station, that Station must either necessitate Transcendence (التنزيه), Immanence (التشبيه), or the combination of both. In any case, the ruling of the Theophany (التجلي) is one in terms of manifestation, but what the recipient of the Theophany finds is different in taste (مختلف الذوق) due to the difference in their essences (*a‘yān*), because this one is not that one, neither in natural form, nor spiritual form, nor in location. Even if this one is a similitude of that one, this one is not that one.

Their ultimate outcome is either that each realizes his Gnosis (معرفة) by himself—and the soul of this one is other than the soul of that one—so that knowledge is attained by this one that is not attained by that one, and we know that they are united in the Essence of Separation (عين الفرق). Or, one realizes his Gnosis by himself, and the other is annihilated (يفنى) from witnessing his own Essence, so they differ in the Essence of Unification (عين الجمع). Or, one is given what is given to the Desired (المراد) and the other is given what is given to the Desirer (المريد). In every aspect, they are different in Existence (الوجود) but in agreement in State (الحال) and Witnessing (الشهود).

If the Station necessitates Transcendence for each of them, the limit of the Transcendence of each is that he transcends the form upon which he is in himself. Thus, they are undoubtedly different, even if they are similitudes. If that Station necessitates Immanence, the state is the same as the state. Likewise, if it necessitates the combination, for the combination is merely the gathering of two extremes in a middle Presence (حضرة وسطي). The state is the state. Thus, they never unite in Existence, even if they unite in Witnessing.

If they are not united by a single Station, and each is in a Station that the other does not possess, and he appears in a form that belongs to his companion, even if they unite in form, they are given the power such that each witnesses the presence of his companion on the carpet of that witnessed reality, because the witnessed reality is a Theophany in a similitude form (صورة مثالية). This Theophany and Witnessing is what allows its possessor to combine address (*khiṭāb*) and witnessing, if the Witnessed Reality wills it. But outside of this Presence, witnessing and address, or the vision of another, do not combine.

Their ruling, when they are in this state, is the ruling of those united by a single Station in their Gnosis of themselves, or the annihilation of one of them, or the establishment of one as the Desired and the other as the Desirer. The Desirer reports of severity and intensity, and the Desired reports of gentleness and affection. There is nothing beyond this. Neither of them reports what happened to his companion, for the inspiration (*ilqā’*) to each of them is only according to the suitability (المناسب) necessitated by his specific temperament, which was the cause of the difference in the forms of their spirits in the origin of creation (*nash’ah*).

When the one whose state is this returns to his companions, he says—even if one was in the West and the other in the East—to his companions: "At this hour, I witnessed so-and-so, I beheld him, and I knew his form and his description was such and such," describing him with the attributes he possesses. Whoever among them lacks knowledge of the Realities (الحقائق) says: "The Real gave him the same as He gave me." But the matter is not so, for neither of them was made to hear what the other received, due to their separation in suitability, as we mentioned. If he is among the people of Realities and perfect Gnosis (المعرفة التامة), and he is asked what the other received, he says: "I do not know, for I only know what my own form necessitates and what I am, for The Real does not repeat a form."

Since this chapter encompasses every possessor of a soul (نفس), as The Real (حق) and as Creation (خلق), we needed to explain in it what the All-Merciful relieved (نفس) concerning Himself when He described Himself as loving to be known. It is known that everything only knows something from itself, and He loves to be known by others. That other only knows Him from itself. If the knower is not upon the form of the Known, he will not know Him, and the purpose for which Existence (الوجود) was intended will not be achieved. Therefore, He must necessarily create him upon the Form.

He, Exalted is He, is the Gatherer of the Two Opposites (الجامع للضدين); rather, He is the very Essence of the Two Opposites (عين الضدين): <<هُوَ الْأَوَّلُ والْآخِرُ والظَّاهِرُ والْباطِنُ>> (He is the First and the Last, the Manifest and the Hidden). He created the Perfect Human (الإنسان الكامل) upon this rank. Thus, the human is also the Essence of the Two Opposites, because he is his own essence in relation to the two contraries. He is the First (الأول) by his body, the Last (الآخِرُ) by his spirit, the Manifest (الظَّاهِرُ) by his form, and the Hidden (الْباطِنُ) by the necessity of his rulings. The Essence (العين) is one. He is the essence of Zayd, and he is the Essence of the Two Opposites. Zayd is the very essence of the four conflicting and opposing humors (الأخلاط الأربعة), nothing else, and he possesses the psychic spirit and the natural compound.

Here, Al-Kharrāz said: "I knew Allah by His gathering of the two opposites." Our companion, Tāj al-Dīn al-Akhlāṭī, upon hearing this from us, said: "No, rather He is the very Essence of the Two Opposites." And he spoke correctly, for the statement of Al-Kharrāz suggests that there is an essence that is not the Essence of the Two Opposites, but which accepts both opposites simultaneously. The matter in itself is not so; rather, He is the very Essence of the Two Opposites, since there is no additional essence. The Manifest (الظاهر) is the Essence of the Hidden (الباطن), and the First is the Last. The First is the Essence of the Last, the Manifest, and the Hidden. There is nothing but this. Thus, I have informed you that the human creation (*nash’ah*) is upon the Divine Form. The discussion of the creation of the human, in terms of the totality by which he is human, will return in Chapter 361, in the section on the Stations (المنازل), at the station of sharing with The Real in estimation.

The Divine Oaths (الأقسام الإلهية) from the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) mentioned in the Quran and the Sunnah are what Allah used to relieve (نفس) the one sworn to, from the constraint (الحرج) and distress (الضيق) that His saying <<فَعَّالٌ لِما يُرِيدُ>> (Doer of what He intends) imparts to existent things. His Will (إرادته) has an unknown connection; what He intends is only known through divine definition (تعريف إلهي). When He confirms it with an oath and a vow, it is a greater removal of constraint for the one sworn to.

Just as Allah relieved the believers who were not certain by His oath concerning provision (الرزق) and what He promised of absolute good, and good conditioned by stipulations for those who fulfilled them and in whom they were found, that it is true, <<مثل ما إنكم تنطقون>> (Just as you speak). Allah relieved them through this, and certainty (اليقين) was attained by them. What remained for them afterward was only natural agitation (الاضطراب الطبيعي), for the sensible natural pains are beyond human capacity to remove once they occur, unlike psychic pains, which are within his capacity to remove. Thus, relief occurred through the oath that provision from Allah is inevitable.

Yet, in the hearts of some who were certain of this, there remained the constraint of specifying the time of its occurrence, which was not defined. Even if it had been defined, it would not have removed the natural agitation. Since The Real knew that He would not grant relief by specifying the times for this, He did not define them, for Nature (الطبع) is more controlling, and the senses are stronger in taste (الذوق) than the soul (النفس). The reason for this is that the sensible thing is in a single form that does not change, while the soul accepts transformation in forms. Therefore, the ruling of Nature concerning the existence of sensible pains is not lifted due to its stability, while psychic pains are lifted due to their rapid transformation in forms. No one is annihilated from natural pains except by a powerful divine or spiritual influx (*wārid*) that removes the pain of Nature if it affects him. The cause of that influx may be either a sensible or an intelligible matter that is not restricted, such as the arrival of an absent loved one, whose presence preoccupies him with the joy of his arrival, annihilating the pain of hunger and thirst he felt before seeing this absent one or hearing of his arrival. This is a sensible cause. The intelligible cause is known to the scholars.

Thus, the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) appeared in the Divine Oaths with the utmost clarity. This oath imparted to the scholars the magnification of the object sworn by, since an oath is only taken by that which possesses a rank of greatness. Thus, Allah magnified by the oath the entire World (العالم), both the existent and the non-existent, since its individuals are endless. He swore by all of it in His saying: <<فَلا أُقْسِمُ بِما تُبْصِرُونَ وما لا تُبْصِرُونَ>> (Nay, I swear by what you see and what you do not see)—which includes the existent that is absent from sight and the non-existent. This oath includes the contingent (المحدث) and the eternal (القديم).

However, since Allah knew His greatness in the hearts of His servants—their monotheists and polytheists, their believers and disbelievers—He swore to them by contingent things and by things other than Himself. He knew that it was established among them that an oath is only taken by something great in the view of the one swearing. Therefore, the knower necessarily believes in the magnification of contingent things, especially since He supported this concerning some contingent things by His saying: <<ومن يُعَظِّمْ شَعائِرَ الله>> (And whoever magnifies the symbols of Allah)—which are contingent things—<<فَإِنَّها من تَقْوَى الْقُلُوبِ>> (Indeed, it is from the piety of hearts). Among the attributes of The Real (الحق) is Protective Zeal (الغيرة). Thus, out of His Protective Zeal for us, He forbade us from swearing by anything other than Him, even though we believe in the greatness of that other due to Allah’s magnification. This prohibition is a beneficial remedy for the ailments and diseases that swearing by contingent things instilled in the hearts of those whose insights (البصائر) are weak in perceiving the Realities (الحقائق). The oaths are numerous, and there is no benefit in mentioning them, given what we have mentioned of the Comprehensive Matter (الأمر الجامع) that encompasses them, which suffices for their detail, as the book would become too long by mentioning them. Every person, upon encountering one of these oaths, knows immediately in what context it occurred, what Allah relieved through it, and for whom Allah granted relief. We should only mention what is obscure to some or most understandings, in order to achieve benefits that are difficult for most people to attain.

Also from the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) is the legislation of independent reasoning (الاجتهاد) in rulings concerning the Foundations (الأصول) and the Branches (الفروع), the consideration of differences, and the establishment of the ruling from The Real’s side by affirming it as a legal ruling (*ḥukm shar‘ī*) for the *mujtahid* (one who exercises *ijtihād*), which he is forbidden to violate, even with opposing rulings. Thus, He established two opposing rulings and made the *mujtahidūn* rewarded for their effort. The *mujtahid* legislated from the Divine Law (الشرع) that Allah permitted this Muhammadan Community (الأمة المحمدية) to legislate. I do not know whether this was exclusive to them or if it was always present in the communities before them. The apparent truth is that it was always present in the communities, for the Breath of the All-Merciful necessitates universality, especially since the Quran contains what indicates that this was always present in the communities, in His saying, the Exalted: <<ورَهْبانِيَّةً ابْتَدَعُوها>> (And monasticism, which they innovated). They only innovated it through their *ijtihād* and seeking a general or specific expediency. He praised those who observed it as it should be observed, and this was mentioned concerning the Children of Israel. Likewise, concerning the Foundations, in His saying: <<ومن يَدْعُ مَعَ الله إِلهاً آخَرَ لا بُرْهانَ لَهُ به>> (And whoever invokes with Allah another deity for which he has no proof)—meaning, in his claim, for in reality there is only one God.

For this reason, the Prophet established the ruling of the *mujtahid*, whether he was correct or mistaken, after fulfilling the right of *ijtihād* to the best of his ability and the strength of insight Allah granted him in that matter. He established for him one reward if he erred and two rewards if he was correct. Know that the *mujtahid* may err concerning what the matter is in itself, yet Allah has made him worship Him through that, and He gave him the reward for *ijtihād* due to the hardship involved, because it comes from *juhd* (effort), and *juhd* is specifically the exertion of capacity. Indeed, Allah only burdens His servants with their capacity in reality. The Prophet did not specify the *ijtihād* to a branch over a foundation; rather, he generalized it. Whoever specifies it to the branches without the foundations, that specification and generalization are also part of *ijtihād*, and both are rewarded for their independent reasoning.

Also from the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) is His saying, relating from an infallible one (معصوم) concerning error, who is the Messenger of Allah: <<ما من دَابَّةٍ إِلَّا هُوَ آخِذٌ بِناصِيَتِها>> (There is no creature but that He holds it by its forelock). This statement narrowed the wide scope. Allah granted relief (نفس) by completing the verse and defining it with His saying: <<إِنَّ رَبِّي عَلى‏ صِراطٍ مُسْتَقِيمٍ>> (Indeed, my Lord is upon a Straight Path). Thus, the saying <<اهْدِنَا الصِّراطَ الْمُسْتَقِيمَ>> (Guide us to the Straight Path), with the definite article (alif and lām) signifying a known entity, refers to this Path upon which the Lord is, so that it may be witnessed by us at the time when The Real walks upon it with us. It is the path of those upon whom He bestowed favor and those upon whom He incurred wrath. Its origin lies in the way that separated it from His Way, which is the Path upon which He is. It is veiled from our witnessing, and only the felicitous (سعيد) witnesses it. Even if one does not witness it but believes in it and acts as if he witnesses it, he is felicitous. It is known that the action of every creature may be associated with a language of praise or blame due to accidental matters on the path, which are designated by the States (الأحوال) and the rulings of the Names (أحكام الأسماء). The origin remains preserved in reality, witnessed by the Messengers, peace be upon them, and the elite among Allah’s servants.

Also from the Breath of the All-Merciful (نفس الرحمن) with which Allah granted relief to His servants who believe in the Messengers is His saying: <<وهُوَ مَعَكُمْ أَيْنَ ما كُنْتُمْ>> (And He is with you wherever you are). Allah granted relief through this from the thoughts that had arisen in hearts that Allah, Exalted is He, does not know particulars (الجزئيات). Even though the one who said this intended Transcendence (التنزيه), he is one who exercised *ijtihād* and erred. If he said it based on *ijtihād*, he has a reward. For the matter does not change from what it is in itself, and the ruling of the *mujtahid* does not affect it, neither by correctness nor by error. Since the matter in itself does not change with the change of *ijtihād*, the ruling belongs to Him, and nothing comes from Him in the Hereafter (العقبي) except good, for He is pure Goodness in which there is no evil. The change that the *mujtahidūn* experience from His side is only what they change in themselves: <<إِنَّ الله لا يُغَيِّرُ ما بِقَوْمٍ حَتَّى يُغَيِّرُوا ما بِأَنْفُسِهِمْ>> (Indeed, Allah will not change the condition of a people until they change what is in themselves). And what they change in themselves is Allah’s change through them, because they have not departed from what Allah gave them, for Allah does not burden a soul except with what He has given it. What He gave it at that time is only what He called change. Thus, He is with them in their state of change until its duration expires, and then <<يَبْدُو لَهُمْ من الله ما لَمْ يَكُونُوا يَحْتَسِبُونَ>> (There will appear to them from Allah that which they had not anticipated), which is the witnessing of what the matter is in itself.

Allah granted them relief by what appeared to them from Him, and nothing appears from Goodness except Goodness. This is as the Mu’tazilite said, who used to advocate the execution of the Threat (الوعيد) against those who died without repentance. When he died holding this belief, and after death attained the witnessing of the matter as it truly is, he was seen in a dream and asked what Allah had done with him. He replied: "We found the matter easier than we had believed," and he reported that he was shown mercy and the Threat he believed would be executed against his likes was not executed.

The Real’s informing His servants on the Day of Resurrection of the crimes they committed and the sins they perpetrated is not for the purpose of rebuke or confirmation, but rather by way of informing them of the vastness of Allah’s Mercy (اتساع رحمة الله), since, due to its vastness, it reached those who did not deserve it.
